Memorably compassionate.
Beautifully judged ensemble pieces.

movie_title: We Jam Econo: The Story of the Minutemen (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Machado cleverly undercuts audience expectations and refuses to make moral judgements about the behaviour of the threesome, choosing instead to reveal their inner vulnerability and celebrate their capacity for defiant survival.
Another low-budget gem from the New Argentine cinema.
The searing Paths Of Glory continues to impress with its striking blend of formal brilliance, economical storytelling and emotional directness.
Boudu Saved From Drowning is one of Jean Renoir's most enjoyable films. Its wit, freshness and spontaneity continue to impress.
movie_title: Boudu Saved From Drowning (Bondé sauvé des eaux) (1932)

movie_review_blurb: Melville handles with consummate cinematic mastery the suspenseful set-pieces.
Absorbing and suspenseful.

Richly atmospheric, with its expressive use of colour, lyrical cutaways, and masterly interior compositions -- predominantly shot from Ozu's trademark low-level camera position -- impressively illustrating the director's visual artistry.
Quote not available.
Capello provides an engaging, deadpan performance, quietly acceding to his increasingly convoluted living and working arrangements, and finding solace in his own gentle style of disco-dancing.
Quote not available.
Expressively played by its two young leads, it's a work which memorably captures a child's perspective on the mysteries of everyday life.
movie_title: The Spirit of the Beehive (El Espíritu de la colmena) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Lacks the emotional resonance that would have made it a more compelling film.
Quote not available.
Succeeds as an amusing critique rather than an empty-headed endorsement of its protagonists' behaviour.
By Haneke's high standards ... it's a minor disappointment, ultimately feeling more evasive than ambiguous.
Quote not available.
The acting honours here -- and the main reason to see the film -- belong to Skarsgård's impressive performance as the bewildered yet still defiant scapegoat, who can't believe his own downfall.
Has the deadpan, melancholic tone that brings to mind the poker-faced entertainment of Finland's Aki Kaurismäki.

Unfairly dismissed in the 1940s as pro-Nazi propaganda, this electrifying work represents a singularly pessimistic vision of the human condition from one of cinema's most bracingly misanthropic directors.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Life of Oharu (Saikaku ichidai onna) (1952)

movie_review_blurb: It never patronises its characters in the quest for cheap laughs, treating them instead with commendable compassion.
Bodysong is not a work lacking in ambition.
Quote not available.
Aided by Golbahari's remarkably convincing lead performance, Barmak generates considerable suspense over the fate of Osama and her female relatives.
Quote not available.
Son Frere may be small in scale, but it's a powerfully uncompromising and sombre work.

Again Fassbinder returns to Germany's past to reveal the workings of its stagnant moral present to powerful effect, boldly combining melodramatic storytelling, vibrant performances, garish visuals and searching analysis.
Quote not available.
Ultimately, it's an earnest rites-of-passage drama that's likely to work better on the small screen.
Deliriously eccentric.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Ki-Duk ... impressively fuses style and content.
Few recent films have been so accomplished in capturing the way people drift through their lives, unable to communicate their emotions and feelings.
Doesn't sufficiently build on its intriguing premise.
Provides an enjoyable ride, even if style wins out over substance.
Teshigahara's creative background was in Japan's avant-garde arts scene, and there's a powerful expressiveness to the film's black-and-white cinematography.
movie_title: Woman in the Dunes (Suna no Onna) (1964)

movie_review_blurb: An intense and imaginatively mounted first feature.
The efforts of an experienced cast ... can't invigorate the tedious screenplay or distract from the stilted direction.
Born In '68 is blunted by a schematic screenplay and uninspired digital cinematography.
Beautifully shot yet distant.
movie_title: In Memory of Me (In memoria di me) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though it follows a familiar arc of assassinations and bombings that provoke savage reprisals, it doesn't flinch from showing the French police's role in rounding up and deporting Jewish citizens.
It's refreshing to see a British film in which place and character are so entwined.
It serves as a moving reminder of how, following the sacrifices of WWII, the British people collectively established a fairer society.
The film belongs to Arena, outstanding as a man growing ever more delusional in his quest to acquire celebrity status.
With its inventive sound, masterly lensing and diverse mix of characters, Filho reveals a society haunted by both its past and by the threat of future violence.
A self-aware, genre-subverting piece of postmodernism, which culminates in a deliberately OTT finale.
The strength of One Mile Away is that it gives the viewer a palpable sense of what it's like to be caught up in these 'postcode' wars ...
Gracefully shot, it's an amusing film that's imbued with Ray's generous humanity.
There's a quiet power in the mood of loss and loneliness, while the landscape lensing is little short of stunning.
[An] absorbing documentary, which charts the Israeli-Palestinian conflict from the Six Day War to the presentday.
The performances possess a powerful authenticity, whilst the poignancy of the fog-bound finale lingers in the mind.
It's strong on the details of itinerant life, and allows plotting to take a back seat to character.
Writer/director Trapero arguably crams too much into the film's running time, but potent turns and Michael Nyman's yearning score are among the compensations.
A fascinating rockumentary that pays tribute to its subject's impressive musical odyssey, while illustrating the enormous emotional costs he's incurred along the way.
In her process of cinematic adaptation, Nair has removed much of the source novel's ambiguity.
Assayas ensures that nostalgia and cynicism are kept at bay, keeping us aware of the doubts and insecurities of youthful characters.
The colourful retro designs and the leads' sparkling chemistry help to Tipp-Ex over some of the predictability.
A classic that screams to be seen on the big screen.
movie_title: Aguirre, the Wrath of God (Aguirre, der Zorn Gottes) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Like Someone In Love explores familiar Kiarostami themes - how we slip between roles in our relationships - with a terrifically light touch, making for his best since 1999's The Wind Will Carry Us.
Though it struggles to transcend its Sunday-TV feel, Christopher Menaul's film boasts sturdy turns from its three leads, while the outdoor lensing is a breath of fresh air.
Though it covers similar thematic ground to Laurent Cantet's Haiti-set Heading South, Seidl's gruelling film proves his knack for leaving viewers emotionally discomfited.
Evil has rarely seemed so banal.
Francois Couturier's score is overly emphatic in places in tugging at our heartstrings, but the film's gentle humanity is to be cherished.
movie_title: Io sono Li (Shun Li and the Poet) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Gharavi finds an element of poetry in the wide-open spaces of the North East countryside through which Nasrine passes in her journey of self-discovery.
Opppenheimer's high-risk strategy of avoiding historical analysis and giving the film over to bragging mass murderers pays huge dividends.
Overly dependent on the beauty of its Edenic setting, which is lushly photographed by Taiwanese cinematographer Mark Ping Bing Lee.
Laying bare his characters, Seidl uncovers the doubt beneath the armour of religious belief.
Sophie Lellouche's slick debut is chock-full of Woody-com quotes and references, yet it remains an inconsequential, undernourished trifle that does sod-all with its potential.
In the face of the film's overwhelming visual beauty, no official religious faith is required to feel that you are witnessing paradise gained and lost.
[Conveys] a palpable mood of claustrophobia, which gives the desire of the characters to escape abroad a convincing emotional resonance
[An] inventive, urgent and humane prison drama, in which real-life Mafia and Camorra prisoners act in a version of Julius Caesar.
This oblique and understated tale of lost innocence conveys both an individual's experiences and a powerful sense of a ruined nation.
Make allowances for Ivor Novello's hammy acting as the mysterious lodger wrongly accused of the killings, and relish instead Hitch's intuitive grasp of visual storytelling.
movie_title: The Lodger: A Story of the London Fog (1928)

movie_review_blurb: This thoughtful film is modest in scope, but remains quietly moving in its portrayal of both nature and the transience of human feelings.
Polley proves to be a perceptive observer of the body language between couples, particularly the passive-aggressive dynamic between Margot and Lou.
At a taut 81 mins, this crisply shot two-hander is further proof of how modern French cinema consistently allows Scott Thomas opportunities to excel in psychologically challenging roles.
Shot in warm, summery tones, TSOK muses pertinently on justice and forgiveness while painting a moving portrait of an enduring marriage.
Did the script really have to perpetuate such crass racial stereotypes?
A gruelling and sometimes exasperating film, notable for its raw performances - as well as its avoidance of close-ups and point-of-view shots.
The film itself serves a powerful metaphor for Berlusconi-era Italy, in which Catholicism has seemingly been supplanted by a hysterical collective craving for celebrity status.
Effortlessly shifts between genres, tones and styles, thus becoming an inquiry into this gifted if erratic filmmaker's whole career.
Backed by a sparing Philip Glass score, Elena eloquently shows how, in modern Russia, even family relationships are at the mercy of business.
Like her 2008 debut Home, Swiss director Ursula Meier's accomplished follow-up focuses on those living on the margins.
There's plenty to savour in Chesnais' expertly judged performance, while Becker's warmth towards the gentle pace of life in provincial France is palpable.
Feels lopsided in its focus on Erik, with Paul remaining a strangely remote object of the former's romantic devotion.
Absurdly amusing (in places), rigorously directed, and more interesting on an intellectual level than an emotional one.
The powerfully acted The Hunt concerns itself with how an innocent individual is caught up in a modern-day witch-hunt, based solely on the false memories of a child.
Persuasively argues that punitive laws against users have historically involved disproportionately targeting poor, non-white communities.
This is a perceptive, warm-hearted work, anchored by Knoller's impressively less-is-more performance.
A slice of modern London noir is served up in writer/director Barnaby Southcombe's debut.
A sobering primer in the hard-hitting photojournalism of the '60s and '70s.
Disappointing.
The result feels dramatically and emotionally unconvincing, and a step backwards from Riklis's poignant allegory Lemon Tree.
A film which poses lots of questions, rather than provides any definitive answers.
After an impressively choreographed opening set-piece ... The Lookout soon runs aground.
[It] displays plenty of visual imagination, but this overcooked film is in sore need of streamlining.
It deserves its cinematic release, thanks to its lingering, poetic-realist images of uncluttered Norfolk landscapes and to Michael Nyman's yearning score.
If it now appears quaintly old-fashioned in its attitudes and assumptions, it still impresses thanks to Dirk Bogarde's performance.
Details the ways, in the face of devastating evidence, that the Catholic Church attempted to cover-up a priest's serial criminality.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Shot in long, deep-focus takes, Beyond The Hills shows how not just the church but a whole society has failed these vulnerable young women.
The way the camera lingers on the lividly bruised and battered faces of his characters, plus the clichéd use of slow motion, epitomise the film's limitations.
A beautifully assembled film which pays close attention to nature and judiciously incorporates black and white photographs and home movie footage alongside its interviews.
Cantet's film avoids period nostalgia, paying attention to the solidarity and tensions in the proto-feminist band as they struggle to break the shackles of mainstream society.
The film reminds us of his genius, without sugar-coating his self-destructive tendencies.
Avoiding the pitfalls of prurience and sensationalism, this dreamily photographed film reveals its young subjects to be vibrant and articulate individuals.
Masterfully filmed in long takes, this slow-burner lays bare a world of systemic corruption.

With every word taken from Baldwin's own prolific literary output and public appearances, the film couldn't be more timely in presenting a despairing analysis of how racial injustice bedevils American society.
Troubling but compelling, this unflinching thriller deftly builds to its chilling conclusion.
François Ozon crafts a sombre monochrome melodrama, which adopts its female protagonist's perspective and skilfully plays with viewers' expectations.
Donaldson does a fine job of celebrating his subject's many achievements. Yet compared to, say, Ayrton Senna, McLaren himself doesn't cut a compelling figure.
It's lushly photographed and costumed, plus dreamily confusing, yet it vividly brings a past to life.
Occasionally rambling, it's kept afloat by an eclectic soundtrack and Christopher Doyle's striking urban lensing.

A critical docu-portrait of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, shot over a six-year period in which he was under house arrest in Norfolk and then holed up in the Ecuadorian embassy following sexual assault allegations.
Choice performances from Anthony Hopkins and Emma Thompson, but any social criticism is weakened by the veneration of the privileged milieu.
Bringing to light a little known and far from honourable chapter of Danish history, this is convincingly acted and insanely tense.
Superbly shot in high-contrast monochrome, it unfolds in a stylised universe where character is defined by actions and costumes rather than words.
An attractive if conventional biopic of French underwater explorer Jacques Cousteau.
Newcomer Lee has crafted a timely romantic drama, rooted in a keenly observed rural environment.
Including clips from nearly 100 films made between the '30s and '70s, he pays heartfelt tribute to the directors, stars and composers who ignited his passion.
movie_title: My Journey Through French Cinema (Voyage À Travers Le Cinéma Français) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The personal is the political in Maysaloun Hamoud's vibrant, taboo-breaking debut feature ...
The film's analysis is somewhat superficial, but comparisons to current White House incumbent Donald Trump's vows to "make America great again" are inevitable.
Blending archive footage, contemporary interviews and dramatic reconstructions, the film reminds us how dangerous the sport could be.
Trophy challenges audience preconceptions, revealing the complexities of the issues at stake.
This dreamily shot US indie is an insightful study of sexual repression and awakening, featuring a compelling lead performance from Brit newcomer Dickinson.
This is a taut, timely drama, even if the pay-off doesn't quite match the build-up.
Tracing how the world's peaks came to be viewed as playgrounds, it needs to be seen on the big screen for its vertiginous images of high-altitude adventurers.
There's poignancy too, thanks to Brize's build-up of telling details and Chemla's subtle turn.
Blurring the fiction/documentary lines (it features non-professional actors), it's spiced with eccentricities: alongside Marxist theorising, we get ostriches and even a song- and-dance number.
movie_title: The Nothing Factory (A Fábrica de Nada) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's proficiently put together but decidedly derivative, right down to the Usual Suspects-esque twist ending.
Movingly conveys both Curry's brilliance and his inner torment.
This sentimental drama comes undone via the redemptive romance between its emotionally introverted protagonist and Bérénice Bejo's compassionate female doctor.
Against the odds this is a sometimes droll and surprisingly tender affair, and a fitting end to Seidl's magnum opus.
Johnson's compassion shines through, while the images raise vital ethical questions about the responsibilities of the nonfiction filmmaker.
A genuine treat for cinephiles.
Closer to Abbas Kiarostami (Like Someone In Love) than Berberian Sound Studio, it's a lyrical if emotionally muted journey.
Expertly avoiding sensationalism, this potently acted drama reminds us of Jean Renoir's celebrated dictum, that everyone has their reasons.
There's a dream-like quality to this nimble-footed tale, in which coincidences, repetitions and digressions abound, and where various characters appear seemingly magically within scenes.
A confident, vigorously acted debut, unsparing in its scrutiny of oppressive 'family values'.
It's an intimately focused, calmly composed drama, albeit one that can't help seeming a little outdated given the ongoing upheavals in Egypt.
movie_title: El Sheita Elli Fat (Winter of Discontent) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Unwinding at its own gentle pace, Museum Hours delicately explores a platonic friendship between two emotionally reserved people.
Despite its admirable ambitions, Born in 68 feels like an inferior imitation of The Best Of Youth, with some talented actors let down by an inferior screenplay and unimaginative cinematography.

There's something trance-like about the flow of images here, as close-ups of details within illustrious paintings are juxtaposed with shots of faces and buildings in the streets of contemporary Vienna, alongside numerous fades to black.
The motormouthed Zizek serves up an intellectually provocative psychoanalytical dissection of Hollywood movies.

Assembled from a plethora of visual sources, including the title footage, this impressively edited and dynamically scored film successfully combines visceral bursts of action with intimately observed sequences ...

Propelled by the powerfully credible performances of its non-professional teenage leads, and punctuated with contemplative images of post-industrial landscapes, The Selfish Giant ultimately achieves in its poignant coda a note of unexpected grace.
An affecting film, thanks to Fukuyama's understated turn and Koreeda's typically graceful visual storytelling.
Sticking tightly to its heroine's everyday routines and rituals, this deft blend of humour and pathos fully earns its defiantly upbeat dance-floor denouement.
It's an elegantly shot and designed tale, yet strangely lacking in emotional weight.
It's through the dysfunctional mother-son relationship at its core that a pointed critique of the corruption bedevilling Romanian society emerges.
The leads struggle with an undernourished script, and there's a cheapo televisual vibe throughout.
The director paints a partisan picture, but offers an eloquent and effective challenge to orthodox eco-wisdom.
Impressively designed throughout, The Unbeatables also keeps the laughs kicking, both in its characterisations and its nods to the likes of 2001: A Space Odyssey and Citizen Kane.

This heartfelt documentary explores Foley's restless life and his warzone reporting work. Most moving are the testimonies from Foley's fellow hostages, who pay tribute to his selflessness and generosity of spirit.

Deadpan Scandi-humour runs through writer/director Grímur Hákonarson's carefully crafted tale, and there's no doubting the film's empathy for its protagonists. Shame, then, that the final-reel shift into tragedy feels misplaced.
An unsentimentally observed, credibly acted study of a marriage turned sour, in which a dance sequence involving the whole family movingly conveys a former shared happiness.
There's no denying the artistry, with strikingly lit and framed compositions, but Horse Moneys opacity proves frustrating.
It clearly aims to move, but the cutting between three timelines dilutes emotional impact. And despite Spall and Fox's efforts, there's something too good to be true about the characters.
It's not the most probing doco, but the man himself, mobbed wherever he goes, emerges as a genuinely charismatic, likeable individual.
Kleiman seems less interested in explaining the whys of his scenario than in observing his characters and their interactions -- a strategy that pays off thanks to excellent lead turns.
Feels like TV sketches, with not enough laughs.
Released to mark the 50th anniversary of England's World Cup triumph, this polished doc pays tribute to that winning team's golden-haired captain Bobby Moore.
There are some huge narrative implausibilities, but Schipper's virtuoso style propels us through his characters' highs and lows. Ace performances, too.
It's simultaneously a very knowing and strangely innocent film...
Feels slightly diffuse in its analysis.
Sweeping landscape shots and the reliable presence of Sergi López, here playing a scarred private investigator, can't distract from the clichés of a particularly dim-witted script.
The ambition, scope and drive impress greatly, as does Ramírez, who nails his character's fascinating contradictions.
Entertaining and enlightening, this sporting underdog doc chronicles the efforts of the fledgling Afghan national cricket side to reach the World Cup Finals.
There's a genuine vibrancy and the championing of sexual diversity and tolerance is heartfelt.
Misplaced critical vitriol torpedoed the original 1960 release of director Michael Powell's psycho-horror. Fifty years later, it's an undisputed British masterpiece.
Shot in a gloomy palette of greys and browns, Execution offers a chilling re-creation of everyday life under Stalin.
Beautifully acted by its ensemble cast (especially Lambert Wilson and Michael Lonsdale), it immerses us in its subjects' rituals, everyday tasks and spiritual dilemmas.
Anchored by Froggatt's powerful performance, this is stark social realism steeped in honesty and humanity.
Enemies incisively interweaves archive footage with revealing interviews...
Pilger assembles an impressive range of interviewees, including 'embedded' war correspondents and whistleblowers.
Ozpetek could have trimmed some of the sub-plots, but it's broadly amusing (especially when our hero's camp pals pitch up) and the performances are as warm as the southern setting.

Heeding Jean-Luc Godard's maxim that all you need to make a movie is a "girl and a gun", Isabelle Czajka's freewheeling feature is built around a captivating turn from French rising star Anaïs Demoustier.
movie_title: Living On Love Alone (d'amour Et D'eau Fraiche) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the distancing preciousness, there are compensations in the beautiful Lisbon vistas, fado music and unexpectedly moving resolution.
Performances are perfectly pleasant, but more of Ramona's flights of fancy and less lingering on the adult romance would've added some oomph.
There are no dissenting voices to be heard in Norberto López Amado and Carlos Carcas' movie, but then it's easy to admire Foster...
movie_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster? (2012)

movie_review_blurb: If the tea-drinking Nénette remains an enigmatic figure, Philibert makes fascinatingly clear how we humans project our own feelings and thoughts onto her.
It's a marginal improvement on previous outings, if only because Lawrence is slightly lower in the mix.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: British writer/director Joanna Hogg follows her debut Unrelated with another insightful, impressively acted study of upper-middle-class family friction.
Valdivia captures his characters' bubble-like existence without neglecting the bigger social picture.
Powerful, semi-improvised performances bring us closer to the isolated characters, who movingly earn themselves the possibility of redemption.
There's nothing earth-shattering here, but the acting's credible and the wrap-up unexpected.
The laughs are defiantly non-PC, but there's no doubting the sympathetic handling of the working-class heroes, nor the righteous rage at the injustices of contemporary capitalism.
Revolution is vibrantly shot, scored and edited, yet permeated by a mood of disenchantment.
Unfolding in wintry Portland, this is a beautifully photographed tale, where the mystery itself is a red herring.
Luc Besson returns with this entertaining adventure-cum-fantasy, set in 1912, and adapted from Jacques Tardi's comic series.
movie_title: Les aventures extraordinaires d'Adèle Blanc-Sec (The Extraordinary Adventures of Adèle Blanc-Sec) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A refreshingly non-judgemental and amusing portrait of homosexuality in the pre-AIDS era, Taxi Zum Klo matter-of-factly addresses the mundane and the perverse.
movie_title: Taxi zum Klo (Taxi to the Toilet) (1981)

movie_review_blurb: Wider themes of leadership and social class are explored, but it's fundamentally aimed at cricket fans, who'll doubtless relish rewatching Beefy's heroic feats with bat and ball.
Despite the theatrical execution, it's winningly acted, while Blier provides a typically defiant resolution for his transgressive lovers.
movie_title: The Clink Of Ice (Le Bruit Des Glacons) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Nowrasteh's approach is hardly subtle, favouring didactic dialogue and overblown scoring. That said, a 20-minute stoning sequence possesses the shocking brutality of The Passion Of The Christ
Unearths the flawed humanity behind the apocalyptic theorising.
Drawing on India's rural-versus-urban divide, Rizvi spins a dynamic, enjoyably-acted yarn that balances farcical humour with a satisfying seriousness.
Poignant and illuminating, it's also suffused with Varda's playful, eccentric spirit.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Deliberately paced, it has the timeless, brooding quality of a tragic folk tale, in which violence begets more violence. Strickland builds and sustains an ominous atmosphere through stark images, artfully heightened sound design and an otherworldly score.

Newcomer Peter Strickland's slow-burning tale of female revenge in deepest Romania impresses with its pared-down storytelling, its eerie visual and aural atmosphere and the ambiguity of its characterizations.
Shot with clarity and plenty of dry humour, this impressive collection of five short films is proof of the youthful vitality of the New Romanian Cinema.
Bromberg tells the fascinating story of a controlling director who was given free rein to push back the boundaries of cinema, only to find his own sanity jeopardised.
Strong echoes of Michael Winterbottom's In This World in this affecting immigration drama from French writer-director Philippe Lioret.
Despite being engagingly acted and smartly structured, this ambitious effort from Rémi Bezançon ultimately presents a sentimental vision of la vie famille.
movie_title: Le Premier Jour du Reste de ta Vie (The First Day of the Rest of Your Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully shot on HD video and Super 16mm, this tender film channels the romantic spirit of Wong Kar-wai, über-cool soundtrack and all.

Writer-director Michel Hazanavicius amusingly sends up the genre's visual and verbal codes, and relishes satirising OSS 117's sexist and anti-Semitic views by pairing him with a beautiful female Mossad agent.
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne répond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Koreeda's big theme is the transience of all our lives, but he doesn't make a meal of it. Instead, he essays a moving restraint that evokes Ozu's vintage domestic dramas - no mean feat.
That Blaize is also the producer might explain the absence of any dissenting voices in a work which seems happy to act as a cheerleader for her career.
Admittedly, the characters are schematically drawn, but there's real chemistry between the freestyling leads and, refreshingly given the milieu, there's not a gun in sight.

The functionally photographed She, A Chinese isn't at all lacking in thematic ambitions, but there's a disappointing sketchiness to the storytelling and Lu's opaque central turn hinders an emotional engagement in her character's quest.
A single viewing only scratches the surface of this dazzling montage-based Hitchcock quasi-doc.

Drawing on vivid archive footage of working conditions in rural Nicaragua, director Fredrik Gertten also benefits from a charismatic protag in Juan Dominguez, the Ferrari-driving lawyer representing the underdogs.

Even if you don't know your pliés from your jétes, it's impossible not to be impressed by the athleticism, agility and stamina on display, though the star of the show is the ballet's imperious artistic director, Brigitte Lefèvre.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Handling potentially lurid material with restraint, Llosa finds a measure of beauty in the rituals and superstitions of community life.
movie_title: The Milk of Sorrow (La Teta Asustada) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A sensitively directed and movingly acted story of forbidden love.
Writer/director Bellocchio boldly orchestrates a whirl of archival newsreel footage, silent-movie clips and fictional re-enactments.
The storytelling may be pedestrian, but the swooping aerial images of the massed pilgrims journeying on camels and circling the Kabba are wondrous to behold.
A wonderfully eccentric offering from Resnais, with fine ensemble performances to match.

Moving fluently between the film's contrasting worlds, writer-director Catherine Corsini's emphasis is less on exploring her characters' psychological motivations than showing how they are overwhelmed by their emotions.

Worth seeing for Duris' athletic, charismatic and quick-witted performance, not to mention his snake-hipped recreation with Paradis of Dirty Dancing's pas de deux. And yes, he does dance like Patrick Swayze.
A moving tribute to the dedication, humanity and camaraderie of its female subjects.
Contrasting elegant surfaces and heartfelt feelings, it's an enigmatic gem -- and at 64 mins, truly succinct.
movie_title: Eccentricities of a Blonde-haired Girl (Singularidades de uma Rapariga Loura) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A superior procedural.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Following events over several years, director Julia Bacha uses visual sources and interviewees (including Israeli soldiers) to sculpt a timely testimony to the power of peaceful resistance.
It powerfully demonstrates how the successes of these sportsmen, in a game associated with white colonial superiority, proved inspirational in the global struggle for black equality.
Chronicles the rise and fall of Renato Vallanzasca, a notorious Milanese gangster in the '70s and '80s who's serving several life sentences.
The polar landscapes and fluctuating weather are superbly shot, while there are compelling turns from the two actors, who bravely perform their own stunts.
Rich HD cinematography, the vivid sense of community and the dramatic focus on its young heroine all stop proceedings becoming weighted down by social issues.
The opaque Sokolowski is a real discovery, and this mysterious film builds to its climactic act of salvation...
It's glossy but saccharine, hammering home its coming-to-terms-with-life message as Laurent steers the story into contrived tragic waters.
Belgian filmmakers Benoît Delépine and Gustave Kervern return with an often surreal road movie, which blends social commentary with deadpan humour.
Haneke fans will be impressed by this rigorous, finely acted study of a suburban paedophile. Skillfully avoiding sensationalism, it nonetheless compels the viewer to contemplate the banality of evil.
Closer in metaphysical spirit to Kiarostami than to Leone, it lingers thanks to beautifully lit widescreen images of lived-in faces and barren, beautiful landscapes.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Reveals not only the realities of artistic censorship, but its firework-laden finale shows how cinema thrives on spontaneity.
Corpo Celeste's acute sense of place, feel for adolescent confusion and miraculous resolution suggest that Rohrwacher is a talent to watch.
A warm-hearted salute to both classical French cinema and working-class solidarity.
It ranks proudly alongside The Rules Of The Game as Renoir at his stunning best.
Chronicles the life and times of the first musical superstar from the third world to gain a global audience, with the reggae singer's posthumous Legend album selling some 25 million copies.
Despite a very modest budget, A&T manages to be both intimate and cinematic, fully earning its upbeat seaside finale.
Conjures poignancy, grace and a feel for symbolic seasonal change that's positively Renoir-esque.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Alex Beaupain's songs effectively convey emotion, but Beloved doesn't scale the heights of the Truffaut and Demy films it pastiches.
Seeks to channel the paranoid spirit of early Polanski, but contrived attempts to 'explain' the film's many mysteries ultimately disappoint.
Pistereanu mines a fine, compelling blend of menace and innocence.
movie_title: If I Want To Whistle, I Whistle (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's an undeniably didactic drama, but scores points for stylistic ambition and its heartfelt sympathies towards the dispossessed.
Modest in both budget and impact, it's nonetheless intelligently executed...

There are interesting ideas here about the gulf between the world-weary adults and the prematurely-sexualised and often foul-mouthed adolescents, but overall Polisse is a clear case of a film that needed much more stringent editing.
It's certainly enjoyable to watch the beanie-hatted, craggy-faced Dafoe set animal traps with his bare hands.
A self-promoting yet revealing documentary from venue owner Tom Lawes.
Balancing sectarian tragedy and earthy humour is never easy, and Labaki crams in too many stereotypes.
Writer-director's Jerome Le Gris' sub-Hitchcockian thriller piles up the genre clichés to the point where you assume the whole enterprise must be an Agatha Christie-style parody.
movie_title: Requiem for a Killer (Requiem pour une Tueuse) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Scripted by ITV news correspondent Tom Bradby from his novel, Shadow Dancer sidesteps many of the clichés of films relating to this particular armed conflict.

This is more than just a scathing satire on the political, religious and military representatives of the ruling elite. Ever the surrealist, Buñuel is also paying tribute to the poise and resilience of the very people he spent his whole career attacking.
movie_title: The Discreet Charm Of The Bourgeoisie (Le Charme Discret de la Bourgeoisie) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Greater female input might have alleviated the film's tiresome chauvinism.
A film that makes you ponder the mysteries of human existence anew.
A valuable reminder of how athletes can take a courageous stand.
Lanners makes effective use of a string of fairytale settings (woods, rivers, spooky houses) in this atmospheric coming-of-age yarn.
An overlong, emotionally shallow study of so-called 'twin flames', possible reincarnation and learning to let go of love.
We're immersed in the routines and rituals of the female prostitutes, in a world smelling of "sperm and champagne".
The human characters are rather sketchily drawn and the storytelling follows a blandly 'uplifting' path.
It's a demanding, high-brow watch, yet ably conveys the rootlessness and dislocation of the immigrant experience.
A richly shot, impressively acted film containing a powerful, bleak vision of both childhood and a repressive adult world.
Expertly shifting between present and past , writer-director Denis Villeneuve displays an impressive command of his material, patiently building up to an emotionally explosive climax.
Impressively shot and acted, A Separation refuses to judge its characters: everyone here has their reasons.
Robustly acted and dynamically photographed; Tavernier is equally adept at directing intimate encounters as choreographing savage battles, conveying the sense of a society tearing itself apart.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Wilson deftly uses cinematic means - widescreen framing, sound, focus, PO V - to convey her protagonist's ordeal, eliciting exceptional acting from Macedonian newcomer Petrovic.
movie_title: As If I Am Not There (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's a hypnotic quality to its flow of images, allowing the viewer to see the insect world anew.
Liz Garbus' intimate film combines impressive archive footage with candid interviews with Fischer's friends and colleagues.
It's light-hearted rather than provocative, though the gag about the elderly customers' love-making stamina is a bit of a flop.
Built around a multilayered performance from Duris, it's a film unafraid to pose more questions than it answers.
Shot in long, fixed takes and relying on natural light and sounds, this is a beautifully photographed if emotionally muted study of lost innocence.
If the father/son relationship follows a tried-and-true trajectory, its obvious debt to Bicycle Thieves is repaid with sincere sentiment and strong acting.
Despite bold imagery and topical social commentary, a slender running time leaves characters and scenes under-nourished.
The fluent past/ present time-shifts are seasoned with moral ambiguity - as well as the possibility of fresh beginnings.
There are moments of lyrical beauty and Porterfield never patronises his subjects, but a sense of tranquilised resignation dominates.
Salvadori generates few laughs from this convoluted tale, whose romcom trappings sit uneasily with its lonely, troubled characters.
The multi-layered screenplay, stunning sets and a terrific ensemble are just some of the enduring pleasures of a truly collaborative masterpiece.
movie_title: Children of Paradise (Les Enfants du Paradis) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: There's a deceptive simplicity to British writer-director Andrew Haigh's poignant, fluent character study, which has already earned comparisons to Before Sunrise.
Eschewing voice-over, director Yves Hinant spotlights the reality of an occupation where an unpopular call can result in death threats.
Secretly recorded footage from a Guantanamo Bay interrogation of 16-year-old Canadian citizen Omar Khadr forms the core of this compelling doc.
movie_title: You Don't Like the Truth: 4 Days Inside Guantanamo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Heartfelt and inventive, this documentary from exiled director Ali Samadi Ahadi chronicles Iran's abortive Green Revolution during the summer of 2009.
Flashbacks, overlapping sound and dynamic editing viscerally convey Harris' state of mind, leaving a bleak picture of the struggle to win the Afghani people's trust.
Its undeniable star is raspy columnist and ex-crack addict David Carr, whose rigorous reporting upholds the paper's finest traditions.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An intriguing forerunner to François Ozon's Swimming Pool, it's languidly paced and elegantly lensed, though its prize asset is Delon/ Schneider's sexual sizzle.
Skilfully smudges the boundaries between documentary and fiction.
This tale of unexpected emotional connections is charmingly acted and surprisingly moving.
The debut feature of twentysomething Rebecca Thomas, who herself grew up in the Mormon faith, this US indie is a decent coming-of-age yarn, adorned with some magic realist flourishes.
Building to a horrifying Vanishing-style conclusion, Larrain lays bare a society poisoned by violence.
This clinically shot oddity ultimately mystifies.
It's brash and bright, with a plot that's improbable in the extreme.
I Saw The Light delivers none of the emotional gut-punch that country music might claim as its chief contribution to popular song.
A must-see for music fans partial to the odd improvisation and bold re-interpretations.
A light, loving satire that laughs at the pretensions and follies of the over-educated.
It's brightly coloured eye-bait, Jim, exactly as we know it.
A short, bittersweet comedy which connects four separate stories of everyday weirdness through the welcome denominator of dogs short in limb and long in torso.
It mostly holds together, but you'd have to hope that David Brent: Life on the Road represents a farewell tour as well as a resurrection.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A period melodrama that's soppier than a seaman's mop.
If you've ever been stuck in an airport lounge, motorway service station or transit hub hotel, you might feel a sceptical appreciation for Passengers.
A Hologram for the King flirts with saying something meaningful about globalisation or the relationship between the USA and the Middle East. In the end, nothing comes of it.
A meditation on grief, bourgeois ennui and the paranormal.
Molly's Game is pure entertainment, funnier than the subject matter might suggest and fired at you with enormous energy.
Mountains May Depart is an affecting and ambitious tale of social upheaval in modern day China.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Bloodlight and Bami presents her as she is: beautiful and strong, sensitive and fierce.

The film's flaws are minor compared to those of Daphne the character, but just like the troubled soul at the heart of this engaging 90-minute drama: a high level of charm is retained in spite of whatever's wrong.
The magic of the film is that it finds the drama of London in the places we seldom look - building sites, old brutalist apartment blocks, underground escalators and scaffolds.
The result is a remarkable debut from a director who clearly excels in close studies of human fragility.
The film will appeal most strongly to golf's many fanatics, but with so much passion for its subject matter even a cynic might be won around by its warmth and earnestness.

Bunch of Kunst refuses to do any navel-gazing or indulge in the possibility of anti-star posturing: it's a matter-of-fact documentation of how a few middle-aged blokes finally get some traction and hard-won acclaim.

Loveless does not rise to the same dramatic intensity as Leviathan - its story and moral message is almost a little too simplistic - but it is still an excellently crafted film, a powerfully assembled portrait of a very unhappy family.
Shows the same skilled direction and sense of psychological nuance that made A Separation such a significant global success.
The exploration of the complicated relationship between mother and son provides the most compelling, emotionally grounded moments within the film.
It's silly, it's ridiculous, it's over the top. And it's a perfect piece of '90s nostalgia.
Jack Reacher: Never Go Back doesn't quite know whether it's a gritty thriller or an action comedy.
There's no 'back to basics' here, it just gets even more insane. They haven't quite gone to the moon yet, but it's getting there.
John Wick: Chapter 2 is a slick and kickass caper that never drags and does exactly what action movies should do.
It might be an ultra-conventional comedy, but at least it makes you laugh.
A candid, revelatory and at times disturbing documentary that represents one of the 'must-sees' of 2013.
Jobs feels more like a movie about Apple than the man who founded it.
Ocean's Eleven for Gen-Y; it's a 'pop heist movie' that's more concerned with looking cool than being it.
A gritty and intensely unsettling story of child abduction and obsession.
An interesting but underwhelming spin on the Wolverine character, where intimacy outshines action.
There's one reason to see this movie, and it's name is Sandrissa McBullock.
It's a giant Hollywood in-joke, but one that invites you to share in the laughter.
A massive-scale battle royale between robots and monsters that doesn't fail to entertain.
Too long, too weird and too darn tootin' unfunny.
A fascinating insight into Wikileaks and the two men behind the world's largest ever whistleblowing scandal.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Baz Luhrmann's Gatsby is a tale of two halves: unremarkable in the first and unexpected in the second.
It's your classic tale of 'boy meets girl, boy tries not to eat girl'.
Better than the sequel but far short of the first, Part III is...an adequate finale.
Massive in scale yet also capable of intimacy, JJ Abrams' latest movie is another blockbuster hit.
An ambitious and twisting crime drama about fathers, sons and responsibility.
What the studio's calling 'an action movie' - the Secret Service will call 'a comedy'.
Like a 'Best Of' album for sci-fi movies, Oblivion's gorgeous production value brings new life to old classics.
Don't let Identity Thief steal two hours of your life.
A remarkable and harrowing story about modern-day piracy and understated heroism on the high seas.
Between the magic beans or a ticket to this film... maybe take the beans.
Yippee-ki-NAY
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A charming film that raises, rather than replaces, the original Wizard of Oz.
Part road-movie, part restaurant-review, 100% hilarious.
Jason Bourne meets Run Lola Run in a movie that brings terrifying new meaning to 'child abuse'.
A confronting and compelling look at post-9/11 racism in America.
A confronting and at times deeply moving (if also sanctimonious) take on the US Civil Rights Movement.
A powerful true story of wartime horror, honour and forgiveness.
To use an old cricketing quip: The Counselor has all the gear but no idea.
A proper-sized blockbuster, where the humans are wholly incidental.
Dark, enthralling and undeniably exhilarating, this is the X-Men movie for X-Men aficionados.
A genuine artificial intelligence would've completely redesigned this film.
Dull villainy almost defeats a rather lovely romantic comedy.
Eloquent, offbeat and charming, The Grand Budapest Hotel is Anderson's most accomplished film to date.
It's all very Hunger Games Lite.
It's no Godfather Part II, but as far as sequels go, it's not bad either.
Trust, betrayal and good ole-fashioned right and wrong lie at the heart of Marvel's latest offering.
A wry, playful and intelligent piece of filmmaking that, like Toy Story before it, rises far above its station.
A powerful story of belief, devotion and ruinous obsession.
An animated corpse of a film about a reanimated one.
Flat and expressionless, like a punctured tyre that gets you to your destination yet denies you the pleasant diversion along the way.
A mostly-forgettable pantomime of blood, gore and sculpted abs.
An entertaining thriller let down by a stupefyingly illogical ending.
The most harrowing combat film since Saving Private Ryan.
This much-anticipated chronicle of depravity at once amuses and nauseates.
47 Ronin's emphasis on authenticity leaves it an altogether dour affair.
An unflinching, uncomfortable and entirely necessary modern classic.
A beautiful film about love and loneliness in the technological age.
An appealing tale of one young girl's attempts to make sense of the senseless.
An unexpectedly tender film about Walt Disney's 20-year effort to bring Mary Poppins to the big screen.
Enough action to entertain and enough Tolkien to satisfy.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A star-studded black comedy for anyone who's ever fantasised about killing their boss.
Absurd, bewildering and yes...still funny.
An acting masterclass delivered by some of Hollywood's best.
A compelling origin story for some of America's great storytellers.
A Wikileaks story that fails to match the drama of its real-life inspiration.
A slick, action-packed sequel for Marvel's God of Thunder.
A dark, uncompromising look into the disturbing world of human trafficking.
A high school killing spree leads to a captivating examination of parenthood and the 'nature vs nurture' debate.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Kevin Smith breaks with his lo-fi comedy tradition to deliver a horror story with themes of sex, religion and politics.
One good film deserves another.
When you think of vibrators, 'charming' probably isn't the first word that comes to mind.
An ambitious, honourable and satisfying conclusion to this genre-defining trilogy.
Some wildly entertaining dancing (and stripping) underscores several impressive performances.
If you thought the American Civil War was about ending slavery, you're in for a rude surprise.
Poking fun at the nastiness of elections, The Campaign finally brings together two of Hollywood's funniest comedians.
Legacy intact! The Bourne Legacy ensures we've not seen the end of the franchise just yet.
Messing with memories is how you forget that a better version of Total Recall happened 22 years ago.
Wes Anderson's darkest movie yet retains his whimsical sense of humour and Fantastic Mr Fox-styled absurdity.
Light entertainment at its lightest, The Watch does at least elicit some laughs.
A fresh, intelligent and action-packed addition to the time-travel anthology.
Brad Pitt excels amongst an incredible ensemble cast in this gritty crime thriller.
Short, silly and charmingly harmless, it's likely only the Stooges aficionados will find a whole lot to love.
An impressive Aussie line-up shines in this tale of Prohibition-era bootleggers.
Despite sumptuous cinematography and sublime acting, Paul Thomas Anderson's latest film ultimately feels a touch pointless.
Visually stunning with video game violence, this is Hollywood's answer to The Raid.
This Jake Gyllenhaal buddy/cop drama features some of the best on-screen banter in years.
A very British Bond, and also a very personal one.
Peter Jackson's return to Middle Earth feels familiar and unfulfilling.
A violent adaptation of the bestselling novels about an Iraq War veteran turned vigilante investigator.
A guaranteed musical tear-jerker about a jerk who becomes a teary hero.
A violent and cartoonish take on the '40s gangster scene in LA.
Tarantino's take on slavery is wildly creative, funny and frightening, true to form yet never predictable.
A spellbinding performance and a beautifully nuanced film about statesmanship, quiet contemplation and - above all else - principle.
Steven Soderbergh's superb (and supposedly final) film offers twists and intrigue in its dark examination of prescription medication.
Even 15-year-old boys will find this disappointingly puerile.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Time travel and unexpected love combine for one of the best films of the year.
A fascinating, unflinching and tragic documentary about the chimpanzee we tried to make human.
A refreshingly original idea backed by excellent performances and terrifically funny writing.
Courage, independence and family are all beautifully brought to life by Pixar.
Hands down the coolest film of 2011, Drive is a stylised genre film where the genre is constantly changing.
One long, extended chase sequence interspersed with awkward flirting.
Moneyball isn't just a great baseball movie; it's a great movie about baseball - and there's a difference.
A taut, historical thriller about the capture of one of Nazism's most evil.
Finally an action movie that recaptures the fun and adventure of old.
A masterful adaptation of John Le Carre's 1970s spy thriller about the secret British hunt for a high-ranking KGB mole.
A creatively unconventional invasion movie let down by its utterly unlikeable heroes.
Meryl Streep mesmerises in her portrayal of Britain's groundbreaking but controversial leader.
A beautifully touching, tragic and amusing follow-up film from the director of Sideways.
Scorsese's moving and magical tribute to the pioneers of filmmaking.
David Fincher's Hollywood take on the Stieg Larsson bestseller is a sleek yet somehow soulless adaptation.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Superpowers mightn't be for everybody - especially angry, disaffected teenagers.
Visually impressive but a little hollow overall, not unlike its lead.
It's 'Man vs Wild Wolf' in this suspenseful Alaskan survival film.
A fun and tender tale of infatuation backed by two outstanding Oscar-nominated performances.
This adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foer's 9/11 novel is long, shallow and unconcealed in its efforts to make you cry.
An entertaining but misfired take on the formative years of famed Gonzo journalist Hunter S. Thompson.
Chaotic and far-fetched yet funny enough to have audiences rolling in the aisles.
An exhilarating debut from the bestselling series about teenagers engaged in a deadly bloodsport.
Action so relentless, the stuntmen probably asked for stuntmen.
It's just like the board game, assuming the board game cost $200 million and was dumb.
Audrey Tautou stars in a light but charming French tale of 'Beauty and the Bumbling'.
Consistently offensive, and not in a way that should automatically be dismissed as 'edgy' or 'provocative'.
An action film so cack-handed it borders on parody.
Josh Brolin and a dose of Back to the Future breathe life and laughter back into the franchise.
Neither Tom Cruise nor a solid 80s playlist can keep the Rock alive.
A provocative and uncompromising study of a man haunted by sexual addiction.
Funny, suspenseful and terrifically imaginative, Edge of Tomorrow is a thinking-person's action film.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Woody Allen's magic trick here is misdirection via beautiful scenery.
Tender, tense, intelligent and morally complex, this is a genuine contender for blockbuster of the year.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Dark, gritty and heavy on the nostalgia, what Rogue One lacks in dialogue it makes up for in action.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With dazzling effects and wondrous new characters, J.K. Rowling's world of witchcraft and wizardry is back with a 1920s steampunk feel.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating study of the man who turned a small-scale hamburger joint into a $62 billion empire.
A terrific example of how to put the 'science' back into 'sci-fi' without compromising pace or action.
This improbable thriller starts out strong but quickly becomes bogged down in unnecessary plot twists.
Mel Gibson returns to the director's chair with a brutal, confronting and uplifting true story of extraordinary heroism.
Visually, this is Inception dialled up to eleven, a world-bending, shape-shifting and time-distorting Escher painting filled with heroes and villains duelling over the possibility of immortality.
Like a dull double-episode of NCIS.
We'd rather just watch Tom Hanks wander the great museums of the world with a Go-Pro strapped to his head and hear him whisper interesting tidbits and trivia.
An earnest tribute to the men who lost their lives and a solid rebuke to those who were responsible.
An old-school western, full of good guys, bad guys, gunplay and grit.
Eastwood and Hanks back to doing what they do best: understated Everyman heroism in a gripping yet heartwarming piece of cinema.
Over-produced and devoid of tension, Assassin's Creed ignores all the things that made its source material great.
Bland, unimaginative and ill-befitting the extraordinary story behind it, War Dogs feels like an amazing opportunity gone begging.
Overblown and underwritten, Leto plays the Joker like a pantomime gangster whose only threatening quality is the possibility of more scenes.
This previously genre-defying franchise now feels very much conventional.
A superhero movie with a social conscience that continually flits in and out of getting the balance right.
It's a reboot, not a remake, and its four new leads are fantastic.
Full of potential but light on substance.
'Big, Dumb & Fun' is a legitimate genre, but Independence Day: Resurgence forgot the fun.
Offbeat, intimate and impressively affecting, this Kiwi comedy is one of the year's strongest films to date.
A fast-paced but thin-scripted affair that does little other than re-confirm Idris Elba's action man credentials.
Not only does Civil War eschew the dull trend of city-wide destruction, it bases its entire plot on the consequences of having caused all that ruin.
A film so confused it honestly doesn't even know if it's a prequel or a sequel.
It's like an infomercial for The Great Society, and Moore's least cynical film in years.
The sequel nobody was calling for.
More like a reunion episode than a film, bouncing from scene to scene with barely a plot in sight.
Bryan Cranston shines in this remarkable true story about one of the darkest periods in Hollywood's history.
A captivating and unflinching portrait of private grief amidst one of history's most public tragedies.
Not even a determined McConaughey can make this real life drama about the hunt for gold sparkle.
The Commuter runs disappointingly close to the far superior Non-Stop.
Freaky Friday meets Indiana Jones in this surprisingly funny reimagining of the Robin Williams classic.
Unjustifiably long and with misplaced humour throughout, The Last Jedi nonetheless delivers some scintillating action, spine-tingling lore and a loving farewell to Fisher.
Weary, joyless and stammering, Affleck's Batman acts more like a corporate recruiter than a caped crusader in this dull, CGI affair.
Fast-paced, irreverent and with a delicious 80s aesthetic, this might be Marvel's most entertaining movie yet.
Overly long and lacking much of the spark of its predecessor, this sequel still entertains with its wildly outlandish brand of action.
Whilst still entertaining enough to satisfy, Lego Ninjago is definitely the weakest entry in the franchise.
All the ingredients are there, yet the final product fails to deliver.
A bland and lifeless recreation of a Stephen King story that was anything but.
Like comedy comfort food, this third instalment offers little by way of new material yet delivers in spades on what you know and love.
Majestic. Breathtaking. A Masterpiece. Use all the best words then invent new ones. War for the Planet of the Apes is an astonishing achievement.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It may have taken 15 years and 3 reboots but Spidey finally has a decent villain.
This suspenseful and unsettling thriller is a welcome return to form for writer-director M. Night Shyamalan.
At one point Sir Anthony Hopkins (Remains of the Day, Shadowlands) says: "What a bitchin' ride". That's all you need know.
Let it drown.
Guy Ritchie gives the Arthurian legend the full Lock Stock cockney treatment, but we've seen it all before.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A gory, frenetic return to safe and familiar territory for Ridley Scott's epic Alien franchise.
An enjoyable ride, yet less innovative than its predecessor, mostly expanding upon existing plot lines, jokes and glitzy action sequences.
Despite the major departure from its origins, The Fate of the Furious still delivers in spades when it comes to entertainment.
Some TV reboots would be better left un-rebooted.
An entertaining, self-aware take on cinema's grumpiest superhero.
Intelligent life on Mars, perhaps, but none in this by-the-numbers sci-fi horror flick.
Big, dumb and fun, Kong is an exhilarating, old-school action romp.
A violent, gritty and soulful tribute to the character behind so much of this franchise's enduring popularity.
A strong contender for both 'Worst Film' and 'Least Funny Comedy' of 2017.
Spectacular costumes and a literal cast of thousands, yet not a single, well-defined character in sight.
Had it not been for all the clumsy Dark Universe building, The Mummy might well have soared as an old-school, Gothic-era Monster Romp.
The science shines brightest in this confronting true story that brings shocking new meaning to the phrase 'contact sport'.
Like 2016's surprise hit The Shallows, The Wall proves you can achieve a lot with very little.
Powerful, absorbing and deeply moving, Spotlight is almost certainly the best film about journalism of at least the past decade. Probably more.
Burton has crafted one of his most understated films; a fascinating study into 1950s sexual politics and art-world deceit.
A Lebowski-esque adaptation of Thomas Pynchon's novel that's as bewildering as it is entertaining.
Surprisingly enjoyable in spite of its flaws, Focus almost 'cons' you into having a good time.
With the events of Ferguson so fresh in our memories, Selma is uncomfortable yet necessary viewing.
The Theory of Everything serves as a fitting reminder that beyond the extraordinary maths lies a man: mortal, flawed and confounded by love.
Filmed like a play but choreographed like a dance, Birdman is cinematic ballet.
The Imitation Game is an astounding story, both for its marvel and its misery.
Introducing Baymax: the most loveable, huggable character in film history.
The strength of Russell Crowe's directorial debut is its entirely inglorious depiction of the ANZAC experience.
A better title for THE HOBBIT: THE BATTLE OF THE FIVE ARMIES would be: 'Rubbish: The Desolation of Tolkien'.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Girl On Fire has gone up in smoke.
"This is where I leave you" is what Warner Bros ought to have said after reading the script.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Action trumps horror in this fast-paced zombie thriller.
Keanu Reeves quips and kicks and does it all with an impossible level of cool.
Imagine Groundhog Day without any of the good bits.
Whiplash is a 'jazz thriller' and it's exceptional, engrossing cinema.
Downey Jr and Duvall keep this otherwise cheesy legal drama mostly watchable.
Dracula Untold: a story that's been told many times before, and far far better.
Another violent 'lone vigilante' flick from the team that brought you Training Day.
If it's a twister film you desire, save your money and revisit the only one worthy of the name.
Taika Waititi and Jemaine Clement's mockumentary about the undead keeps the genre alive and well.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An uncomfortably real film about corruption and deceit in the NSW police force.
Big, dumb and fun.
Another sci-fi film that eschews the science for too much fiction.
A cavalcade of great songs keeps this otherwise lacklustre adaptation from floundering.
A balanced and often critical perspective of the flawed visionary behind Apple, Pixar and everything 'Mac'.
FURY is a grim, violent and uncompromising WW2 flick told from the perspective of an American tank crew.
A simple but tense thriller told from the perspective of kidnap victim and 911-responder.
INTERSTELLAR might not be Nolan's best film, but it's certainly his most ambitious.
Ferocious and irresistible, Mad Max: Fury Road is a modern masterpiece that could redefine the action standard.
Tense, claustrophobic and predictably violent, Tarantino's latest is a slow burn, three-hour epic that would have been better served as two.
Too violent to be taken seriously and too serious to be any fun.
New planets and old faces, original characters and veterans to guide them - this is a franchise reborn, not reinvented.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's A Wonderful Life meets Pineapple Express in this stoner Christmas comedy.
Not quite The Armstrong Lie, it's still a compelling look inside "the most successful doping program" in cycling history.
A fittingly bleak and violent conclusion to this compelling (if also protracted) franchise.
A refreshing 'un-romantic' comedy detailing the many pitfalls of modern dating.
It's no Skyfall, but SPECTRE still contains all the elements of a classic Bond.
It's no Man On Wire, but it is a rare and welcome example of 3D done right.
The long overdue return of Johnny Depp, dramatic actor.
A heartwarming tale of friendship and a constructive engagement with feminism and gender inequality.
Mad Max: Fury Road for kids.
Worthy of its name, Everest is a staggering and spectacular piece of cinema that deserves to be seen.
A film defined by spectacular performances and misfiring direction.
An excellent idea turned into a children's film where almost every joke is aimed at people over 30.
Tomorrowland proves too preachy for adults yet too confronting for children.
Sadly, Jurassic World's magnificent dinosaurs just aren't enough to overcome the logic failings of a surprisingly recycled plot.
Juvenile and offensive, Ted 2 fires off a lot of jokes, yet few of them find their mark.
An overwhelmingly tragic and absorbing portrait piece.
In the year of the franchise, Genisys is far from perfect, but much more fun than Jurassic.
Big, Dumb and Fun' should almost be its own genre by now, and San Andreas is nothing but.
Sexy, funny and surprisingly heartwarming, Magic Mike XXL is an appealing road movie in disguise.
A traditional romcom with an entirely untraditional difference: a strong, sexual female lead.
Style wins out over substance in Guy Ritchie's playful reimagining of the popular '60s TV show.
Strong performances from Gyllenhaal and Whitaker save Southpaw from otherwise being a complete write-off.
A slick, provocative and timely biopic about one of hip hop's most iconic groups.
Funny, charming and very family friendly, Ant-Man is a solid debut for what will almost certainly develop into a meatier and more assured trilogy.
The best little horror movie since last year's acclaimed hit The Babadook.
At times it's like The Shining directed by Cotton Mather.
An indispensable general history of the enduringly controversial church.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The tone is exactly right, and the passage of a few years has been good on everyone's looks.
In short, the movie has just about everything.
If Spielberg doesn't capture the anarchic whimsy of Roald Dahl's 1982 novel, his film has the soft enchantment of what the giant would call a phizzwizard. A very good thing indeed.
There are many, many good jokes, the performers all seem to be enjoying the ridiculous bits offered them and the songs are both melodically catchy and clever in their abject puerility.
Director James Wan pulls off one terrific set piece after another. You'll squirm or jolt in your seat according to the puppetmaster's whim.

The marvel of Dory, and of so many Pixar movies, is that the primal payload is securely delivered even as the plot gets crowded with vivid, scene-stealing characters and takes wildly inventive twists.
When the film is on the move, it really moves.
Some of this is funny. A fair amount of it -- including the toilet joke -- isn't.
The voice work, including Dana Carvey's as an old basset hound with wheels propping up his hind legs, is terrific. But Slate wins Best in Show.
The acting, at any rate, is uniformly good. Clooney's performance belongs with his best... And his smart, casual chemistry with Roberts is still on the money.
Director Jon Favreau sure doesn't monkey around: The pacing is sure-footed, Mowgli's big faceoff against Shere Khan is exciting, and the story goes straight to the heart.

The Truman Show is a provocative, daring drama, and Carrey, heretofore the Silly Putty-limbed star of such lowbrow joy buzzers as Dumb and Dumber and Liar Liar, pulls off the movie's tricky leading role with aplomb.
This is a sweet, simple, dignified movie about young lovers whose every move is chaperoned by death.It seems safe to say that it will have millions of people verklempt between now and forever.
[Gone Girl] is something of a marvel, a disturbing, one-of-a-kind creature as confoundingly dangerous as a poisonous snake equipped at either end with a head, forked tongue and fangs.
The Coen brothers, director Ethan and producer-cowriter Joel, have finally latched onto a story strong enough to carry their eccentric mix of black humor and self-conscious style.
Not only is it a fawning love letter to the City of Light where it was shot, but the film is based on the comforting premise that the big city is just a small town when folks get to know each other.
The story of 8 Mile isn't far removed from Eminem's own self-mythologized life -- a Jerry Springer-style saga out of Detroit -- but the unslakable anger is gone.
Moore gives one of the year's great performances -- subtle, lingeringly rich -- in director Todd Haynes's peculiar revisionist homage to old Hollywood women's pictures.
The movie is full of battle scenes, all of them interchangeable.
If the story gets dangerously thin, Grant is pretty well flawless. And Collette, always good, is heartbreakingly believable.
A brief nightmare sequence, which appears to be some sort of hallucinatory blend of collage and live action, is simply one of the greatest bits of animation I've ever seen.
Although seemingly about a creep who kills, it is as much about our own voyeuristic fascination with movies.
The plot provides a worthy lesson for kids, but it plays out like George Orwell's Animal Farm as retold by Barney. Kinda weird.
A little red herring is one thing. But don't smack me in the face with it, all right?
It plausibly lays out Palin's path from unsteady candidate to confident (or arrogant) rogue player.
[Damon] has lost none of his battered gravity, and director Paul Greengrass keeps the action racing forward in a splinteringly rough documentary style.

When the big battle between Magneto and Xavier's forces gets going, you have lightning bolts, steel claws, magnetic fields, explosive red rays and flyaway tongues. It's a variety show, and all the acts have rushed onstage at once.

Arriving a mere five months after Batman v Superman, a DC Comics epic as vaultingly joylss as a memorial chapel in Valhalla, Suicide Squad at least has some rumbling, crunchy kick -- and, amid a sprawling, grungy cast, a terrific Margot Robbie.
Tim Matheson captures the essence of the Reagan persona - a born performer whose public and private selves were so in sync, perhaps even happily, that they became indistinguishable.

Director Frears maintains a quick, frolicsome tone right up until the moment Florence receives her coup de grace, which he delivers with a bold, simple and unexpected shot that's something of a masterstroke.
It's wild and funny. Also disturbing. Also borderline insane.

One problem is that Freed can't risk pushing the trilogy's S&M scenes any further without becoming seriously kinky, subversive or violent: To actually turn anyone on would be tantamount to a turn-off.
Lawrence's exceptionally moving performance, the one subtle thing here, is probably all that makes the film bearable.

Gal Gadot's Wonder Woman was the best thing about the swampy Batman v Superman, and now her solo outing is the far superior film: Wonder Woman, directed by Patty Jenkins, elevates her from third wheel to real deal.
The movie will make fans happy, very happy, and it will reduce everyone else to a mass of cooing, goo-goo-ing ninnies, all in the thrall of a character named Baby Groot.
What will keep [fans] happy during Fate's two hours, are the spectacular run of car chases and pileups.
Daring, funny and thumpingly suspenseful.
Johnson is (as she was in the first one) probably as good as the material and direction allow.

The movie wouldn't tax the intelligence of a flea -- it's about a dog, reborn through many canine lives, in search of meaning and happiness -- but even so it succeeds on its own, Kleenex-consuming terms.

Director Shyamalan really gets his mitts on you with this one: It's wild and suspenseful, and without his trademark trick of pulling the rug out from under you at the end with such a vigorous tug that you end up on your backside and not terribly amused.

Lights can also stand as Fisher's tender, touching, typically rueful goodbye-to-all-that, a summing up of her life both at the heart of and somewhat off to the margins of a classic celebrity narrative.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [Washington and Davis' performances], both prior Tony winners and now nominated for Golden Globes, will be remembered as two of 2016's very best.

Deliberately paced but highly rewarding, Arrival ups its IQ with Jeremy Renner as a soulful physicist, gorgeous production design... and a poignant twist that brings the drama back to the human level.
La La Land always feel emotionally direct and natural, rather than cloying, playful or cute. If it's meta, it's also millennial.
Director Bill Condon sets this all in a storybook production that's sumptuously ornate.
The highly hummable score, by a team that includes Lin-Manuel Miranda, includes a big song for Moana, "How Far I'll Go," that should finally allow you to let go of Frozen's "Let It Go."
This comedy has everything going for it, not least of which is Cruise's most appealing performance since Risky Business.
Every detail shines with significance.

Sawyers is uncannily good as Obama while avoiding plain mimicry. He's the proverbial young man in a hurry, only too cool to let you see him sprint. Sumpter has the trickier, tougher role (the first lady probably knows the feeling).
Near the end, as we watch aviation re-enactors simulate the cockpit conditions under which Sully was operating, even these relatively humdrum moments have their own white-knuckle tension.
You'll be repeatedly fooled and surprised. Just like Rachel.
It's like the first film, corny and broad but sweet. It's kind.
Even if the movie doesn't add up, it's fun.
Director Barry Jenkins has somehow figured out how to envelop this turbulent story in an atmosphere that's achingly tender and even beautiful.

Flowers, both the book and the new movie, is completely absurd - if you want to gauge the absurdity, just know that one of the darkest secrets in the narrative involves a doughnut - but somehow also psychologically coherent. It has a grip.

Any other actor in a high-collared burgundy cape and goatee would risk looking like a lounge magician. But Benedict Cumberbatch is so unmannered, so smart, so playful, he makes the title character...one of the best Marvel movie superheroes yet.

The movie itself is a bit of a push-me-pull-you - a properly magical experience (the production design, including the animals, is enchanting) tugged in other, darker directions by Rowling's sometimes unwieldy screenplay.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Writing this is making me sad all over again, so let's end by saying that the acting throughout is exceptional, and that Affleck is phenomenal: It's a black hole of a performance, and its pull is overpowering.
Cotillard always remains the movie's center: With her large eyes and delicate nervousness, she projects genuine mystery and an air of potential doubleness.
Nation is an impressive movie, emotionally raw, occasionally overwhelming and also occasionally disconcerting.
Convincing performances from David Oyelowo and Kate Mara - as an escaped killer and his drug addicted hostage - are the saving grace of Captive ...
Welcome as it is to see Scorsese (somewhat) back in the groove, it's even more welcome to see Day-Lewis burning up the screen once again after a five-year absence.
In almost all martial arts action movies, plot is subordinate to action, and 'Kiss Of The Dragon' is no different.

'Hart's War' is a perfect example of a film that remains anchored in mediocrity from beginning to end. It plods along like a chronic asthmatic, meandering to a conclusion that's both irritating and implausible.
Perhaps the biggest surprise is Liotta, who turns in a hilarious turn as Dean, in a blatant send-up of his mobster screen persona.
Blessed with immense physical prowess he may well be, but Ahola is simply not an actor. And in truth, cruel as it may sound, he makes Arnold Schwarzenegger look like Spencer Tracy.
As the plot hemorrhages from one dire encounter to another, the clichéd old psychic routine is used to explain the plot to anyone who might still care.
This charming, thought-provoking New York fest of life and love has its rewards.

'Last Orders' has class stamped all over it.
A plodding narrative and anodyne script don't help, but the main problem seems to be in the characterisation of the most important character in the whole piece.
As with 'Swingers' before it, the sparkling chemistry between Favreau and Vaughn is undoubtedly the highlight of 'Made'.
An intelligent and expertly-judged microcosm of the inanity of war.
This is really all about Williams. Whatever he does next, 'One Hour Photo' will almost certainly go down as one of his finest hours.
Childless couples everywhere should rejoice.
History has shown us - quite brutally at times - that sequels are often little more than shameless cash-ins. 'Final Destination 2' conforms ruthlessly to this trend.
Bridges completely steals the show from the more lauded Spacey, who's simply on autopilot throughout.
'Dragonfly' tries to gather momentum by dipping into the box of tricks marked 'Shyamalan'.

Spielberg's insistence on labouring the Pinocchio resonance becomes extremely jarring, and nostalgia for the wide-eyed charm of his 1982 masterpiece 'E.T.' strengthens as the film staggers to its over-wrought climax.
This is an unusually patient and composed feature - it's solidly scripted, it knows where it's going and arrives there with a minimum of fuss.
should bring Barrymore at least the promise of more interesting scripts through the letterbox.
A powerful film of lasting emotional resonance.
Ultimately, it's in scenes where Schmidt's grief and emotional shock are evinced that Jack shows he's worthy of the plaudits which so freely come his way.
Despite a script which remains faithful to the sparse language of the novel, and some breathtaking cinematography, the whole production feels too lethargic.
Enjoyment, or even tolerance, of 'Along Came A Spider' hangs upon a couple of plot twists, which even by Hollywood standards are pretty far-fetched.

Slight, but at least fitfully funny.

It never tries too hard to please, never deigns for obvious laughs and it always manages to keep sight of what it wants to do and how it wants to do it.
'Bully' demands attention for the way in which it forces us to watch and digest a dark slice of American society. American beauty this ain't.

On paper, it may have looked like 'Cats and Dogs' would prove a winner with both children and adults. Maybe even another 'Babe'. Something, however, obviously went seriously wrong between the drawing board and the transformation to celluloid.
An adaptation that is often confused as to whether it's a love story set in wartime, or a war story with a love angle.
