Often tedious, occasionally cheap looking and always unimaginative, this should certainly put paid to any plans for a third installment. But, this being Hollywood, I wouldn't bank on it.
Forget the storyline, just laugh (and cringe) at the period.
If the yardstick for mob flicks is 'Goodfellas' (and it should be), then 'Brother' doesn't stand a chance. On its own, however, it is a stylish, colourful film.
There's just about enough charm and laughs here to keep Farrelly fans happy. Even the fat ones.
A refreshing, provocative and often hilarious tale of desire and reality, and the conundrum of how to satisfy the two.
Ultimately, it staggers out bloodied, partially bowed, but at least not totally beaten.
The most pathetic attempt at comedy in a long time.
movie_title: What's the Worst That Could Happen? (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Frazzled and edgy, Smith invests Dawn with the required measure of world-weariness and, crucially, she never succumbs to the temptation to slide into flippant, mocking territory.
...predictable and routine in the extreme.
The amount of laughs [here] is about the same as the number of Oscars Nicholson has. Maybe one less.
No matter what other aberration comes our way in 2003, there's no way it'll stink as much as 'Dumb and Dumberer'. You've been warned...
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Well-made, superbly acted and, for the most part, tightly written and structured, this is a worthy legacy to a remarkable chapter in Irish life.

a warm, melting analysis of life through the cold eye of death.
should have been left on the stage.
hopelessly sub-standard feel-good fare
reminds audiences that simple techniques are sometimes the most effective means of telling a dramatic story
looks good, sounds great, and essentially it's just one long party until the debauchery inevitably comes to collect its tax

five uninteresting characters and one seriously flat ending

Atmospheric in detail, the film's visuals are its strongest point.

movie_review_blurb: A tender memoir of one of the few occasions when the world united in awe.

Errol Flynn can rest easy in his grave.

It is startling that such a funny play is not so funny a movie.
A radical, avant-garde mood piece that is among the most mysterious artefacts in cinema.
High on tension, low on fat and fully deserving of its reputation as one of the finest war films ever made.
A glimpse of both the inner life of the soldier waiting for combat, and the literal reality of the most devastating war the world has ever seen.
Full of the drifting long shots, slow zooms, and overlapping dialogue that would help to characterise Altman's later masterpieces.

movie_review_blurb: Aidan Moffat is endearing and game throughout, providing the film with a lilting, self-reflective narration.
As mad as meth-fried badgers having shoes thrown at them... and makes about as much sense.
Not quite the guilty pleasure the first movie was, Goal! 2 can't quite stick it in the back of the net, pull off the double etc, etc...
t's fun in places, but the second you're out the cinema, Ghost Rider vanishes from memory in a big puff of smoke.

Grow Your Own has about as much edge as a prize melon, but even if the land's been well filled, there's still plenty of fertile soil here. Occasionally melancholy, often funny, this is touching, lyrical home-grown fare.

A bold, brash blast of a movie that will fade from memory like a puff of gunsmoke but still has the cordite whiff of a future cult hit about it for the leathered-at-2am crowd. Just don't expect plot or much depth.
you will be entertained even if, in rock'n' roll terms, it's less satanic metal than cutesy chart pop.

With such guiltily enjoyable hokum as a Dan Brown page-turner, you wonder what would have happened if someone actually had fun with it and, maybe, let us have some too. By treating trash as art, they've really taken the thrill out of this thriller.

While Skyfall might explore the past, its real success is in looking to the future; the movie promises that James Bond will return, and, as a result, the whole franchise feels re-energized, relevant and ready for action.
Feeling like a short that's been stretched out and mugged of its unpredictable tensions, it's a static slice of ghetto hell.

If the teenage girls sitting in the preview screening were giggling at this film's awkward sentimentality and its nosedive of an ending, maybe a rewrite was in order.
In many ways, this serious side of Young@Heart is what ultimately makes the film memorable.

movie_review_blurb: Captures the uneasiness of dating like few other movies.

Flawed, yes, but marvellously ambitious, and unforgettably gorgeous to look at.

Such an honest depiction can only contribute to a deeper appreciation of this remarkable artist.
Baker cuts to the chase - the iceberg strikes 30 minutes in - and maintains tension with consummate skill: not an easy task when the outcome is already known.
It's ... remarkable to see a mainstream movie touch on so many fascinating, powerful ideas without losing sight of its prime directive: to scare the socks off its audience.
Always deliriously entertaining.

A brilliant mish-mash of styles and genres, crammed with ideas and intelligence and carried off with a sense of rebellious fun and breathtaking invention not seen since, well, 'The Wrong Trousers'. Glorious.
The overall sense of chilly disengagement becomes trying, and there's a last-minute switch that suggests that Campos is trying to have his croissant and eat it.
There's no sense of threat or danger: this is a film with its head stuck firmly in the clouds.
Odd, intermittently amusing but wholly unsatisfying, an oddball experiment that simply doesn't work.
Hardcore horror heads may scorn its snail pace and shaggy-dog sweetness, but for discerning viewers, 'The Innkeepers' is a slow-burning charmer.
Two hours is a long time for something this restless and unforgiving - but it is fascinating, studded with moments of exhilarating beauty and remarkable, unexpected power.
'Total Recall' is Hollywood at its worst: pointless, witless, and so very unnecessary.
'The Three Stooges' is exactly the film it wants to be. Was it worth ten years of anyone's life? Probably not. Is it worth 88 minutes of yours? Absolutely.
Overall, this is a solid take on the material, but it could have done with a little less narrative incident and a little more cinematic sparkle.
Martens punctuates proceedings with moments of black humour and sudden, shocking violence, while the sheer frequency of twists, double-crosses and switchbacks keep the plot rattling along.
[A] low-key tale of life in rural Albania.
There are enough interesting ideas, memorable lines and inventive choices to make this is a notable entry into the overstuffed DIY horror canon.
'Undefeated' is no 'Hoop Dreams', but it's sturdily built and worthwhile.
The most affecting aspect of the film is its sense of compassion: we're never asked to condemn or condone, merely to understand.
Yet more proof of the astonishing vigour and inventiveness of current Korean genre cinema.
For those of us who don't have an deep interest in freeze-drying, 'El Bulli' is astonishingly, sub-'Masterchef' dull.
Lee's legions of fans might get a kick out of this, but newcomers would do better to invest in a DVD of 'Fist of Fury'.
There's no faulting the lyrical excellence on display. These guys are legends for a reason.
movie_title: Something from Nothing: The Art of Rap (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The way the various strands tie up is a mite predictable, but it's satisfying nonetheless.
Aboud has a strong visual sense - the framing is precise, the colours rich - but with a threadbare, episodic plot, thin characters and uninspired dialogue, this soon outstays its welcome.
With its confidently sustained mood of adolescent unease and discovery, 'Electrick Children' almost achieves something special.
An affectionate and affecting tribute.
Rather one-note in its bleakness, and doesn't have a vast amount to say beyond 'reform school sucks'.
This is a watchable but rather drab romcom which relies too often on Apatow-school cliché.
A combination of flat scripting and dull camerawork leave 'The Man Inside' languishing in TV-movie hell.
A fascinating, timely film.
There's heart, soul and personality to burn in 'Short Term 12' ... But this is a film that, like many of its young characters, desperately needs to calm down.
It's undeniably entertaining - and worth seeing for Kingsley alone - with the misfires never fully overshadowing the moments of glory.
Junking Verhoeven's sledgehammer satire in favour of real-world politics and 12A thrills, this is a slicker, shinier, admittedly inferior affair - but it's by no means a write-off.
The script is witty, the satire surprisingly pointed, and the animation tactile and imaginative.
This star-studded loopy melodrama is brash, foul-mouthed, self-consciously offensive, intermittently insightful and has a gaping hole where its heart should be.
The plot is a confusing, derivative mishmash of half-baked supernatural clichés, and the total absence of characterization makes it hard to care what happens.
The cumulative emotional effect is devastating: the final scenes are as angry, as memorable, as overwhelming as anything modern cinema has to offer.
This has big laughs (if not nearly enough of them) and wild ideas - provided you're tuned into Hill's idiosyncratic brand of slyly subversive, surreally silly seaside slapstick.
The film itself is a little too rough around the edges to fully engage. Fascinating subject, though.
The Wolf of Wall Street plays modern tragedy as epic farce, reminding us just how much fun Scorsese can be when he's in a playful mood.
A thoughtful, intelligent examination of the US war on drugs.
movie_title: How To Make Money Selling Drugs (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Not the disaster some feared it might be, but neither is it the endlessly quotable, deliciously idiotic follow-on so many of us were optimistically anticipating.
A grim, desperately unfunny parade of dick jokes, masturbation jokes, dick jokes, paedophilia jokes, dick jokes, rape jokes, gay jokes and dick jokes
'Homefront' just isn't the Southern-fried smackdown it should have been
This is tame, lifeless stuff, following the characters as they drift from bar to party, coffee shop to dance class.
With contributions from Coppola, Spielberg and Scorsese, the film does approach Milius with a certain reverence, but it can't disguise the fact that he's a troubling figure.
Most of what worked in 'Thor' works again: Hiddleston is campy and treacherous, Hemsworth is puppy-dog keen and there's a nice line in knowing jokery.
Ropey performances, join-the-dots plotting and nail-shreddingly awful dialogue.
Yet another intriguing, complex, strangely unlikeable big-budget experiment destined to thrill the fans and befuddle the rest of us.
Protechnically impressive, but something important is missing: tension, originality and memorable characters.
As the Palaces Burn metamorphoses from slam-dancing rock doc to genuinely gripping courtroom drama.
movie_title: Lamb Of God's As The Palaces Burn (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This remake of Clint Eastwood's Oscar-winning epic may lack the austere, classical weight of the original, but it makes up for it in visual splendour. Unexpectedly brilliant.
There's something rather bland about Veronica Mars ... But the one-liners are sharp, the plot unpredictable and the whole thing ticks along with a minimum of fuss.
There's no faulting Fletcher's unfussy, quietly impressive directorial style. A solid start.
There's enough goodwill to balance out the clunky bits.
Josh is simply too brittle a central character to empathize with, and as the noose tightens, it becomes increasingly hard to care what he thinks, says or does.
The suggestion that prostitution is a risk-free route to self-discovery for suburban soccer moms is glib bordering on offensive, but Robin Weigert is tough and terrific in the lead.
This relentless tale of small-town treachery spiralling into bloody vengeance is one of the year's best indie thrillers
It's always fun to watch scaly, skyscraper-sized behemoths lay waste to civilisation, but a bit more human drama would be welcome.
The effect is somewhere between incredible beauty and mounting discomfort.
Fans who made the first movie such a huge success will doubtless find much to enjoy here, while others will long for the boldness, scope and wit of The Avengers.
Stays on the rails thanks to strong performances, snappy dialogue and a relentless pace.
Willow Creek doesn't take us anywhere new -- the climax is abrupt and unsatisfying -- but it's a whole lot of jarring, juddering fun while it lasts.
When a documentary feels the urge to shout about its celebrity cast with a lengthy, elaborate opening-credits sequence, could it be making up for shortcomings elsewhere?
It's all very intimate and convincing ... and the performances are naturalistic throughout. But there's nothing here we haven't seen before.
movie_title: An Episode in the Life of an Iron Picker (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The sort of movie that adjectives like 'frothy' and 'bubbly' were invented for.
Ti West may possess one of the most compelling voices in horror, but the wit and originality that characterised his earlier films is all but absent.
The first half of Magic Magic is greatly enjoyable: the performances are strong, the photography is crisp and immersive, and the mood is ripe and ominous.
There's nothing wildly original here, but it's carried off with charm and wit, and a pair of very enjoyable central performances.
There are problems here ... but the characterisation is feisty and memorable, the song-and-dance sequences intricate and colourful, and it'll charm the socks off little people.
There's nothing wildly original here, and the gotcha scares get repetitive. But the script is witty, the cast are simply terrific ... a spiky, intelligent little throat-grabber.
It's a taut, unflinching first act ... But as the bodies pile up and the plot circles in on itself, that beautifully constructed web of suspense begins to unravel.
It's superbly structured and consistently suspenseful, offering keen insight into a conflict most of us won't even be aware of. Welcome back, Mathieu.
These two enormously watchable old-school heroes deserve better.
There's plenty to enjoy - smart one-liners, nifty shocks and one truly unsettling confrontation in a cemetery - but nothing to give Joss Whedon a run for his money
The young cast are smug and forgettable; the action sequences barely get going before they're over; and the whole affair is riddled with product placement and pop cultural references ...
Frustrating, lazy and lifeless.
The result will amuse hardcore Cash fans, but few others.
movie_title: My Father and the Man in Black (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This is an unambitious, old-school thriller, nothing more and nothing less.
All the little blue-collar Bosses and Bossettes out there in Jungleland will lap up this lively low-budget love letter.

This is a tighter, smarter film than either 'Shaun of the Dead' or 'Hot Fuzz', and buried beneath all the blue-goo aliens and terrible punning is a heartfelt meditation on the perils and pleasures of nostalgia.
Despite its defiantly un-PC 'fear-a-hoodie' message, the film nails its urban setting, filling every frame with a richly sustained sense of despair, decay and dread.
If Del Toro is pitching for an audience of 12-year-old boys (and we do mean boys: this is old-school macho), he's done a bang-up job.
This is a film built on sensation, misdirection and randomness. The result can be maddeningly obtuse, but it's also breathtakingly lovely and genuinely unsettling.
No comedy classic, then, but a good natured and engaging slice of goonish self-mockery.
A smart, gripping and enormously enjoyable parable.
'Black Rock' is never dull, but it's hardly the attention-grabbing calling card its creator presumably intended.
None of this ever feels remotely honest or real.
It's beautifully animated - the climactic sequence in Earth orbit is breathtaking - and its philosophical digressions are fascinating, if completely bananas.
Most disappointing is the film's lack of ambition, as what could have been a sparky mainstream space opera becomes just another tedious jungle chase movie.
For all its honesty, the film feels frustratingly incomplete, a great character in search of a story.

There's much to enjoy in 'The Reluctant Fundamentalist': fine photography, juicy supporting turns from Kiefer Sutherland and Om Puri, and a powerfully sustained sense of a man adrift in a world going mad.

Has plenty to recommend it, thanks to a string of memorable one-liners and Coogan's unmatched knack for skin-crawling physical comedy. But this is a long way from the back-of-the-net strike it should have been.
[A] conceptually bold, sporadically engaging but ultimately bland blockbuster.
The first hour may be Bay's career high point: it's fast, freaky, gloriously tasteless and startlingly pointed in its attacks on western insecurity, shallowness and greed.
The final shot is one of the most convincingly grief-stricken in cinema.
A self-serious, obviously heartfelt mood-piece which would have benefited from a bit more clarity and a lot less drifty, indie-by-numbers vagueness
'United States of Amnesia' comes not to bury Vidal but to praise him right to the rafters
movie_title: Gore Vidal: The United States Of Amnesia (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An ugly, nihilistic film, striking on the surface but empty underneath
This is a woman who has been through hell and come out kicking, and the result is as much a celebration as it is a documentary
A supremely intelligent, beautifully constructed film, interweaving comedy and character, satire and subtext
With its soap-operatic performances, bonkbuster plotline and sparkling seafront setting, all 'Adore' really lacks is a cameo from Alf Stewart
For the most part this is furiously compelling stuff, convincingly mounted and superbly acted
A joyous celebration of youth, friendship and rebellion
One of the most intriguing and thoughtful American films of the year.
Ari Folman takes a determined stride into the past with this dizzying, disjointed, always fascinating live action-animation hybrid
As a portrait of encroaching mental illness, For Those in Peril works superbly.
Ambitious it ain't, but Forget Me Not is a modest, memorable and rather moving slice of DIY cinema.
The focus is on Hawking's scientific achievements and celebrity status at the expense of much emotional content, but it's hardly fair to expect a warts-and-all portrait
If all you're after is a pair of mismatched heroes wisecracking their way through a series of explosive, well-mounted set pieces, look no further.
The hoax may have fallen flat, but the insights Boyd and Bain's story offers into creativity, commerce, obsession and insanity are unique and unmissable.
It's flavourless: the aliens are unscary and easily despatched, Vin's too silent to be interesting, and the other characters are either dull or offensive.
This isn't just the best-looking film of the year, it's one of the most awe-inspiring achievements in the history of special-effects cinema.
It's hardly high art, but for a cheapjack homegrown action flick this is surprisingly solid.
There's only so much shakycam and shrieking a person can stomach in one go.
The result is unlikely to linger long in the memory, but it's enormous fun while it lasts...
The Landlord succeeds thanks to terrific performances, political nous, flawless photography from Gordon Willis, a handful of sublimely witty moments and an overall sense of rebellious fun.
The result is less a film, more a bland Britcom box-ticking exercise.
Casts a superficial and short-lived spell.

The romantic trials of two wealthy, good-looking people, whose only barriers to happiness are their own petty insecurities, become tedious, and it's not helped by some stilted dialogue and awkward, mannered performances.

Bad-movie enthusiasts will doubtless have fun watching these oversized piscine predators leaping from the ocean and laying waste to Florida's coastal regions, but hasn't this tiresome, kitschy, so-bad-it's-good fad run its course?
The biggest problem remains the characters: neither Slade nor Stewart are capable of turning manipulative whinger Bella into anything more than a joyless black hole sucking the life from every scene.
This is Brand's movie all the way: he's the one snorting the drugs, throwing the tantrums and getting the lion's share of the laughs.
Kutcher and Heigl are unable to bring any warmth to what is at heart a bitter, cynical script. Just awful.
The result is a wonderfully entertaining and affecting patchwork of ideas, incidents, contrivance and coincidence.

In fusing European experimentalism and Hollywood boldness, Herzog has created a genuine oddity, a furious and unforgettable hybrid which may well prove to be 2010's most purely enjoyable moviegoing experience.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Prince of Persia won't linger long in the memory -- but then it probably wasn't meant to.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The endless plot twists may be perplexing, but they work to make the movie feel eventful and involving: after 140 minutes, audiences will feel like they've been somewhere, lived through something.
No masterpiece, perhaps, but Hot Tub Time Machine is post-pub perfection.
Iron Man 2 is a lot of fun: it's shiny, likeable and never boring. But it's also wildly uneven and unnecessarily convoluted, leaving the viewer unsatisfied and hungry for something more substantial.

Whatever the flaws in the script, there's no faulting director Louis Leterrier's visual ambition: this is a film of mighty vistas, beautifully designed beasts and intense, well-structured combat sequences...
The visuals are striking, the script sharp and well paced and it all wraps up with a breathtaking aerial battle sequence.
Perrier's Bounty is still a pleasure to watch: not exactly memorable, but packed with enough intellect, incident and strong performances to justify the investment.
There'll be worse films released in 2010 -- but not many.
Harper has done enough with this striking, ambitious debut to herald the arrival of a major new filmmaking talent.
Bold, unpredictable and quietly devastating, Mother is Bong's first masterpiece.
The credibility of faux-documentary filmmaking relies on clear plotting and convincing, semi-improvised acting.
It becomes clear why Oprah is such a huge Perry fan.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: At 81 minutes with credits, Jonah Hex feels crude, lazy and entirely perfunctory.
Imagine it's 1953 and you're watching a movie called 'Brain Suckers from Planet X', and you might even have a good time.
A film with no beginning and no end but a whole lot of expository middle, this is the least satisfying instalment in the series since Chris Columbus folded up his director's chair.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The moral and scientific implications of the project are deftly sketched and engaging.
Yes, this is shrill, crass mainstream Hollywood product, but it has a tendency towards lurid kitsch freakout which makes it not just relentlessly entertaining, but borderline subversive.
There are some decent laughs scattered throughout Due Date, but Phillips can't find a way to make his two leads likeable: they remain obnoxious and ill suited right to the schmaltzy finale.
The humour may be too broad in places -- corpse-based slapstick pales with repetition -- but, for the most part, 'Burke and Hare' is well-timed and often funny.
There are a handful of soaring, immersive and at times beautiful fight-and-flight sequences which utilise 3D in the best imaginable way.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: One of the year's most likeable family entertainments.
For fans of Larsson's books this could be the highlight of the cinemagoing year - for the rest of us it's a solid, enjoyable but emotionally unengaging detective story.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A few broader references might have made this punishing one-note trawl through the eminently spoofable tween-vamp saga slightly more watchable.
Genre-benders who like their Leone-esque historical slapstick buddy-action epics with a side order of political tragedy will find much to enjoy here.
movie_title: Little Big Soldier (Da bing xiao jiang) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The bravest, smartest comedy of the year.
It's good to welcome back one of the undisputed masters of modern genre cinema -- and adventurous kids will love it.
Perhaps the biggest problem is that there's nothing we haven't seen before: shower room shenanigans, cruel wardens and holy innocents marching towards an unconvincing date with destiny.
There's a wealth of joyously berserk idiot humour, fusing slapstick and satire, surrealism and stream-of-consciousness improv into what could well prove the funniest movie of the year.
The result is an entertaining mess: lively and stylish, but frustratingly inconsequential.

Simply by treating these characters as real, with all the uncertainty, emotional baggage and bad decisions that entails, the Duplasses expertly expose the hypocrisy of the airbrushed all-American ideal.
My Son, My Son... may be a minor work in the Herzog canon but it's still one of the more fascinating, frustrating, disturbing and beautiful experiences available to cinemagoers this year.
movie_title: My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This is a solid, unsettling, at times very entertaining thriller -- but the jury's still out on Reynolds.
The film's biggest problem is its repetitive, meandering script, a catalogue of coming-of-age clichés -- the first date, the first kiss, the first sip of booze -- that can't find anywhere new to go.
As senseless, perverse and unwieldy as it undoubtedly is, Shutter Island might be Scorsese's most enjoyable film in a decade.

Mary is a memorable comic creation for all the wrong reasons: glibly written, offensively characterised and bizarrely dressed, she's the classic screwball ditz taken to grotesque and at times unwatchable extremes.
Charles Crichton's direction is subtle but inventive - check out the snaking, near-single-take opening in a Rio cabana - and the performances, writing and plotting are faultless.
The comedy tends to the smirk-inducing rather than the laugh-out-loud, and the second half wanders somewhat, but Zelig is a strong contender for Allen's most fascinating film.
The result is the sweetest, smartest and most joyous of all the Ealing comedies.
Thirty years on, bustin' still makes us feel good. In fact, few movies have the power to make us feel good-er.
An unashamed study of selfish, sadistic criminality, and all the better for it.
An odd, unsettling movie overall, vague in its characterisation and narrative, dotted with bewildering asides and lacking any real warmth or humour.
There are moments of breathtaking visual creativity, from the not-quite-freeze-frames over the opening credits to a series of confrontational close-ups when things turn violent.
It's arguably the most beautiful of rock movies, while the musical highlights - 'The Weight' with the Staples Singers, Van Morrison's firebolt 'Caravan', every Levon Helm vocal - still astound.
The result is nothing less than a modern masterpiece, and a film ripe for rediscovery.
The fierce sympathy it extends to its unfashionable central character puts the film a million miles above the contemporary line in sick exploitation.
The result is less a story and more a collection of incidents and character studies, all of which inform each other and extend our understanding of Nicholson's mode of survival: flight.
There's a grey, plodding quality to the film which sidesteps oppressive, doom-laden inevitability and goes straight to slightly dull.
movie_title: Nosferatu: Phantom der Nacht (Nosferatu the Vampyre) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: Still truly unnerving, one can only imagine how terrifying it must have been for audiences facing the very real threat of Nazi enslavement.
It's the most haunted and dreamlike of all American films, a gothic backwoods ramble with the Devil at its heels.
Lynch's remarkable first feature is a true original.
A remarkable film, and an unmissable rediscovery.
Takes a long time to tell us nothing we didn't know ... A missed opportunity.
Dante gleefully sinks his teeth into the kind of fluffy, sugary, sickly small town fantasy beloved of his pal and sometime producer Spielberg.
It's no wonder a generation of holidaymakers still thinks twice before stepping into the water.
Filling out and greying at the temples, Van Damme is far from convincing, even in the tedious fight sequences.
This is arguably the high-water mark of Hollywood's love affair with the infinitely slippery possibilities of the English language.
Not just gory but actually frightening, not just funny but clever, 'American Werewolf...' has its flaws, but these are outweighed by the film's many, mighty strengths.
It's unlikely Gilliam's own, undeniably brilliant career will be revitalised by this rambling, undisciplined and indulgent piece of work.
his sense of unpredictability, coupled with some breathlessly paced and visually stunning action scenes, makes this the animated success of 2009... at least until Up opens next month.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As a sweet-natured character comedy - and a subtle exercise in generic boundary-pushing - this is a real charmer.
Coming on the heels of such DOA fare as X-Men Origins: Wolverine and Terminator Salvation, this gung ho popcorn flick feels positively visceral.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It doesn't help that the central cast is almost entirely forgettable, from the smug lounge lizardry of Bradley Cooper to the boisterous Jack Black-lite of Zach Galifianakis.
In less sure hands this parade of oddities could have become tiresome. Which only makes Rudd's central performance more impressive, holding the entire edifice together by sheer force of personality.
At an epic two hours the stilted dialogue and eye-scorchingly oversaturated film stock threaten to test the patience. But as a self-conscious exercise in kitsch graverobbing, 'Viva' succeeds.

Randy Newman's songs are a little too blandly Randy Newman-ish and the story is uneven, but there are some great characters, some even better jokes, a general sense of good humour and that entrancing, eye-ravishing old-school animation.
The overall impression is one of unbridled enthusiasm on the part of the film's makers, both for its predecessors and for the brave new universe Abrams and his crew are exploring.
There's something admirable about the entire enterprise: its ungainly size, its unrelenting weirdness, its willful, challenging intensity.
Those who surrender to Demme's disarming, almost participatory technique will find themselves overwhelmed, exhilarated and inspired by the eternal possibilities of cinema.
Dr Jekyll combines gothic horror, aristocratic romance and madcap Freudian psychodrama into a dizzying, exhilarating brew.
Perhaps the film's key problem is the feeling that Klapisch lets his ambition obstruct his storytelling.
Even for a high-concept, lowbrow summer release Meet Dave is drab, shoddy work.
A gracefully mounted, stunningly photographed historical account, fascinating in its attention to detail if somewhat unengaging in its story and characters.
'Sarah Marshall' remains a film of glorious moments and memorable scenes, lovingly crafted characters and sparkling one-liners.
The performances are note-perfect and Pinter's script is smart, subversive and sly, lifting the lid on our age-old feudal hierarchy and having a good dig about inside.
The end product, while shallow and sometimes disconcertingly furtive, offers an enlightening, pleasurable peek into one of cinema's more enticing dark corners.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: 'Rare Exports' is an enormously entertaining and unpredictable Yuletide romp packed with sly wit, solid scares and naked geriatrics.

Appropriately, the sequel suffers from almost the same problems as the original: while it's visually dazzling, thematically intriguing and fronted by the single coolest man in the universe, it's also empty, derivative and rather directionless
Fred is a withering, unerringly precise satirical pastiche of the me-first 'American Idol' generation. The only question is why an audience would choose to spend 83 minutes with him.
This is quite simply one of the saddest movies ever made, a tale of loss, grief and absolute loneliness, an unflinching stare into the darkest moral abyss.
This solidly constructed documentary aims to do for food production what An Inconvenient Truth did for global warming.
As the credits roll, the film's many flaws come sharply into focus. But while it lasts, Kung-Fu Panda is something of a guilty treat.

Niccol's major problem is timing: action sequences and dialogue scenes lie flat on the screen, while his tendency to play around with pacing means that any tension quickly dissipates. Life's too short.
Think of it as a high-end Christmas panto, as a red-faced, enthusiastic cast are put through the paces by their barking, domineering director. Louder, faster, bigger, more!
Mildly diverting, but quickly forgotten.
A film which, in both its rip-roaring, globe-trotting narrative and its visceral dedication to pure white-knuckle thrills, is the true successor to his original 'Indy' trilogy.
As solid Saturday night entertainment goes, this is a consistently compelling, enjoyably old school potboiler.
Satisfyingly sturdy and no-nonsense, a multiplex monster smartly constructed from tried-and-trusted parts.
If nothing else, it's nice to see this director refusing to play by the rules of the multiplex.
Sure, it's shallow, but it's also slickly compelling, beautifully crafted and so damn shiny.
This is witless, saccharine and lifeless...
Occasionally amusing but too often aggravating: pretty people in ugly places listening to crap pop and looking pleased with themselves.
Tiresome and unconvincing.
Allow the film to take hold and its power is inescapable: the effect is like placing your head in a vice and waiting as it inexorably closes.
Rent the original instead.
A hugely entertaining but frustratingly disorganised film, packed with priceless moments which never quite coalesce into a rewarding whole.
When future film historians look back at the cultural fallout from America's financial collapse, 'Take Shelter' will be a key text. That is, if the storm doesn't sweep us all away.
As an example of smarter-than-average Hollywood fare - and a sly dig at modern sporting politics - 'Moneyball' has all the key bases covered.
50/50 is about right.
For all its pretensions to bad taste, this is surprisingly heartwarming festive fare.
A film that, despite a strong visual sense, has simply no grasp on its characters or its plot. 'Nevermore', indeed.
A very entertaining, unusual and loveable mess.
For a film about revolutionaries, this plays it far too safe.
Yet another case of Hollywood execs trying way too hard to give the audience what they think it wants.

Sure to provoke furious reactions in those unwilling to succumb to its mood of reckless abandon. But for those who can, this feverish slice of LA noir is set to be one of the purest cinematic pleasures of 2012.
'Iron Sky' just proves that even the dumbest idea needs a smart mind behind it.
The results are solid and educative.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A singularly intimate and honest experience, as powerful bonds are formed between 'us', the viewer, and 'them', the subjects.
A diverting but rather pointless affair, undermined by its obsessive and clinical commitment to recreating past glories.
'The Woman in Black' is old-fashioned, ornate, imposing, occasionally creaky - and possessed of more than a few enjoyably nasty surprises.
Har'el's film is at times bizarrely uplifting, at others crushingly sad...
After the excesses of 'The A-Team', this is Carnahan stripping it back to basics - seven men, one wilderness, countless beasts.
A noisy, unfocused, frequently annoying and intermittently offensive slapstick misfire.
There's literally nothing here that works: the SFX are limp, the acting is dire and director Chris Gorak seems to be fighting a losing battle with the concept of narrative logic.
It's Scott who gives the movie its heart, delivering a performance of quiet strength and unexpected subtlety - when he's not cracking skulls.
Mostly this is just aggravating, as the volleyball girls flap and pout, the wizards glower and prance and the film trundles from one half-hearted and predictable action sequence to another.

Bird relishes the chance to play with real people - the central suspense sequence, in which Hunt scales Dubai's Burj Khalifa one-handed, is dizzyingly effective, particularly in IMAX - and the pace rarely slows.
A fitfully amusing but largely unsurprising and uninvolving action-movie-by-numbers: elementary, and not in a good way.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A film bursting at the seams with sheer, unadulterated joy: watch it, and the world seems just that little bit brighter...
Pacy and punchy, but not quite a knockout.
Just be sure to up your internal disbelief setting from 'suspended' to 'nonexistent'.
Overall, the film lacks that precise hook of exactly why it's worth telling this story now, but it remains a fascinating story nonetheless.
It crams in all of the best Bugs and Daffy Duck cartoons from the post-war period, plus a dizzying 15-minute compilation of Roadrunner sketches.
An uplifting, understated and wholly engaging insight into a world entirely unlike our own...
Employs a terse set-up and sparse characterisations to rein in any sentimentality and stress the ambiguities of its rich political and allegorical depths.
There are some wonderful things in 'Rango': the dialogue is witty, the animation is dizzying and the action is stunningly choreographed.
Predictable and tedious, and it all wraps up in an unconvincing would-be emotional climax.
This is a bold, inspiring piece of work, putting experimental techniques in the service of a heartfelt, insightful and surprisingly audience-friendly work of art.
'Drive Angry' is a mish-mash of familiar elements, but it's all lashed together with such relentless drive, blunt invention and pitch-black wit that it's hard not to get dragged along by it.
The door is left wide open for a sequel, but it's hard to imagine there'll be much call for it.
The characters are thin, the dialogue is bland and the animation is plasticky, though the 3D effects are sometimes interesting in a lurid, sub-Pixar fashion.
'Confessions' may be too grimly cynical to convince fully, but its combination of visual excess, dark wit, random violence, psychological insight and raw emotional intensity is intoxicating.
Al Daradji directs with a sure hand, avoiding icy realism and chest-beating melodrama. The result is warm, human and quietly devastating.
A flawed, frequently ludicrous but overwhelmingly likeable film, old-school to the core and none the worse for it.

The problem with 'Rabbit Hole' is that it plays at one unrelentingly gloomy frequency: occasional moments of humour or tension are simply unable to puncture the overriding sense of oppressive sadness.
Brisk, witty and entertaining, but far from classic Disney.
Traditional and unambitious it may be, but 'Conviction' is a good tale persuasively told.
Farmiga radiates warmth and Caan hasn't had a role this meaty since 'Misery'. A quiet triumph.
In the third act, both Haggis and his actors kick it into high gear, leading to a breathless chase sequence, the outcome of which is unpredictable to the last moments.
It's creaky, predictable and frequently idiotic. But for a tipsy Saturday night, this should tick all the right boxes.
Pretty, empty, and immediately forgettable.
This is the kind of film that thinks it's feminist because the girls hit back...
Best of all is Anthony Dod Mantle's breathtaking photography: the Scottish Highlands have never looked so eerily, threateningly beautiful.

With McBride and Franco trying on knowingly bad Brit accents and the entire cast clearly having a whale of a time, the impression is of the world's daftest, priciest, least self-serious end-of-the-pier panto.
Sick but fun.
While it's unfolding, this is just terrific fun: eye-scorching, ear-battering, heart-pounding cinema of pure spectacle.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is moviemaking on autopilot.
Mostly this is fairly agonising: long, loud, lurid and lacklustre.
An effortless blend of bad taste and good humour with a wholly believable, often very touching emotional core, all centred around one of the finest star-making comic performances in recent memory.
[An] unpredictable, episodic, deeply resonant character piece.
A solid slice of summer entertainment: forgettable, perhaps, but plenty of fun while it lasts.
'Last Night' is an empty exercise in sheer self-regard, a tedious, lifeless trawl through the secret lives of the rich and beautiful.
The 'Polar Express'-style CG-meets-live-action visuals are creepy and flat, the characters are largely nonexistent and the story takes so many short cuts that it becomes meaningless...
Surprising, amusing and oddly melancholic: a genuine human drama.
It's hard to know how seriously anyone besides Statham is taking this - but that only adds to its absurd, cock-eyed charm.

What's just delightful about this wittily observed and touchingly truthful affair is the fact it offers consistently sherbety entertainment in the moment but ultimately holds to its purpose of saying something useful and genuine about real lives.
'On Stranger Tides' is simply lifeless, a reductive, insulting moneymaking exercise with as much charm and depth as a slot machine.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Did Paul Bettany know, when he donned the cowl of the albino monk in 'The Da Vinci Code', that he would soon be typecast as Hollywood's go-to guy for God-bothering multiplex action movies?
While the film as a whole may be episodic and wayward, and not always in a good way, the action scenes are uniformly sharp, inventive and gripping.
Well-acted but plodding...

An endearing throwback to simpler times: when men were men, gods were gods and heroes looked like bodybuilders who'd just raided the dress-up box. Just don't expect to remember much about it afterwards.
Katz's characters are beautifully observed, the autumnal photography of downtown Portland is lovely, and the tension is expertly maintained...
A film of pure sensation, dazzling audiences with light and noise, laying bare the stark horror - and unimaginable thrill - of combat.
Finds poetry in the whirl of people in motion, in rapidly changing fashions, in urban sprawl and development, in the fading of the old ways and the rise of the new
As an introduction, this is entirely serviceable.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A convincing attempt to give a voice to some of Britain's most marginalised residents.
The great director's least satisfying, most disconcerting film - and that's what makes it extraordinary.
It may veer towards sentimentality, but overall this is a warm and absorbing melodrama.
Men! We're awful, aren't we?
Embarrassingly pretentious.
movie_title: Ming Of Harlem: Twenty One Storeys In The Air (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Not since the original crew stepped down have we felt such a vivid sense of adventure and comradeship.
Five movies in, the 'Ice Age' series has jumped the sloth.
Bullets fly, curses are hurled, Willis threatens some chumps.
Hey, Nicolas Winding Refn: this is how it's done.
A sympathetic portrait of a genuinely idiosyncratic, outrageous individual.
There are fascinating nuggets, but nothing you couldn't pick up from a decent biography.
'The Happening' with phones.
Imagine 'Gomorrah' remade as a Ben Stiller romcom.
movie_title: The Mafia Kills Only in Summer (La Mafia Uccide solo d'Estate) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Vigas tries every trick in the arthouse book - long silences, meaningful looks, out-of-focus imagery - to sell his story.
An insanely OTT sequel to the already-ludicrous-enough alien invasion smash.

Long episodes of helpless tedium interspersed with brief moments of intense heartbreak.
Sleek, pretentious and puzzling.
The action scenes just about justify the existence of this fourth instalment.
Total Recall is slick, sly and subversive, and if some of the special effects have aged somewhat, that only adds to the charm.
Just a teensy bit tiresome: two addled junkies falling about and bellowing at each other for 112 long minutes.
An intimate and at times unforgiving portrait of a wife, mother and megastar.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Captures what it really feels like to play your first gig, to release your first album, to stay up for five days snorting crystal meth then freak out on stage at the Whisky a Go Go.
One of the most idiosyncratic movies in the horror canon.
The jury remains out on this one.
Next time, how about the deprived girl from the mean streets has ambitions to be a scientist?
Accusations of tastelessness have some justification - if your priority is to respect the dead, why hire the director of 'Battleship'?
Like four or five Harry Potter books squeezed into a single movie.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A corking story, told with a good amount of sparkle.
This might be the best kids' movie since Up.
A time-capsule character study of great warmth and compassion.
Determinedly bizarre, psychologically inquisitive and in the end rather wonderful.
Exactly the film you imagine it's going to be: handsome, honey-coloured and simplistic.
Works up a good sweat, but never quite lands that killer punch.
There are moments here that approach the sublime.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

movie_review_blurb: At times astonishingly beautiful. The closing credits sequence alone is lovelier than some entire movies.

movie_title: Asterix and Obelix: Mansion of the Gods (Astérix: Le domaine des dieux) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If nothing else, this is a reminder of what a beautifully realised and horribly relatable a character David Brent is. We all know someone a bit like this man.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You've seen it all before -- but hell, it's worth seeing again.

A noisy, funny but fatally glib and self-regarding comedy thriller.

Unique and intoxicating, an art movie that grips like a thriller.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A messy, hectic, fitfully amusing film-nerd farce.
The fact that it's all played completely straight only makes it funnier.
Tales of remarkable men in extraordinary times.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Wiig strolls the line between adorable and obnoxious with the ease of a pro.

Proof that life goes on, even under occupation.
Matthias Schoenaerts gets back to what he does best - scowling silently with his top off.

Sometimes intriguing, sometimes faintly ridiculous.
Predictable but unexpectedly enlightened.

So tasteless in its depiction of India that it makes 'Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom' look like a triumph of racial awareness.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film never admits it, but almost everything here has been invented for the screen. That leaves a bad taste: Edwards is still very much alive, and his story is bizarre enough without embellishment.
Has a grimy, off-kilter charm not seen since the heyday of '70s exploitation.

Packed to bursting with the one ingredient 'Batman v Superman' lacked: joy.
After 'Insidious' and 'The Conjuring', James Wan has his method down.
Calm, reflective, gorgeously uneventful.

One of the most annoying, tedious and unpleasant filmgoing experiences in recent memory.
movie_title: Top Cat Begins (Don Gato, el inicio de la pandilla) (2017)

movie_title: Minuscule: Valley of the Lost Ants (Minuscule - La vallée des fourmis perdues) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Spielberg's greatest work.
movie_title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)

movie_review_blurb: No other director is simultaneously so precise and so otherworldly.
Like 'Game of Thrones' performed by badly programmed robots.
It's hard to imagine a more Tom Hanks-y setup than this.
A brash, sarcastic just-about-family-friendly adventure.

As low-budget Ozploitation goes, it's snappy and effective.
A movie for anyone who's ever been judged on their appearance, their outlook or the way they choose to live.

Rarely has a film used London's landmarks so cannily.
Stuffed with that snarky, sarky adolescent humour that so many modern screenwriters seem to mistake for wit.
An empathetic, often heartbreaking piece of work.
Equal parts charming, strange, goofy, unpredictable and genuinely horrifying.

Beautifully simple and simply beautiful.
Goes from a fairly forgettable romantic drama into a full-tilt fiasco.

A compelling but relentlessly downbeat Japanese melodrama.

Heavy-handed at times, but this is a sweet story honestly told.
The characters are still fun to be around, the one-liners are still sharp and the soundtrack is, of course, terrific.

Could've been 'War, Actually' - but this witty, sophisticated and unexpectedly sober romcom never falls into the obvious traps.
Peppered with moments of pure, neck-prickling sensation, but the emotional centre remains elusive.
Unlike its frontman, this multi-Oscar-winning drama hasn't aged particularly well.
movie_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975)

'The Big Sleep' with bruvs. Which isn't an entirely off-putting proposition.
More interested in metaphysical ponderings and so-called 'human truths' than in telling a convincing story.

movie_title: It Was Fifty Years Ago Today... Sgt Pepper and Beyond (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's mostly carried off with aplomb, particularly by Charlie Wright, who looks like a slightly less evil Ezra Miller and gives a genuinely funny performance as permanently perplexed metalhead Rodrick.

movie_review_blurb: Charlie's Angels director McG used to know how to marshal a decent action scene (if nothing else), but that touch seems to have deserted him.

movie_review_blurb: An enjoyable, mildly pretentious documentary about music photographer Mick Rock, who just happened to be born with the right name and skillset at just the right time.

A jaw-dropping profile of one man's battle with world governments, common decency and his own out-of-control ego.
An enjoyably twisty little throat-grabber.

Feels as sly, modern and bracing as it must have in 1967.

A messy, troubling and strangely enjoyable film.
This one will haunt your dreams.

movie_review_blurb: A gentle, fan-friendly Iggy Pop doc.

A gloriously unfettered throwback to the wild days of '80s horror.

We've watched this young man struggle and fight for answers, only to have them drop into his lap at precisely the right moment. It's a drastic misstep that ruins whatever chance Lion had of doing justice to a fascinating true story.
A stupendously entertaining movie, crammed with delights.
Like 'Psycho' and 'Snakes on a Plane', this Japanese horror movie does what it says on the tin.

A grim but necessary watch.

A terrifically watchable, heartfelt documentary.

Frank, unashamed and bruising.

Sit back and enjoy the stunts, the speed, the style.
Documentary as visual art: quiet, empathetic, occasionally unfocused but visually gorgeous.
One of the most beautiful films ever made, plain and simple.

Passive and relentless, familiar and terrifying, predictable and shocking - and impossible to shake off.

The single most immersive and tactile world ever created for the cinema.

Inoffensive but flavourless, and crammed with familiar elements from better movies like  Lilo and Stitch ,  Toy Story  and  Despicable Me .
Too often feels like just another slice of brainless Eurotrash, packed with saw-it-coming plot twists, half-hearted car chases and an angsty hero with zero charisma.
One of the most entrancing and elemental landscape films ever shot in these isles.

A predictably unpredictable tale of conmen and women complete with the industry-mandated quantity of fast cars, short skirts, sharp suits, slippery billionaires and "Oh, it was that guy all along!" plot twists.
A sombre, intelligent drama that critiques Obama's ongoing drone policy while still positioning its button-pushing characters as tortured anti-heroes.
Welles's most human film, his most poignant, funny and empathetic.

More battles, more creatures, more not-quite-comical asides, more stern speechifying and more gob-smackingly elaborate action set pieces.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Lucy is not about to win any prizes from Mensa ... but this isn't quite like any other blockbuster you'll see this year.

A forgettable addition to the proud British tradition of haunted-country-pile movies.

To misquote Forrest Gump's mother, Guardians of the Galaxy is like a box of chocolates. Or rather, it's like a vast, family-sized festive crate of chocolates, all wrapped in the shiniest packaging, all exploding with sweetness and surprises.
Strap on your swordbelt, buckle your sandals and oil up your rippling six-pack, because here comes yet another interminable, CGI-drenched mythic mish-mash with far more money than brain cells.
A magnificent mess of switchbacks and revelations, climaxing with one of cinema's most outrageously inventive sequences.

'Branded to Kill' is one of those films that feels so far ahead of its time, we may still not have caught up to it. The violence is raw, the sex even more so, and the monochrome photography is flawless.
It's a straightforward story simply but powerfully told.
It may lack its predecessor's lofty ambitions, but once the bullets, spears and hairy fists start flying you'll be too wrapped up to care.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Maxine Peake does a fine job of playing a seriously unlikeable character in this frosty, low-budget British drama.
When the badass cyclones muscle into town, ripping up schools, banks and airports, the film is fairly fun. Sadly, everything else about it is, well, a bit of a disaster.

Breathlessly paced and surreally funny, The Boxtrolls fizzes with visual invention and wild slapstick. But the grotesquerie is overbearing
A captivating look at a man battling to rediscover his place in the world.
The spy who bored me.
This modest, sci-fi-inflected 1956 horror movie may come to be seen as the defining metaphorical work of the twentieth century.

A visually sumptuous experience, it also typifies the very worst excesses of hippie-era filmmaking.

An excruciating misfire.

movie_review_blurb: How do we know when we're truly living authentic lives, or have fully given ourselves over to passion and trust with another? It wouldn't occur to most romantic comedies to ask those questions. "The Man On Her Mind" answers them.

movie_title: Living Is Easy With Eyes Closed (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, "Burkholder" is about what we owe each other in loyalty, sacrifice and kindness. This very human film deserves a wide audience.
Enthralling ...
The world turns, the sun rises and sets, and the ocean's waves splash on idyllic beaches in Eric Rohmer's "A Summer's Tale."

movie_title: Evergreen: The Road to Legalization in Washington (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Schwarz can't make enough out of that goofy notion - visually or narratively - to get a comic steam going. But there are sidebar pleasures to be found ...

movie_review_blurb: A bright, eccentric testament to the mutual regard that Pulp's members and ordinary Sheffield residents feel about one another.

An ingenious blend of high drama and surprising whimsy.

movie_review_blurb: Chastain proves near-heroic embodying Jolene's innate strength and incremental wisdom. Yet she also makes us understand how the heroine's wobbly resistance to manipulative characters is overwhelmed time and again.
Nowhere Boy is fully accessible for everyone, not just fans.
The point is effective, though the story paints itself into a corner with the mawkish particulars of Mahi's misery.
An utterly charming work of pure pop exuberance, Bandslam is full of unexpected pleasures set to a surprisingly retro soundtrack.

It's always hard not to think of classic Disney as the standard for a film like this. Using that yardstick, Crest Animation/Lionsgate's Alpha and Omega is far from an emotionally rich, fulfilling experience.
Abstruse and confusing, Tales from Earthsea's story grows increasingly blurry the closer it gets to what should be a deeply satisfying conclusion.
It looks like raw notes and impressions for a future novel.

Along with such fantasy elements as rich, primary colors and an ending that suggests we've jumped to some other cinematic dimension, Wild Grass, like compulsive filmmaking, embraces the intensity of subjective experience...
A strikingly physical as well as thoughtful drama.
Despicable Me appeals both to our innocence and our glee over cartoon anarchy.
The sprawling story is so dramatically compressed there is barely enough oxygen for relationship growth (crucial in Avatar), let alone traces of an interesting director's personality.
Hitchcock would have loved it, even wrapped in the Safdies scruffy enigma of a movie.
As revivals go, this one is well-above-average by dint of its intelligent reappraisal of major elements in the first movie.
Multiple Sarcasms has a way of creatively meandering into unexpected pockets of comedy and poignancy, heading toward some kind of eventual grace, a little like real life.
Well-paced, methodical and seemingly thorough...
Fact and fiction intermingle in Paper Heart, but discovering where the line is drawn is the tricky part.
Soul Power is the indispensable companion film to Leon Gast's thrilling 1996 documentary When We Were Kings.

Fortunately, Eimbcke's laconic if fanciful storytelling strengths ring more true than his somewhat artificial and hackneyed visual style, which includes a penchant for lengthy wide-angle shots that make the world look like a feverishly alien place.

Smart, sharp, original and very funny, Bolt could be the model for a certain kind of midrange, nonevent (i.e., not WALL E) animated family film that would be more welcome right now than such bizarre junk as the recent Fly Me to the Moon.
Happily, Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa is a worthy follow-up that builds on its predecessor's successes and adds to them.
An unexceptional police drama that doesn't live up to its high ambition, Pride and Glory feels like a television cop show that made it through one season before disappearing.
If you don't speak the jargon of sailing and racing, most of the conversations between teammates mean very little. Impenetrable editing reduces the action to a meaningless blur.
Above all, Marsden and Green are a genuine delight.
Though City of Ember is a bit hurried in execution, this first live-action film by director Gil Kenan has the subterranean feel of a dream being described.
We might be talking about windshield wipers instead of industry pollution in Flash of Genius, but somehow justice seems more dear in this odd movie.
Chihuahua turns out to be a pretty good family comedy that is more than the sum of its effects.

The content of each journal is so entertaining and compelling that, if one didn't know better, a viewer might assume The Corporal's Diary was yet another faux documentary about the war told from the perspective of a fictional serviceman.

While Fuel takes persuasive swipes at the influence of oil-based energy companies over domestic and foreign policy, the film is more dazzling as an introduction to all kinds of clean energy alternatives many of us have never heard of.
Cinematically unexciting but a welcome glimpse at the complications of life after age 40.
Writer-director Jacobs is one of those rare filmmakers who forgoes conventional narrative in order to tell a story through the visual details of a world and the behavior of characters within it.
The Little Red Truck is more interested in exploring MCT's process than in its real-world results. That's fine, but let's not call this a documentary. It's public relations.
A keenly insightful film concerning an unusual training program for war-bound U.S. soldiers.
The film's real accomplishment, in this era of masked superheroes, is making a paladin of a regular guy whose ethics we can all emulate.
A narrowly interesting story by French writer-director CÃ (C)line Sciamma about three girls whose lives are connected by synchronized swimming.

The absence of star charisma in Journey denies the audience some focus in a movie that keeps changing backdrops and is ultimately no more than the sum of its wild-eyed parts.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though lacking narrative focus, it offers rich impressions of a New York City artistic community that profoundly influenced American popular culture.
movie_title: Greenwich Village: Music That Defined a Generation (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's impossible to watch this grotty, sometimes unbearably undisciplined yet genuinely tragic movie and not think about the first films directed by John Cassavetes and Paul Morrissey.
While the film playfully telegraphs its inspirations, Mister Foe never persuasively comes together as a dark fable about an adolescent misfit stuck in loss.
Despite official efforts, this is a film that can't be dismissed.
Better than a lot of animated features released in the past few months.

Gorgeous and mesmerizing, Azur & Asmar eschews computer-generated imagery to render a flat, storybook-style animation that never stops delighting with its ornamental detail, range of color and exotic story.
movie_title: Azur et Asmar (Azur and Asmar: The Princes' Quest) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Parents already in dread of taking their children to this 3-D kids' movie by uber-producer Jerry Bruckheimer will find much to appreciate, though G-Force is lots of fun all around.

[Director] Baratz's access to every stage of the process -- from Zopa's selection of a candidate to the testing of that candidate to the blessing of the Dalai Lama himself -- is phenomenal, almost indescribably privileged.
As unpredictable and tragic as it is genuinely riveting.
Even new scenes involving the once-hilarious Scrat, the hapless critter who can't hold onto an acorn, feel worn out. That's when you know it's time to go.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In Atom Egoyan's disconcerting and unpredictable Adoration, a young man's attempt to make sense of himself and his family's history turns strange when his re-imagined version of that history becomes a combustible topic for online chatter.
Fallen would do well to turn itself into a bland, eighteen-wheeler and drive out of town.
If there were any doubts that Murphy can still be as boldly funny and charismatic in the flesh as he has been when providing the voice of Donkey in the Shrek franchise, Imagine That helps allay them.
A glum and slack family drama, Newcastle is punctuated by bright bursts of dreamy surfing images, but not enough to make the film rewarding.
A dystopian view of future interplanetary relations, and a real bummer of a picture of humankind's future, Battle for Terra is a solid, though not sugarcoated, animated film for the whole family.
[The directors] can't quite locate a core of buoyant energy in the film as a whole.

[Director] Saura's personal love of fado goes back to his youth, and Fados reflects what is clearly his deeply imaginative, inner relationship with the genre's songs about loss, shifting hopes and elusive happiness.
The result is lumpy and irritating, but 17 Again regroups whenever Efron is back on screen.
Here's hoping the talented Rogen, in the future, sifts out junk like this from the many opportunities before him.
Miranda, a busy and successful director of commercials, shoots it all with slick economy and efficiency.
Harvard Beats Yale 29-29, a mosaic of storytelling told by former college-level gridiron athletes, pieces together the remarkable story of a fateful 1968 match between the titular Ivy League teams.
Smarter than it looks from its ubiquitous trailer, but not smart enough to be a fully satisfying adult comedy.
One of the most fun and engaging IMAX movies to date.
Movies don't get more headache-inducing than Push.
You can think about Outlander 16 different ways, and still arrive at the same conclusion: It just doesn't work.
A brisk and engaging adventure for kids who love books as well as for those who don't.
Shoddy and never credible, The Mysteries of Pittsburgh is an ungainly coming-of-age drama based on a (hopefully much better) novel by Pulitzer Prize-winning author Michael Chabon.
What makes this unhinged, wildly self-conscious comedy-adventure more than a two-hour gimmick is an inspired vocal performance by Verbinski's "Pirates of the Caribbean" star, Johnny Depp.
The best thing about Notorious is its across-the-board, excellent cast, especially the soulful Woolard and Mackie's mesmerizing work as the complex Shakur.
Certainly there are a few times "Limitless" teeters on interesting possibilities, but it has a weird way of pulling back on its most stimulating ideas.
A hybrid work that will appeal to both surf-movie fanatics and armchair sociologists.
A compelling, wholly original tale marred a bit by its young heroine's incessant chatter on the soundtrack.
movie_title: À pas de loup (On the Sly) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It is less unified and more predictable than its predecessors, and doesn't play to all the franchise's earlier strengths.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A somewhat clunky family movie about childhood escapism, alternating a little too conveniently between the grim and the adorable.
"Savages" is never quite one thing or another.
Hansen-Løve films with an eye toward discovering and rediscovering these characters in pure moments of simple, poignant humanity - wading in a river, clambering over rocks.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This dull documentary looks and feels like a season of MTV's "The Real World" set in mountainous India.
Ingeniously, and warmly, looks at a surprising chapter in the story of an internment camp in Eastern California.
A tepid, superficial sports documentary about Ultimate Fighting Championship middleweight king Anderson Silva.
A wrenching but illuminating look at what actually happened during Iran's Green Revolution in 2009-10.
Mesmerizing, somehow otherworldly...

A visionary composition on a series of spoken reflections about a literary work - itself full of layered free-association - Gee's intricate, prismatic film might sound as if it must be buried in abstraction.
Much of this film quickly vanishes from memory, but there's some gold here. That's pretty much the message about life itself in "Death of a Superhero."
A well-meaning but overreaching documentary that strains to make a Theory of Everything argument about power and powerlessness in America. Ultimately, it fails to convince about much of anything.
A mesmerizing, beautiful drama, "Jean Gentil" is the rare film that teaches one to see.
Like a stroll through Amsterdam's red-light district at night. It's an experience far more sad than sexy.
[A] truly disturbing documentary, which pretty much argues that human beings are hard-wired to self-destruct.
The makers of "Chimpanzee" appear to have captured a lot of genuine and genuinely lovely footage of instinctive compassion among animals.

The more "This Is Not a Film" underscores the cruel containment of a great artist, the more we actually become aware - very indirectly, in a very Panahi fashion - of a city in chaos outside, with sounds of gunfire and distant street blazes.
This is a movie with heart but too many distractions.
A strange and agonizingly engrossing drama despite its repellent subject.
"The Salt of Life" finds gentle comedy in the dilemma of a still warm-blooded if sexually marginalized fellow for whom kindness is second nature and lecherousness is alien.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "The Bullet Vanishes" charges ahead at a perfect clip. Lo's delightful, hyperbolic audacity includes sharpshooter Guo's knack for banking bullets off walls to hit bad guys, as if playing pool.
Surely, some Hollywood studio in the 1950s made a prototype of the sprightly if erratic comedy "You May Not Kiss the Bride."
movie_title: You May Not Kiss the Bride (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Elegiac, witty and deeply reflective, "Night Across the Street" strikes a mature and complex tone.
Self-consciousness passing for style.
What's missing, especially in an era when we've invested so much hope for extraterrestrial life by sending real probes to the real Mars, is a sense of wonder.
The film's guilelessness in stoking classic themes, folklore and paradigms in American culture would be absurdly self-conscious if Nichols didn't have such an original voice as a storyteller.
The heart of Hogan's film is in the right place, and Collette is masterful as an agent of anarchy.
Sutton's approach is observation: We're not so much pulled into a narrative as watching images float in ethereal atmospheres.
Writer-director Jon Van Dyke offers rugged production values, and his real agenda - getting Christian viewers to help end sex trafficking - mires the movie in self-conscious angst and speeches.

In an interesting way, "The Croods" is about storytelling - cave paintings, hints of oral tradition, stumbling upon metaphors - and the impulse to remember amid change. There's something touching in that ...
Whatever one's political stripe regarding Israel, it's hard to dispute the impressions and perspective of the film's six eyewitnesses.

Yung seems to anticipate real-life emotional beats and positions his camera at exactly the right moments, yet nothing seems artificial or scripted. The result is an unexpectedly tender film about the price of coming into one's own.
[It] eventually finds its own rhythm and meaningful chaos.
"We Don't Care" deftly compensates for the missing element in a film about performance art: immediacy.
movie_title: We Don't Care About Music Anyway (2009)

movie_review_blurb: From a bounty of low, low moments in "Parental Guidance," it's difficult to choose the absolute lowest.
All this random action, Carax suggests, is for some vast, abstract audience anxious to lose itself in imagined narratives.
A chamber piece rooted in semi-improvisation.
In the end, "This Must Be the Place" isn't just bad. It's inappropriate.
Barratier can't seem to do anything with it other than keep raising the violence and anger.
movie_title: La nouvelle guerre des boutons (War of the Buttons) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A startling, haunting documentary about a once-great city, "Detropia" is all but a eulogy for Detroit.

The Archers' sometimes near-exotic chord progressions, their blend of raw power and mesmerizing hooks on the likes of "Fabricoh," "Might" and "Wrong," and their '90s slacker-rock flourishes make "What Did You Expect?" a winning concert movie.
movie_title: What Did You Expect? The Archers of Loaf Live at Cat's Cradle (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There's much to enjoy here in a disposable way, particularly jokes about monsters having ordinary problems with kids and spouses.
Herzog is not insincere. His passion for outsize experience has always captured our essential human identity against big backdrops. He captures it again in "Happy People," but this time with a twist.
movie_title: Happy People: A Year in the Taiga (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A case study in the phenomenon of mastery.
An eye-opening documentary about a bizarre sociological phenomenon that has been evolving on an Ohio farm since 1995.
It stokes memories of an era of clever, adventurous and genuinely sweet movies for kids, on one hand, while planting a future memory of quality for today's tykes.
Equally fascinating and tedious, "Bellflower" is a lost cause of a movie, torn apart by incompatible ambitions.
[It's] undercut by a jokey, smart-aleck approach to every scene that plays like disposable sitcom humor.
Virzi approaches mawkishness but he never crosses the line.
movie_title: The First Beautiful Thing (La prima cosa bella) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: While the end of "Don't Be Afraid" is creepy, it's far from emotionally satisfying.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "The FP" works best as an operatic parody of mixed genres with lunacy on the fringes.
Part thriller and part harrowing account of an outrageous, based-on-facts story of official corruption in the former Yugoslavia, "The Whistleblower" is a tense and shattering drama.
This Conan barely qualifies as a character, smirking and hacking his way through life, never evolving into someone who can change or whom you want to follow.

Though Cooper plays look-a-like characters, it is always clear which of the two men is on screen at any moment, including those moments when Yahia is impersonating Uday. That says a lot about the inner wellspring of great acting.
All in all, it's hard to know for whom "Hop" is made.
Prosserman wisely skirts the esoterica of high finance, though he cleverly uses good visual devices to suggest the shocking scope of Madoff's crimes.
[An] enjoyable if simplistic black comedy loosely based on a novel by Larry Beinhart.
Never has the special relationship between people and horses appeared more magnificent and even lyrical on film than in "Buck."
As a tale of squabbling gangsters and prison intrigues, "Angel of Evil" is ordinary.
Ayoade is better at establishing a road map of what "Submarine" is supposed to be rather than pulling all its elements together cohesively.

This thin follow-up feels like a betrayal of its predecessor's accomplishments and goodwill, cheapening what worked in the first place to emphasize some wrong things this time around - particularly the film's 3-D presentation.
A richly cathartic experience with a wide range of emotional colors.
"Louder Than a Bomb" is a good reminder that students need a variety of opportunities to excel.
What we get from this film: a specific and personal sense that 32,000-year-old artists, with all their ideas and passions, were not, fundamentally, that different from us.
"Rio" is strong on relationships, visually novel, full of fresh ideas and featuring a few vocal actors you might not have expected to be part of the fun.

In many ways, what works about "Rodrick Rules" is the reverse of the first film, which found the ethically challenged Greg willing to throw his geeky friends under the bus to improve his social status.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The fun is in enjoying the two leads, both strikingly good, and the extra (if sometimes misplaced) textures provided by a strong supporting cast including Richard Jenkins, Patricia Clarkson and Jenna Elfman.
A lively, winning family movie starring the very sea mammal at the center of a true story that inspired this film.
There is less in-your-face grit in Cape Town-born director Oliver Schmitz's vision for this film than there is a careful pacing of somber revelations.
Casts a wide net of inquiry over this sometimes appalling story, which raises timely questions about the differences between creation and exploitation.
It's mostly another raunchy buddy comedy - albeit one with welcome comic discipline, more focused on maintaining pitch than continually lowering the bar on gross-out jokes.
Much of the film follows the fascinating production of a book full of surreptitious iPhone images by photographer Joel Sternfeld.
movie_title: How to Make a Book with Steidl (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The poignant, frightening and visually striking documentary "Windfall" places debate within a very human perspective.

Where the film falls short is in its basic obligation to tell an accessible story.
Noisy street crowds and an "Attica!" shoutout allude to Sidney Lumet's classic "Dog Day Afternoon," suggesting what "Ledge" director Asger Leth is hopelessly, vainly reaching for.

It's about taking a complete leap of faith toward life-altering changes, a running theme in all the director's movies.

It's amazing a movie hasn't been made about these Reagan-era events before now. But the enjoyable "Big Miracle" offers perspective, balancing sentiment with healthy skepticism about human motivations.
What, if anything, the film's final burst of idealism offers universally is hard to say. But it feels good to see in these acrimonious days.
Much like the creations of its subjects, "Eames" is itself a dazzling, sensory adventure.
movie_title: Eames: The Architect And The Painter (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from novel and smart uses of 3D effects, the new movie is largely a bore, all but sidelining Williams and straining to offset the monotony of a protracted rescue story with the sour misadventures of a pair of fussy krill.

The good that "Silenced" has done certainly outweighs its flaws, but there are certainly some of those: character and plot tropes that pad out the story but have little to do with it.
A visually interesting, well-acted and economical movie that ought to work yet doesn't gel as a complete experience.
If there is anything objective that can be said about education it's this: Good teachers matter.
movie_title: Mitchell 20: Teacher Quality Is The Answer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "Toast" has three things deserving of adoration: spectacular lemon-meringue pies, the songs of Dusty Springfield and Helena Bonham Carter.
