From the fly-on-the-wall, cinéma-vérité style of the '60s to a more aggressive, advocacy approach in the mid-'70s, "Mixtape" is a wide slice of nonfiction film history.
If this all sounds like tripe, that's because it is.
Director Gregory Hoblit can't seem to find any real heart in this story.
Hot Fuzz is warm at the beginning, too cool in the middle and boiling at the end -- which makes it too close to lukewarm.
Passable spook-show nightmare scary fare.

An admirable first effort and likely to be enjoyed by women who wouldn't mind meeting that good-looking, self-effacing young man, and men who may be under the illusion that they in some way resemble him.
Filled with foggy shots stolen from LOTR and laden with decapitations, Pathfinder is faux-period gore trash with no redeeming qualities and a high dullness factor. Find another path.
Filled with both youthful angst and innocent energy, which makes for more interesting contrasts than you might expect in a slasher-next-door flick.
A can't-miss experience and likely one of the year's very best films.
Considering the twirliness of the story, this is a fairly straightforward film that knows where it's going and how to get there. And there's much to be admired in that.
Grindhouse is insider fun when Rodriguez is in charge and regrettable trash when Tarantino takes over.
OK, Letters from Iwo Jima it's not. Firehouse Dog, though, serves a purpose, and it's a purpose you'd know quite well if you had a 6-year-old.

The essential message in this strongly felt film comes clear: 'It's Iraq.' It used to be bad, but now it's worse. And anyone in his right mind, including Iraqis, wants to get out.
Year of the Dog is a feel-good, feel-bad movie about personal choice in the face of an overwhelming world. It brings more than you expect and leaves you wondering. How extraordinarily brave.

Tykwer has to set a unique tone here -- fairy tales about serial killers being somewhat rare -- and he manages the absurdity of his subject matter well, keeping Jean-Baptiste right on the edge between monster and genius.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: What's worse is that after a fairly pedestrian opening, director Sam Raimi loses all control of the film as it rambles from storyline to storyline in search of a center.
Ocean's Thirteen is hack Hollywood garbage, the sort of film that thinks so little of its supposedly sure-thing audience that it never breaks a sweat. That's not cool; that's lazy.
Marred by sudden dead spots and afflicted with a few alarming fits of double entendre inappropriateness.

A sweet, raw blessing of a film.
Running nearly three hours in length, it continues the pointless excesses of the second film while again entirely missing the romantic charm of the first.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Starts with a nice premise, but ends up fractured.
Despite cliches, film does click.
Part satire, part action flick and complete ball of confusion, it's hard to tell what director-writer Hal Hartley intends with this often-amateurish, often dull, always frustrating film.
The formula still works. Maybe not as well, but it works.
This is one of those films where everything simply feels wrong, from the clunky dialogue to the obvious staging.

A somewhat cold and calculated film that apparently unconsciously exemplifies that which it intends to criticize.
The deal was wrong right from the beginning on Lucky You.
Plays like a well-intentioned but somewhat dull HBO special.
Not only is there nothing there, the nothingness is a complete bore. When a film's highpoint is a soundtrack that relies heavily on other soundtracks, you've got problems.
Breach is the sort of studiously serious, well-made, based-on-fact film that critics go crazy for and audiences find earnestly dull and eminently avoidable.
An entertaining heist flick with some real emotional heft at its center and a series of plot curves that mix the unique and familiar. The Lookout is a must-see.
Norbit may be the most disturbing, morally repugnant, nightmare-inducing film of the century so far.
Director Peter Webber delivers all this with a painfully straight face, and the result is actually less interesting than your average horror movie of the week.
As opposed to the bulk of low-budget films, the look here is lush and beautifully crafted; even the make-up is excellent.

Venus is a fine reminder of the wonders we're presented with every day.
A noteworthy mess for the sheer mass of talent it squanders, Catch and Release is best not caught.
Every Valentine's Day should be blessed with a confection as fluffy, light and satisfying as Music and Lyrics, a date movie filled with laughs and tunes and nothing too terribly serious to say.
Meaningless violence incarnate, a pointed mix of laughs and wanton death; and yes, that might actually mean something, but precisely what is never clear.
Make no mistake, all is epic, violent, bloody madness once the director hits his stride, and fans of Zhang's work will not want to miss Curse of the Golden Flower. But brush strokes are amiss here.

Watanabe is appropriately noble and regal, if a bit stiff at times; but it is Ninomiya's grunt soldier who gives the film its soul. Alternately philosophical, humorous, terrified and crafty, he is everyman trying to survive hell.

movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Darkly poetic throughout, the film starts with an explosion and ends drifting in fog with no clear resolution in sight. How brave and oddly satisfying.
For the odd at heart, it will be worth the wait.
Stomp the Yard panders to every cheap expectation. Actually, director Sylvain White goes a bit cheaper than his immediate predecessors, drawing out the low booty shots for giggle and jiggle effect.

Terabithia picks up a lot of emotional punch as it rolls along, and anyone leaving the theater with a dry eye should be checked for a pulse.

If you like the TV show, you'll like the movie. If you like stupid movies you'll like the movie. If you want to have your soul elevated, look elsewhere.
The Namesake is three-fourths of a fine film. Which is, of course, far better than most.
Reaser really doesn't stand a chance. She's plucky as heck, and you like her despite the script, but she can't save the movie.
Maybe this is actually a treatise on the dissonance between East and West, science and nature, promise and tragedy. Nah. It's just a dumb, crappy horror movie that wants to be celebrated as such.

All good stuff. Rock delivers some laugh-out-loud lines, Washington is sexy and dangerous, Torres makes her character something more than a frigid harpy, and the workplace scenes are well-played.

movie_review_blurb: Premonition, for all its far-fetched nature, never lets go of its momentum and holds the audience every inch of the way.
One of those completely disposable and clumsy attempts to make a gay romantic comedy that constantly slips on its own good intentions.
It is undeniably exciting and awe-inspiring; but it also lacks a sense of tactile warmth, a crucial core of reality.
A political thriller that's consistently as inventive as it is creepy.

The Zodiac killer was never found. Dealing with a murder mystery that's still unsolved gives Fincher shaky enough ground for drama. Add in a protagonist who seems driven by a vacuum, and you pretty much have a movie about nothing going nowhere.
Eminently forgettable.

Having established his characters and built their bond, having cooked up a sense of place so strong you can taste it, Brewer can't find anywhere in particular to go. Suddenly he brings a gun into the mix, then takes an awkward Dr. Phil turn.

Yes, the too-hot Alba is still miscast, and the film suffers from clumsy moments. But when it soars, it soars, and it is both blessedly brief and bloodless.

movie_review_blurb: Bang. Bang. Bang-bang blood, blood, blood. There, you've seen the movie.
Crazy is the word for it, and if writer-director Dan Klores seems a bit too sympathetic at times, he still lays out a twisted story of obsession that ends in well-maintained mutual madness.

A bit too involved and convenient at times, but still classy and heartfelt all the way.
Across the Universe is a classic example of ambition exceeding execution.
...manages to blend the clashing of cultures, family resentment, ugly heritage and the unlikely promise of new life without going in circles.
Directed by actor Justin Theroux with a surprisingly saccharine hand, the film is neither believable nor novel.
There should be enough gut-troubling truth to In the Valley of Elah to make it transcend political squabbling.
The contrast between the near-surreal space footage and the down-to-earth men who were actually in those spacesuits is awe-inspiring.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Wow, bet the Brazilian Tourism Board hates this movie.
It is vengeance porn dressed up as an important film, a reverse slasher movie feigning some weak pretense of meaning beyond its own bloodlust.
It's got old-timey atmosphere with just enough new-age empathy to work. Throw in plenty of gun fighting and two fine actors circling one another with glee, and you've got one hot pistol of a movie.
A movie about the allure of groupthink and how the warm comfort of being surrounded by peers wilts all sense of balance.
Bright and engaging a great deal of the time, but it ends up exhausted.
Both the story and (literal) execution here are cheap and somewhat embarrassing for Bacon and company. Kill this movie.
Balls of Fury is a stupid movie that's not quite stupid enough, or at least not quite funny enough.
Dorks deserve better than this. Amanda Bynes deserve better than this. Most importantly, audiences deserve better than this.
The film lacks both the personality and central figure (as well as the all-important sense of humor) that made last year's similar An Inconvenient Truth so watchable.
Into the Wild takes your heart and shakes it, offering inspiration, exasperation and blunt realization in a true story of one young man's dream and nightmare.
Elizabeth: The Golden Age is a Rolls-Royce, car-crash of a movie -- classy, beautifully made and ultimately crushed beneath its own pretentiousness.
An amiable but awkward Christmas bauble that depends too much on charm substituting for timing.
Director Menno Meyjes keeps the sci-fi suspense quotient up just enough to make the ending somewhat disappointingly pat.

Despite Noonan's balancing social friction and fantasy, Miss Potter entrances and delights throughout. It's a beautifully made fairy tale with roots in reality, and all the more satisfying as a result.
It sounds so promising. It plays so disappointing.

Every bit as generic as its title, American Gangster is a Frankenstein creature of a film, put together from the parts of other famous gangster flicks yet lacking in both the fury and wild-eyed vision the best of the genre have to offer.
It's the script by Nancy Oliver, the very idea of the thing, that steals your heart. Kink has never felt so sweet and decent.
Rambunctious and rousing from beginning to end, the hugely entertaining King of California offers Michael Douglas his best role since Traffic.
A barely disguised anti-abortion tract, Bella is simple-minded, heavy-handed and as subtle as a gorilla in a tutu.

The movie has some nice plot turns, it settles around a painful moral dilemma, and features some fine acting. But it's the sticky sweat of the street and the fine attention to detail that pulls you in and keeps you glued to the screen.
This film is indeed Limited -- in appeal, sincerity and substance.
Rendition succumbs to a fatal imbalance brought on by terminal star power.
The problem is that the ghostly culprit, some sort of nature spirit, isn't nearly as terrifying as the arguments that Pollack makes, or the fact that the ice in such places really is weakening.
Mixing a stately pace with bursts of raw violence and blunt eroticism, Lust, Caution indeed deftly blends those two attitudes.
The one thing you're not supposed to do during a Western is doze off.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The previews make Dan in Real Life look like a tepid romantic comedy that makes little use of Steve Carell's gifts. Well, the previews are right.

Rocket Science flies beyond the standard teen preoccupations, moving into territory that combines humor and eccentricity with fragile hope and ambition, making for a film that embraces every awkward angle of adolescence.

There's supposed to be an underlying message here about the value of family and giving up the bad life for respectability, but writer-director Franc Reyes is really just using it as an excuse for a standard (at best) gangland shoot-'em-up.
Jackson does some good work, sporting a high gasp of a voice and letting his character surface to reality smoothly, but the movie becomes too much of a morality play as it unwinds.
Hairspray is a wondrously entertaining ball of spunky musical numbers, talent set free and fun, fun, fun, with just enough of a message to make it sizzle all the more. Don't miss it.
This is indeed an equal opportunity movie. But it's also a movie that beats its one joke into the ground.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, the nerdy loser thing has been done to death, but writer-director Taika Cohen brings surprising depth to this film...Napoleon Dynamite dreams of being this movie.
...there's a resolutely indie spirit at work here that keeps things interesting even when they shouldn't be.
Writer-director George Ratliff may have intended to make a movie no one would enjoy. He's succeeded.

Yates is wise not to stuff too many characters into this yarn, and plays everybody well, if sparingly. He can't offer a sense of completion -- more movies to come, you know -- but he offers a thoroughly enjoyable and interesting transition.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, it's well-intentioned and at times funny. But it's also strained and clumsy and a bit too simple-minded to be effective.

It's supposedly a romantic comedy, so imagine a couple of hilarious physical jokes -- you know, a guy takes a baseball to the face, ha-ha -- and channel in a few moments of Robin Williams doing his improv shtick around some key words.
It's doubtful even Michael Moore would claim Sicko as the last word on the subject. But it is a first word -- a very loud first word -- and while it may have been said better, at least Moore said it.
Ratatouille has the technical genius, emotional core and storytelling audacity to lift it into the ranks of [the best] Pixar films, the crème de la crème of modern animation.
The most perfect protagonist is always the imperfect protagonist. Leave it to John McClane to bring back the action hero.
A film that manages to find sunbeams between the corpses and drunks.

Should end up one of the year's best dramas, an intricate, jolting look at life out of control and one woman's fight to hold onto her dignity and love in the midst of unimaginable tragedy. It's not an easy story to watch. Imagine living it.
If the Lord does indeed work in mysterious ways, he or she had absolutely nothing to do with the making of Evan Almighty, a predictable and totally typical piece of Hollywood comedy overkill.
Transformers may be the most spectacularly stupid film ever made, and with modern-day Hollywood being what it is, that's quite a feat.

The Simpsons is pretty much exactly the movie everyone hoped it would be -- fast, funny and filled with a thousand quickie jokes and odd angles that enhance the central story without distracting from it.
Not as good as you'd expect, but with Boyle expectations are almost unfairly high.
On paper, it had to look like a guaranteed chick flick for the Food Network generation. On film, though, it's too tepid to work.
There's a surreal tinge to The Nanny Diaries that works both for and against the film.
A refreshingly blunt reminder of the simple roots of comedy in these grim, overly manufactured times.
It might have been nice to see Hirschbiegel's original concept play out. As it is, the film's essential eeriness gets mashed into Hollywood hogwash.
The Ten is nowhere near a 10. Let's call it a six.
This movie keeps falling out of rhythm just when it should be picking up pace. It's a fitful piece of wrong beginnings and false ends.
Unfortunately, putting witches in a script does not guarantee magic. Stardust simply has no sparkle.
Rush Hour 3 is everything a sequel shouldn't be: wasteful, unwanted, crass, inept and just plain awful to watch.
Poison ivy jokes. Poop jokes. Runaway bus jokes. Young love jokes. Skunk jokes. Some fake fatherly tender moments. Vomit jokes. This film has them all.
Misery, misery, misery.
Consistently laugh-aloud funny, a guilty chucklefest of ridiculous stunts, gleeful pummelings and questionable jokes that looks as if it were made by high school buddies who had a few weeks to kill.
Parents beware. Bratz will rot your child's mind, drain her soul and likely encourage early Botox dependency.

Insistent, ingenious and slammed full of five heart attacks worth of action, The Bourne Ultimatum may be the best conspiracy action-thriller ever made, a beautifully crafted mix of mayhem, well-earned paranoia and unlikely introspection.
[A] well-acted film about making the move from the street to the mainstream.
Takes what could have been a mundane if well-made war story into something greater -- more harrowing, more hungry and more human.
Expect to see this French film Americanized in the near future, but that's no reason to pass on the original.
Hardly heart-racing stuff.
There's a straight-ahead spirit to Freedom Writers that lifts it above its too-many peers in the 'troubled youth' category of films.
That a film about kids dares to be so without being exploitive or easy is both astonishing and admirable, if also shockingly harsh at times.
Dreamgirls is a knockout, no two ways about it, a sizzling adaptation of the successful Broadway musical that is bound to leave audiences howling with pleasure.
The specificity of the indulged lives in this film is delivered so ineptly that it seems as if rich kids have been shooting home movies in their own back yards. Which may be the case.
[A] thoroughly enjoyable mutant-palooza conclusion to the X-Men series.
A small portrait of friendship and intergenerational connection, painted in delicate strokes and warm tones.

Ultimately Hedge is déja vu all over again, a computer-generated work of wonder that could have come out last year, last month or two months from now, a film so reminiscent of other films it almost immediately dims in the memory.
Here's the gospel on The Da Vinci Code: It's a total snore.
Watered-down in every way imaginable, Poseidon capsizes under the very large load of corn it carries.
As an off-beat anatomy of a troubled couple, the film almost succeeds. As summer movie fun well, it's not.
But still, who was Bettie Page? The film offers not a clue.
Hoot is safe enough to take your kids to, but you might want to have a talk with them afterward about continuing to go to school and shying away from major felonies.
A perfect blast-off for the summer movie season and the rare sequel that's notably better than its predecessors.
Hard Candy is sweet poison indeed.
Brick is smart -- perhaps too smart for its own good at times. But in the end, its affectations add up to entertainment.
This is art engaging grim reality in the hope of perspective, understanding and perhaps even closure.
A cute little Matzoh of a movie.
Soapy, sappy, silly and sluggish, La Mujer de Mi Hermano (My Brother's Wife) is one of those issue movies that wants to cram every hot topic it can think of into a melodramatic situation.
It walks a middle ground between humorous perspective and dark insight. Then again, don't most of us?
Who hasn't wanted to leap down a stairwell, bounce from rooftop to rooftop, do a backflip over a bad guy, give him a few chop socky blows and then take away his gun?
Future generations can only hope something so nice happens when they get their Omen revival. For now, there's Damien Part Deux. Enjoy him, kids. Chances are, he'll be around for a while.
Depressing and hugely important.
Yes, it's brightly colored carnival fun. But this ride, in the end, only goes round and round and round. Which is ultimately more ho-hum than ho-ho-ho.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's a surface satisfaction to Wordplay that's absolutely undeniable. But there are also just enough smarts here to make you wish for something more.
Slight but entertaining, The Devil Wears Prada is an ugly duckling-Cinderella tale set in the fashion industry, in which the wicked stepmother is far more interesting than the princess-to-be.
Superman Returns is arguably the most expensive film ever made, and yet you leave the theater thinking, wow, those Spider-Man movies are really good.
Its mix of cheap jokes, common fantasy and shared anxiety should resonate with just about anyone who has a pulse. Pause and have a good laugh.
An intense piece of wilderness ugliness that mixes family, honor, decency, revenge, racism and mindless blood lust in a manner that satisfies even if it never astounds.
If you're looking for gunning gangsta action on a hot summer night, Waist Deep is an effective-enough story of urban outlaws in love and on the run. It's sweet, sweaty stuff, for a while at least.
The Lake House may float your boat if you're starved for romance, but really, love deserves better.
Nacho Libre is a funny idea for a skit that's been put on the rack and tortured into a screenplay.
Too scattered, too confused, too patched-together to work dramatically.

Those who have the sense to seek out this film will find themselves delightfully transported as Altman and screenwriter-star Garrison Keillor tackle issues of time, mortality and family while offering up great dollops of homespun entertainment.
Matter of fact, it's surprisingly entertaining, if ultimately shocking.
It's touching, it's funny, it offers cautions about the modern pace of life, and it depends on a sense of rural Americana for its soul.
A crazy-cool screech of a movie, The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift is a complete gas, a mad cross-cultural twist on a near-forgotten film genre that keeps your eyes glued to the screen.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There are tense situations, daring escapes, shots fired, innocent civilians at risk, foreign terrorists. What else do you need?
American Dreamz is an often uproarious, always ambitious gutting of modern America that cuts painfully close to the truth from beginning to almost-end.
A disturbing film about courage, idealism, youth and the grim mechanics of mankind gone mad.
A Cock and Bull Story is a grand giggle of a film, well worth your time and money and a game well played for the audience.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Filled with gristle, gore and mutant mayhem, The Hills Have Eyes is a blood feast for horror fans hungering for something more than the by-rote splatter platters that lately have been filling movie theaters.
If you're in search of a film with any real emotion or believable story, forget it. If you're OK with a flick that has some funny bits and a kooky couple playing second banana -- hey, launch on.
The Shaggy Dog is just what it wants to be -- wholesome, slapstick, family fun with nice animal rights and 'don't mess with mother nature' messages running beneath the surface.
It's hopeful, it's healthy, it squeals in all the right places and it offers proof positive that being stuck up is a bad thing.

While 16 Blocks may be two blocks and three left-hand turns too long, it's still one sturdy cop thriller, filled with grit, corruption, action and redemption and fueled by strong performances from Bruce Willis, Mos Def and David Morse.
Dunmore slogs through the story with an overripe sense of gravity that, when mixed with the film's carefully botched look, makes for one murky moviegoing experience.
...an off-the-wall celebration that mixes humor and music to amusing, if not life-changing, effect.

Funny, tough, filled with cut-to-the-bone moments and bleached in the heat of the Texas sun, The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada is a movie that sears itself into the viewer with uncompromising vision and stark approach.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, by Hollywood standards, Night Watch is about three Wookies and two Neos short of convincing. All the gobbledygook is in place, but the special effects are minimal and somewhat frustrating.
An exhilarating bloodbath of a film, Running Scared may not be perfect, but it's got adrenaline, wild eyes and sleaze to spare.
Situations that should have great emotional impact drag on into embarrassing shrillness; moments that are supposed to be heavy become leaden.
It's missing the movie part of being a movie. And so it sort of just sits there talking.
This film is so formulaic, so thoroughly what you'd expect that by the time you're done watching it you feel like you've just seen it for the second time.
Neil Young: Heart of Gold is one of the best live concert films ever made. If you like Neil Young, that is.
V for Vendetta has something going for it that's rare in mainstream films: It has ideas. It has questions. And even when it pretends to have answers, it also raises questions about those answers.
UWM is one thought-provoking piece of filmmaking, raising questions about the very essence of personality.
Tsotsi never lets go of its edge, and that edge draws blood.
The biggest problem Buscemi has is that his central character has, by definition, very little distinct character.
If ever there was an aptly titled film, it's Preaching to the Choir.
Pure amateur-hour stuff: a low-budget, poorly written gay movie that revolves around a crude joke and repeatedly delivers embarrassment when it's supposed to be offering humor.
There's nothing all that wild about The Wild, a tame but entertaining-enough computer-animated film from Disney.
Frighteningly silly, intentionally incorrect and stupendously stupid, Scary Movie 4 skewers everything in its path with a wild-eyed glee that's contagious.
Marilyn Hotchkiss' Ballroom Dancing and Charm School may stumble at times, but at least it gets out on the dance floor and has a good time.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: With its curlicue plot, consummate cast and crackerjack dialogue, Lucky Number Slevin is the sharpest bang-bang flick of the year so far.

What slop. Take the Lead is a rotted ground chuck of a movie, made up of the rancid processed parts of a plethora of films, good and bad, that have come before it. At first it seems awfully familiar, and then it just seems awful.

In the end, Nick and the world in which he traffics ends up a comic interpretation of a serious situation, and while the amoral ambiguity of the entire film is intriguing for a while, in the end you realize this patient has no pulse.
The sequel to Ice Age is very much like the original: witty and imaginative at times, dull and predictable at others.
ATL starts out somewhat fresh, but then turns slowly stale as its story of African-American kids in Atlanta takes on more and more of the standard elements of growing up in the hood movies.
In the end, this is a movie that makes the original Basic Instinct look good. And in a way, that's quite a feat.

A great bloody joy of B-movie madness, Slither is a hilarious concoction of gore and wisecracks that offers plenty of nods to horror history while maintaining enough slimy integrity to stand, or rather, slither, on its own.
Funny, disturbing, smart and consciously outrageous.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Inside Man brings Lee back into the mainstream while still letting him have some fun, and he passes that fun on to the audience.
Anybody who doesn't find themselves on the edge of their seat for this film's final minutes shouldn't be going to movies.

You, Me and Dupree is lazy, obvious, never emotionally real and, most unfortunately, sporadically funny at best. It's a movie you've seen before and you've seen done better. Owen, it's time to grow up.

Here's a guy willing to take risks, willing to tackle challenging material, willing to assume his audience has a brain. Unfortunately, his audience's collective brain is going to be hurting mightily for the first hour of this film.
Everyone but the terminally tight should find themselves laughing. And all should be awestruck by star Amy Sedaris.
Here's all you really need to know about Happy Feet: Singing penguins! Dancing penguins! Funny penguins! We're killing them! Smile for the holidays!

Casino Royale tries to have it both ways, moving toward the genuine while still grasping for the outlandish. The result is a film that's caught between caution and abandonment. And that's probably not a place where James Bond wants to be.
...The movie consists of waiting for what you know is going to come. Waiting some more. And then waiting some more.
A wondrously funny modern fairy tale, Stranger than Fiction manages to blend romance, satire and fantasy into a story that's both fully satisfying and patently absurd.
It celebrates individuality, hidden artistry, uncelebrated brilliance and the essence of the American spirit and is a general gas to watch.
Something of a one-note film, albeit a beautifully played note.

They say you don't want to see what goes on behind the scenes in the making of sausage or politics. Fast Food Nation blends the two, and the result may not be a very good movie, but it certainly is effectively disgusting.
Flushed Away is more fun than a bushel of slugs in a sewer. And considering the slugs in this sewer, that's saying quite a bit.
What truly sets Deliver Us from Evil apart from other documentaries is interviews with the monster himself.

Catch a Fire blurs the distinction between labels and resonates through today's global conflicts. More importantly, the film offers a taste of the desperation and fear behind the restrictions and the cruelty that whites forced on blacks.
Death of a President manages to be predictable and astounding at the same time.
Just as the title implies, Running with Scissors falls down and impales itself at nearly every turn. It's one big uh-oh and ouch of a movie.
Borne with grace and honor on the back of Helen Mirren's astounding title performance, The Queen manages to encompass the personal and political with both depth and grace.
Indulgent, immature, self-preoccupied and downright silly a good deal of the time, Shortbus manages to make sex look like no fun at all.
Borat packs all the intellectual punch of the standard pack of ultra-serious Oscar hopefuls. Plus it makes you laugh until your lungs hurt. And that's why it's one of the best movies of the year.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Dixie Chicks certainly don't shut up, but they do sing in Shut Up & Sing; and while some may wish they'd done more of one or the other, there's no denying the power of this documentary.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This fractured beauty-and-the-beast fairytale comes off disturbingly simple-minded.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Fountain is the most ambitious, rich, romantic and ridiculous film of the year, a movie that's both awe and giggle inspiring.

Painfully overlong, weighed down by its own self-conscious seriousness and filled with nonsurprises, The Good Shepherd will appeal only to those who like dreary tales filled with unlikable characters.
A history-based, murder-mystery war-yarn that goes round and round in circles.
Volver is rich, crazy, ambitious and filled with heaven and earth in a way that no other filmmaker can touch. It is a flawed beauty, but the beauty is so much more important than the flaws.
Night at the Museum is not just a wild runaround of computer-generated creatures. Well, OK, that's mostly what it is. Still, there is something of a plot.

The first four-fifths of the film is a meandering lead-up to the inevitable getting-in-shape montage, run up the steps and a big fight. Up until that point, all Rocky does is talk. And talk. And talk.
The characters are full-on clichés spouting wooden lines, given no time to develop as the film races from one silly conflict to another.

How could Charlotte's Web go wrong? It doesn't. It's a perfectly respectful, take-the-kids, down-home but enchanting-enough adaptation of the story of a pig who learns about life from a spider. Take the kids, especially the young, unsullied ones.
The Pursuit of Happyness attempts to be a warm movie with a good message. But its message is substantially skewed and the resulting warmth factor is decidedly low.
Blood Diamond loses its way at times, but the power and tragedy of civil war, of greed and tainted motives, is undeniable.
This is a chase movie with a fancy set-up, that's all.
Obviously intended as a romantic throwback to the good old days of Hollywood, The Holiday instead comes off as a self-indulgent, insipid piece of seasonal trash.
Nonbelievers need not apply. And that means you, Manilow fans.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [Director Christoper Guest] finds the absurd (and shares in the discovery with his cast) but always sees some human, tender truth behind the laugh lines. As a result, For Your Consideration is certainly worth your consideration.
The most interesting person in this maze of a movie is by far the title character. And his absence leaves an inescapable void.
A quirk-filled, paranoid, blood-and-sweat thriller that offers perfect pulse-racing escape for a holiday weekend.

A small wonder of a movie that puts its characters in playground swings and then gives them a push. Watch them fly this way and that, dangling between peril and ecstasy. And see if you don't recognize yourself.
The film manages to be a lush period piece, a love story, an examination of culture clash and a slow revelation of character emerging from stunted emotion.

A great contraption of a film, The Prestige is a classy little maze of distractions, obsessions and showmanship, a magic trick of a movie that keeps the viewer mesmerized and then ends with a flourish.

She was born into fabulous wealth and fame. By the time she was a teenager, her name was well-known to both the public and the well-to do. So is it any wonder Sofia Coppola wanted to do a movie about Marie Antoinette?
Go to school and do your best, but check out Accepted before you go just as a reminder of the glory of rebellious foolishness.
Little Miss Sunshine makes you want to gather all the kooks in your life and take a road trip.
Aside from the dance steps, you've seen it all before.
World Trade Center hits us where we live. And it reminds us how lucky we are to live, and love, and even struggle.
While there are occasional funny bits, the question remains: Why should you go see this movie instead of its competitors? The answer is: You shouldn't.
The Descent is a sharp hammer to the head and a claw to the gut, a blood-drenched creep show that wants to eat you alive. Beware, and bon appetit.

It is a great cheeseball of silliness, a 'B' movie that has enough sense to embrace its 'B'-ness and then squeeze, like a boa constrictor. It is intentionally sublimely ridiculous from beginning to end.
Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby is perfectly stupid chuckleheaded bliss, an achievement of the lowest and highest order. Every week should hold a movie like this.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's a sweet simplicity and humility to this film. Amid all the animation hype, it's just a very good movie. It's no big deal; and thus, it is.
Things don't really get ugly in Scoop, they just feel very familiar very quickly, which doesn't mean it's necessarily bad, just awfully lightweight and terribly unoriginal.
Directed by Ivan Reitman with the same loopy amiability he brought to hits like Ghostbusters, Junior and Dave in decades past, it is a solid summer confection with no pretensions.
Clerks II is dumb. Clerks II is brilliant. Clerks II is a rehash. Clerks II is surprisingly fresh. Clerks II will disappoint you at the same time that it keeps you fully entertained.
The result is an efficient film that never really catches fire, but satisfies along the way.

These days, movie fans have grown accustomed to being force-fed a film's reality, to having it hammered home from first loud frame to last. Lady in the Water offers more subtle submersion, a baptism of soulful quirks and daringly sweet imagination.
Don't go see Peaceful Warrior. Don't tell your friends about it. Try to forget you ever heard of the movie. Clear your mind and live in the now.
They're [Disney] not looking to make a complex, textured analysis of competition and ambition here, they just want a football movie that ends with the audience cheering for the hero.
Scene by scene it's funny enough, but it goes exactly where you expect it to go, which makes the last third a lot less funny than the first two-thirds.
Cross Crossover off your list of movies to see.
Montiel brings enough of his own emotional confusion and life experience to the party to make the cuts feel real, to make one more tale of mistakes and mangled youth worth following.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Man of the Year is a well-intentioned mess, a dated, yuk-it-up sloppy civics lesson with such a lack of conviction that it backs away from the very questions it poses.
Infamous is a well-made movie about a fascinating character, and if it weren't essentially a repeat of last year's Capote it would likely be one of the hot flicks in filmdom right now.
If this one doesn't win Scorsese an Oscar, then there's something seriously wrong with Oscar.

It's all very cosmopolitan (the dialogue is English, French and Spanish), very independent, a wee bit juvenile and very confusing, of course. But The Science of Sleep is also remarkably magical and desperately romantic beneath it all.
While it's not completely waterlogged, The Guardian is more than a bit soggy. It begins efficiently familiar and ends with a series of splashes that seem like desperate dogpaddling.
There's too much familiarity in School for Scoundrels for it to be break-out funny. There are chuckles, sure, but they're chuckles you've had before.
Sometimes corn works. Sometimes it doesn't. Flyboys flops.

Ungainly and bloated with an unearned sense of self-importance, All the King's Men is nevertheless worth watching for Sean Penn's mesmerizing performance as a corrupt politician who exults in his own dirty ways.
... The Last Kiss is a simple movie, but it should spark a great many conversations between couples leading to potentially dangerous territory.
If you like any of the lead actors, don't go see this movie. If you like good movies, don't go see this movie. If you're a steady customer at Helga's House of Pain, this one's for you.
It may not be a great film, but it is a thoroughly admirable movie.

This isn't the sort of film you stand up and cheer for -- it's too subtle and dark for that. But it is a film that lingers in the mind, asking questions without answers, telling a story that has no clear ending.
An aimless movie about an aimless man is still an aimless movie.
You know people keep saying 'they don't make movies like that anymore'? Well, in the case of Lassie, they have. And they've made it well.

There's some slight, indefinable lack to Flags of Our Fathers, some piece of missing brimstone that keeps it from setting the heart afire, leaving it a wholly admirable piece of filmmaking, but nothing more.
What a movie. What a director.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A lightweight romance for the senior crowd, Last Chance Harvey does nothing in particular, but it does it fairly well thanks to stars Dustin Hoffman and Emma Thompson.
Mr. Magorium's Wonder Emporium should delight audiences in the mood for holiday magic.
Taut and amazingly timely, The International is a conspiracy thriller that harkens back to the perilously paranoid '70s.
Bottom line: Any laugh's a good laugh these days.

The saddest thing about this film, coming on the heels of the deplorable Bride Wars, is it continues the trend of supposed chick flicks that treat women as complete morons. Ladies, you're better than this. Way better.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Spooky, stunning and savvy, Coraline is one of those kids movies that makes you wonder if all the kids are going to walk out of the theater with hair scared white and eyeballs frozen in awe.
One long mistake from start to finish, this is a film that never gets its rhythms or bearing right.
Yes, this movie offers dumb hope in wretched times, but for many, dumb hope is preferable to no hope at all.
There is so much wrong with Confessions of a Shopaholic -- timing, execution, resolution and moral stance, to name a few -- that it's hard to know where to begin.
Bottom line? Action junkies sign up, school marms stay home.
An American remake seems inevitable, but it will be hard to re-create the haunting spell cast by this wonderfully strange film about being young and going steady with a monster.
Outlander is a cheesy, low-budget, space alien Viking monster movie. And seemingly proud of it.
Even if it can't quite conjure up the movie magic it intends, Inkheart does serve as public service announcement promoting literacy. And as such, your kids could do a lot worse at the cineplex.
The story is inspirational; the movie isn't.
If this film makes money, and it probably will, there may never be a final Final Destination. And that is the most disturbing thing about this movie.
Sensationally stupid, haphazardly made and qualifying as unmitigated trash by any standards, Paul Blart: Mall Cop also manages to be consistently hilarious, thanks to star Kevin James.
Che, the story of a failed revolutionary, also fails as a film.

Bitter, nerve-wracking, ugly and relentless, Revolutionary Road is Big Drama done right, a mesmerizing look at desperate lives, wrong moves and spoiled dreams that hits hard right from the beginning and never lets up.
The very definition of a small film, Wendy and Lucy nonetheless packs some serious wallop thanks to a quietly extraordinary performance by Michelle Williams.

Nobody's going to get all that fired up about Fired Up, the latest in what seems like a million-mile-long line of purposely dumb adolescent sex comedies. But as genre entries go, this one's passable fun.
It's just such a thoroughly typical ghost story.
A big, silly spoof of an animated film, fast and funny and visually dazzling.
Malkovich keeps Buck an enigma -- part fool, part unheralded genius -- and if the film moves in expected ways it also hits some subtle grace notes.
Lifted by a trio of fine performances, Sunshine Cleaning thrives on the unexpected and revels in the low-key.
Duplicity, like all con movies, relies on charm, and there's plenty to go around.
The key here is to keep things moving without letting the logical (or illogical) complications weigh down the action, and [director] Vigalondo does this well.
The plot may not be much -- amazing creatures live in the sea and if we keep polluting the world a bunch of them will die, so let's stop being such jerks -- but the visuals are absolutely fantastic.
Race to Witch Mountain isn't magic, but it moves.
Mammoth, mangled, violent, confusing, dazzling, dark, excessive and occasionally brilliant.
The fact that it's based on a book written by a former teacher who also stars in the film gives it more than a bit of authenticity
Hell seems terribly familiar in Gomorrah, an Italian gangster film with a near-documentary feel.
Instead of opting for a big dramatic setting he stays small, finding the tender truth within what could have seemed a cliché.
Fanboys is pretty much for fanboys.
A wholly original and emotionally devastating animated documentary confessional.
A splendid little offbeat love story, Moscow, Belgium is a near-quintessential foreign art-house film: smart, sweet, intriguing, well-made and emotionally familiar while still unique.
With uncommon intelligence and brutal honesty, The Wrestler examines the cost, and need, of battle.
Setting feminism back at least a century, embarrassing a potential Oscar nominee and insulting the very idea of romance, Bride Wars is every bit as awful as it sounds.
It's a bit shaky in approach, execution and ending, the work of a grand master in middling mode.
While Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa may offer hope to inter-species romance enthusiasts, for most adults it will simply serve as a way to keep the kids occupied.
There's a raunchy energy to Soul Men that cannot be denied. Even if the film is derivative, predictable, visibly low-budget and crude, it's also darn funny a good deal of the time.
A movie that should be seen by everyone.
Sally Hawkins, in a blinding, Oscar-worthy piece of acting so good you barely see it, plays Poppy, a perpetually upbeat elementary schoolteacher in London.
What Just Happened? is just a plain clumsy movie.

There are laughs. Big, loud laughs. Laughs of self-recognition, laughs at social duplicity, laughs at prejudices of all types. Lots of laughs about the most basic of human functions. And many, many laughs at our own inhibitions.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Forster is indeed a fine director, but he's hardly a specialist in action films, and it shows. He can't quite keep things moving fast enough to speed past the absurdity of the premise.
This is a movie that's just sort of there, and nobody much would have paid any attention to it without the Madonna connection. And chances are nobody much will even with that connection.
Not that the movie's a knockout by any means. But it does bring enough integrity, good acting and old-fashioned mean street snarl to the formula to show it can still work.
Max Payne may be the worst movie of the year. The "may be" qualifier is only because the year isn't over yet.
As a film, it simply attempts too much, consequently accomplishing little.

There's a quiet charm to The Secret Life of Bees, a family movie that dares to tackle some serious subjects along the way. It's feel-good most of the time, feel-bad some of the time, and well made throughout.
City of Ember is one of those sparkling and smart family fantasy films that breed respect for the writers of young adult novels and serve as reminder that good things do come out of Hollywood.
Russell Crowe's portrayal of an overweight, amoral CIA honcho in the Middle East thriller Body of Lies is mesmerizing, chilling, disturbing to the bone and one of the best performances of the year.
It's a successful experiment that leaves you with a mix of hope and despair. To the lovers, best wishes. To the lonely, our sympathies.
In truth, the film is sure to stop the hearts of many who see it. There may indeed be hope in hell, but better to avoid hell altogether.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Witty, sweet and -- in 3D -- often visually dazzling, Bolt is an unexpected pleasure, a showbiz, sci-fi spin on a classic Disney tale that's sure to please small kids and parents alike.
Finally, a chick flick with some bite to it.

At times The Reader is an interesting exploration of both the needs of man and the limits of law. But there are so many dead spots in the film after it gets rolling that the rolling too often comes to a stop.
Initially intriguing and often dazzling, it ultimately drags on too long, with its wonder succumbing to frustration as the minutes drift by.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: John Patrick Shanley the writer should never again hire John Patrick Shanley the director.
Marley & Me is everything you could want in a holiday movie -- family friendly, touching, funny. Plus, it's surprisingly intelligent and real. It may be the best family film of the year.
Seven Pounds features the best performance by a jellyfish in a film this year. Really, the thing is mesmerizing.
It's obvious Carrey still has the juice; he just needs someone to give him the right squeeze.

Both a crackerjack entertainment and a sharp look at the roots, and limitations, of ambition, while stars Frank Langella (Nixon) and Michael Sheen (Frost) put on the year's most provocative and finely tuned display of dueling egos.

It's the latest entry in the dysfunctional family holiday genre... that dark blossoming group of films that remind us how thoroughly messed up life is even at special times before concluding that family makes it all worthwhile.

Despite all the fog machines and giant glowing spheres and TV actors excited to be in a big-budget movie, this remake of the 1951 sci-fi classic that gave baby boomer kids chills simply fails to strike any sparks.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's one of those films stuffed with odd characters in overblown situations. Unfortunately, you don't care about any of them.
Progress is slow, but Harvey Milk was one of the first to set the wheels in motion. He more than deserves a movie this good.
It's an endurance test that ends in moans of recognition as characters seem to be acting out scenes from other, better movies. Really, you don't want to sit through this.
Transporter 3 is so bad it's good, and it knows it.
Bruce is a thoroughly silly low-budget film made for people who revel in thoroughly silly low-budget films. Fanboys rejoice. Filmistas beware.

A surreal exploration of art, love and death, it has the Fellini-esque feel of some lost European cinematic masterpiece that reaches far past the normal boundaries of drama and into the very essence of existence.
Everlasting Moments offers such breadth and complexity it can be forgiven exceeding its grasp. In fact, it should be applauded for doing so.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Express is a somewhat ordinary movie about an extraordinary life.
Yes, you've seen much of it before, and the nervous James character is now officially a cliché. But Stewart makes you care anyway. This, folks, is an actress.
This franchise is out of gas.
A coming-of-age story that also examines the pull and push of the modern and traditional, Tulpan is a striking, unique, narrative feature debut for director-writer Sergei Dvortsevoy.
Egoyan is nothing if not low key; and as dramatic as passages are here, he keeps the tone under control and the story believable.
As beautifully made as it is -- and this may be the best-looking, best-directed Potter film yet -- there's an undeniable level of frustration built into Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Keaton the actor should work with Michael Keaton the director more.
A sweet effort that touches all the bases that have been touched so many times before.
Outrageous, unnerving, brave, topical, revealing, appalling and consistently hilarious, Brüno manages to be both cutting-edge cultural commentary and post-modern comic genius.
The question isn't how do you live with the buzz of looming death; it's how do you live without it? No answers are offered, or even suggested.
The result is a witty, well-played work without an adequate center. If you can get past that, Whatever Works does.
More interesting than involving, Public Enemies focuses on history at the expense of the characters that lived that history. It's all story without emotional impact.
If you are what you eat, we are mostly genetically modified, poorly regulated, unhealthy meat byproducts generating profits for a few gargantuan corporations.
There just isn't enough beneath the surface in Cheri to justify all the talent on hand.
Somewhere there is a stranger film than Big Man Japan, but it would be hard to find.
The film comes perilously close to reveling in the horror while revealing it. And dramatically, this is distressingly simple-minded fare: ugliness leads to ugliness.
A surprisingly lovely movie about an absolutely awful subject, My Sister's Keeper features what also may be the year's first performance worthy of Oscar mention.
Nobody seems to be working too hard in Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A great grinding garbage disposal of a movie, Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen isn't so much a narrative film as a cacophonous series of explosions intermittently interrupted by needless dialogue.
This is movie magic most unexpected.
Filled with the sort of pent-up vitriolic humor that Brits specialize in, it's one of those films that keep you laughing even as you realize how awfully close to the truth it likely is.
Food has never been funnier than it is in the spirited, animated family film Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: 9 is a captivating film with much to say about the human spirit -- even if humans are nowhere to be found.
A screwball comedy missing more than a few crucial screws.
Part road trip, part coming-of-age story, the film ultimately reveals itself as a Hollywood memoir, but it saves any stardust for its last moments.
It has all the ingredients for cult immortality and will likely live on long after this year's Oscar winners are forgotten.
A portrait of our times painted from an immigrant's mirror, Amreeka should be seen by every American.
hat this movie manages to be hilarious while honing in on the particulars that go into hilarity is a rare achievement. But then few films would dare look death right in the face and laugh aloud.
Lee takes the viewer on a sweet-enough and nicely personalized trip through a corner of the '60s. And even if he skips the main event, he finds plenty of color in its surroundings.

There's no getting around the character's plight as an eternal outsider or the natural sympathy it draws. But writer-director Mayer never loses control of this fact, offering a story that's both sweet and tart, unique and familiar.
His journey makes for a complex film that goes beyond the obvious. It, too, travels. And it travels well.
Basterds is not great Tarantino but it's solidly good Tarantino, and that's sweet news for his fans.
The acting here is surprisingly even and Neelam rarely betrays himself as a newbie behind the camera. For a local indie film, this Ocean is smooth indeed.
Slight, silly, sweet and, yes, quirky, Paper Heart doesn't really have a whole lot to say, but it says it in a unique and inventive way.
Fluffy, sweet and deliciously delightful, Julie & Julia is a hoot of a movie and a surefire recipe for a good time, assuming of course you can do without robots, superheroes and comics who curse.
Post Grad may be the strangest film of 2009. Unfortunately, not strange in a good way, strange in a bad way.
A straight-ahead romantic comedy that relies on the considerable charms of its stars, The Proposal feels so comfortable and familiar you might feel like you've seen it before.
Pointedly strange and whimsical, O'Horten mixes the surreal with the mundane in its depiction of the retirement and eventual rebirth of a train engineer.
Year One is a good short skit drawn out far, far too long, another big, dumb offering to the summer movie gods that is unlikely to appease or please anyone.
The dysfunctional suburban family drama has become so ubiquitous that the genre has lost all impact.
How do you make mutants dull?
Please, ladies, don't go see this movie. (Chances are most men would rather put out their eyes than go see a film with such a title.)
A study in the cost of pursuing a dream that's probably the wrong dream, Anvil! The Story of Anvil looks for the high notes but doesn't -- or can't -- shy away from the lows.
The Informers is such a wretched piece of garbage that there's a certain amount of guilt attached to even writing about it.
Disarmingly entertaining.
A film that should appeal to longtime Trekkies, sci-fi neophytes and pretty much anybody who likes a good action flick.
The Soloist foregoes easy solutions, and even more importantly, it foregoes any easy sense of friendship.
This is a film that doesn't know when to shut up and gaze in wonder.
State of Play makes you wonder where we'll be in a decade; more importantly, it makes you wonder where we are now.
It could be better, it could be worse.
Equal parts ridiculous and romantic, Shall We Kiss is an airy French puff pastry of a film, delicate and sweet, if lacking in any heavy nutritional content.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Mawkish but energized.
Writer-director Jody Hill is obviously trying to accomplish something here. But just what is none too clear.

Brutal, wrenching and filled with desperation and meanness, Sin Nombre signals a major new talent in writer-director Cary Fukunaga, who never flinches while telling a story so grim and sad it moves beyond tears to numbness.

First-time feature director Benny Boom and writer Blair Cobbs get a lot of help from their cast, and the banter is often akin to a thug Three Stooges routine. But blood and predictability sour things in the end.
The result is a film that's funny, sad and oddly brave.
This is a film that finds certain purity in disillusionment and freedom in failure. Which may not be sweet, but it is tasty.
It's hardly painful, but it's not exactly thrilling, either.
Management has two things going for it: Steve Zahn and Jennifer Aniston. Luckily, those are two very good things.
These are good actors telling a good story, so the virtue is indeed easy to grasp, and a fine time should be had by all.
The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3 is a near-perfect summer entertainment thriller that shows good story, good director and good actors trump gaudy special effects any day.
When it comes to movies, there's good stupid and there's just plain stupid. Land of the Lost is just plain stupid, and that's not good.
Superbly cast, well-written and so silly it makes your teeth ache.
Fans of fluff comedies filled with soft smiles and knowing glances will likely welcome the return of Nia Vardalos in My Life in Ruins.
There are not words enough to express how good Up is.
A sweet pearl of a French film, Summer Hours may work as a perfect antidote for those seeking refuge from the summer blockbuster season.

Battle of the Smithsonian is packed with odd characters, eccentric arguments and ornate special effects, and while it's never transcendently funny enough to be seriously impressive, it is chock full of family-friendly giggles.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It is a fast, gritty-yet-slick, bombastic modern action film filled with tortured souls. It's not exactly a gas -- how much post-apocalypse fun can be had? -- but it is often electrifying and always entertaining.
A well-played if too-familiar story of oppression and injustice.
This is a film about a problem, not a solution, and it's effectively upsetting.
Something of a cliché.
[It's] not anti-Catholic. It is, however, anti-exciting, anti-sense and anti-involving.
Revanche, a recent Austrian entry in the foreign film Oscar race, is both shocking in its starkness and subtle in its low seethe of dangerous intent.
After Appaloosa establishes its slightly modern characters in a traditional setting, it has nowhere to go but toward the completely expected.
Doesn't show us anything we haven't seen before.
The film stumbles at times... but it's essentially solid storytelling.

You expect The Band's Visit to be a sweet little snapshot, a delightful and endearing culture-clash movie -- funny and poignant and human. And it is all those things. What's surprising is how it manages to be just a bit more.

Yes, the film deals with women of an age who are usually ignored in film, and it further deals with questions of mortality and loss, which are equally overlooked. The problem is, it doesn't deal with them very well.

It's broadly comic, sweetly sentimental and sharply satirical at times -- particularly when it takes on the concept of celebrity -- and both parents and kids should walk away satisfied if not quite elated.

Wow! Hot dueling sisters. Beheadings. Untold wealth and power. Lush costumes. Decisions that change the course of history. And, again -- hot dueling sisters! So how come The Other Boleyn Girl is such a snooze?

Semi-Pro is precisely that: a movie that is sort of professionally made and sort of professionally acted with no serious expectations beyond earning money and offering audience members some passing entertainment.
The Signal is electrifying, deliciously mad and twisted filmmaking. It's certainly not for everyone, but chances are it will inspire many.
Barney Rubble had a lot more charisma than anyone involved in this movie.
Charlie Bartlett may not be a great movie, but it does serve as a splendid introduction to a supremely promising talent.

There's an undeniable sense of wonder to Be Kind Rewind, a belief in both the beauty of the creative process and the magic within all men. It's an unabashed ode to common potential; it's also a lot of fun to watch.
Observes with ruthless, artful precision. While plunging a knife through your soul.
It's hard to mix dark wit with real tragedy, but that's what writer-director Martin McDonagh pulls off with In Bruges, a wonderfully realized examination of unintended and deadly consequences.
Full zombie satisfaction.
The big news here is the intelligence, the balance, the real romance in Definitely, Maybe. No, it doesn't follow the formula. And really, how cool is that?
A herky-jerky mess of a movie, Jumper leaps about so erratically you get the feeling bent pogo sticks were employed in the editing room.
You can watch a Bugs Bunny cartoon from 10 different angles, and it's still a Bugs Bunny cartoon. Vantage Point is a Bugs Bunny cartoon.

It's a solid history lesson that's less solid as a movie, simply because so much of the weight seems to be crammed into a too-fragile framework. As a film, Honeydripper is fine history put to less fine use.
A tight, classic-feeling film about losers banding together for one big score, then scrambling furiously as they realize they're in over their heads. It's fast, nifty, sharp and sweet.
Horton Hears a Who! brings a masterwork into the here and now with both respect and wide-eyed enthusiasm. So smart, so stimulating, so much fun.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Throughout which, you ask: Why is Al Pacino in this movie?... The better question: Why are you in the theater?
If you want to break the kids in easy to the whole martial arts thing, this may be the way to go. After all, clean fu never killed anyone.
Smart is indeed the word for Smart People, an extremely well-acted film that manages to be simultaneously funny and troubling.
If you've seen Training Day, you've seen Street Kings done better.
This is how great rock and roll was meant to be filmed: By great filmmakers.

There's a stiff, constructed feel to Nim's Island, a constant sense of assembly that keeps the film from ever feeling natural. And no matter how unbelievable a tale might be, it has to take on a reality of its own to work on the screen.
There's an easy congeniality and air of old-school wit to Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day, and even if the film tries too hard at times, it's awfully enjoyable despite itself.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A nicely made if slightly stodgy jewel heist flick that offers Michael Caine one more juicy, low-key role and Demi Moore another step back up the ladder to career revival.

There's a keen and ugly sense of anguish to Stop-Loss, a caged sense of powerlessness beyond political outrage that makes this film far and away the most effective effort yet at capturing the frustration of the war in Iraq.

There's a cheeky, cross-continental exuberance to Run, Fatboy, Run that lifts it over its predictability and keeps you laughing louder than you know you should. It's an upfront guilty pleasure without pretense; what a pleasant surprise.
Paranoid Park becomes a portrait of the skate punk as repressed personality. The movie doesn't really go anywhere as a story, it simply unfolds.
So do the final 15 minutes negate the power of all that's gone before? Unfortunately, yes. Unless, that is, you're in the mood to embrace awfulness. In which case, rock on.
Overly familiar, underwhelmingly funny and thoroughly predictable, Taylor is a one-joke movie that doesn't even get that one joke right.
It's one big ball of icky attitude, violence and nihilism.
It's disposable, watchable and forgettable filmmaking for would-be easy millionaires.

One of those small films that give a glimpse into a culture that's both foreign and familiar. It's filled with real-life touches and small insights and wonderfully human characters, and the whole thing feels as real as crossing the street.
Good enough for an HBO special. But for a full-blown movie? No way.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It is such a prefabricated, false-feeling, scattered and awkward stab at a romantic comedy you feel embarrassed for everyone involved and sorry for anyone who spends money on a ticket expecting a decent date movie.
It's vaguely interesting, but vagueness isn't a big turn-on for most audiences. You keep wishing The Walker would break into an extended run in some direction. But instead it merely meanders.

Future is overlong and will best be enjoyed and understood by fans, but even newcomers will appreciate the essential drive of the man, who died of a sudden heart attack in 2002, and admire his ability to balance anger and ecstasy.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This is a film that might have contained itself better, but it still stings with bitter truth.
Ah, nuts.

Writer-director Noah Baumbach solidifies his standing as the modern bard of American dysfunctional families with Margot at the Wedding, but at the same time he's recycling material he's already covered, and covered more exquisitely.
Redacted, director Brian DePalma's ugly little Iraq War movie, wastes an interesting approach on trite, crude and painfully superficial content.
A cheeky, good-looking splatter fest that humorlessly shoves the grimness of Stephen Sondheim's stage musical in the viewer's face. The result: ugh.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Todd Haynes has come up with the most interesting psycho-cultural-biographical mix in memory here, managing to make the film reek of the artsy '60s at the same time it unfailingly honors its subject.
Ultra-violent, nonsensical and peppered with gratuitous nudity.
There's so much wrong going on, things start to feel forced.
A cold, rough look at the dissolution of just about everything. It will bother you afterward. It should.
Immature, crude, poorly made and a waste of time.
Epic in its ambitions and romantic to its core, Love in the Time of Cholera may not please everyone, but it has to be admired.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's more dazzle than disaster, but the technical ambitions of Beowulf work too sporadically to be completely effective, while the screenplay adaptation of the classic story suffers from serious bouts of corn poison.
Enchanted is not a perfect movie ... But it is so thoroughly delightful when Adams is on screen you forgive its faults with a smile.
For half an hour or so, Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story is hilarious. Problem is, the movie lasts an hour and a half.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A well-intentioned wreck.
It's about as quiet as a film can get. But for those in search of for nuance, intelligence and fine acting, this is a must-see.
This is a film that's completely happy being its silly little self. And if it produces some giggles along the way -- and it does -- it has done its job.
Honestly, this is a carbon copy of every other 'gotta dance' flick ever made, down to the cheesy emcees who host the big dance-off (it's in Detroit!) and the wannabe heart-tugging conclusion.
There's a deceptive simplicity to Woody Allen's Cassandra's Dream, a directness and clarity that's too rare in modern filmmaking.
This leap might be a bit easier to take if the robbers involved weren't all straight from the female stereotype handbook. And if any of their male companions were given an ounce of credibility.
Cloverfield is visceral attack that it leaves the viewer reeling for details that flew by like so many bricks raining off broken buildings.
Katherine Heigl is a movie star. Even in a fluffy romantic comedy like 27 Dresses, she lights up the screen.
A terrible mess of mystical mumbo jumbo, but you have to give Francis Ford Coppola's Youth Without Youth this: It is one magnificent and interesting failure of a film.
A well-made, Spanish ghost story that will creep you out and draw you in.
Your enjoyment of this movie may depend on the Tracy Morgan factor. Rarely has there been a comic who can switch from funny to unbearably grating with such speed.

By the end of The Bucket List, silliness has been replaced by pretension, and while there may not be a dry eye in the theater, many of those tears will be shed in embarrassment for giving in to such hooey.
[Director Julian] Schnabel isn't going anywhere astounding in this film; it is, after all, about a man who can't move. But he is exploring the vast potential of both imagination and spirit.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Powerful, painful and yet unerringly funny as it points out our emotional and physical vulnerabilities, this is a film that finds the humor in tragedy while keeping both omnipresent.
Even if it does precisely what you expect it's going to do, you still love it for doing it so well and telling a tale that bears repeating.
If The Kite Runner flies only to flutter and fall a bit, at least it flies for a while.
Juno is the best movie of the year. It's the best screenplay of the year, and it features the best actress of the year working with the best acting ensemble of the year.
Although Osama wraps up a bit too quickly, and ends a bit too obviously, the thing Spurlock finds is, for the most part, these people resemble us.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Horse-racing fans will likely just find fun and nobility here; others may find a too easy faade stripped bare and ugly. Fate intervened in this film. Perhaps it was trying to tell us something.

It's not that Baby Mama is an outright bad movie. It's just so thoroughly typical, a one-note, odd-couple, laff-lite film featuring two Saturday Night Live veterans that reminds you of so many other dashed-together SNL vet films.

Deception is one of those films that leave you feeling vaguely dirty and wholly unsatisfied, a distasteful and wholly unbelievable mix of soft porn and obvious duplicity that holds not one ounce of emotional truth.
Astonishing. Daring. Mind-boggling. Visually stunning. A true heart-stopper. And, oh yeah, the movie's pretty good, too.
Henry Poole is Here is one of those average guy-miracle stories that are supposed to make you feel good, but instead it just makes you feel used, and used rather badly.
Rich, complex, funny, erotic, compassionate and thoughtful, Vicky Cristina Barcelona may be the most fully realized film Woody Allen has made in two decades.
The saddest attempt yet to capitalize on the success of George Lucas' original sci-fi epic.
Tropic Thunder will have you laughing much of the time, but it may also leave you wondering: Couldn't this have been done a bit better?
The result is, predictably and enjoyably, old-fashioned macho mayhem with a post-modern twist. This movie knows it's ridiculous. Heck, it's proud to be ridiculous.
It sort of gurgles, with some pleasant-sounding pops here and there. But this is essentially a film that squanders a good idea by playing things too safely.
It's passable, while hinting at better things.
Small, intimate and achingly modern, Brick Lane is a lovely study involving both one woman's awakening and the inevitability of cross-cultural pollination.
Swing Vote is an amiable lug of a movie, part public service announcement, part political satire and part good-old-boy comedy with a spritz of sentiment hanging over the entire enterprise.
You've seen it all before. You don't want to see it again. It will hurt your head and lay waste to your soul.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It will doubtlessly end up preaching to the choir -- Bush backers beware -- but that choir should enjoy it.
This version feels fairly condensed.
There's a brittle pomp and circumstance to The Last Mistress, which suddenly turns into a sensual witch's dance, once star Asia Argento is let loose about a third of the way into the film.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Murder, marijuana and mayhem. Good times to the max, bro.
It has the tough guy lead, dozens of mad car crack-ups, tons of gratuitous violence, sweaty B-movie appeal, and even a couple of A-talent actors, but in the end Death Race runs around in circles.
Boy, is it stupid. Boy, is it funny.
The best dramatic film of the year so far.
Although crassed-up for modern audiences, Nick and Norah's Infinite Playlist may be the closest anyone has come to matching the teen agony-and-ecstasy romps that John Hughes pumped out in the '80s.
No two ways about it, Religulous is going to offend a lot of people who have never even see it. Chances are, it's going to offend a lot of people who do see it as well.
Though extravagantly pretty, The Duchess still manages to be a costume drama in which the drama survives the costumes.

A goofy blend of quirky characters, strange situations and wrong relationships, with just enough sadness running beneath its eccentricity to keep things somewhat real, Choke is a conscious oddball of a movie.
How unusual. How enjoyable.
The movie undeniably has its powerful moments, but it runs a crooked, crazy race moving from one to another, leaving the viewer both exhausted and frustrated.
Die Hard meets The Fugitive meets 2001: A Space Odyssey in the fully paranoid Eagle Eye, a frantic thriller that's nowhere near as good as its influences but still manages to get the job done.
In Search of a Midnight Kiss is a surprising charmer, a wandering modern romantic comedy with enough bittersweet aftertaste to give it substance and enough wit to keep you entertained.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gripping, disturbing, powerful and likely outright offensive to many people, Towelhead is an often brutal study of clashing cultures, adolescent abandonment and sexual confusion.

As Lakeview Terrace moves forward, it becomes clear this isn't a movie about the shuffling of black and white; it's a film about abusing power and desperately clinging to the status quo. It's a film about the fear of the future.
A friendly little piffle of a movie, Ghost Town nevertheless serves as a fine and funny introduction to Ricky Gervais for American audiences.
Hopefully that audience won't be fooled by this cast's potential and the clever concept; the final product here is anything but fabulous.

A thoroughly disposable comic romp made by a bunch of people who probably should have been working on bigger and better things, Burn After Reading is sure to frustrate just about anyone who goes to see it.
Frozen River isn't just a good movie made by a woman; it's a good movie on anyone's terms, one of the year's best. To find hope beneath this ice, in this ugly terrain, is to dream big.

Flat and just plain boring most of the time, Traitor wastes some fine actors -- Don Cheadle, Guy Pearce, Jeff Daniels and Said Taghmaoui -- and a topical story, finding no sparks in what should be an incendiary tale of terrorism.
The Wackness, for all its eccentricities and emotional pain, is really a sweet little film.
It's a brutal mess, and Braun doesn't sugarcoat things.
Do not go to Step Brothers looking for anything remotely meaningful, sincere or spiritually enhancing. Go for a laugh. It's got plenty of them.
Tell No One darts its way past all the improbabilities and clichÃ (C)s that weigh down most mysteries, shooting toward a conclusion that's both endearingly old-fashioned and satisfying.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's an efficiently made, appropriately terrifying film, downright minimalist in approach and all the more horrifying for it. It's so basic it's believable.
After staggering around a bit at the beginning it settles down and finds its groove. It's appropriately flashy, nicely naughty and wholly improbable, just as it's supposed to be.

Satisfying if not fully electrifying, Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull offers fans all the familiar elements: bullwhip, fedora, ancient texts, hidden clues, obscure maps and cliffhanging moment atop cliffhanging moment.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: These two boys have, along with writer-director Garth Jennings, turned a coming-of-age story into a treatise on both the fragility of artistic vision and the danger of popular opinion.
If there's one thing The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian accomplishes, it's this: It makes you realize just how good those Lord of the Rings movies were.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A few plot turns too many undermine Helen Hunt's Then She Found Me, and that's too bad, because Hunt shows some nice touches here both in front of and behind the camera.
The Fall may indeed stumble at times, and it's certainly hard to categorize. But it's also exhilarating in reach and vision while admirable in execution. If only more films aspired to such wonder.

Incompetently made and covered in corn, this is a martial arts movie that makes you yearn for The Karate Kid. Yes, that movie was corny, as well, but at least it was fun. Redbelt isn't fun, just laughable.
Ashton Kutcher and Cameron Diaz almost pull off Vegas despite everything. And there's quite a bit of everything.
In the end, Life is a challenging success, with Wood's performance again affirming her status among the young generation of actors, and Perelman's vision promising more intrigue to come.
A pleasant little piece of puffy French pastry reminiscent of many other pleasant little pieces of puffy French pastry.
