An unabashed piece of Hollywood fluff garnished with spry slapstick and appealing actors.

Industrial-strength comic book moviemaking of the most entertaining order, Iron Man is darn near invincible fun, a perfect mix of high-tech dazzle and good old-fashioned charisma that's bound to leave audiences begging for more.

An undeniably sweet mix of disarming honesty, inspired gumption and brutal reality, Young@Heart somehow manages to avoid the maudlin while enhancing the obvious with its portrait of a chorus of senior citizens who sing contemporary rock songs.
An eye-popping, day-glo videogame that's as emotionally empty as it is visually exhilarating, Speed Racer is style, style, style without substance, but then it moves so fast that many may not care.
Very much a Hollywood production -- formulaic, made for marketing and never quite as inspired as it could have been.

Deliciously twisted and divinely ill, Stuck does everything a good horror movie should: It contrasts the insane and the mundane, it reflects the social condition, and it offers jolt after jolt of gory surprise.
Truth is a matter of perspective in director Errol Morris' Standard Operating Procedure, a piercing look at the abuses at Abu Ghraib prison and the aftermath of their discovery.

he sheer exuberance of the production overcomes its difficulties, and the incongruous mix of nostalgia, James Bond crooning and the world's greatest actress bouncing up and down on a mattress is an undeniable kick. Mamma Mia! is major fun.
Let's face it: If you're any sort of pop-culture or movie freak, you're going to see this flick. And you should, just for Ledger.
Gonzo shows the man, warts and all.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a silly kid's movie, nothing more. But for some, this may be a chance to meet Eddie.
The film's flaws wither in the light of its brilliant ambitions.
Hancock is the sort of Fourth of July cinematic fireworks celebration Hollywood dreams about but rarely achieves.
Wanted may be the most absolutely stone bonkers, crazy-good movie of the century. Or it may be a gargantuan piece of trash. Chances are it's a combination of the two. But man, does it rock.
This is a film that stretches the expectations and reaches of animation at the same time it offers fantastic entertainment value to its audience.
A broad, old-fashioned epic in the David Lean mold.
A little more unabashed silliness might have made Get Smart a better movie. As is it's a chuckly comfort-food film that you neither love nor hate, serviceable fare for a warm summer daze.
Broad, loud, straight-ahead and raucous, The Incredible Hulk may not be the smoothest or smartest movie ever made, but it sure captures the spirit of its giant green protagonist.
Smart, touching and enlightening, a combination that makes Bigger, Stronger, Faster the best documentary of the year so far.
It's downright stupid.
The jagged energy of this film's opening and closing moments leave you wondering where it might have gone and what it might have been.
It's also pretty funny at times, even if its central joke wears thin.
Was this stuff always this bad? Or is this simply the fabled 'worst episode ever?'
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Pink Panther is like a pratfall that doesn't work. It should be funny, but it hurts more than it should.
The film serves as reminder and educator for those who've forgotten or never knew about the situation in Rwanda.
The World's Fastest Indian, in which Anthony Hopkins gets to play an adorably cantankerous old man, is a pretty safe bet as far as movies go.
An under-achieving film about how much women can achieve, featuring actors of such potential, seems more than a bit cynical even by Hollywood standards.
It reminds you of the power of film like no other movie in memory.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Has a simple, undeniable power.
Repugnant in its salacious superficiality, Porn Theatre manages to be boring and vile beneath its transparent veil of artistic pretense.

Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion is not just well-intentioned, it's admirably well-intentioned. Its intentions are so good they sparkle... The only problem is, that sort of stuff doesn't always make for the most fascinating movie.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A well-felt celebration of romantic, emotional and physical maturity, filled with laughs and tears. It's also something of a revelation when it comes to Diane Keaton's range.
A safe bet.
Most of us have seen this movie before, and seen it done better.
This is one of those films that decries war while reveling in it, that praises the purity of the noble savage and then slays him, exulting in the blood while worrying over the act.
The Haunted Mansion is likely the exact movie Disney wanted. Why they, or anyone else, would want it is another question.
The Missing is an absolute knockout, a western, a chase movie, an epic and the story of a splintered family and two civilizations at odds.
Just plain hilarious, a dark comedy triumph that beats on your typical holiday movie with a baseball bat.
This Dude, Where's My Sword-time travel mess is funnier than a good many intentional comedies.
My Life Without Me only has one way to go, and it makes some dippy turns getting there. But Polley makes the trip worth it.
Silly, outrageous and surprisingly sweet.
Small kids should love it, and parents may find themselves pleasantly amused.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A film about one death that is fully vibrant with both life and love.
Not that there aren't award-worthy performances here, there are. And not that it isn't good, it is. It's just not THAT good.
A movie that cares about its audience, cares about the concept of community and makes you laugh time after time after time.
A somewhat incongruous mix of high drama and street dancing in which the street dancing is fabulous, and the high drama is low grade at best.
Interesting stuff that's plain fun to watch.
Date is precisely a date movie, nothing to be ashamed of but nothing to get all that excited about either.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Girl With A Pearl Earring is one of those quiet, restrained films that softly haunts the viewer for weeks afterward. It won't knock you over, but it won't soon leave you either.
The whole thing starts out amiably enough, but then loses all momentum just as it's supposed to be lifting off.
If you're interested in returning to Neverland -- or taking some young person along for the ride -- this Pan will serve you well. For others, though, the flight might seem too familiar.
It's got ... a solid sense of humor about its own awfulness.
One of those efficiently made formula films that keeps movie houses open during the early part of the year.
It is powerful, powerful stuff.
Funny, touching, smart, whimsical, dazzling and, at times, downright magical.
The performances, the way Inarritu deconstructs and reconstructs the narrative, the grainy, gritty feel and look, all lead to the rare sort of experience that only a truly great film can offer.
Silly, noisy, comforting fun.
Instead of a nifty thriller, Woo delivers typical bombast, making what should be an exciting film feel like 'Exhibit A' in the case against modern action films.
Its series of weak excuses and cliched insights illuminate nothing, and the movie ends up little more than a lesbian slasher flick.
It's sure, scary stuff, and fans of heart palpitations will likely find themselves pleased.
Fascinating at times, exciting and harrowing at others, and always visually arresting.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Suffers both from being too retro (in terms of style) and too modern (in terms of hyperactivity and crowding).
Kill Bill may be mindless fun, but it is the most mindless fun in memory.
Splendid fare, a fun-filled power chord of a flick all ages can enjoy.
Soggy at the beginning, silly at the end, but often riveting in between, Out of Time is another Denzel Washington movie that's nowhere near as good as Denzel Washington.
A sure-fire audience-pleaser that makes up for its dearth of ideas and originality with spunk, a self-effacing smirk and gobs of humor.
Textured, thoughtful and touching.
A low-key delight, a funny study in gullibility and dependence that wonders at the wimp in all of us.
An amiable romp of a movie, a romantic comedy in which romance is plundered and ridiculed while simultaneously longed for.
Secondhand Lions is not a great movie, but you'd have to be an old coot not to like it at least a bit.
This is not the sumptuous visual feast Scott usually delivers, and that's likely intentional. He's going for character here, for connections, and he gets them for a while. Then he lets go.
Cabin Fever may be low-budget gore-gore silliness, but it's passionate low-budget gore-gore silliness.
Just another stunted-up silly blood bath with no real passion, intelligence or wit.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's mostly a lurching, clumsy affair, a very poor man's Catch-22.
Every bit the disposable piece of piffle you think it's going to be, Dickie Roberts: Former Child Star is nonetheless mildly enjoyable.
Step Into Liquid delivers eye-popping shots pumped up by the genuine cowabunga enthusiasm of true believers. By the end all you want to do is get in the water.
A noisy, tiresome affair that can't manage one moment of wit or real tension.
A movie that just doesn't live up to its potential.
It is a story without a story, helpless and wandering, enjoyable for its parts but failing as a whole.
Artistically, its heavy-handed clumsiness undercuts its goals.
It stands completely on Downey's tragi-comic performance, although the rest of the cast -- particularly Penn and Gibson -- do good work as well.
It's a thoughtful, well-paced look at one pathetic kid's lies, and our equally pathetic willingness to accept them as truth.
As movies go, it's wholly predictable, occasionally and intentionally dull, and apparently quite lazy.
Perfectly wonderful if not completely perfect.
You'll laugh hard, you'll laugh often, and you'll leave wishing you still believed in Santa.
This isn't revolution, this is devolution.
A near-perfect holiday film about families and imperfection.
Ultimately the question people may ask about In The Cut could be, She took her clothes off for this?
A platinum-class production that tackles the major hot-button issue of American racism and yet somehow never manages to connect emotionally either through its main characters or story.
Worth watching despite the miscues.
It has the tasteless thing going on but no film can succeed on vomit alone.
There is depth in this movie, and fine acting. But even more intriguing, there are questions... questions with no clear answers.
Wonderland may not be the feel-good movie of the year; in fact it feels pretty lousy most of the time. But it offers a dark story well-told with some truly fine performances.
A standard, industrial-strength, ensemble courtroom drama that offers nothing special beyond a set moral stance on a hot topic, which is nice but hardly enough to fuel an entire movie.
As wasteful an example of indie-picture indulgence and incompetence as you're likely to find.
Do not catch Catch That Kid, unless your own kids threaten you with direct bodily harm. Even then you might want to skip it. They're little, the punches shouldn't hurt that much.
An audacious mix of documentary, animation, comic and staged film that somehow finds heart and hope in the gray wash of a real life.
The only people likely to be disappointed will be those who bother to wonder how good 50 First Dates could have been.
It offers lackluster fantasy propped up by cliches. Kallen's story deserves better.
It tells instead of shows for the most part, and the telling isn't as effective as it should be.
By no means a great movie, but it's efficiently watchable, thanks to Marshall's direction and occasionally buoyant thanks to its stars.
Doesn't really have any interesting characters to live through those disasters and its central storyline makes little sense.
Shrek 2 is thoroughly enjoyable and will keep audiences of all ages laughing.
Funny, sickening, scary, entertaining and undeniably educational.
A lot of sexy stuff wrapped in an obvious morality tale with some philosophical hooey and clunky symbols thrown in to justify the cheap, but undeniable, thrills.
A movie that seems to think it's more interesting than it really is.
Riveting entertainment with a bit more on its mind and a sense of grandeur that's undeniable.
No one's going to argue that Van Helsing is a great movie, but it's just the sort of loud, splashy, silly, summer fun flick we've come to expect.

The unapologetic, no-consequence nature of the characters' activities here, as well as the constant flow of dress-them-up Barbie outfits the twins don, wallow in the worst sort of amorality and image-is- everything indulgence.
Envy is not something you should feel for anyone who happens to see Envy. Pity, in truth, would be more appropriate.
A strong diva-whore portrayal by Isabelle Adjani and fine sense of time and place give Voyage just enough grounding to make it worth the trip.
Will likely be soon forgotten by all who see it, although the scientific controversy it glosses over seems destined someday to anchor a far better film.
Disappointingly tepid and lacking in essential chemistry, Laws of Attraction simply never adds up to much.
Worth seeing.
It's good for some laughs. And that's all it intends to be.
A complete pleasure.
The problem is, the characters eventually start to seem like a couple of idiots.
A small, smart film filled with heart.
Those looking for a heartwarming, funny and adventurous story about wild animals will certainly find it in Two Brothers.
A film every citizen of voting age in America should see.
Derivative, crude and so predictable it hurts.
The value in Control Room is simply that it shows what America never got to see while also serving as a reminder that nobody serves up the real truth, everybody just serves up their truth.
This may not be a great movie, but it may prove a great feel-good balm to many.
Artful, fast-moving and engrossing.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: There are many blessed moments in this movie.
Weighed down by a by-the-numbers plot.

Full of itself, as fiercely independent as it should be and primed with real passion, Baadasssss! is a salute to an imperfect man, a history of an imperfect time and a celebration of an imperfect film that kicked doors open.
Quote not available.
A stylish comedic re-imagining of the '70s feminist thriller, filled with witchy wit and war-of-the-sexes stingers as well as a number of delicious performances.
A child's film for adults.
It's interesting, not fascinating, intriguing, not electrifying. But for those in the mood for an offbeat pleasure, A Slipping Down Life may well satisfy.
It's incredible how little actually happens considering all the possibilities.
Earnest, old-fashioned and undeniably dull.
Satisfyingly offbeat.
A look at the fame machine, done with tongue in cheek, eyes open in wonderment and a brazen sense of playfulness that's hard to resist.
Taking Lives isn't bad, really, it just isn't distinctive.

Dizzying, dazzling, smart and, most importantly, honestly struggling with the variables of love, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind is a mesmerizing mind game that still manages to find perfect pitch while pulling heartstrings.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A big chomping horror delight, Dawn of the Dead reworks director George Romero's zombie classic with gobs of blood, buckets of black humor and enough cocky style to induce giggles between shivers.
It's smart, quick and engrossing, and even if it's also imperfect, it at least attempts to engage subjects too often ignored.

There is undeniable pleasure in watching Depp have fun with a role, turning a character in an inferior movie into something worth treasuring. Still, it would be even more rewarding watching him work his magic in a good film.
You don't have to be some obscure movie junkie to enjoy it, you just have to have a sense of humor.
A cute but insubstantial exercise in stylish silliness that will likely be quickly forgotten.
If you walk away from Touching the Void amazed at the strength of the human will to survive, even without faith or solid hope for the future, the film has likely done its job.
As tremendously stupid as it is unavoidably funny, Starsky and Hutch is one of those slop-job, slapstick movies you can't help but laugh at.
As titles go, Twisted doesn't go quite far enough. Convoluted might have been better. Stretched also would have worked. Ridiculous would be most appropriate.
The music could be better, the story could be better, the dancing could be better and the casting could be better.
A filmed bloodletting like no other on record, essentially a terribly graphic two-hour torture sequence.
The best and worst thing about this film is it seems completely true. And no amount of water can wash away the sins portrayed.
A comfortable movie.
This is a bigger-than-life, feel-good yarn with just enough dramatic charge to keep it from floating away.
An ambitious, energetic and wholly satisfying movie about the dawn of dramatic and personal freedom and much more.
A family-positive movie that's far more interesting than most competition in the genre, but not nearly inventive enough to stand up to Smith's other work.
Walking Tall is absolutely terrible, dumb beyond fun, truncated, ludicrous and completely disconnected from reality.
Man on Fire lacks the depth to truly ignite the screen, so instead does a slow, steady burn. It singes beautifully, but never explodes.
An engaging and wholly preposterous gumdrop of a film.
Dogville is in no way a standard film and likely won't appeal to many. But Von Trier is so inventive, so outlandish and so filled with energy he has to at least be admired.
A sometimes sad, sometimes heartening look at what happens when the ultra-hip age.
Brassy, sassy and laugh-aloud funny in a let's-put-on-a-show way.
A flatline affair from beginning to end, The Punisher is painfully dull, offering no characters, actions, scenes or special effects of note.
Kill Bill Vol. 2 is violent, smart, funny, fast, bloody, overblown, explosive and surprisingly romantic. And utterly, utterly crazy cool.

It offers no great insights into the majority of its characters or the politics of the time; it is not the proudest or most shameful moment for any member of its cast; and it is neither overly long or dumbly abrupt. It's simply what it is.
A stylish, sweet and saucy spring surprise loaded with laughs and unexpected smarts.
Invigorating fun -- cheeky, saucy, a bit crass and just drunk enough on its own sense of playful invention.
A thoughtful, mature, daring work that looks beneath the surface of an awful act and asks questions few would ask.
Johnson Family Vacation is one of those comedies where you keep waiting for the comedy to show up.
A coming-of-age, coming-out, romantic comedy, religious intolerance flick, and if that sounds a bit crowded, that's because it is.
Entertaining, not inspiring.
The best comic book flick since Spider-Man and a bonafide blast of a film.
An out-of-print postcard of a movie, neither shocking or smart enough to matter in the modern world, and too disjointed to be involving.
Well worth seeing for comic and action fans, but let's hope for a lower hand-wringing quotient next time around.
It is a strong, affecting movie about man's ability to twist holiness into horror.
It is a well-dressed film filled with thought and sly observations.
Has a mad energy and proud idiocy that's impossible to deny.
A blast from beginning to end and shows first-time director George Clooney is equal parts fearless, brilliant and perhaps daft. But an intriguing daftness it is.
The film revels so brazenly in genre cliches that it eventually earns admiration for boldly going where nearly everyone has gone before.
As stunning an acting showcase as you'll find.
A romantic comedy that's as completely predictable as it is eminently forgettable.
Take a camcorder to the zoo and make your own kangaroo movie. Trust me, it will be far superior.
As films go, it's as bad as an Elvis movie some of the time and better than an Elvis movie, but not by much, the rest of the time.
Loud, crass, dumb and then even dumber.
Narc is fast, brutal and a lot smarter than it at first appears to be.
The Pianist breaks no new ground, but serves as a strong reminder of one of mankind's truly awful moments.
The thorns in this film prick real blood, the color of which too few films can or care to examine. It is fine stuff indeed.
You will spend an hour and a half feeling adequately entertained if you're a sucker for sci-fi-run-run-run flicks.
The culture clashes you expect follow, but what isn't expected is how marvelous Jackman is in the role.
After a while, you start wondering where this movie is going, and then it goes nowhere.
It's just sort of there, one more adaptation of a long rambling Charles Dickens soap opera well-stocked with respected British actors playing painfully stereotypical characters.
Novocaine isn't the kind of movie you can really sink your teeth into, but it is a nice passing fancy, a creative spin on a classic crime form that has just enough bite.
The Recruit is serviceable spy fodder made a great guilty pleasure by Pacino's 'OK, no Oscar here, let's have some fun' performance.
Too often mistaking obscurity for complexity and moodiness for depth, director Lynn Ramsay squanders an intriguing premise and a layered performance by Samantha Morton.
At least Morgan knows the smartest thing he can do is just let Glover go nuts.
Washington may like the timing, but the serious considerations of war and horror here are ultimately undermined by sentiment and schlock.
While Bringing Down the House is far from perfect, it is still guaranteed to get you laughing.
Sloppily made, frustratingly inconsistent, purposely lowbrow, blatantly derivative and never once enlightening in even the slightest way, Old School is also undeniably howl-out-loud funny at times.
Too many elements of David Ayers' screenplay fall flat, from individual lines to Bobby's sudden change of heart.
Not a great film, and it's doubtful its 'surprise' endings will surprise many people, but it manages to be both smoothly entertaining and engaging while carrying a strong point of view.
The best film of the past year, Talk to Her is adventuresome, sad, hilarious, odd and completely at peace with its own admittedly mad premise.
Despite a low budget and predictable story line, Lockdown has undeniable power to it, fired by some fine performances and a terrifying portrayal of prison life that rings disturbingly true.
Completely devoid of subtlety or sense, the film is a series of bad scenes connected by empty characters, most of whom seem like leftovers from scripts abandoned long ago.
Caine is the center of this film and he's never been more brilliant and less blinding.
If it's not a completely successful film, it is at the very least an intriguing effort to humanize the demon.
A sure delight for both guys and gals.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: As frothy, sex-obsessed romantic comedies go, Deliver Us From Eva pretty much delivers the goods.
If Knights isn't exactly great filmmaking, it is at least a lot of silly fun.
The characters are sweet -- OK, the new baby character's a bit of a nuisance -- the music is fun and, yes, that bear can indeed dance.
A noble failure in the canon of America's best sibling film team, a movie that was there just a bit too long.
A winner from beginning to end.
You may walk out of this movie with a headache, you may walk out angry or or you may feel like you've just come back from Oz, but you will not walk out unaffected.
Eye of the Beholder suffers from blurry vision at best. Don't let your eyes behold it.
Gossip breaks out of the teen genre in surprising and ultimately pleasing ways .
Well-filmed, well-acted and certainly riveting, American Psycho nonetheless is a movie without heart about a man without heart.
Lots of exploding heads and oceans of blood, moves fast and with no discernible meaning but looks good.
Still, the movie is pretty bad. It's Rush Hour meets 48 Hours meets Bad Boys except this time around there's only one bad boy and the script and direction are subpar.
The cars are the funniest thing in the movie. And really, they're not all that funny.
Manages to both capture the spirit of a counterculture and reflect on the essentially conventional lives of those who lose themselves in the buzz.
A sure bet!
Except for Myers, and for many he will make the movie worth watching. He's absolutely shagadelic and completely unexpected. This should have been his movie.
A big, dumb piece of fun that will do little for your heart or intellect, but will undoubtedly leave you laughing.
All formula gloss, a romance that tackles some difficult issues by missing them altogether.
movie_title: How Stella Got Her Groove Back (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Bringing Out the Dead is a screaming siren of a film!
Crazy in Alabama manages to be both sweeping and small, quirky and sincere, and offers Melanie Griffith her best role in years.
There are some literally killer performances here, most notably Johanna Wokalek as Gudrun.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to get outraged about a movie this bad.
Pure garbage.
Intelligent, inventive, worried and surprising.
A piece of mass-market movie bubblegum that stretches incredulity and then snaps apart.

Too bad we're ready for the film's final pay-off 20 minutes before it comes. Less is more in comedy and a bit less would have made Bandits more successful. As it is, both the performers and the audience end up robbed by excess.
About halfway through you start wondering if anything else is going to happen to make things more interesting. The answer: Nope.
Lukas Moodysson shows ... wit, warmth and a stealthy eye for human need in this wonderful import.
The Deep End does what too few films even attempt -- it takes an ordinary life and places it in an extraordinary situation just believable enough to be terrifying.
A touching study of alienation that comes with no easy answers or excuses for those who cannot seem to connect in life.
Deliciously inane, transcendentally outrageous and purposely preposterous, Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back is destined to be seen by some as the greatest cinematic achievement of the year.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It's your basic, steamy black widow tale with one of the most implausible set-ups in memory.
The only reason to see Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within is to gaze in amazement at what the future of film may hold. It's not a particularly good movie, but it's a movie that may change the movies.
The film never really regains the opening scene's momentum.
Quote not available.
The Watcher isn't that hard to watch, but you could find better things to do with your eyes.
Road Trip is the best dumb party movie of the year; if that's what you've been craving, buckle up.
A bloody mess!
Too Shallow!
Sixth Sense is scary -- and smart!
The Hunted isn't grand cinema, but it's a good jog around the action flick track. Sort of like The Fugitive, except ...
It's bloody, it's loud, it's gratuitous, and it's ridiculous. Sweet.
Even though it is hugely self-indulgent, painfully slow and as repetitive as walking around in circles in the desert, the film has a sort of twisted charm by its end.
It walks an odd path through romance, psychology and the netherworld, but it's a walk worth taking.
The rare horror film that splatters and pauses to consider the splatter, that follows a traditional storyline and then improves upon it, and that avoids cliches while playing one out.
Insomniacs in search of a solid two-hour nap should greet the arrival of Alex & Emma with some enthusiasm. All others will want to diligently avoid this film.
Hulk may not jump as high as some had hoped, but it still packs a solid wallop.
The film doesn't really offer much behind its story.
Mostly this movie swings and misses.
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Glutted with car chases, hot tubs, yoga lessons, psychics, rap murders, glitzy locales and smirks, smirks, smirks, Hollywood Homicide is obviously supposed to be a rollicking good time. Instead it's sporadicly, mildly amusing formulaic mush.
Like the first Angels movie, it is purposely vacant and proudly shallow, a silly piece of cinematic cotton candy and a blast if you're in the mood for such nonsense.

The Thornberrys just happen to be visiting the same island the Rugrats have been marooned on, a coincidence born in corporate cartoon heaven, letting the newer franchise prop up the older a bit. The good news is, it pretty much works.
The sort of film that sounds completely kooky until you see it. At which point it's still pretty kooky, but you realize just how cool kooky can still be.
movie_title: Rivers and Tides: Andy Goldsworthy Working With Time (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Immensely satisfying, and if it's also puzzling and frustrating at times, so is life.
movie_title: The Man on the Train (L'homme du train) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It may not steal your heart, but you won't feel robbed.
A simple test of humanity: If you don't laugh aloud while watching it, you've got a battery not a heart.
There is something so purely and positively American about Spellbound that it is indeed spellbinding.
Manic has quite a bit to recommend it as well, not the least of which is the lack of Hollywood gloss mental patients.
A mediocre film that could have been much worse.
The mix of such fascinating events with the memories of those who endured them is undeniably compelling, even if much of what's described here has been described for decades.
It's enough to make you think people really can talk to whales.
A downhill rollercoaster of a movie that's consistently entertaining and explosive, at the same time T3 just isn't as emotionally connected or philosophically challenging as it predecessors.
A typically loose and mindless Hong Kong vehicle.
Good, wholesome fun with no pretense.
It ponders human worth, physical and emotional, with a mix of outrage and tenderness that's hard to fault.
Still has all the crude, rude fun of its predecessors.
Its awkward Rain Man- meets-gangsters- in-love plot lurches forward with such clumsiness it's hard to believe writer/director Martin Brest avoided seeing this thing flushed direct-to-video.
Too self-indulgent.
Light, flighty and just smart enough, Jet Lag isn't worth losing sleep over, but it is worth seeing.
It's the kind of movie that makes you feel better for having watched it, a film of endless hope and energy.
It is the loudest, crassest, fastest, most destructive, biggest and dumbest.
Gentlemen is not in a league of its own, but in a league with too many others.
Surprisingly dull.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A Tarantino-esque mishmash of tough crime cliches spit out in Aussie accents.
Lacking in wit, originality and spectacle, it is passable at best.
movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Although some good laughs are to be had in Blonde 2, there's really very little tying them together.
A film as boring as its title is grammatically incorrect and long.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's just another Hollywood comedy. There's nothing terribly wrong with that, but there's nothing terribly right with it either.
Yep, this is the Carrey America loves -- off-the-wall, over-the-top, elastic, spastic and fantastic.
It is not revolutionary, but it brims with promise and a love of film, and is a fine if worried dance indeed.
Every bit as awful as it sounds.
A pretty nifty mystery about deranged love, and if nothing is truly startling, it's still smartly put together and completely entertaining.
movie_title: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Stark, experimental and surprisingly affecting.
An ode to love and art while simultaneously a reminder of human frailty.
Anger Management plays the same tune too much of the time to live up to its potential. Still, it's good for a giggle.
Spider isn't nearly as disturbing as it is intriguing, despite its subject matter.

Purposely and often brazenly politically incorrect, it is essentially a one-joke film, but that joke happens to be about race in America, a subject that resonates long after the quick laughs are gone.
The reason it works is simple: Farrell.
Plays very well indeed in modern America, where our melting pot of immigrant cultures inevitably leads to clashes over assimilation and tradition.
The Core is formulaic Hollywood swill done on such an epic scale of incompetency, it must be seen.
Cuba Gooding Jr. achieved fame by shouting 'Show me the money.' Obviously he was not acting.
The power of voices raised together comes through with a clear elation that's undeniable, and in the end Amandla! makes you want to sing.
movie_title: Amandla! A Revolution in Four-Part Harmony (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Dreamcatcher is a serviceable action-horror-sci-fi flick much of the time, but it has a bit too much going on for any of it to have real impact.
A predictable piffle of a movie that never comes close to the heights its talented cast promises.
It is mesmerizing at times, repetitive at times, and most revealing when it separates the Adolf Hitler the world knew from the private Hitler.
This is the sort of family film people keep wishing Hollywood would make. Well, they made it. Go see it.
Confidence isn't great and it's not trying to be. It just wants to take your money and show you a good time. It's an enjoyable way to be taken.
It isn't a standard slasher flick, but it impersonates one for so long you want to slap it around.
Blue Car isn't an easy ride, but it's worth taking.
The complete lack of authentic feeling in this film as well as its obsession with period without finding any meaning in that period doom it.
Few nonbelievers will be persuaded by the film, even fewer of those within the fold will be discouraged by it, but despite its faults, The Matrix has indeed been reloaded.
A celebration of the under-appreciated, and if any purpose beyond that is a bit fuzzy, it's a harmless aimlessness that likely won't get in the way for fans of the music.
An old story, The Emperor's New Clothes turned inside out, but screenwriter Craig Sherman and director Francois Velle have such fun with the material that it's completely contagious.
While Guest never forgets to laugh, he never forgets to love either, embracing the very subject he is simultaneously throttling.
Simply one of the great feats of filming.
Family films we need. Films like this, we never need.
LaBute seems to be relying on big moments that never show up and surprises spied long ahead of time.
Offers little to love, despise or even care about.
It is good, clean fun and likely does not spell the end of Western civilization.
A slightly flawed film that will nevertheless give fans of the comic book and first film a plenty good buzz.
One very fine film.
It's not a perfect work ... but it is so filled with energy, angst, talent, authenticity and passion that it stands heads above most supposed youth-culture releases.
Sometimes shrill, often dull, it has nowhere in particular to go, and it takes far too long not getting there.
Banks takes a nice premise and does absolutely nothing original with it, instead burdening a plot derived from too many James Bond movies with cheap special effects and flat jokes.
Depth, complexity, questions, expanse of feeling -- these are things that make America great. How terrible that a film called America's Heart and Soul missed both those elements.
It's a moderately creepy, man-beyond- civilization exercise that can't decide whether it's arty or scary, and thus ends up being neither.
Whether this is filmmaking or recording is always up for debate; that it's fascinating isn't.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Amazing. Incredible. Unbelievable. Astonishing. Painful. All these words come to mind in just the first 10 minutes of viewing this film, none of them in a good way.

The frank lack of condescension and mean moments of Murderball make it more than a film about sports or quadriplegics: It becomes a movie about life, about struggle, about pain, bitterness and pushing forward.
[Stealth] is the filmic embodiment of all that is indulgent, gratuitous and downright dumb in pop culture.
A good-natured and witty mix of two modern film genres, Sky High is classic Disney filmmaking -- fanciful, family-friendly and, most importantly, fun.
There appears to be much more to Yao than is captured here. That's where the movie drops the ball.
Bad News Bears isn't Linklater's or Thornton's greatest work, but it's funny from beginning to end and properly improper at every turn. This is religiously irreverent stuff. Pray for more.
It's good to know someone can still make a good stupid movie, a movie that knows how to laugh at itself instead of merely catering to mankind's lowest instincts.
The Island seems like the movie Michael Bay was born to make.

A film of indescribable and often unmentionable charm, Me and You and Everyone We Know is one of those completely unexpected artistic experiences, a work from an unknown with such a compelling, unique perspective that it boggles and inspires.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Burton has included a far more satisfying ending.

You get the feeling a script is a bit beyond itself when words constantly appear on the screen explaining biographies, plot twists and such, and Roos depends on a constant parade of such explanations in Happy Endings.
No one's going to mistake it for a major piece of cinema, but it's the rare person who won't find themselves consistently laughing aloud . This is one reception you won't want to miss.
A low-budget, mildly enjoyable oddity.
The film is part nostalgia, part wary tale of wasted youth and part underdog struggle.
Hustle & Flow is a celebration of crude aspirations, of raw art, of raunch and street and yearning and, beneath it all, family values.
It's duly considered, absolutely serious, self-consciously modern and, unfortunately, fairly dull.
Ridiculously violent, crude, homophobic, brash and often plain absurd.
It never gives its characters enough character to build the sentiment required.
As a drama, it isn't much. As education, its heart is certainly in the right place. As an entertainment experience, it's more than a bit of a repetitive.
The situations feel real, the injustices believable and the human frailty is all too recognizable.
Consistently entertaining and ultimately satisfying, offering Robert Redford his best role in a decade. Kids, this is why everybody used to love this guy.
The Transporter 2 is good trash, the sort of loud bang-bang flick that's so over-the-top you buy it with a laugh.

This is not a movie that will shock you or thrill you or rock your world. Instead, it will move you, it will stick with you, it will give you pause and effect you in ways not easily described -- which is something the best films always do.
Features an astounding performance from comparative unknown Amy Adams that is all the more satisfying in that it doesn't overwhelm the film.
A pretty good movie.
Logically, all the monsters would eat all the humans at once, and the movie would be over in about three minutes. In the case of The Cave, that would have been a good thing.

All this silliness swirls around for about an hour and a half and then you get to leave the theater. Unless you're being held there at gunpoint. And really, that's about the only excuse for being in a theater watching this thing in the first place.
What makes Grizzly Man remarkable are the edited tapes that at first seem to show a man at peace among nature, and then later reveal the startlingly fragile state of that man's mind and persona.
Audiard has a nice stride here, establishing Tom's world and then altering it with slow insistence.
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrêté (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: There are no dinosaurs, starships, monsters or special effects involved. Just two humans pressed too close to one another, locked in a fight for survival. What could be more frightening?
It's all terribly self-conscious and desperately arty and fairly bad.
Completely charming, but ultimately slight.
Terry Gilliam casts such a mad, magical spell over the proceedings that the film is endlessly energized and gleefully imaginative.
Dark Water is a murky business indeed, painfully sloooow, absurdly derivative and just plain embarrassing for the wealth of talented people involved in it.
A film that's nowhere near as fantastic as it should be. Something's missing. And that something is most likely a strong director.
The thing with Rebound is: If you've seen the poster, if you've seen the trailer, if you've seen the commercial, you've seen the movie.
Bloody good fun a great deal of the time. Love the accents. Love the guns. Bang-bang.
This is powerful, intelligent filmmaking filled with emotional resonance.
Good old-fashioned fun from kickoff to the last crossing of the goal line.
A safe-as-milk, toy-ready, born-to-cross-promote piece of animated Hollywood product that will likely please children but leave adults dreaming of The Incredibles.
All those who wondered whether writer-director George Lucas was going to end his sci-fi career in a downward tailspin can rest easy.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: No one with any kind of mind should waste it on this film.

The young ladies all perform well, the script is like a well-built tear-duct milking machine, and parents should be pleased their kids are going to see such well-intentioned drivel instead of the mean-spirited drivel that's far more prevalent.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Fluff has it's place, and it's awfully good to see feel-the-burn Jane back in action, unrepentant and laughing at herself and the world.
There is not one redeeming moment in this movie, unless you consider Paris Hilton stripping down to her underwear and getting killed redeeming.

Dramatically, the problem is it's a lot easier to root for someone battling tigers and gladiators than it is to cheer on a guy wondering about the meaning of life. This is why Waiting for Godot has never been made into a summer movie blockbuster.
This is garbage, fun garbage at times, but action-bang trash nonetheless.
A Lot Like Love is about fairly average if absurdly cute people who develop a relationship over a period of seven years. Sound exciting? You're right, it's not.
Pollack drives this movie as if it's a well-tuned automobile, taking turns smoothly, accelerating at the right moments then easing off the gas pedal without ever losing momentum.
So filled with crazy energy that it seems to leap off the screen, Kung Fu Hustle is the most wildly inventive, purely entertaining and cuckoo-cool flick to hit movie houses this year...
So, yeah, this is a terribly flawed film. Then again, it's a film featuring Jiminy Glick; nobody's really expecting much.
A grand piece of old-fashioned Hollywood filmmaking that is easily the best movie of the year so far.
Lords of Dogtown rocks.
You don't like Don't Move, you admire it for daring to be a bit more complex, for caring about characters who are hard to care about and for plowing forward through all manner of ugly business.

In his latest science-fiction epic, director Steven Spielberg shows he's better at blowing up the world than anyone else alive. Unfortunately, he also shows he has no idea how to put the world back together.
It's the revealing performance from Press that breathes life into the film.
A funny, sharp and touching look at middle-aged angst.
Land of the Dead is living proof that films still can be inventive, that Hollywood is not the absolute center of the filmmaking universe and that a zombie film still can be scary and smart.
Rize is actually a film about how art can be subverted and perverted by the same social and internal pressures that spawned it in the first place.

Bewitched is respectful of its origin, and it's brave enough to go beyond the obvious. Unfortunately, it goes beyond in a somewhat wrong direction. As a result, this broom stick doesn't really fly, it just glides along.
This isn't a movie for the ages, but it is a movie for young ages, the kind of film you can unashamedly take your kids to and know they're learning the magic of film.
Ultimately turns out to be something of a bore, a film that, like one of its main characters, wanders around touching on subjects and then fleeing before connecting fully.
If it's still something of a formula teen movie -- cute guy, kids fixing parents' lives, spunky sidekick, darling outfits, etc. -- it also touches on some issues outside the formula.

An undeniable return to good form for the enduring comic book hero, an industrial-strength summer-action flick fantasia that manages to capture the excitement of the early Batman films while working in a decidedly darker tone.
The man at its heart is a 76-year-old Palestinian named Musa, and if he and we are never quite sure what the movie is truly about it's still a pleasure to make his acquaintance.
It's a two-hour therapy session with lots of firepower. What a blast.
Watch this movie and you wonder: How did it get made?
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's as if the movie is half Honeymooners remake and half typical weak comedy, which doesn't add up to a whole lot of anything.
The film's unintentional revelation may be that the competition isn't near as important as the education. The trophy is only a faint shadow of what has been accomplished.
If heaven is a big ball of cotton candy, then Just Like Heaven lives up to its name. It has no nutritional value, and it won't fill you up, but it's bright, pink and fluffy.
Completely cheesy and mildly enjoyable.
Patrick McGrath's screenplay, based on his novel, has moments big and small, delivered in appropriate dollops of awfulness.
Flightplan has holes and blank spots you could steer an airbus through.
If love does indeed conquer all, it should win hearts across America. If not, then its focus on a tragic stigma will remain as valid as its story suggests.
What was supposed to be a jewel turns out to be a simple Christmas trinket.

Monstrous. Monumental. Magnificent. Use any term you want, there's no denying the power, genius and spectacle of King Kong, which is certainly the biggest movie of the year and possibly the biggest movie ever made.
Rambling and disjointed, Protocols of Zion starts out pretty interesting and then begins skidding all over the place, losing focus just as it should be building momentum.
A purposely jagged and harsh news story of a film, Syriana attempts to take on the powers that run the world and for the most part it succeeds.
It would be easy to brush off The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe as Lord of the Rings-light. Very light. But the film really isn't even that good.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Cute kids. Harried fathers. Wise, understanding mothers. Some stupid pet tricks. A little girl falls in love. Over-protective father messes things up. Money isn't everything. Tender moments. And lots of pratfalls.
By the end of Pulse the world seemed a whole lot creepier place. I'm pretty sure that means it worked.
Yes, it's sick. Yes, it's funny.

Yours, Mine and Ours is indeed recycled garbage, but it's fairly harmless recycled garbage. It's certainly not enough to make you gag. Set your standards low, and the worst you should get is a hiccup or two.
The Ice Harvest is indeed a cold movie, and aside from a few nice wise-cracking death scenes, it never really does pick up any heat.
Rent is still Rent, and devotees should adore it while haters will hate it (there are, apparently, plenty of both).
Egoyan simply offers too much in terms of twists and trysts.
Tempts with a bit of a buzz, but then can't deliver and becomes more than a bit silly and self-admiring.
There's probably a good snowboarding movie coming some day. This isn't it.
Walk the Line is absolute standard biopic stuff, so familiar that it blatantly echoes last year's Ray, which similarly failed to do justice to the legendary Ray Charles.
The performances are good, the visuals are lush, the span is epic, but the film simply never soars.
Breakfast on Pluto may seem a fairy tale at times (no pun intended), but this Kitten has claws.
Something New is a message movie and it doesn't hide that fact. But it also goes beyond the message, and that's why it works.
Big Momma's House 2 is an atrocious film. But what's even more frightening is that Hollywood thinks people will find it funny.
Competently made but painfully similar to a plethora of films that have come before it, Annapolis is simply too familiar to land any real punches.

Soderbergh uses the mechanics of the grimy doll factory ... as metaphor, carefully tracking the shiny distractions we hide behind, revealing the awful little facts about their glued-on eyelashes and the identically blank faces they all start out with.
Nanny McPhee offers solid family entertainment in the face of it all. Mary Poppins, eat your heart out.
A generally fun movie that offers a different perspective on, well, a different perspective.
A ribald, witty costume comedy filled with delightful performances and wily plot turns, this is the sort of film that makes you wonder why more films like this aren't made.
This is Woody beyond Woody, his best work in more than a decade and the antithesis of most fans' expectations.
The sheer convenience of the situations and characters involved ultimately undermines its impact.
It's a variety show of a film with something for everyone if nothing of great consequence.
The visuals are passable. The story's a lot of fun. And the story is what sells the movie.
Glory Road is a can't-lose slam dunk of a movie, the sort of film that charges right over its minor flaws thanks to good intentions, fine execution and a breathless air of excitement.
In the end, Tristan & Isolde is never painful. It's just a bit of a dull blade.

The chief joy in this film is the balance of vulnerability and conniving slickness that [Pierce] Brosnan brings to his hit man and the easy kick that a middle-class husband and wife get out of knowing him.
Whatever you're looking for in a movie -- depth, empathy, enlightenment or just plain yuks -- look elsewhere.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: More impressive than wondrous, it won't transform the series, but it moves it along, pushing its charges toward adulthood and the mean sorcery of the grown-up world.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Hany Abu-Assad can't tell the entire story in Paradise Now, but he can show glimmers of it.
Featuring a number of nicely honed performances and weaving three initially disparate tales into one, Loggerheads delivers far more than you might expect.
This, folks, is not entertainment.
The sad conclusion of Good Night is that while we have made no more room for Murrows in this world, the potential for McCarthys lingers. In which case, good luck indeed.
Domino, director Tony Scott's hyperactive, roll-in-the-mud, blow-stuff-up and jiggle the cameras every which way extravaganza, is one of the most awesomely awful films ever made.
Ultimately, the movie isn't as strong as the idea behind the movie, or the people inside that idea.
If the premise is wonderfully silly, the pursuit of its end is a dazzling parade of invention and inspiration.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's a chick flick for non-chicks too, one of those movies that makes you laugh and cry and leaves you feeling satisfied and drained and vaguely embarrassed for having such a good time.
A tight little film that's so painfully civil it makes you want to slap the characters around, which may be the point.
You can see why Pacino takes such roles: They're so Al, so tragic, so lowdown, so easy for him. He invented guys like this. But he must have other inventions left in him.
Yes, we laugh; yes, we cry; the sun rises and sets. It's all quite enlightening.
Oliver Twist as presented by Roman Polanski is pretty much the same as Oliver Twist presented by anyone else, except perhaps it's a bit duller.
If you want to take a trip to the stars, this is the rocket to ride.
Never makes it to so bad it's good, stalling instead at so-bad it's bad.
Crackling good work, emotionally and intellectually interesting and grandly entertaining, saved from pomposity a good deal of the time by its sense of humor.
At the very least it's oddly admirable, at its best it's both passionate and disturbing, two words that come close to describing all of Cronenberg's work.
If you're looking for a hefty serving of rude fun with a side of light meaning, order up Waiting.
This movie doesn't take the easy way out. Instead it tries to track the ripples of devastation caused by misunderstanding and then blind dedication.
Stay is a cheap trick. Avoid it.
In overdoing the theatrics and hammering the clichés North Country does artistic injustice to its own important argument.
Fast, flashy and filled with gunplay, gumshoes and gangsters...

There is a wonderful old-fashioned zest to "Zathura," an air of jet-propelled innocent wonder that has just enough modern grounding and grumbling to ring emotionally true. It's the sort of movie that feels simultaneously classic and new.
No one is terrible in this film. The acting is passable; the camera's in focus; the lines make sense. But it's all been done before, far too often.
Crippled by a trite story line and a serious lack of flash from rapper and first-time actor Curtis '50 Cent' Jackson, Get Rich or Die Tryin' pretty much dies trying.
It's a quiet, amusing, sad and hopeful film about the dissonance between age and youth, commitment and freedom, growth and stagnation.
If you've seen all the above films, this will all sound just as silly as it is. If you haven't, it will just sound cuckoo.
Nicely acted, beautifully shot and pretty much devoid of action and context, Jarhead has to be considered one of the year's biggest failures, simply because so much talent went into a film so empty.
It's almost as if Disney was so nervous about its big chance at computer animation that it crammed in the cheap jokes and disposable music and wayward side plots to make sure it appealed to everyone.
It's a movie filled with pain and frustration, but it's also consistently funny, riding the fine line between tragic understanding and comic observation.
A nuanced meditation on the context of happiness and the problem with great expectations.
It is complex and thoughtful and tragic in the end. And it is certainly one of the best movies of the year.
It offers an unlikely romance in a somewhat comic situation, finding both humor and emotional truth.
Saw II lacks quite a bit of the cutting edge that made the original such a guilty, grisly pleasure last year.
It may not be a great film, but it's better than a poke in the eye with a sword.
Absolutely solid family entertainment, Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story is corn-fed, wholesome and thoroughly satisfying.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Mildly cute while thoroughly forgettable, the chief achievement of The Baxter is it serves to remind viewers how thoroughly adorable Michelle Williams can be, even in something this inconsequential.
It's supposed to invite you in, and it does, with eccentric characters, soft stories and a sense of spare solidity that feels more true than precious.
Exults in its own audaciousness, in its abandonment of convention and flaunting of unexpected intelligence.
This is definitely Farrelly-lite, or more accurately, Farrelly-soft. Simply put, the movie could use a bit of hair gel.
Old-timers, showbiz buffs and big-stage wanna-bes will not be disappointed.
What it has is a tired narrative frame ... a lost ensemble cast, no depth of character and a series of situations taken straight from the land of obvious.
All of this is obviously completely predictable and you keep waiting for something unexpected to happen. You're still waiting when the film ends.
There is something heartening in the way Waters continues to get away with such films.
Witty, energetic and appropriately self-mocking, cheesy fun.
A surprisingly action-packed wingding of a flick, a snappy Twilight Zone episode blown satisfyingly large beyond expectations.
Funny, dazzling, fast and frisky, Shark Tale is a sparkling addition to the modern animation canon.
Bernie Mac is too talented to be wasting his time in movies like Mr. 3000. And you'd be wise not to waste your time with it as well.
In its simple portrait of a bully Mean Creek may be one of the most political and socially conscious films of the year.
The progression of Evergreen is fairly familiar and director Zentelis relies heavily on characters who aren't inherently that interesting.
Any person voting in this year's presidential election owes it to America's future to see this film.
The disparity between Richard and Rodrigo is too great and the impossible coincidences of the ending are too far-fetched.
It is, admittedly, pure trash. But it's trash with a bit of flash and a resonant bad science message.
Comes fully charged if just a little bit silly, a wham-bam action flick with no pretense and plenty of fun.
A technological wonder from beginning to end.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An uncomfortable jumble of Harvey, Bend It Like Beckham and The Birdcage.
This movie wears its agenda proudly. If at times awkwardly, it has something real it wants to say.
A completely inane buddy flick filled with flashy car chases, ridiculous situations, cheap self-help advice, unabashed mugging and a few good laughs.
Its odd allure comes from the sad reality of its story. The monsters here are memories that won't leave, that we cling to and fall prey to, illusions that will not fade.
Even if playwright Jeffrey Hatcher was a bit too tied up in his original play, there's no denying the wonderful wit at its center.
If it's hard to watch, its crude power is also somewhat mesmerizing.
Walken manages to deliver something pure and heartfelt here. Unfortunately, he's doing so in a film weighed down by coincidences and quirks.
Major stinker. We're talking hold your nose as you walk past the theater.
Anyone who has ever seen a horror flick will know where this one's going every inch of the way.

To be sure it's blatantly partisan, but this documentary about the current presidential candidate's youth is also a moving exploration of Vietnam veterans who ended up protesting the very war they had fought in.
movie_title: Going Upriver: The Long War of John Kerry (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Adventurous, challenging and filled with small moments of delight. Unfortunately, it's also self-indulgent, repetitious and the sort of movie you wish was great but isn't.
Utterly vile, purposefully malicious and just stone brilliant a good deal of the time, Team America: World Police contains something to offend virtually everybody. Yes, even you.
Invigorating, hopeful, funny and perfectly consciously corny at times.
Well-acted, beautifully shot and broad and personal, The Motorcycle Diaries is nonetheless undermined in the end by a clunky search for meaning and depth that seems forced.
There are few things as satisfying as watching the wealthy, righteous, powerful or pompous get fully duped. As a result, there is a great deal of satisfaction in The Yes Men.
Contains just the right mix of grunting, cheerleading and backbiting, of failure and success, of broken dreams and great expectations.
What Hilary Duff will do when she grows up is anybody's guess, but for now she's the Duffinator, and things could be a lot worse.
What is it with Robin Williams playing creepy roles? How did the one-time funniest guy on earth turn into Mr. Spooky? Come back, Mork, your work here was not done.
There are no thrills, psychological or otherwise; the plot twist comes halfway through and then gets beaten to death; and none of the characters take on any depth or texture beyond their obsessions.
A bit stiff and predictable.
Earnest, overbearing and fully depressing, We Don't Live Here Anymore features a quartet of fine performances that are somewhat undermined by the numbing, one-note tone of the entire enterprise.
Shyamalan's most mature and least showy film to date.
Catwoman is fully as terrible as you guessed it might be.
As thrillers go, Supremacy is indeed supreme.
Dead could have used a direct blast of energy at some point instead of the trickle it finally gets. This film's already asleep.
It's an independent film about a specific culture that manages to bring that experience to life for any viewer in a funny, heartfelt, engaging way.
The story is sad. The music is witty, wary, impassioned and delightful. The balance is what makes De-Lovely special.
The rare remake that takes on its own times and spirit. It's not better than the original -- in some areas it's weaker -- but it is its own movie.
Will Smith fans will likely be disappointed, and lovers of fine cinema best look elsewhere. But if you're looking for robots going crazy, this one's worth your money.
Well-acted, well-shot, humorous, touching, thoughtful and sharp, it nonetheless is missing that certain spark that lifts solid work above itself.
A simply amazing film -- touching, sexy, smart, sad and, beyond all, passionate about the value of time and love.
The makers of Sleepover have read the 'tweeners film plot handbook and adhere to it closely.
Ferrell has an absolutely magical way of making complete morons lovable.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Most folks, when asked about the legend of King Arthur, don't immediately conjure up an image of Keira Knightley in a leather bikini.
An independent take on a Hollywood tradition, undermined by its cliches but saved by its performances.
Nothing's particularly risky or original, but neither is anything all that repulsive.
It's nothing terrible -- a typical kid's fantasy -- but it's nothing any sober person is going to want to sit through.
Doesn't quite satisfy -- it all seems too simple, too glowing -- but it tries, and that's something. Not quite enough, but something.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Fans will undoubtedly thrive on every second. For the rest of us, Monster is precisely that: a creature powerful but ungainly.
A stunning epic of China that serves up both a visual feast and fascinating narrative.
A gussied-up bore.
Precisely what you think it is: a workmanlike sequel to a thrill-kill flick that doesn't even pretend to be good.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It is perhaps the most incompetent and least funny comic film ever made. There aren't even any good diaper jokes.
Scattered, clumsily ambitious, sexist, amateurish and just plain dumb, She Hate Me is a bad film, most likely the worst film Spike Lee has ever made.
A film about lives of quiet desperation that stay quiet while getting a bit less desperate. It challenges, it rewards, but it never roars.
Without a Paddle can proudly take its place in the pantheon of perfectly likable stupid movies.
A provocative, classy, low-key sci-fi tale that presents a world so within reach it's scary.
The kind of movie that reminds you why you love movies so much, a film so filled with unexpected energy and ambition and sly intelligence it gives you hope for the future.
It is a rough jewel unearthed, and if you care at all about the era, it will shine for you.
It's not the sweet gem the original film was. But it's still a nice shiny bauble of a movie.
If you want to be consumed by special effects, go to any of the many formulaic thrillers in theaters these days. If you want to feel the real chill of fear, go for a swim.
One of those films that finds strength in its directness, that passes up the fireworks and cheap tricks and just goes straight for the starkness of a powerful situation.
There aren't that many action films that end in musical numbers and this film makes you wonder why. Nutty stuff.
A fairly typical bang-bang exercise with outrageous shootouts, lots of dead bodies and well-placed comic relief.
The music numbers are lively, the supporting cast solid, and the direction by Taylor Hackford is fully efficient.
Staunton is brilliant as Vera.
An incredible amount of fun.
Sideways is one of those films that's a bit too good to review: It strikes a unique tone, blends a bit of tall-tale fun with everyday life, and pretty much hits every note in your psyche.

The film's one redeeming quality may be its eventual use as a thesis subject for some would-be Phd ('Be Cool: Deconstructing Hollywood at its Worst'). But that will be little consolation for anyone who wastes nine bucks on a ticket for this movie.

It's inventive in story if somewhat standard in character, but it really trips up by leaning on pyrotechnics that never really catch fire. That ultimately puts it in the category of interesting, but not mind-blowing.

The whole thing is a melodrama; there's nothing fatally wrong with that. But the set-ups are so easy and obvious, the humor so broad and the characters such one-dimensional stereotypes that the drama is laughable.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This is a movie to take your kids to.
Admittedly, a big bunch of supernatural mumbo-jumbo, and it's also a cool looking big bunch of supernatural mumbo-jumbo garnished with a healthy dollop of religious cynicism.
While Tony Jaa is bad in a good way, Ong Bak is bad in a bad way.
Vin Diesel is baby food in The Pacifier. He's strained peas, pureed plums and all manner of pabulum. So all older than 5 beware: This is a movie you'll likely want to spit up.
The film leaves no doubt that the movie was an important cultural lynchpin in the '70s, but its import beyond those crazy, heady days may have been swept away by the home video revolution.
Reality, fantasy and cinema interweave with such grace and power that it's often difficult to separate one from the other, which is, of course, the point.
This is a movie that wants to break out and be tepid. It would like to dare to be tepid. But it just can't find the energy.
Simple, slight and a bit saccharine, Les Choristes may satisfy a sweet tooth, but anyone wishing to bite deeply into something will be disappointed.
Beyond a doubt the biggest movie ever made about shrimp, Aliens of the Deep is a technical marvel that still manages to fall somewhere severely south of marvelous.
A flawed film that's well worth seeing.
Is it over yet? Is it over yet? Is it over yet?

Smith, of course, is so cool he can afford to pretend to be uncool; but what really works for him here is the interplay with James, whose inner-wild-man dance moves alone are worth the price of admission.
If you can buy the entire psychic flying about and enjoy a bit of sick torture, The Jacket is a lot of fun -- fast, frightening and furiously intent.
Bardem is simply astounding as Sampedro.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Dan Harris piles so many problems on top of a suburban family here that eventually both problems and characters lose impact and believability.
Half works, and the half that doesn't work isn't so bad that it's not worth sitting through to see a Woody Allen comedy starring Will Ferrell.
If there are no simple solutions offered to calm Israel's troubles, there is still hope in this fine portrait of a country torn too many ways.
Explores the dangers of idealism, of belief and even beauty, with a touch that's neither overly cynical nor sentimental, even though it does slip logically here and there.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's loud, large, sick and a whole lot of fun.
Fine as far as it goes -- a worthy lesson in counter-culture history and the rise of media hysteria.
movie_title: Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A consciously lightweight romantic comedy that pokes fun at racial stereotyping, it starts out a bit shaky but begins to cook as stars Bernie Mac and Ashton Kutcher find their chemistry, and by the film's end it's become pretty darn likable.
A sweet, witty, magical fantasy peppered with innocence and optimism.
Despite its wild dreams, it becomes just another rusty piece of animated machinery, going through the motions somewhat mechanically.
MC 2 is one limp, dead fish of a comedy, all predictable characters and nonsensical storylines, filled with cheap would-be yuks and loads of talented people picking up paychecks.
One seriously enjoyable film, filled with laughs and recognizable situations and people you might know or like to know.
Almost delivers.
All the parents in Ice Princess are pushy. Pushy-pushy-pushy. All the teens are squeaky clean. Squeaky-squeaky-squeaky.
The sort of movie that deserves every heart it wins, and it will win many.
Fully entertaining and visually astonishing if a bit spare in the story department, Robots is nonetheless a 100-percent guaranteed kid-pleaser that will also bowl over adults.

Not that there's anything wrong with testosterone and senseless destruction as long as they're balanced by some true sense of heart and at least a smidgen of believability, neither of which survive here.
Gleefully filled with corruption, violence, paranoia, thug-speak and mayhem. It's mad, it's bad and it's bloody. Yep, it's a bonafide blast.
A tale well told, a look at history in the making and those being shaken in the process.
About as viscerally and visually exciting as film can get, and yet it is also fully, ripely romantic in a way that few modern films would dare.
While there's no denying its positive message, there's also no denying that it offers absolutely nothing fresh or innovative.
Closer is an actor's showcase that looks a bit too much like an actor's showcase, but it still manages to satisfy thanks to an acerbic sense of humor and a passion for the follies of passion.
This is what movies are supposed to feel like -- provocative, exciting, chilling, complex and fully engaging.
One heck of a flick, paying homage to an imperfect man whose impact on history may be substantial, and yet painting him as a clumsy, passionate fellow who's simply trying to figure things out.
It's heady stuff, though stretched too far for convenience.
This is a movie almost totally devoid of feeling or any sense of connection.
The script here is barely passable and the direction is downright awful, completely lacking in any sense of comic timing, visual grace or character development.
It begins dark and depressing, but ends up merely dull.
It's a reminder that a sense of play is at the heart of every play -- at the heart of every artistic endeavor, for that matter -- and yet life is more than just a playground.
The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie is an inventive-enough trifle that will make both parents and kids laugh. And that's all it wants to be.
A jigsaw puzzle made of pieces that may or may not fit together, it assumes the intelligence and interest of its audience, a brave move that pays off big.
Don't worry, it turns out Thai women's prisons are pretty fun places to hang out, and all the girls just dance around singing Madonna songs and share boyfriend stories.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's big, dumb fun at its best, and it isn't always at its best.
Zombies have their place, but not in Christmas movies.
Being Julia isn't perfect; but Bening is, and that makes the film sing.
A formula-action exercise that's part Indiana Jones, part Da Vinci Code, part history trivia lesson and all bluster, Treasure proves quickly that it's fool's gold at best.
It's a typical vehicle for comic-book corn with elaborate plot contrivances, assaultive explosions, stereotypical characters and a laughable sense of gravitas.

Who doesn't want to see George Clooney nuzzling alongside Julia Roberts, sipping champagne on the patio of an Italian villa? They're just so darn attractive and wealthy looking and on top of the world.
Don't forgive its failures, just try to ignore them. And keep an eye out for Paz Vega. This woman is a movie star.
Hmmm, where have I seen this before? Oh, yes, I saw it Wednesday night on television. Except her hair was pink. And I had eight more bucks in my wallet.
About as much fun as watching static on TV.

Ji-woon Kim may be the Korean David Lynch and his juxtaposition of seemingly innocent and suddenly searing situations is marvelously unnerving, as are the constantly shifting personalities of most of his characters.
It's a weeper, a fighter, a dreamer of a film that treads on ground that's been fairly trampled over the years. It should stink. Instead, it's flat-out wonderful.
For the most part this movie is a kick to watch, and what a crazy-cool thing for a guy with two Oscars to attempt, a salute from one wandering artist to another.
A film that forgets to bring its central character to life.
For all the madness and tragedy in The Aviator, this is very much a movie that believes in crazy dreams, in reaching and recklessness and accomplishment.
A ruse of a film that doesn't have a tenth of the wit it thinks it has.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Meet the Fockers is not a movie for the ages; it's a movie for a few good laughs.
This is grand cinema.
With its stately pace and theatrical roots showing at all times, Phantom may work as a reproduction for the faithful, but it never really connects as a film.
A pointless, wandering tale of obsession that seems to have little purpose beyond showing that gay characters can be in a messed-up movie too.
While the film follows Duffy's business disasters and blusterings, it never really offers much depth on either its central subject or his posse.
Despite a basic premise that's ripe with promise, the film leaps way over the top with a key performance while also succumbing to some silly cliches.
[It] may be the best live-action children's film of the year, a woven series of dark fairy tales that are witty and inventive enough for all ages.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Topher Grace, Dennis Quaid and Scarlett Johansson all turn in fine performances. But they all seem to tread water, waiting for the next big wave that doesn't come.

Offering Robin Williams his richest role in memory while serving up a nice cold bowl of shock soup for the audience, World's Greatest Dad is a surprisingly smart and severely twisted dark comedy from comic Bobcat Goldthwait.
At the age of 79, Woody Allen is still a formidable filmmaker ("Blue Jasmine" was just two years ago). But he is also, inevitably, Woody Allen.
It's serious stuff, intended for serious movie people. The only problem is, serious movie people have already been there, done that.

Throughout the film, Sorrentino delivers gorgeous images, crazy images, startling and sexy and serene images; it's a visual bath of sorts - the great beauty is everywhere, Jep (and we) just have to be open to it.
It's highly entertaining if occasionally (and appropriately) cringe-inducing and offers some fine actors the opportunity to strut their stuff. And that's the truth, sans vino.
The many misspellings in the film's subtitles do liven things up, even if the film's patchwork use of Bengali, Swahili, Portuguese and English make them somewhat inevitable.
Chances are you don't ever want to see this movie.
It's hard to be all that you can be when you're a corpse. In essence, the film admires the team but exposes the game. And the game is ugly indeed.
Letts loves manic people, twisted situations and barbed lines that cut with glee and he's disturbingly good at delivering all three.
Branagh runs through all of this efficiently enough, but it feels awfully familiar.
Delightfully entertaining, if slightly unnerving ...
At the highest level, it really is about getting your own, forget those down below. If so, that could have easily come across in two hours, it didn't need three.
The life of Nelson Mandela is simply too big, too complex and too important to be contained in one movie.
This is a notably more upbeat attitude than the original short story had and Stiller sells it well.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Ambitious even as it studies, exploits and explodes ambition, "American Hustle" is as good as any American film this year. It's also a lot of fun. Don't miss it.
In the end you feel Llewyn's pain even as you realize he is a pain. Llewyn Davis is nobody you'd want to be inside.

The sap doesn't run too thick, although it does run, and the movie certainly has a patented Disney upbeat feel much of the time. It's more a spoonful of sugar than medicine for aging baby boomer's souls.
The AIDS epidemic was not a happy-ending story. But it was certainly a test of the human spirit. Ron Woodroof passed that test.
As with the best stories, "The Trials of Muhammad Ali" puts one man's story within a greater context. This is Ali's story, but it's America's story, too. Here, it's well told.
"Let the Fire Burn" offers a searing picture of how dumb and dangerous humans can be.
Fiennes and screenwriter Abi Morgan adapt Claire Tomalin's book with delicate grace, presenting love as blessing, curse and, perhaps, inevitable force.

Thin, intense and yet somehow cool, Kinnaman is on his way to stardom, and it's easy to see how these movies gave him lift off. This is a tough, crackling crime story, well-executed and tense throughout.

Koreeda's film never feels gimmicky; he uses the situation to examine both nature and nurture while dealing with ties that simply can't be broken. "Like Father, Like Son" ponders the meaning of family.
Just sit back and enjoy. "3 Days to Kill" is big dumb fun anchored by a good actor's refusal to take himself too seriously.
For those who want sweeping, "In Secret" offers all the essentials - unbridled passion, deceit, fate so unkind, a classically creepy mother and grand tragedy.
"The Selfish Giant" is a story of dependence, damage and desperation, told with grit and grimy frankness. It's also a portrait of friendship born of need and emptiness, on the road to nowhere.
Stupidity is an international condition. How reassuring.
