"The Best Offer" is at its best when it's decidedly weird.
You have to stretch your imagination just a teensy bit - OK, a whale of a lot - to buy into it.

Most people will go see this film for the extensive gun play and the body count, which of course make for swell entertainment. But you don't have to pull back the curtain very far here to see the drone that will soon hover over your neighborhood.

Clooney's obviously going for old-school charm and camaraderie here, but the first half of the film is so scattered, and the characters are so lacking in specifics, that a sense of group bravado never feels earned.
"Gloria" is that rare work, a truly adult film. By its end, you want to cheer the simple act of living.
Understand, the production values here are hardly slick. But this is director and co-writer Edouard Deluc's first feature and its ping-pong nature is somewhat charming.
"Run & Jump" pretty much paints itself into a corner, but it has a nice time getting there.
After dragging a half hour sitcom's story out to 100 minutes, Fitoussi hurriedly and clumsily resolves things (sort of) at the film's end.

Farhadi has pulled off the dysfunctional family mystery trick twice now, brilliantly, and perhaps three times in a row would be too much. But it's doubtful he will leave behind the fertile ground of family ties and modern messiness. He sees so much there.
This film could lose an hour and be much better for the cutting. But then again, it never really needed to be made in the first place.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Yes it has a fine cast, and all do good work. But this overly obvious film about the downward spiral lives of lower-class brothers barely scraping by in life goes through mostly expected motions.
One odd movie, from the casting of its leads to its backdrop to its final twist.
"Last Love" starts out promising enough, but alas, it doesn't last.
You may or may not be convinced, but you will be affected.
In the end, "Capital" is just a dark comic sketch of bald-faced greed, with little nuance or real feeling.
The fights are spectacular - Tiger Chen doesn't need wires - the camera work is cool, the music sizzling.
Twisted, sad and undeniably disturbing, "The Silence" is a study in the sick ways of men.
"The Counselor" is guilty on all counts.
The script is so willy-nilly about the complexities of the issues it introduces that it winds up collapsing.
Eventually, even the effort to survive becomes questionable. We are all isolated, we all succumb at some point. "All Is Lost" studies that point.
In the end, "George" becomes almost as irritating as that mother-in-law.
You have a tangled story being told by director Nick Ryan and writer Mark Monroe in a somewhat tangled way. The result isn't as much confusing as it is distracting.
Levine has fun with the genre, but he's found more interesting movies to make since. "Mandy" isn't quite dandy, but it's a cut above average.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It may be a bit chilly, but "The Fifth Estate" is good, scary information well-processed.
As Hollywood vehicles for aging action stars go, it's at least serviceable. Of course it's ridiculous, but what else would you expect?
Moore is terrifying as a guilt-addled true believer, and Moretz caresses her role when she gets the chance. And the hot topics do indeed remain hot.
"12 Years a Slave" lays out an institution so twisted and wrong that its honest portrayal has been avoided for centuries. Yes, it's dark and brutal. It needs to be.
More considered than your standard lunk-headed blockbuster and certainly visually engrossing, this game is played well.
The way filmmaker Nashef captures the specifics of Detroit life and opens them up to wider understanding is both fun and enlightening.

Can we please cease and desist with movies where not just the fate of a person, or a family, or a city, or even a world but where THE FATE OF ALL EXISTENCE is at stake? Wouldn't it be nice to see a superhero simply rescue a puppy sometime?
"The Armstrong Lie" simply offers up the Armstrong lie. Sorry, but we've all already heard that one.
"Nebraska," it turns out, isn't as bleak as it first looks.
Dench is a delight, playing dowdy instead of her standard regal, and Coogan is appropriately droll and disillusioned. Together they manage to make a sad story feel somehow bright.

Hudson soars (duh) on the vocal numbers, and Whitaker (double duh) is a tower of integrity and crushingly human. But "Black Nativity" isn't about stars, it's about unity, faith and family. As such it shines.
"Frozen" is a winter wonder of a family film, the sort of movie you hope for during the holiday season. Well, it's here, go see it.
"The Book Thief" may not be perfect, but it may steal your heart.
You don't need to know the Beats to understand "Kill Your Darlings," you just need to know the twinkling promise, and dark turns, of life.
It's all far-fetched, silly and light. But then it's supposed to be.
An improvement in almost every way from its pretty decent predecessor.
Even though you learn that Charlie is absolute aces at running from bad guys, the character pretty much remains a confusing, empty vessel. As does the movie.
"The Best Man Holiday" gives holidays a bad name.
"How I Live Now" is uncomfortably easy to believe.
An astounding, complex film about the ecstasy, the danger and the beauty of love.
The film can't find the woman beneath the façade, despite Watts' best efforts. Maybe she didn't exist. Or maybe there's a better movie to be made.
Filled with heady outrageousness at the same time it continuously skirts the apparent emptiness in the man wearing those crazy wigs.
A story of love and betrayal set against political tumult and violence in Palestine, "Omar" is both classic and painfully present in its concerns.
In the end, you simply wish the characters (and the actors) were in a more subtle and focused film. "Computer Chess" plays a risky game. Unfortunately, it loses.
It's all thoroughly, intentionally lightweight, and the film's final 10 minutes is a rush of highly unlikely smiley face resolutions. Still, Wood somehow makes it work as well as it can.
Unexpectedly dazzling.
Children of all ages should be dazzled.
As wonderful as it is to watch the man work, and to review many of the startling images he created over the years, the film has its dead spots.
It's the stuff of melodrama, elevated by Gray's sure hand and made more by Phoenix and Cotillard, lovers and haters and something beyond.
That Coppola finds occasional grace and spirit here shows understanding and compassion. Her next assignment? Make a movie that's not about the troubles of the privileged and bored.
The fireworks, the super-power circus, lots of surprise cameos and Big Moments - "X-Men: Days of Future Past" has them all. Logic? Who cares?
"Locke" is one riveting film.
"Half of a Yellow Sun" deals with human tragedy, but it never really makes a human connection.
The film simply looks lovely, never moreso than when Mbatha-Raw is on screen.
Turns out accents and attitude only go so far.

Everybody in this movie is a bore, or at least something of a blank. The script by Max Borenstein, from a story by David Callaham, doesn't give anybody time to be endearing or sarcastic or human in any way.
You laugh a lot. And you don't feel guilty for a second.
"Fading Gigolo" may be far from perfect, but it's near impossible to dislike.
The grief, the madness of the community, the plain stupidity of the cops, the mass protests that followed the convictions, the horrible power of it all - none of it comes across in this drab film.
We are eating ourselves into oblivion; talk about an inconvenient truth. When will we notice? More importantly, when will we do something about it?
"Wolf Creek 2" is gory, disturbing, inventive, twisted and rather well made.
Somehow it's all very entertaining and weird and fitting, with Detroit looking like a place any vampire would be happy to be.
Is this great art? Of course not. But it's a kick.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An amiably daffy look at perpetual adolescence, French-style.
"Begin Again" sets out to be a feel-good movie and, despite such obvious intentions, it thoroughly succeeds.
Slate is adept with biting remarks and self-deprecation, and she balances Donna somewhere between flightiness and innocence.
Seriously, the next movie should just be called "Transformers: Hammer to the Skull."
In the end, Ida has to confront where she's come from, decide who she is and who she wants to be. Then again, don't we all?
It may leave you asking: Why did I just watch that old guy's birthday tape?
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Jersey Boys" hits the high notes with ease, and offers the low ones for contemplation.
Hall does his best to make sense of Dane, but the plot turns simply don't add up. Good work in a not-so-good movie.
Writer-director David Michod ("Animal Kingdom") likes his violence, but what he's really offering here is an odd bond between two severely damaged men who have little in common beyond the damage.
The sad thing is, there are so many unexplored areas here that do deserve films, including a serious investigation of the Kochs.
It's all very sweet. And a big stretch.
There's no real reason "22 Jump Street" should work. Yet it does.
Collette, as amazing as she can be when given something to work with, can't lift this limp story through sheer will.
Essentially the very thing it wants to make fun of.
The honest, human performances from stars Ansel Elgort and especially Shailene Woodley keep it grounded, even when things start to wander or threaten to get too precious.
"Night Moves" is a study of murky actions, fuzzy ideals and wrong moves for righteous reasons.
Every time one of her photos flashes on the screen, the woman's genius is undeniable.
A riveting revenge thriller written and directed by Jeremy Saulnier and built around a singular performance by Macon Blair.
At times the movie takes on a light, nearly silly attitude; at others, it's all heavy mystery or life and death; and then when the action scenes hit, it's mainly the equivalent of visual screeching.

Writer-director Emmanuelle Bercot certainly hits a lot of notes along the way, playing neither dark nor light in full, traipsing through family dysfunction and betrayed love with both mortality and a smile ever overhead.
The performers carry on - Owen is particularly good - but this bird doesn't fly.
This is twisted, funny stuff.
Fans of the book will likely be pleased. More importantly, people who don't know a thing about the books may get swept up, as well.
"Enemy" is quietly and effectively eerie except when it's idiotic. Oh, well.
For a film about love, Bright Star is curiously cold, more pretty than emotional. True stars have heat.
"Budapest" is pretty much an old-fashioned screwball comedy garishly dressed. It's goofy, eccentric and often downright silly. There are many scenes that would have worked in a "Three Stooges" movie.
Honestly, Aaron Paul, what were you thinking?
Honestly, it's hard to see why "Jimmy P." was ever made.
A noirish kill fest stocked with offbeat characters, lots of gunplay, unlikely plot turns and a lavishly coiffed Robert De Niro.
"300: Rise of an Empire" is a bloodbath and not much else.
It follows a search for personal salvation while painting a portrait of Laotian life that's both revealing and relatable.
"Adult World" is a coming-of-age story in which the starting age seems to be approximately 9. As a result, it just doesn't work.
When Jiro dreams, "Wind" soars; when he comes down to earth, the film can feel a bit stiff and murky. But then, that may be the point.
By the time the film gets to its ridiculous stretch of an ending, we've all seen the great fun to be had with drugs while also learning of their danger. How convenient. How empty.
The world painted by directors Nana Ekvtimishvili and Simon GroB is almost relentlessly grim, and even the giggles of two schoolgirls get drowned.
Felicity Jones, who is actually 30, makes Sophie both irresistible and real, a somewhat open book of wonder and innate wisdom.
For the most part, it works.
You don't so much care where Dom is going as how he's getting there, and he's getting there loud.
It's young Sheridan's Gary who makes the film work, with his mix of earnest ambition, stubborn courage and hopeful endurance. He gives "Joe" the honesty it needs.
A direct descendant of Nicolas Roeg's classic "The Man Who Fell to Earth," "Under the Skin" is the kind of movie people will be talking about, and dissecting and puzzling over, for years.

The question of whether we're too tied to technology and when or if it will prove our downfall is undoubtedly important and probably somewhat pressing. It certainly deserves a better movie than "Transcendence."
It leaves you wondering about how many artists are working on such wild dreams these days, and hoping it's more than you think.
It's very weird, given, but it's also effective.
"Oculus" is haunting because it messes with your head. That's where the ghosts are.
When you don't just have commercials before the movies, but the movies themselves have become commercials, something has gone wrong.
Old age, romance, grief, delusion and desperation all intersect in "The Face of Love," a far-fetched tale that nevertheless manages to be affecting.
"Elaine Stritch" is filled with bluster and memories, blunt outbursts and funny moments. But more importantly, it is filled with honesty.
"Nymphomaniac: Vol I" is crazy. It's funny, it's lewd, it's disturbing, it's odd, it's extremely graphic, it's brutal. And if you can handle all that, it's pretty good.
Obviously, the potential for shifting tones here is great; unfortunately, those tones shift rather erratically.

Blues musicians in Finland. Who know there was such a thing?
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An examination of social context, elitism, cultural bubbles and more, The Square is - to put it precisely - absolutely bonkers. But purposefully bonkers.
It does not browbeat or preach, it simply shows, and what it shows is overwhelming.
A righteous exercise. It just could be a better righteous exercise.
All anybody's expecting is rapid-fire absurdities and Three Stooges violence, which Killam serves up aplenty.
It's fascinating, if overlong. "Ex Libris" is the kind of film that makes you realize what wonders we too often take for granted, and how much work and passion go into such wonders.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This coming-of-age love story is all texture, tone and nuance...Luca Guadagnino has made a lovely cinematic feather. And it floats down beautifully, riding a soft breeze of melancholy and grace.

A fascinating study in contrasts, "Fire at Sea' shows how the normal and painfully abnormal exist side by side - the horrific and the serene, the tragic and the mundane, global crisis and daily humdrum.
First-time director Johnny Ma goes for gritty realism in this mostly psychological thriller about a good Samaritan drowning in dark waters.
Simultaneously heartwarming and heartbreaking ...
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the history of cheap gore films, "The Mind's Eye" is just another blip on the bloody screen.
Lane uses creative animation, archival footage and recordings - the good doctor apparently loved to be filmed - to tell an absolutely outrageous story of neediness, greed, delusion and gullibility.
There are moments of joy, revelation, connection, sadness and hope, and the film is very, very moving.
This is writer-director Maya Vitkova's first feature and she deftly blends the mundane, the operatic and the bittersweet.
Most of the movie is poking bulls, blaring rodeo announcers, time spent in the back of the truck as the bulls are moved from point A to point B. Not exactly riveting stuff ...
"Hunt for the Wilderpeople" is a hoot with heart.
An affectionate reminder of what an impact one writer-producer had on the modern world.
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Obviously anyone can see where this going, but director Abu-Assad wisely makes the journey fascinating by factoring in cultural and political considerations.
Farhadi manages to skirt the political and focus on human emotion, deception and frailty with such force that his setting and artistic restraints are rendered near irrelevant.
The film posits LBJ and King as imperfect men who sincerely wanted to do good, even if their paths weren't completely straight. Much of the backroom dealing and power brokering is revelatory.
Richardson deserves better. Hemingway certainly deserves better. And so does the audience.
A tale of hardship and perseverance, "Sunset Song" is both visually lush and classically carved, if occasionally overwrought.
It is gripping, challenging, engrossing stuff, beginning to end. Seriously, what a film.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The sting of Confirmation isn't how poorly the system worked then; it's how little things have changed since.
"Francofonia" is terribly over-directed and seems strange just for the sake of being strange.
Any true Zappa fan will eat this stuff up. For novices it may open up the universe.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's fascinating, scary (so scary), interesting stuff.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Eva Hesse" is a remarkable film about an even more remarkable artist, a woman who playfully and resolutely turned the world of sculpture inside out.
It's all very alarming and upsetting and terrifying.
The film's feminist message is hardly subtle, but it's still effective. And the peak into the nomad lifestyle - where an eagle just sits on a perch in the living room - is fascinating.
The look of the movie is amateurish beginning to end. It's impossible to tell if any of the actors are any good because the film itself is so thoroughly awful.
Imagine the shock, imagine the adjustment, imagine not wanting to adjust. "Don't Call Me Son" imagines all that and more while calling into question the nature of bonding, blood and close ties.
movie_title: Don't Call Me Son (Mãe Só Há Uma) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Go see it. If you love cinema at all, go see it.
Something of a tour de force for star Rebecca Hall who, in keeping with the film's approach, does so much while seeming to do so little.
Look, you can see where all this is going in the first 15 minutes, but getting there is plenty of fun.
This is not a film about racism in America. It is, instead, a film about the increased militarization of America's police forces. And it is scary stuff indeed.
This isn't a movie about a situation; it's a movie about a fully formed, red-blooded character dealing with a situation while also dealing with everything else.

There are meditations on mortality, art, relationships, love, fear, sexuality and spirituality in this sumptuous-looking film. They cohere into a portrait of a young woman as complex as any big screen character can be.
The performances here, from complete nonprofessionals, make you wonder whether acting is as much a natural inheritance as a trained craft.
"A Man Called Ove" starts out gruff and unlikable and more than a bit stereotypical. Then it opens up and becomes something of an epic about ordinary life, touching, funny and engrossing.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Don't Blink" is a portrait of an artist, a portrait that draws upon Frank's own improvisational approach to filmmaking, but which also manages to capture a life's story, as well as its subject's essence.
Max Rose, and Jerry Lewis, deserve a better movie than this one.

Using a lot of real-life West End of Cincinnati dancers and athletes in the cast lends the film an authentic feel without ever feeling amateurish, and the specificity of Toni's story resonates outward.
While the ghosts of teen romances past no doubt hover over many of us, after a while you might find yourself wanting to slap Paul Dedalus across the face.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to say this is the worst film Nicolas Cage has ever made - there are just too many contenders to choose from. But it's near the bottom.
A fine blend of the universal - teen love, rebellion, tragedy - and riveting specificity, while also working as sharp social critique.
While "That Sugar Film" is filled with powerful and what should be downright alarming information, it also suffers from distracting bouts of cinematic candy coating.
"Exodus" is an exercise in visual trickery that reaches for nothing beyond the obvious.
If only things had started out on more solid ground and headed toward some sort of resolution. If only.
Your kindergartner might like "Yellowbird." You, not so much.
'Reach Me' is the sort of movie where careers go to die.
"The Theory of Everything" offers intimate scenes from a very specific and challenging marriage, warts, black holes and all.
"Mockingjay - Part 1," however well done, can't compete with the first two films, although it sets up what should be its stunning ending well enough.
There's nothing particularly wild about "Wild," a forward-plodding story of redemption that follows Reese Witherspoon's determined march toward a best actress Oscar nomination.
Stewart's enthusiasm for his story and passion about injustice ring clear, but throughout what could have been a dreadfully somber film, he remembers to breathe.
"Horns" is a good-ideas-gone-wild movie that leaves the best of itself behind.
It isn't Hitchcock, but it will do.
'Nightcrawler' manages to be a scathing look at ambition and journalistic sensationalism while still delivering as a dark thriller.
A celebration of music, perseverance and human connection, "Keep on Keepin' On" is for both jazz lovers and lovers of life.
Challenges, surprises and dazzles while still working at the edges of a frazzled mind.
The film is testament to how soul-sucking poverty and good intentions can inspire wrong, dream-ending moves.
In a world of ISIS, Ebola, dwindling retirement funds and severe drought, somehow this film seems needed.
You don't just meet and learn about Nick Cave in "20,000 Days," you feel him.
Director Bennett Miller ("Capote," "Moneyball") has a fascinating story here and he knows it.
Well, at least there won't be another one for a while.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, this could happen anywhere, but you get the feeling it happens often in Russia. The only real hope here is that a movie this hard on the motherland could be made there.

This is the clash of ancient and modern, of rulers and ruled, of rabid dogma and the joys of daily life. It is a portrait of the ugly folly of imposed ideology, a too-common condition for far too many.
"Mommy" is a shockingly honest, nerve-wracking and dazzling piece of cinema. If this doesn't rattle your soul, you don't have one.
In the end, "Black Sea" is a taut warning about the evil allure of greed. It also makes clear why vacationing on submarines has never caught on.
"Black or White" stumbles even as it tries to move forward.
'Cake' is delicious stuff - low key but affecting, funny while tragic, quirky but never so bizarre it loses you.
There are some key elements that make this "Night at the Museum" sequel work better than its predecessor.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The fluidity and tension of the battle scenes is breathtaking, Eastwood at his cinematic best. But it's the ever-tightening knot inside of Kyle the director really wants to understand.
Nothing feels forced in this movie, which is testament to Colangelo's skill as well as the cast's. You believe the coal dust on these people; you grieve for their secrets.
Some storylines conclude, some collide, others dissipate. But the film's main crime is this: It's boring.
It develops into a study of obsession, hypocrisy, righteousness and self-doubt, questioning motive and then gob-smacking the audience with the wholly unexpected.
'Love is Strange' takes something so right and leaves it hanging all wrong.

It's a film about drive, about imagination, and how brilliance thrives outside the mainstream. These are common enough themes given uncommon purchase in a film about a man who likely saved millions of lives by never fitting in.
'Whiplash' is electric from beginning to end, a musical story of obsession, frustration and outright cruelty built on two knockout performances.
'Paddington' is an absolute delight, visually inventive, thoroughly goofy and goosed by a mix of dry British wit and pratfall shenanigans.
'The Blue Room" is a tight little look at love gone wrong, something of a stripped-down French "Gone Girl" without the surprises.
Wow, "Viktor" is stunningly bad.
Mostly it's Keanu playing bang-bang. If that sounds great, go see the movie. If not, congratulations on aspiring to better things.
Brendan Gleeson delivers a typically towering yet warm performance in "Calvary." Too bad the movie's something of a mess.
"The Giver" offers more than just the standard clamorous post-apocalyptic claptrap that fuels far too many films these days.
One of those rambling European films with little plot but lots of atmosphere ...
Cahill spends the entire film bringing a sense of wonder to the desperately rational Ian, and if the film takes on a glow toward the end, that glow feels well-earned.
As disaster movies go, "Into the Storm" is fairly disastrous itself.
There are virtually no laughs to be had in this movie, though it's dressed up as a romantic comedy. It mostly resembles an overlong lecture on the power of reason and man's need for escape.
"What If" flies by on the instant and lasting chemistry between leads Daniel Radcliffe and Zoe Kazan.
"Guardians of the Galaxy" has wit, energy and zaniness to spare. It will pop your corn and leave you hungry for more.
"Lucy" may be scientific hogwash, but it does raise all sorts of questions you rarely find in a shoot-out flick.
Hoffman brings a balance of fierce obsession and weary resignation to the role, and ends on a howling note that's so deeply human it brings shivers.
This is the story, understand, of a group of people taking shelter in a basement following a nuclear holocaust. It's pretty clear right from the start that all or most of them will die. Good times.
Sex is treated first as brainless imperative, then as acrobatic duty, then as desperate consequence - it's never sexy in any way.
Even if the story begins to melt into itself, at the end it's still fascinating to watch Haggis move his players.
The visual look of the apes themselves is what brings it all home. Seeing is believing, and the magic of "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is that it is so easy to believe.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Linklater has crafted what may be the most ingenious film of the century here and given it a tone like no other ...
"Land Ho!" is an indie oddball of a movie that wanders about with two seniors looking to squeeze a bit more out of life. The squeezing is gentle but affirming, just like the film.
"Are You Here" doesn't feel all there.

It sticks halos (probably well-deserved) atop the heads of its doctors, it goes for poignant moments without being all that poignant and ends up bemoaning without seriously suggesting any concrete paths to improvement.
"St. Vincent" may not be a great movie, but it is a great lot of fun to watch.
"Fury" is a brutal film that too easily celebrates rage and bloodshed to no clear end beyond ugly spectacle.
No matter how grim the future may be, it deserves a better movie in the here and now.

Let's just say any film that has a high school romance rekindled, hints of incest, cancer, professional baseball, mental disability and repeated vomiting has too much going on, especially when some things have no tie to the basic story.
It is the year's scariest film simply because it's the year's most realistic: Welcome to your nightmare.
The expected twinkle never really leaves "My Old Lady," but it certainly goes through some rough times along the way. And the film is all the more interesting as a result.
Yes, it's all just a regurgitation of murder machine tropes - right up to the very end shot - but as regurgitations go, "The Guest" is fine, sick fun.
Rapace somehow layers on a New York accent, Hardy brings his sweet, slow fuse and Gandolfini ... well, he makes you ache for more.
"Falcon Rising" is filled with so many action-flick cliches it could serve as a text on how not to do things.
Since it's impossible to see what the attraction would be, the film's emotional logic fizzles.
If it's your cup of tea, you're likely to spill it from laughing so hard. Somebody send these two on another holiday.
There's a perseverance to "Frank" that's also uplifting, a true spirit of unity among the damaged.
You believe in these people, you care about them and their struggles. And in the end, you wish them all the best.
There's a lot of talent up on screen put to no grand use.
"The November Man" is a sturdy-enough addition to the action spy (as opposed to the thoughtful spy) canon. It shoots straight, runs fast and is thoroughly, almost convincingly, paranoid.

Yes, it's a bit corny and convenient at times, but there's an admiration here for hard work, ambition and battling adversity that overrides cynicism. "McFarland, USA" is a good film about good people; nothing wrong with that.
True, "A LEGO Brickumentary" is a barely disguised hour-and-a-half commercial. But as hour-and-a-half commercials go, it's somewhat interesting.
On the surface it's the story of one particular hockey player, but it reflects so much more.
Heineken may be weighed down by the predictable reality of actual events. Or it just may be lacking in electricity and depth. Either way, it's lacking.
It all adds up to a story of the human spirit's ability to survive and even thrive despite twisted circumstance.
None of it is convincing in the least, although the actors do as much as they can. "Phantom Halo" ends up feeling like a mash-up of two many other mediocre films.
It's hard to believe that anyone will make a film more ambitious and more fully realized this year than "Inside Out." Let the talk of a best picture Oscar win begin now.
"The 100-Year-Old-Man" is wonderfully inventive, silly fun.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: After more than a century and a half, Emma Bovary is a classic ball of decidedly human confusion that just keeps on giving.
It's taking a strong stand on the morality of mercy killing, no doubt, but it also acknowledges the precious glory of life. It's a rare film that can smile while studying suffering.
It's pretty hard to get worked up about three thieves this dumb and this bland.
"Jurrassic World" still delivers big, dumb cheap summer thrills. But extinction may be the kindest thing that can happen to this franchise.
Innovation, precision, a complete switch in focus, daring ... these are not things you expect from a Hollywood film biography.
The preaching is earnest and the intentions are good, but the corn is high and the presentation is amateurish.
"Hunting Elephants" will not go down in the annals of comedy history, but at the least it will probably be the best screwball comedy heist movie mostly spoken in Hebrew in theaters this year.
McCarthy is not a one-size-fits-all talent; she needs the right vehicle. Here, Feig has given her precisely the right vehicle, and she shines.
Gangster movies should not be mildly interesting.
Where to begin with Aloha? Begin by not going to the movie.
Repetitive, repulsive, empty while stuffed with cheap ennui and wholly lacking in either insight or inspiration, "Saint Laurent" is absolutely everything you don't want to see in a biographical film.
Come for the humor and thrills and visual delights - there are many. Leave with the thought in your head: We can, we need to, do better. This is summer moviemaking at its best.
By the time the mystery is solved, it hardly seems to matter. What matters is the casual lack of honesty that almost everyone seems to depend on.
"Fresh Dressed" shines a light on the hip-hop fashion phenomenon, but it's not just about hip hop; it's about ambition and absorption and our need - black, white, brown, whatever - for authenticity.
"Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation" is industrial-strength, stunt-stuffed, thoroughly soulless, yet eminently watchable cinema.
You may find "Sunshine Superman" exhilarating or you may find "Sunshine Superman" terrifying, but you almost surely will not find it boring.

Ruffalo is generally wonderful at finding the tone and mood of a character and holding to it; here he has to bounce about, but again he latches onto a consistent energy that makes Cameron a singular life force.
It's Gyllenhaal -- physically ferocious yet tenderly forlorn -- who sells the movie, putting both the beast and the heartbeat within on full display.
The absolute best thing about this film, aside from Schumer's strong, smart voice, is the promise of more to come. This lady's just getting started.
Delicate, warm and worried, "Felix and Meira" is a coming-of-age film about two grown people stunted by social circumstance.
There are many reasons to fault "Me and Earl and the Dying Girl," but it's sweet enough, and smart enough, to overcome every one of those reasons.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Uneven would be a kind word for "Safelight."
"Minions" is every bit as cute as it's supposed to be, a happily empty-headed animated frolic that rarely pauses to take a breath.
Just when you're ready for "Aloft" to take wing, it ends.
It certainly provides Kidman with some meaty, twisted material. But the film abandons the viewer in the end, leaving the audience as lost as those kids.
Plenty of folks praise Winehouse in "Amy." But no one was there to save her. Perhaps it wasn't possible. But perhaps it was.
Brice goes a bit too broad at times, but he keeps things just funny and edgy and open enough for "The Overnight" to work.
"Terminator Genisys" is the first fully worthy successor to Cameron's original films and it shows Arnold may be old, but he's not obsolete.
Somehow, Vikander sells it all, not with braying and big gestures, but with vulnerability, sincerity and the sort of ethereal realness that can't be quantified. More, please, more.
'In the Name of My Daughter" is one of those French films that leave you going "huh?"
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: 'Iris" is a joyful look at an aging eccentric and an examination of the playful nature of design and fashion; it likely won't change your life, but will bring a smile to your face.
"Good Kill" is darkly enlightening, but it's not really all that good.

Aside from an eye-opening investigation of useless and harmful flame repellents pumped into furniture, it sticks to climate change without broadening its scope to other examples of corporate spinning, which must be plentiful.
File this one under "odd and interesting but ... "
"Woman in Gold" may be a bit obvious, but it's still a story worth telling.
Ultimately the movie is wearying, but then it's likely supposed to be. If Viviane's going through the wringer, you're going through the wringer too.
movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "It Follows" is the creepiest movie in years.
Will you laugh? Absolutely. Could this have been a better film? Definitely.
Danny Collins is the cinematic equivalent of a well-sung easy rock tune, enjoyably light and bouncy, with some darker notes hidden within the chords.
"Deli Man" is a delicious little concoction, a consideration of the history of the Jewish delicatessen and how it reflects Jewish culture in America.

It's epic stuff, and at 170 minutes it's a commitment. Schiller seems to be blazing a trail for German über-confidence, seeing his modern man as the grand product of all that's been right with history.
"Cinderella" feels real enough to be sincerely touching at the same time it's visually inventive enough to be magical. We've all seen this story, true; but we haven't seen it told this effectively.
Authenticity is the warm blood that pumps through "Stop the Pounding Heart," a low key but mesmerizing look at adolescent awakening in a fundamentalist family.
There's a stretched and buffoonish quality to the aptly named "The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel" that detracts from any sincere sentiment or wisdom the film hopes to impart.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe it's something in the water Down Under, but these fellows have managed to concoct a whole new perspective on fangsters.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's a bubbling cauldron of newfound freedom and energy coming to life, an inspiring reminder of what people of a like mind and heart can accomplish. "She's Beautiful When She's Angry" is a thing of beauty indeed.
The action sequences are well done, some of the visuals are spectacular, and at it's heart Insurgent is wrestling with some very basic questions about ambition and human interaction.
There is probably a better, more complete film to be made about Burroughs someday, but it will likely contain parts of this film that are irreplaceable.
The great joy of the film, whether you know piano or not, is watching Bernstein teach.
Jones delivers her moral righteousness with a passion the rest of the film lacks. Otherwise, this is just the story of an awful human and the dupe who loved him.

There's no great meaning here - it's a basic story of rebellion and redemption. But there's such energy and visual invention in a world so fully realized and dazzling that the roller coaster ride is more than enough on its own.
There's no ducking the frank admiration and love on display in "I Am Big Bird: The Carroll Spinney Story." Then again, there's a lot to love and admire here. It's freaking Big Bird.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film has enough twists and dark reveals to grab the viewer. But it's Macdonald's sad turn as Alice that eats away at your soul.
A movie with attitude and energy that's not as aca-amazing as the original, but still makes for semi-shiny summertime fun.
Lambert and Stamp are at least a bit fascinating, or at least somewhat interesting. But this film runs nearly two hours. They are at best an hour-and-a-half's worth of interesting.
A cringe-filled comic rumination on the cost of being cool, "The D Train" starts out as straight silliness and then turns to more aching matters.
Mulligan is fetching and sure, as always, but the smoldering Schoenaerts is outright magnetic while consistently low key. Take note, Hollywood.
The only thing hot about "Hot Pursuit" is its scant 87-minute running time. And it still feels like four hours.
The problem, aside from not much going on, is that Schwarzenegger remains a severely limited actor, so there's not that much character to study. Potentially interesting concept; wrong star.
For the most part, "Avengers: Age of Ultron" is the hard-charging, mind-boggling spectacle fans are looking for. Smash indeed.
If only "Dior and I" told us why we should care.

It meditates long and hard on questions of age, sincerity, celebrity and love, piling irony on irony. And it features a remarkably natural performance by Kristen Stewart that's so unastounding it's astounding.

"Ex Machina" takes its time, wrestling with questions of responsibility, morality and compassion while getting ever weirder. At its heart is Ava, played with a fine blend of innocence and quiet panic by Vikander.
The film feels purposeful and true. Good job, mate.
A tough little movie set in the waters and coastal jungles of Colombia, "Manos Sucias" dashes naive hope with cold, brutal reality.
There's a sense of being trapped that permeates "Bad Hair" - trapped in your own flesh, trapped in circumstances, trapped in the family you're born into.
The last hour of this movie is pretty much nonstop, and it's a gas.
In the center, of course, is Bell, still right on target with the wisecracks and attitude that made "Mars" work.
"The House I Live In" leaves you shaking your head in deadened wonder at the waste of it all.
A disconcerting and challenging film. It leaves you wondering. How cool is that?
Heaven knows what inspired Zhang to undertake this nutty project, but the results are, at the least, amusing.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's a solid if somewhat straightforward story of sacrifice and allegiance.
More love triangle than musical, the effective and often sweet Nowhere Boy offers a sense of the time and tension that produced John Lennon.
Classic Woody -- an ensemble cast of brilliant actors, a timeless story that could be set virtually anywhere and crisp writing and direction that neither lollygags or rushes.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: You're never too old for mayhem.
Eastwood and Morgan skillfully and slowly unveil each character's struggles and then send them on their way to inevitable encounters with one another.

Davis easily ties a sick education system to a sick society. But when it comes down to it, in the end he has no clear cure for what ails us. At the very least, though, he has exposed the disease for all to see.
Secretariat is a winner, but only by a few lengths.
You don't see that many supernatural serial-killer romantic comedies.
Weird. And disappointing.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's all low budget and inventive, and mildly impressive if far too repetitive and ultimately fuzzy.
movie_title: GhettoPhysics: Will the Real Pimps and Hos Please Stand Up! (2010)

movie_review_blurb: What's frustrating about the film is that even though it's clear Stone is making a number of valid and important points about both media manipulation and America's untoward political influence, he's also so obviously biased in his reporting.
Good vibrations are achieved even if this is the most laid-back documentary ever made.

Oddly cold and detached, as if director Mark Romanek and screenwriter Alex Garland couldn't decide precisely how to interpret Kazuo Ishiguro's popular novel and so they just laid it out flat. And flat it feels.
This is basically an excuse to watch skulls crushed like melons, guts ripped from body cavities and torsos halved. And such things go on with relentless and disgusting regularity.
A charmingly direct film of simple contrasts about the difficulty of change.
Due Date is funny enough, but it should have been funnier.
Jake Gyllenhaal is great in Love & Other Drugs. So is Anne Hathaway. Too bad the movie's a mess.
Tangled is the best animated film from Disney in the past 15 years.
Fair Game" is such a brutal and personal testimony to the consequences of dirty politics that it often feels too ugly to be true. Unfortunately, it is.

Directed and co-written by Danny Boyle in a style that travels from ecstatic to nerve-wracking and back, this is a film about perseverance, strength and the importance of always letting people know where you're going.
Suspenseful if not wholly believable, the main problem with The Next Three Days is it lasts about a half day too long.
There's plenty of humor, plenty of magic and even a bit of romantic stress, although there's also quite a bit of mulling and standing about.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If you haven't seen the first two films, do so and then see this one. If you have seen them, chances are you're already in the ticket line. Hornet's Nest has such a sweet sting.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Dazzling, challenging and heartening all at once.
There's a gut-level simplicity to "Unstoppable" that works despite all its clichés.
Morning Glory is ultimately something of a morning news show version of a morning news show -- perky, jerky, chit-chatty and polished. And eminently, pointedly, forgettable.
Ham-handed, obvious, overblown and pretentious, For Colored Girls is a plain disaster.
Wall Street owns Washington. You might think you know this, but "Inside Job" makes you feel the enormity of it.
You'll enjoy it. And then you'll forget it.
Hallucinogenic, dazzling, depressing, daring and not entirely successful, "Enter the Void" is obviously out to blow some minds.
There's a whiff of desperation behind the comic romp Tamara Drewe that gives it some unexpected sting.
Hoffman the director can't compete with Hoffman the film's star. And he can pretty much just stand in wonder at the layers co-star Amy Ryan brings to the party. The woman is a natural wonder.
What works so well here is the juxtaposition of youthful innocence and downright puppy love with monstrosity and murder. Mean kids are scary. Kids who drink blood are scarier.
There's a cool precision and honesty to The Social Network, the story of the founding of Facebook, which guarantees its entertainment value even as it limits its emotional impact.
The result isn't awful, but it is awfully familiar. When will someone make a film about being old, poor and ugly in Omaha?
A look at both the tragic folly of war and the camaraderie of men under pressure, the documentary Restrepo holds both hope and horror.
In terms of flat-out nonstop laughter, it's the best comedy of the summer.
Too much of the time, the film seems intoxicated by its own sense of importance.
It's a sly, small film that shies away from too much gravity at all the right times.
Easily the scariest movie of the year.

It's a razzle-dazzle compendium of quick-draw humor, superhero stunts and gamer references wrapped around a teen dream love story, starring -- who else? -- Michael Cera, the first genuine nerd superstar.
Where's a vampire when you need one?
Salt is a smart, fast, breathless blast of a spy flick that emulates the Bourne films in all the right ways.
Definitions of family, love and friendship all get put to the test with wit and warmth in The Kids Are All Right, one of the year's most honest and endearing films.
While the parts are quite good, the sum is pretty pedestrian.
An oddball documentary that strives to capture the essence of an entire culture through one preoccupation: insects.
A big gob of mythical makeover and special effects-freewheeling fun.

With its James Bond-on-acid action scenes and puzzle-within-a-maze-within-a-puzzle mind games, Inception is certainly the most daring and original blockbuster of the year, as well as a visual tour de force. If it only had a heart.
Pure, tasteless slapstick silliness with little on its mind beyond cheap yuks.
Manages to mix philosophy, history, hysteria and a love triangle and still be something of a bore.
The question is: Who wants to watch these people?
Slow, dull and wielding absolutely no emotional impact despite a fine cast.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Relentlessly shrill and awkward.
Stone handles the financial stuff quite well.
A gritty, well-made heist flick weighed down by obvious story progression.
An extremely witty, inventive, sweet and perceptive coming-out party for Emma Stone.
An entertaining kinky kick of a movie, a lightweight delight about dreamers and dilettantes.
A documentary examination of the genius, madness, arrogance and abject insecurity of rock music's most famous record producer.
movie_title: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Chances are the joke is on us. The problem is the joke isn't very funny. In fact, it's kind of vile.
Dark and mesmerizing.
It's basically a one-joke exercise heading toward the inevitable big battle between vigilantes and Mexicans. There's lots of gore, flesh and fun along the way, but it gets repetitious.
The film's constant raunch factor balances out its romantic center in a way that will likely surprise and please many.
A bit more clarity would have left fewer questions lingering.
Lovely and astounding, Mao's Last Dancer is a modern epic of art and ambition triumphing oppression.
It's not a bad film, really, just sort of average. But Bateman is so good in it -- natural, funny, yet full of real emotion -- that you immediately want to see him again in a better film.
Let's call it four out of six numbers, with no power bonus. Some payoff, but don't quit your job.
Eccentric and ultimately touching.
This is one of those films that depends entirely on its star, and Thomas mixes sexuality, giddy flirtatiousness, stoic determination and agony in just the right amounts, without ever straining.
The result is a sweet and witty bit of animated fun with both eye-popping 3-D effects and a warm heart.

The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader is still very much a "Narnia" movie. In other words, it's filled with fantastical creatures, bloodless battles, quasi-mystical undercurrents and an unfortunate helping of hooey.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's a delirium that runs through Black Swan, a sense of stress and anguish and mad momentum, that's both exhilarating and terrifying.
Miral has the pedigree, the attitude, the weighty subject matter. It's just not much of a movie.
Hop is just too shrill, slick and sickly sweet for anybody's good. Watching it won't rot your teeth, but it could leave an ugly cavity in your brain.
Insidious isn't scary. It's laughable. And kind of sad.
A smart sci-fi thriller that maybe asks a bit more of its audience than the average movie. But the payoff is solid, and really -- how long is eight minutes?
Monogamy is a tough little movie. And a good one.

Somehow Wasikowska makes it all seem much more personal, more real. With her stark, starched dresses and blunt, elastic face, she draws you in, making both Jane's pain and incredible resolve tangible.
Win Win is a winner all the way.

This sort of emotional-chaos-in-suburbia (it all takes place in Iowa) has been done well, of course, and at times it is here. But Lipsky's overly arch and tangential dialogue has too many curlicues, and everyone's emotions seem just this side of affected.
Happy St. Patrick's Day. Don't go see Lord of the Dance in 3D.
What's going on? Who cares?
This all goes on until Bacha either runs out of budget, patience or film, and ends up cutting to the somewhat positive results.
The results are, again, not-quite-brilliant but funny enough.
Limitless is limited, but intriguing nonetheless.
The ride can be a bit bumpy, but The Lincoln Lawyer gets you where you're going.
If the goal was sensory overload and audience stupefaction, he has succeeded indeed. Snyder apparently is offering lobotomies to all. Step right up.
Stevenson is a good actor, but Kill the Irishman is standard mob fare, neither exciting enough nor interesting enough to matter.
Saoirse Ronan is a talented young actress who tends to be better than the movies she's in. And that tendency holds true with "Hanna," an unsteady thriller that staggers when it should sprint.
Their stories are touching and inspiring, but let's face it, the visuals are what make this movie. Born to be Wild takes you to places you've never been and makes you wish you had.
Rubber will undoubtedly be the best film about a round, hollow serial killer released this year.
This is a film that wants to be interesting, and it certainly is that. Whether you want to dine with the ghost and the monkey-man or not, they bring a new perspective to the table.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: You can't say Fast Five delivers the goods, but it delivers what it's supposed to.
For all its outbursts, it feels more guided than fiery, more orchestrated than emotional.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Potiche is a French sex farce with a time warp feminist message that's more odd than entertaining or enlightening.
Witherspoon sparkles appropriately, Waltz is indeed one scary dude and Pattinson acquits himself well enough, although he leans too much on grinning as a default reaction.
Arthur may not be much of a movie but Russell Brand is one heck of an Arthur.
Rio will not set your heart afire, although its low-level consciousness raising about illegally smuggled animals is nice. Mostly, it's brightly colored fluff, but then, it's supposed to be.
This is the stuff of nightmares, where even the good guy is bad, and as shock cinema goes, it packs a punch.
You really come away wishing Cattrall could take this character to a more serious film. Who better to show the flip side of beauty?
Super just doesn't fly.
Scream 4 is a total hoot. Assuming you can find the humor in knife stabbings.
The film, directed by Xavier Beauvois, moves back and forth between the monks doing their daily chores and the decisions they must face as a group.
This film looks like it was a lot more fun to make than it is to watch.
The Conspirator fairly drips with nobility, timeliness and class. If only it were a bit more fiery.

This is just a big rollercoaster of a movie, filled with dazzling effects and funny creatures and the requisite five-hankie "I love you, Mom" ending. But then, there are some weird gender political battles at play here.
Red Riding Hood is pretty decent, considering it's, you know, Red Riding Hood.
This film feels so much like a videogame your hands keep reaching for controllers -- shoot the aliens, shoot the aliens, shoot the aliens.
Yes, he was a bad guy; but what a great story.
No matter how sweet and good-looking and likeable they may be, the bottom line remains: You know what's going to happen from the very beginning.
It's not an easy movie, but it is a powerful, unforgettable experience.
As heavy, stressful, relentlessly sad dramas go, this one goes quite well.

There's no denying Coppola displays great understanding of wealthy ennui in Somewhere. And as a film stylist, she hits some fine grace notes. Still, she and we have been here before, and empty hotel life does have its limits.
The first feature, written and directed by satirist Chris Morris, may seem profane to some, but if you're doomed by watching it, at least you'll go down laughing.
Jason Statham needs to get a tune-up, switch gears and hit the gas.
It's hard to work up a whole lot of love or sympathy for convicted lobbyist Jack Abramoff.
True Grit isn't so much a major film as a good time, and there's nothing wrong with that. Maybe this movie can get westerns back in the saddle again.
It's audacious, it's fun, it's rowdy, and it's just twisted enough to always be interesting. Beyond that, it's one of the year's best acting showcases and likely to grab multiple Oscar nominations.
A thoroughly enjoyable and surprisingly lightweight romantic comedy from writer-director James L. Brooks.
Artful, smart, funny, sad and in its own small way dazzling.
It's one of those movies where questions like "Why didn't they do that?" or "Wait, what's their relationship?" keep popping up. And for the most part, those questions never get answered.
Lots of sizzle, not much soul, and very little sense.

The jokes are a bit randy, the situations and characters familiar, the touching moments false but fitting. It's all as formulaic as weak egg nog, but it goes down just as easy. Let's hope all involved spend their paychecks wisely.
A French import that's long on grace notes and wry humor, it eschews flash and opts for heart to great effect.
This is a film without spark. The frustrations are real, but they are neither terribly entertaining nor enlightening.
It's sweet stuff, a portrait of an artist in turmoil, under fire and laying himself bare. Howl captures Howl beautifully.
Drinking jokes. Sex jokes. Wild antics. Sincere looks. Nothing goes on here that hasn't gone on -- and gone on better -- in other movies.
Rarely has comedy been as unnerving as it is in The Red Chapel. Perhaps that's because it's hard to tell who the joke is on. One thing's for sure, though: North Korea isn't laughing.
Prediction: Vanishing on 7th St. will vanish from theaters very quickly.
It's hard to imagine a more spectacularly silly film making it to theaters this year than The Adjustment Bureau.
As stiff as it is sincere.
This lovely, aching film opts for romance in the face of modern ruin.

Writer-director Im Sang-Soo injects a certain sense of otherworldliness in the proceedings -- the final scene is straight from David Lynchland --- which may not make things mesmerizing, but does deliver a consistently odd angle.
The film is rarely funny, pointedly tasteless (as if that's new), usually embarrassing and always bad.
Considering it has to do with infidelity, bribery, drugs, drinking, loutish behavior, fraud and prostitution, Cedar Rapids is really kind of a sweet movie.

Unknown" obviously knows its limitations, and it doesn't bother to rise above them. It just keeps throwing the punches the audience wants and expects. It won't cure world hunger, but chances are it will sell a lot of popcorn.
Alas, from its scruffy period melodrama to its repetitious battles and endless cross-country shots, this film is all grandiosity with no real heft.
The parts are greater than the whole in "Barney's Version," a rambling look at a shambling man's adventures in love.
Desperation and fulfillment, anxiety and warmth, pain and contentment -- all come together in the darkly splendid Another Year.
An overloaded agony parade of a film that's such a grim march to devastation that it should be hard to watch. And, OK, it is. But with Bardem at its center, it's like watching a lush train wreck.
There was obviously much to this woman, yet somehow Visions feels curiously empty feeling.
movie_title: Vision: From the Life of Hildegard von Bingen (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Jolie! Depp! Romantic locations! Intrigue! Some movies sound too good to be true. The Tourist is one of them.
I Am is looking for a little bit of hope in this world. Happily, it finds some. A great deal actually.
The girl is still hot, no getting around it.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The question of Winterbottom's intent here isn't easily answered, but the power of his abuse scenes is undeniable.
Youth in Revolt is a teen fantasy filled with lust, imagination, frustration and lots of laughs, artfully made and superbly played.
If the premise seems lame, the actual script by Deborah Kaplan and Harry Elfont is far worse, leaning on so many clichéd situations it's a wonder 45 other screenwriters weren't credited.
Crazy is just too tame for his own good.
While it may not be Almodóvar's greatest work, it still stands well above most other films in terms of intrigue, intelligence and innovation.
Parnassus is fun to watch a good deal of the time, and Gilliam is almost always visually surprising, but Ledger could have used a more momentous send-off.
The film suffers from the simple fact that its songs aren't memorable.
Understand, the film still has power, just not as much as it should.
Director Jason Reitman brings such splendid balance and nuance to Bingham's story that you can't hate the man; indeed you end up pitying him.
Cliché-ridden, stereotype-stuffed and clunky at every inevitably false turn, it's so bad that star Hugh Grant, usually the most relaxed of actors, actually seems to be in pain throughout the film.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The real mystery here is how writer-director Noah Buschel talked recent supporting Oscar nominees Michael Shannon and Amy Ryan into doing this movie.
I have seen the future of movies, and it is Avatar.
An instant if minor classic.
A work of flawed majesty.
A thoroughly enjoyable film that wraps a coming-of-age story around the portrait of a genius.
Nicolas Cage is out of his mind in The Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call -- New Orleans. And it's wonderful to see.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Potent, still relevant and inspiring while maddening, Skin shows some of our best and much of our worst.
A Single Man still stands as a vivid portrait of life behind a veil, and Firth certainly delivers one of the best performances of the year.
As dental experiences go, Tooth Fairy doesn't hurt as much as you might think.

Writer-director Michael Haneke doesn't pull any punches, but then he doesn't throw any wild ones, either. His filmmaking shows precisely the sort of obsession with control that the movie itself is denouncing. Interesting, you've got to admit.
The story is well-told and well worth telling.
A movie that keeps you guessing to the end and then -- miraculously -- makes the guessing pay off.
Munyurangabo may be a simple film with a straightforward message, but the details and conflicts Chung captures give it a reality that cannot be denied.
A great moment in the history of ideas does not necessarily make for a great movie.
Percy Jackson, you are no Harry Potter. You are not fit to walk in a hobbit's wake.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's a bit too easy, a bit too familiar, and maybe even a bit too much fun. But the easy magic Bridges brings to the screen makes it all work.
Director and writer Michael Hoffman, adapting Jay Parini's novel, lets the history play out, and this little-known chapter plays out nicely indeed.
Extraordinarily bad by any measure.
What you end up with is indeed a big pile of goop.
Simply put, if you're wearing a uniform in this movie, you're going to get hammered. And you're going to be too dumb to just draw your pistol and shoot one of the stars.
There's an authenticity and energy to "Bilal's Stand" that cannot be denied, offering a crackling smart vantage point on race and class and identity that's young and fresh and oddly intoxicating.
A brainless, fizzy, romantic-comedy fairy tale with a roster of acting talent far beyond expectations.
The only edge here is in the title. This is indeed your father's thriller.
The most important documentary of the year.
A small gem of an animated film, $9.99 manages to be rich in whimsy and fantastical turns while still rooted in human ground.
It's a tribute to writer Adrienne Shelley and first-time director Cheryl Hines that, despite the film's flaws, it ultimately pulls off its unlikely tone.
There's no challenge to this material, no real emotional pull, it's one of those films that simply rolls by until its right-from-the-beginning predictable ending.

Yes, the future still looks grim and whales are hunted here as they are in all such films, but Stone spends most of his time tracking something positive -- the birth of the environmental movement in the '60s and '70s.
The film is unfailingly funny.
Expertly orchestrated and unavoidably moving, More Than a Game is nevertheless your standard inspirational sports story about spunky kids who defy the odds to become champions.
Intellectually interesting, visually arresting and filled with invention, there's just one crucial thing Where the Wild Things Are is missing: wildness.
Life is pain. Life is funny. Things happen randomly, with no purpose or reason that can be discerned. Searching for answers is futile. Enjoy what you can.
A classy, intelligent, low-key affair and a fine reminder of what's really essential to most lives: family.
Astro Boy is a blast, a jolt of Japanese anime channeled through British slap-shtick that ends up yet another cool cartoon for both kids and adults.
This is one of those films, like last week's Whip It and so many others of late, that looks like it was a lot fun to make. It's just not all that much fun to watch.
It's a good season for zombies.
It's a black-blood-spitting mugging of a movie, but it's also relentlessly funny and innovative, the sort of film that makes you writhe and laugh at the same time.
Michael Moore is up to his old tricks in Capitalism: A Love Story, and that's sure to both infuriate, and entertain and inform, depending which side of the Michael Moore fence you stand on.
Whip It looks like it was a fun movie to make. Unfortunately, it's not all that fun to watch.
The film moves along so quickly, and the surrogate world look is so eerie.
A mesmerizing study of the tension between commerce and creativity.
The result is a film in which age matters not at all and yet still matters hugely, and in which love is still a dream come true and an absolute mess.
This Is It isn't Michael Jackson at his greatest; it's him preparing to be at his greatest. But just watching that preparation is gift enough.
The Damned United is a thoughtful and entertaining study on the perils of ambition that has little to do with soccer and a lot to do with being human. Well-played.
This is grizzled, wild-eyed Clooney, not the suave sophisticate, and it's a nice change of pace.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Sheridan and Maguire orchestrate things perfectly here, running a line of tension through the film that explodes at the end, just as it should.
The Road -- centered by Mortensen's typically physical but tempered performance -- is hard to watch. But it could have been much harder. Hillcoat isn't doing opera here, he's doing tragedy.
The beauty in Foster's portrayal is that it never completely explodes, but anger and aching seethe behind his eyes. Harrelson, meanwhile, is a good old boy with a bad old job.
The result is a quirky film that should work for all ages, with just a hint of dark humor. In this age of high-tech animation, Wes Anderson has found himself in a low-tech wonderland.
Rain is a very talented slaughterer. He could kill you with a pair of tweezers, a hair dryer, two bananas, whatever. Be glad he's a good ninja.
A big bowl of adolescent romantic mush garnished with horror-lite action scenes and a rushed road trip, The Twilight Saga: New Moon is a mess.
If you do watch -- and you certainly should -- you will see one of the most remarkable performances ever set to film, given by Gabourey "Gabby" Sidibe.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Mediocre, clunky and just so not special.
American Harmony is a successful greatest hits compilation of top-level performances of recent years; but that makes you want it to be so much more.
Pirate Radio is a bit of a mess. But an amiable mess nonetheless, with the boys' casual chemistry and the music carrying things along, it's not that hard to watch and it's great to listen to.
Self-loathing, mean, ugly and perfectly made, Antichrist is probably the best film ever that you'd recommend to absolutely no one.
Don't pay money to see it, don't waste your time if it comes on cable; you might not even want to bother reading the rest of this review.
This is fear-mongering, sentimental, horror show shtick, but it's also fairly competent, making 2012 a work of awful efficiency
Unintentionally, laughably bad.
Want the creeps for Christmas? Then check out the latest version of A Christmas Carol.
Smith certainly does his thing here, delivering a film that's part celebration and part parody of the well-worn genre.
Resolutely odd, near static at times and yet strangely effective, Everyone Else goes nowhere in particular, but then that's the point.
There's a crazy-dirty energy to White Lightnin' that's rarely seen in films, a raw beauty and awfulness that's both scary and exciting.
A visually imaginative fairy tale that suffers slightly from its predictable course but still manages to wow at all the crucial moments.
In the end it's the fun movie it's supposed to be. Raise your cosmos in a modest toast.
This movie is little more than a big noise bomb with jerky movements attached.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Looking for Eric is a pleasant surprise -- somehow both ambitious and easygoing, funny and worrisome.

Campanella approaches the material with a classic hand -- no quick cuts, special effects or gimmicks here. This is a flesh-and-blood movie, and both Darin and Villamil bring earthy presence to the story.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Who is supposed to be excited by this? What child would care? What adult would care?
If it's sword-on-sword with arrows-in-the-air action you want, Robin Hood delivers in a big way.
Daring, disturbing and deliciously twisted.
Such familiarity can breed contempt among all but the most bloodthirsty, and it would in Harry Brown as well if not for Caine, who somehow breathes life into the most cardboard of characters.
You can almost see the studio accountants counting the demographic hot spots Just Wright should connect with as the movie reels by.
An amusing, touching, reassuringly wholesome romantic travelogue of a film that flies by on its way to the inevitable happy ending.
Hoax or not, Exit Through the Gift Shop ends up energizing, aggravating, enjoyable and revealing. Is it art or isn't it? Who knows? Apparently no one.
Blessed with no narration, an absence of gimmickry and an embracing love for its subject matter, Babies is as sweet, joyful and filled with curiosity as a you-know-what.
There are too many new characters, too many crossing story lines, not enough romance and our hero's a smug jerk for the first half hour. Who cares? Iron Man 2 still rocks.
An interesting look at the transitory nature of enemies and the way history shifts alliances.
Things go from bad to worse to downright disastrous in the enthralling Australian import The Square.
Those looking for a re-interpretation of a classic fairytale will certainly find it in Bluebeard. They just won't find a very good one.
Kids deserve better. Heck, dogs deserve better.
Obviously, this is emotionally rich ground and Garcia plows it perhaps a bit too heavily.
Overblown, European, operatic, indulgent, patently absurd and somewhat wondrous, I Am Love works for one reason and one reason alone: Tilda Swinton.
Doesn't break ground; in fact, it carries on a tradition. But it does so with both flair and passion.
Stiff, fuzzy-looking, cloddish and disastrous in nearly every way, The Last Airbender looks as if it could have been made by the spoiled son of a studio mogul willing to waste gobs of money.
The empty guy at the beginning of this movie is pretty much the same empty guy by its end.
The result is a film and a character of unusual strength. Pity Ree, question her decisions, wonder about her future. But the girl does not quit.
It's total garbage.
This is personality comedy, and Brand and Hill have it to spare.
Knight and Day is ultimately too relentlessly silly for its own good.
The undeniably fascinating and entertaining documentary that looks at the audacious entertainer in the seventy-fifth year of her life.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: More than with any other Pixar film, there's an edge and sadness that clings to Toy Story 3, even as it's bouncing from one zany situation to the next or trotting out some impossibly cute toy character.
The Karate Kid is precisely the sort of rousing, stand-up-and-cheer, feel-good entertainment movie audiences have been starved for this summer.
Happily, the joy outweighs the guilt.
There's no denying either the influence of Lang's vision -- so much of what he did in this film lives on that we take it as cultural assumption -- or the still valid energy of his storytelling.
The toss-away jokes? Who cares? The idea that B.A. Baracus becomes a peacenik in the middle of the film? Who cares? The ending's complete lack of resolution? Who cares?
There's a bit of a gore factor here, obviously, but this is mostly a movie about brave people trying to hang on to their hearts while saving others.
movie_title: Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A Nightmare on Elm Street may be the most unneeded movie of the year. And that's saying something.
A tasty tidbit of a film, Mid-August Lunch is one of those movies where almost nothing happens but it happens quite nicely.
In the end, the film is about a magical book, but you never really have a sense of what makes the book magical.
Repo Men, rough though it is, is disturbing enough, funny enough and shocking enough to work on some weird level.
The problem with Diary of a Wimpy Kid is the wimpy kid is a jerk.
For serious fans, this is the real Neil, an artist who'll go anywhere his head and hands send him.
Obviously heartfelt but somewhat stilted and disjointed.
There's little fun involved, for either the audience or the diner patrons.
Green Zone hits hard and doesn't forgive. It plays out like fiction, and in some ways it is. But in too many ways, it's not.

The Red Riding films all come across as great, gritty tales of police corruption and human failing, but it's the first film that has the most impact, mainly because the young reporter Dunford is such a mix of romantic notions.
There's a sense of construction to Remember Me that undercuts its emotional impact, and emotional impact is pretty much all this film is shooting for.
The Art of the Steal lays out a good story, but perhaps not the whole story.

North Face" is something of an old-fashioned epic shot with modern wisdom and technique, a man vs. nature flick that also weighs the importance of the individual vs. the social while exposing the mean cost of vicarious thrills.
It's a light romp around a much-visited playground, cute enough but never cutting.
The swirl of visual poetry, political intrigue and personal zeal that Polanski creates gets under your skin and brings an icy hand up your back. This is moviemaking.
Tawdry, slick and self-consciously gritty.
Writer-director Andrea Arnold, working in British lower-class realism, still finds wondrous moments of connection in Mia's life.
Our Family Wedding plays out like an elongated Disney TV episode, going precisely where you expect every inch of the way.
Stands as a wrenching tale of power abused and lives discarded. It is powerful stuff.
Stands as a wrenching tale of power abused and lives discarded. It is powerful stuff.
The 3-D throughout How to Train Your Dragon is perhaps the best match with animation yet -- exhilarating when it's supposed to be, yet integrated into the film rather than seemingly pasted on.
Writer-director Raymond De Felitta is essentially offering a kinky-comic New Yawk version of a Greek tragedy here, and even if the whole thing is pretty implausible, it's also fairly entertaining.
A cheeky little commentary on modern consumption, The Joneses offers an uneasy balance between what's funny and what's not, staying just edgy enough to be uncomfortable while hitting its targets.
Everything you've likely heard about Kick-Ass is true, providing you've heard it's profane, outlandish, ultra-violent, shocking, funny and wildly entertaining.
Disturbing, enthralling and filled with interesting shots that reflect an artist's eye.
Its slapstick story of a married couple enduring outrageous fortune offers a lot of laughs, a bit of romance and plenty for either sex to relate to.
You don't mess with Lisbeth Salander. And you'd do well not to miss her, either.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from following the clichéd (if real) storyline, The Runaways is plagued by something of a split personality, thanks to its two young stars.
This is basically brooding people doing awkward things in a humid environment.
A passionate, bold look at power, paranoia and betrayal in a little-known corner of history, Vincere is steamy, sad and so Italian it feels like an opera.
Apparently the gods need better agents.
Atom Egoyan gets the erotic stuff right but pretty much drops the thriller part on its head.

Part loving postcard to Japan, part redemption story reaching across both racial and cultural divides, The Harimaya Bridge manages to lift itself out of movie-of-the-week hokeyness with sheer charm and perseverance.
The success of Malik is sheer American dream via France: Anyone can make it if they try hard enough. Make it at what, of course, is always the question.
The name says it all.
In many ways this is Baumbach's best film, filled with his bitter but often funny misanthropic perspective, but buoyed by the undeniable likability of Stiller and Gerwig.
A warts-and-all documentary from first-time director Zachary Levy that moves in close and stays there.
Writer-director Martin Koolhoven hits just the right balance of domesticity and oppression here, setting up the film's tense second half with sweet early touches of naivete.
Valentine's Day is a passing nod to love, like a box of chocolates or flowers that soon wilt. It's star-studded amiable fluff with no real value, but it's kind of a tickle if you're in the mood.
Simply put, this would be a better world if there were more films like In a Better World.
"Bernie' isn't a monumental film, but it is a finely tuned character study with some nice innovations.
"Men in Black III" is an efficient Hollywood summer blockbuster product.
Between the gypsy psychic and the distracting characters, "Darling Companion" loses its way.
There's nothing wrong with asking viewers to fill in some holes. But "Sound of My Voice" leaves you dangling, reaching out for something that's just not there.
"Headhunters" will indeed hand you your head.
As documentaries go, this is lip gloss.

Perhaps the best thing about "Snow White and the Huntsman" is it doesn't smirk at itself. It plays out as a story about mortality and greed and oppression in a fantastical world, but it doesn't act as if anything is silly.
"What to Expect" rolls out this shocking revelation: Having kids is a messy and complicated process.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A number of the performances are plain stunning - Aran and Joan, in particular, seem born to move - and in many ways watching the movie is like watching a sporting event; there are winners and losers and favorites to cheer on.
It reasserts Baron Cohen as a comic force who can't be ignored, dedicated to pushing the envelope and working with real ideas.
"Nesting" deals with an evergreen question, grappling with aging, maturity, responsibility. Unfortunately, the person doing that grappling is so lax he doesn't seem worth knowing.
Basically, there's just too much crammed into "Marigold Hotel" for any of it to have impact. It may work as comfort food for old folks, but a bit less may have yielded a great deal more.
How bad is "Dark Shadows"? It makes you long for a "Twilight" movie. That's bad.
The film would probably drag if it weren't so perfectly cast, especially with the gawky-beautiful Gerwig as its center.
"Battleship" doesn't sink, really. It just sits there booming endlessly as you look on aghast.
"The Giant Mechanical Man" won't change your life but it might lighten your heart.
