It's a bit crude, a lot illogical and you might have to be in a certain state of mind to enjoy a film this silly.
The result is pretty much as forgettable as the Cristeros War.
How amazing can it be? We all just saw this movie when "Spider-Man" came out a decade ago.
What Soderbergh and producer/star Tatum are shooting for here is a portrait of a subculture, and that portrait crackles with energy.
"People Like Us" may not be perfect, but Banks is perfectly imperfect.
It certainly shows that fine films don't need big budgets, capturing some sweet lightning in an arresting bottle indeed.
"Ted" is so lazy you want to kick the stuffing out of it.
"Where Do We Go Now?" is more interesting than satisfying.
"The Intouchables" is actually quite touchable.
"Brave" isn't a bull's-eye, but it's close enough.
Scafaria has to work beneath the inevitable looming gloom or else chicken out, and that's a question that ultimately distracts from the characters' dramatic development.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Director Tanya Wexler plays things broadly at times, but "Hysteria" has good fun with history while coming off far more wholesome than salacious.
Anderson never loses his core themes - young love, the need to escape, the bind and bluster of family. His "Kingdom" may not be large, but it is perfectly appointed.
For the most part, rock and roll should feel insulted.
"Prometheus" is genuinely epic.
Nobody deserves this movie.
What next, "George Washington Werewolf"? Laugh not, history profs.
There's great entertainment in "The Avengers" - big bold, action-filled silliness with just enough human spirit to sell itself. This is a comic book movie done right.
"Gerhard Richter - Painting" is a stirring portrait of an artist in search of his art - the mystery of the process, the beauty of the hunt and the wonder of discovery.
"Boy" finds hope, and love, in the oddest corners.
It's a bit too long and a bit too vague at times, but this is a film about dedication, progress and the bond of human effort. It just also happens to include football.
The lives of these sweet, confused, basically decent people wrap around one another in ways that are funny, far-fetched and touching.
"21" makes clear from the beginning it is gobbling up some pop culture refuse in the name of nothing more than making fun of it and having fun with it.
It's all very unnerving, modern and yet veins-in-the-teeth visceral.
Dante Lam is John Woo via Michael Bay; he doesn't want to win you over, he wants to beat you up and make you crazy. And for all its silliness, "The Viral Factor" does just that.
Where's it all go? Nowhere, really, just down a dirty, disappointing hole. Harrelson deserved better.
Based on a true story, "In Darkness" is obviously tough to watch, especially since Holland's camera is both unforgiving and relentlessly human.
Director Ramsay makes Kevin's impact all the more felt by coming at it from all angles.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "John Carter" is a huge bore.
At one point you're looking at the screen going, "This makes no sense!" Then after a long conclusionary explanation, you shake your head and say, "I'm still not sure that made much sense."
As party porn goes, "Project X" has its moments. In terms of drama, character or intelligence, it's pure bong water.
Presented in a wash of animated colors, this story of a hot-headed sexy Latina songstress and her jazz piano player takes on new life.
Much of the movie feels pasted together; the story doesn't flow, it staggers forward.
These people seem so real they might live next door. And they probably do.
"Friends with Kids" goes on a beat or two too long, and lands in the obvious place, but it's filled with smarts and laughs and passion.
Efficient if not electric, "The Hunger Games" is still epic in intent.
"October Baby" doesn't even meet the standards of decent propaganda. It is, in fact, indecent propaganda.
Tradition can be dangerous as well as dumb. "The Forgiveness of Blood" is about a modern kid in an old-world society. It's a terrible fit.
Nasheed is indeed inspirational, a cool-headed but passionate and courageous guy. You end up wishing a lot more leaders were like this guy.
The execution almost overcomes the thinking in "Think Like a Man." Almost.
How do we get past tragedy? Together.

It's really a wonder of nature, a reminder of how we are bound to other species and how valuable and special and downright magical their lives are. It may be a bit corny at times, but it's also downright enlightening.
This is a life story worth telling, and "Marley" does it much justice. Marley may or may not have been perfect, but he was certainly fascinating.
If you like nutty energy, wacky ideas, crisp dialogue and scary, bloody, gory, grotesque and twisted movies - man, are you going to have a blast this weekend.

It would have been nice if the film had reflected its title a bit more and looked at the bullies themselves - what drives one kid to torture another? Is it a reaction to home life, is it fear, is it innate awfulness?
"Footnote" deals with ambition, isolation, the dangers of too much success and the inevitable gap between generations.
"The Raid: Redemption" is sheer action ecstasy.
"Reunion" should be the last slice of "Pie," America.
"The Kid With a Bike" vibrates with desperation, frustration and the simple unfairness of life, leavened with glimpses of hope.
What's somewhat surprising is you don't have to give a hoot about hockey to enjoy the movie. This is just a guy living his dream: Hitting people.
The good news is: "Wrath" is a much better film than "Clash" - lighter, more agile, with much better special effects and pretty decent 3-D.
It's a time machine of a movie; but who will want to take the trip?
If there's one thing that's both surprising and predictable about "Crazy Horse" it's how thoroughly unsexy the film is.
"Savages" makes you wonder where Stone, that most pointed of directors, is going. And then it never gets there, backing off at the last minute. As such, it is literally a brutal disappointment.
If you want some nice light yuks, "This Means War" should do the trick.
It's minor Woody, but it's still Woody.
This could - should - have been a swifter movie, but it sends the Batguy out in style. And let's face it, he's earned it.
Sometimes Levinson goes with a less-is-more approach, sometimes he pours on the buckets of blood, but he definitely is digging the creepiness.
You don't have to give a hoot about basketball to enjoy this movie. This is a movie about identifying with, admiring and responding to achievement in any form.
Exciting, exhausting and energizing, a brazen film that leaves somber cinema seeming too passive for its own good. This is a movie as big as life itself.
Never really [delivers] the sun-in-your-face, salt-in-your-hair, sandy-cocky thrill of surfing or surf culture.
The chief problem here is that Frank is neither likable nor very bright. For the most part, you're thinking, go ahead, bust his kneecaps.
The intention here is plain - we are all human, we can all be family - but Levy weaves the mix of identity crises, cultural mingling and common ground slyly.
It's a well-made movie. But after its opening, harrowing action sequence, the film turns into one of the most familiar stories of our time - a downward addiction and denial spiral.
For a film about aging and romanticism, "Liberal Arts" feels like it needs a more mature script.
A movie that's somehow delightful even as it visits devastation.
"The Well-Digger's Daughter" isn't a mind-blower; it's not supposed to be. It's a light lunch with an old friend whom it's good to see again.
While "Seven Psychopaths" is indeed as crazy as it sounds, it's not nearly as smart as it thinks it is.
It may not have a lot beyond its outrageous story, but the story is undeniably a doozy, and the movie is a blast.
"Frankenweenie" may just be a wacky horror cartoon, but it's an awfully good wacky horror cartoon. Frighteningly good, you might say.
Director Jim Field Smith keeps the quirky characters coming with smooth efficiency and throws in some nice touches along the way.
This film is about a particular African-American experience, true, but it's also about the human experience. It will haunt you. It should.
The best thing about "Bill W." is it paints the man as both inspirational and weak, damaged and determined and always searching. It makes Bill W. human.
It's hard to make a fine actress like Laura Linney look off-key and shrill, but "The Details" manages to do just that. It's hardly an accomplishment.
Great heroes are often enhanced by the villains they face, and such is the situation here. To really work, Bond needs great bad guys. Silva is bad at its best.

Essentially, when the movie comes down to Earth it's pretty good. But when it spends time across the universe -- and it spends a lot of time across the universe -- it's pure geek fare. Which may thrill geeks but leave others yawning.

It appears to be an empty-headed piffle of a film about a dashing former professional soccer star coaching his son's team and having affairs with an assortment of randy soccer moms. And that's precisely what it is.
"Anna Karenina," lush as it is, fails to strike a fully human chord.
Too much of the time "Hitchcock" plays cute and comfortable. It simply lacks weight.
Let's just call it DOA.
Are things better left alone or is revealing all always the best path? "The Flat," to its credit, offers nothing like a definitive answer.
An absolute delight.
"Pi" is a wonder to see; too bad it's not wondrous to feel.
A fascinating, stately thriller.
"Rise of the Guardians" seems a sure bet for kids who still believe - or wished they believed - in magic.
North Koreans? Falling from the sky? Seriously?
Winstead and Paul make their characters feel like flesh and blood, not stereotypical Lost Weekenders. Their love is as real as their future is shaky. And that's the film's great tragedy.
You hope for these characters, and that hope carries the film.
"Simon and the Oaks" branches out in ways unusual and interesting enough to hold your attention and then even shake it a bit.
It shouldn't work - there's just too much going on. But it does. Spectacularly. Go see it.
[Barns] pours on the corn syrup pretty heavy in parts and it's pretty obvious the film has a clear agenda ...
It won't drive you crazy to watch it, but it isn't "The Lion King" either.
"Looper" looks like and is a blast; what's really cool is it's even more than that.
Seriously, if this was the American Dream, couldn't we have come up with something better?
"Hit and Run" is a race to ridiculousness, but at the same time it's a bit of a gas.
Chances are most kids, and most adults, will find "Paranorman" perfectly horrible in the best possible way.
It's nice that "Sparkle" honors the memory of Motown's heyday; if only it could have lived up to those standards.
"The Odd Life of Timothy Green" is the sort of movie you actually hope kids see. How rare is that?
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Gilroy keeps the Bourne mythology firmly intact while moving it forward, and leaves the door open for just about anything in the future.
Emotionally, the film is rich. Something is forged here, something strong and worthwhile.
It keeps undercutting itself by going for cheap laughs. It wants to be an adult film, but it obviously feels adults need constant, broad tickling to hold their attention.
If you share its desire for straight adrenaline, the ride works.
An 8-year-old brain will probably think it's fine. All other brains, pass.
"Journeys" is simply a trip most need not take.
Really, wait for it on cable. At least then you'll be able to change the channel.
Winterbottom has complete control of the film's look and feel, but the story seems to run away from him.

The atmosphere Zeitlin develops here is moist with promise and danger, and he moves back and forth between outright fable and pungent reality with an astounding sureness of vision for a first-time director.
"Ruby Sparks" is a film about the wonder of, and the limits of, magic. Believe and enjoy.
No brakes indeed.
"Lawless" is a sprawling story of dirt road bloodlines and stubbornness, solid but a bit out of control.
"Robot & Frank" hits all the right notes - romantic, fantastic, tragic and sweet.
This is clearly a labor of love that was nurtured and sculpted from the beginning. The result is a film that feels exhilarating, fragile, funny and real.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Steeerike!
Both Phoenix and Hoffman are on fire within their characters. If only they'd had some place to go.
Gyllenhaal and the perpetually under-rated Pena have a wonderful way of bouncing off one another and Ayers is wise to make this the energy that drives the movie instead of mere violence.
It sure makes you want to buy American. Assuming you can find anything American to buy.
It's fun-enough to watch, but it's nothing more than that, even though it seems to want to be.
Mediocre at best.
"Detropia" offers up a mirror to the country: This is what the future may look like. Now, what do you want to do about it?
This is a movie for anyone who's ever been unsure, and surely that's everyone.
The laughs come fast and breezy, just as Delpy intends.
This is a film that's thoughtful and elegant, with just enough loose strings to keep things intriguing.
Is it one for the ages? No. Is it a good time? Good enough.
A fascinating portrait of a modern artist and activist trying to make a difference within China's repressive political system.
The give and take here feels completely real, and each character is likable while also flawed and vulnerable.
If you like your movies filled with twisted humor, sexual perversion, psychological intimidation and sudden violence, "Killer Joe" is the flick for you.
"The Woman in the Fifth" leaves so many holes unfilled that instead of ending up intriguing, it's just plain frustrating.
"The Secret World of Arrietty" is a sweet world indeed.
It's a wonder Gerwig manages to keep the character endearing instead of grating, but she does.
The equivalent of throwing "Jurassic Park," "Avatar" and the absolute worst episode ever of "Land of the Lost" in a blender and pushing "garble."
Pass the bananas.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A Little Help doesn't dazzle, and you can pick at its parts, but Fischer's performance gives the movie a sense of romantic weariness that lingers. Life is a series of disasters to be weathered, no matter how cute you are.
It's a coordinated, stylish dance, but the steps are awfully familiar.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Based on a popular novel by Tatiana De Rosnay, Sarah's Key has perhaps a few too many coincidences and complications, but its impact is undeniable. The scars of war never truly heal.
This is the sort of film that Oscar generally ignores come awards season. It shouldn't. Crazy Stupid Love is a crazy smart film.
It's just big silly fun, the kind you're supposed to have at a summer movie with a ridiculous title.
The images here are undeniably powerful and disturbing, and the footage of the Nazi kingpins is startling in that it shows these monsters to be men, nothing more.
It is quite simply one of the craziest stories ever told, made all the crazier by the fact that it's true. Or at least some version of it is true.
The people here seem real, their world is shaky at best, and the political tension that permeates everything in this film feels palpable.
Part paranoid propaganda, part thriller and part quaint period study, Went the Day Well? is an entertaining oddity begging for an update.
This is indeed good old Pooh, nothing to fear. No space robots or serial killers have been added to the cast.
Gore enthusiasts will find the body count acceptable, others may find the splatter a bit crude.
Deathly Hallows Part 2 sends Harry off into the pop culture pantheon on a thrilling high note. Well played. Well played indeed.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Trip is a comedy about two guys going to fancy restaurants in the English countryside. Sounds hilarious, huh? Well, it actually is.

With its mix of World War II nostalgia, Bam-Pow comic book sensibilities, underdog determination and red-white-and-blue battle scenes, Captain America: The First Avenger is the best Marvel superhero flick since the first Iron Man.
Terri may be strange, but it's a good, heartfelt strange that resonates long after the film ends.
A thoroughly silly, intermittently hilarious reworking of the Freaky Friday body-switch concept.

The Myth of the American Sleepover is an indie movie-lover's dream, one of those rare instances where a lack of budget and experience is trumped by heartfelt vision, natural talent and amateur enthusiasm.
movie_title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Contagion could have been a blood-curdling scream; instead it comes off as Soderbergh's star-powered science project.
There's a brutish beauty to the mean world of Brighton Rock that feels very '40s even in the '60s.
Miranda July may be a bit too weird for her own good. On the other hand, it is a glorious weird.
The Debt has the overall air of an Oscar contender that never got into the ring -- well-made, but not spectacular. Still, it serves as a fine, full introduction to Chastain's potential.
Attack the Block attacks the alien invasion genre with wit, energy and a cheeky insolence that makes it out of this world.
Powerful and revolting, The Whistleblower makes you feel as if it could have been even more powerful and revolting.
A bit jarring while still totally disarming, The Names of Love stirs the pot in more ways than one.
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's rare that summer ends on as sweet a note as Our Idiot Brother.
There are few things finer in cinema than Brendan Gleeson's fat, happy face.
It's both enlightening and a bit messy, but then history is always messy.
Even if you can't tell Formula One from Grecian Formula, Senna is pretty exciting stuff.
Miscasting aside, there's simply very little excitement to the film since you can see where it's going -- chances are even just by reading this review -- right from the start.
The result is an alluring image -- Earth above Earth -- a wrenching story and a wonder-tinged film.
It's a bit like the Three Stooges on crack -- nutty, loud, profane and full of laughs. It won't change your life and it might hurt your ears, but it should keep you smiling.
Appalling, entertaining, touching and perhaps even a bit healing, The Help is an old-fashioned grand yarn of a film, the sort we rarely get these days.
Throughout it all Ahmed is relentlessly upbeat, and he seems to have good reason to be. Yes, he's trying to sell an idea, but it's probably an idea well worth selling.
Drive is pedal-to-the-metal stuff. Don't get behind the wheel unless you can take the rush.
Will most audiences mind this? Probably not. Should they? Of course. They deserve better and frankly, so does Kevin James.
Page One is entertaining enough, but for a film concerned with the value of news, it offers little that's actually new.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: With all the blue-haired, flying, screaming, mind-melding hi-jinks this film has to offer, you'd think it would be able to squeeze in a few novel bursts of fun.
"W.E." is not awful. It looks quite nice at times, and Riseborough delivers an exquisite if overdrawn performance as Wallis.
It's a powerful, disturbing film. May there be a day when such works seem less relevant.
A sly, triple twist of a film, this Italian intrigue is almost never what it seems, although everything ends up making perfect sense eventually. Along the way, though, it's slippery stuff.
Maybe what goes on in Vegas really should stay in Vegas.

What really makes the film work... is director Yuh's sense of timing. She knows how to get in and out of a joke before beating it to death. A quick Pac-Man reference during a chase comes and goes, delighting without ever dragging.
As cheap horror fare goes, YellowBrickRoad emphasizes imagination over gore. This is good, because the gore here is somewhat laughable, while the imagination is just creepy enough to be effective.
The acting throughout -- Foster, Lawrence, Yelchin -- is superb, and this may well be Gibson's finest performance, just as it's Foster's most balanced job of directing.
Morgan Spurlock has sold his soul to help save yours.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's never quite clear what the relationship between Jack and Angelica is. Sometimes it's love, sometimes it's hate; it probably depended on who was writing the script that day.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The only question is: Will Kristen Wiig ever be this good again? The answer is, let's hope so. Bridesmaids rocks. Hopefully, a movie star is born.

Happily, Hesher never lays things out too clearly. Just as you never know where he came from, it's hard to grasp where he's going, or even what he's doing in the moment. But you know he fits somewhere. And that's satisfaction enough.
In the end, Everything Must Go is something of a consciously static study in sadness, both well-made and wearying.
This is the sort of film critics love to praise because the filmmaker has done good work before; and well, there must be something there. Well, there's not.
Forks over Knives is tasty but somewhat undercooked.
Remember the good old days? This is the movie you went to see on a Saturday afternoon in the good old days.

Based on the assumedly truish story of British food celebrity Nigel Slater, and blessed with a soundtrack of Dusty Springfield songs, Toast nevertheless doesn't go down quite as smoothly as it should.
The vision is dazzling. The portrayal of family life palpable. The ending ... well, let's go back to the vision.
This is film as comfort food, and even if it has very little nutritional value, its pleasantly bland texture will help keep you occupied until your next job interview or layoff notice.
OK, I'll admit it -- this is hard -- the big silly thing is sort of great.
As road trips go, this one travels far and travels well.
Forget talk shows; Coco should keep touring and making films like this.
Not that Cars 2 is an actively bad animated film. It's just sort of an average animated film.

The result is a small, delicate comedy that depends on a continuity of tone that it pulls off. Oliver may not live happily ever after; but he manages to live happily enough here, and that's just fine.
Beginners finds life both ripe with possibility and ensnared in the past. But then every morning is a beginning, right? If only we could remember that.
The Art of Getting By wants to be sweet and insightful, but ends up scattered and slight.
Into Eternity is a documentary that may look like a science fiction movie, but it ends up more of a horror film.
The casting is good throughout, but McCarron makes the movie.
As both musical and educational experience, Rejoice and Shout offers plenty of reason to do just that.
Why is Jim Carrey standing around watching penguins be funny? Why isn't he in a movie where Jim Carrey is funny?
As a disjointed rumble in the cosmos, it's both too much and too little, and too dorky looking. In this case, Green means stop.
Familiar though it may be, as samurai movies go, 13 Assassins" is a killer.
Midnight in Paris is a loving embrace of the city, of art and of life itself.
Ironclad is as weighed-down as it sounds.
There's no doubt The Interrupters do some good; but there's also no doubt the problem they're facing is enormous.
The First Grader is every bit as inspiring and heart-warming as you'd expect.
Statham is just good enough to make one wish he'd challenge himself.
The Artist is the most surprising and delightful film of 2011.
A clamorous headache of a movie, it's hard to say who the intended audience for The Adventures of Tintin might be.
This Dragon flies, but it never really breathes fire.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol is top-notch popcorn entertainment, chock-full of dazzling stunts and heroic moments, played out at a near-hysterical pitch.
Shame is something of a dirty date that leaves you wondering what went wrong.
There's a reason spies are called spooks; it's as if they have no human essence. If William Colby had one, his son hasn't found it in this film. But he has found the emptiness. And that's something.
movie_title: The Man Nobody Knew: In Search of My Father, CIA Spymaster William Colby (2011)

movie_review_blurb: We Bought a Zoo is so filled with artificial sweetener that it may cause cancer.
Young Adult may be the year's most engaging feel-bad movie.
One of the year's best films, a bubbly meditation on family and responsibility that weighs just enough to matter.
Good for the kids, good for the parents, and good for Christmas.
Hugo is pure movie magic.
Is it perfect? No. Is it a lot of fun and does it successfully revive this inspired franchise? Absolutely and let's seriously hope so. A world without Kermit is just too hard to face.
The abyss here isn't capital punishment, the ostensible subject of the film; it's the seemingly unending capacity for causing and enduring pointless misery that humans seem to have.

There are few filmmakers -- David Lynch comes to mind, Woody Allen -- who have a completely unique way of imprinting a film. Nobody but Pedro Almodóvar could have made The Skin I Live In. And that's high compliment.
Written on the level of a bad episode of The Love Boat, this is one of those concoctions that intertwines about 10 storylines and then concludes with a cherry on top.
The result isn't groundbreaking, but it's gratifying.

Ultimately, though, it is very much Oldman's film, thanks to a restrained tour de force performance. Smiley is weathered, worn and beaten down by life, but he's also a quiet, sure force of something that resembles good.
"Le Havre" is a passing fancy of a film, but it passes quite nicely indeed.
"Safe House" is a safe bet if you're in the market for a conspiracy-driven action drama. There are times you wish it wasn't quite so safe, but it does deliver the bang for your bucks.
Both Boosheri and Kazemy are newcomers, but their spirited, tender performances -- from the eroticism to the shame and the flights of freedom -- feel completely, devastatingly real.
The film's key twist seems a bit underdeveloped, but there's no avoiding the horror the film captures. Even in modern times, what monsters men can be.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Being Elmo: A Puppeteer's Journey" is the story of a young man who knew what he wanted to do and did it, who made his dreams real. This may be the most truly American movie in memory.
"The Grey" may appeal to those who like entrails, tough talk and bad endings. All others beware.
"Albert Nobbs" is a film of great texture and tenderness, and the actors are a joy to behold.
It's a gangster story, told well, with no punches pulled.
"Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close" is the kind of movie you want to punch in the nose.
The true story is extraordinary; the film is not, although the actors are all fine.
You don't have to be black or lesbian or even know someone who's gay to appreciate "Pariah"; you just have to have gone through or be going through the process of growing up.
The Tuskegee Airmen were serious heroes, on a number of levels. They deserve a serious movie. "Red Tails" is not that movie.
"The Mill and the Cross" might not be perfect, but it's stimulating, hypnotic and, in its unique way, exciting.
The actors seem to have fun, particularly Foster, working against type as the thoroughly unlikable Penelope. But "Carnage" isn't nearly as bloody as it thinks it is.
Yes, Streep is wondrous as usual, but her superpowers have been squandered here.
"Contraband" comes off the factory floor with its engine running and ready to drive. But the ride feels overly familiar.
There are a few reasons The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn -- Part 1 is probably the best of the Twilight films.
The apocalypse starts here.
There's no escaping the sheer terror of a guy standing on a ledge that high up. "Man on a Ledge" delivers the sweats it intends to deliver.
Somehow J. Edgar manages to be both epic and empty.
Moneyball turns an unlikely subject interesting, making a professional sport the nexus where past and future collide.
What looks on the surface to be yet another inspiring story of one man's salvation turns out to be instead both an examination of modern atrocity and a rethinking of the burden/beauty of belief.
Chances are about 90/10 that you'll enjoy 50/50.
This is a sad story in rich surroundings that makes you wonder how many women of genius were left behind.
With her sweet ditz openness, honk of a voice, blonde pixie looks and absolutely fearless comic flair, Anna Faris should be a superstar. But no one's found the right bottle for her elixir.

Courtney avoids all political posturing here, something rare in modern war documentaries. These are the guys, American kids. This is the war, it's awful. And this is what happens. In your own backyard.
Real Steel is a blast, an unabashed crowd-pleaser that mixes Rocky, Transformers, video games and father-son bonding to great, if corny, effect.
It is not an easy film, and perhaps a touch too relentless, but it is a great reminder of how bloody, mad and awful this world can be.

There's a purity -- sense of righteousness and reunion and optimism -- that makes Thunder Soul galvanizing. Also, the music is smoking hot, which is pretty amazing, considering it comes from a high school band. And a bunch of oldsters.
The Ides of March is a well-made actors showcase and fine film. But it never finds that more.
Margaret is a mess. An impressive mess, but a mess nonetheless.
People watching birds is a nice thing. People watching a movie about people watching birds is sort of a snore.
In terms of empty-headed exuberance, it's hard to top Footloose.
It's not rocket science, but The Thing does offer solid cheap thrills for the slick gore crowd, proving once again: Horror doesn't have to be horrible.
A sweet puff of a film, My Afternoons With Margueritte is as disarming as it is absurd.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Restless is consciously lovely in the face of death. How rare.
The Black Power Mixtape 1967-1975 is not your standard documentary dealing with racism in America.
A purposely disturbing portrait of a damaged psyche.
In the end, The Tree is something of a stretch; but it's a good stretch, a mix of mysticism and family dynamics both satisfying and intriguing.
Ann Arbor has never been more lovingly embraced and portrayed.
Harold & Kumar is all about Cho and Penn, who make the doofus duo into likable, harmless, upbeat characters who happen to be blasted a good deal of the time. 3D Christmas is proudly ridiculous stuff.
There's a strong, unsettling sense of disease that runs through Take Shelter, the best drama of the year so far.
That Chandor manages to find the blood in each character is accomplishment enough; that he manages to make his drama both relevant and timeless portends a bright future indeed.
Anonymous may not convince anyone, but it certainly should entertain them.

So what if it's sheer petty escapist enjoyment? Tower Heist delivers the laughs in desperate times.
Love Crime may not have much to do with love, but the crimes are meanly delicious.

Writer-director Rose Bosch is working in unabashed historical epic mode here, balancing individual stories with grand-scale awfulness effectively. She never swerves for cheap sentiment, she just lays it all out.
Is it worth your time? Only if you have time to kill.
Heartfelt if occasionally plodding.

It's a little strange watching a guy from Detroit dance around a modern apartment with his face painted, doing West African drug and healing rituals. But then how weird is it spending your life shooting junk into your veins?
It's imperative for director and co-writer Drake Doremus to color the film with a great deal of blossoming-love sparkle right off the bat, and he does just that.
It ain't Paul Newman and Robert Redford, but it ain't bad.
This sequel fails to recapture the charm and wit that made the original a cult classic.
A very funny movie for adults and children alike.

Scene after scene is either a music-video shoot or a dance scene shot like a music video. The result is a film that's all flashdance and no substance.
The low points are dull, cliché-bound, even amateurish. But the high points are razor-sharp and fearlessly funny -- a hip-hop feel with a punk edge.
With [Kutcher and Reid] as the star-crossed couple, the title of this movie should have been Zero Plus Zero Equals Zero.

Just when you think you've got it all figured out, there's another disorienting jolt.

movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's just the sort of slight, thrown-together mess you would expect from a movie based on a character from a TV show.
Pointless, predictable mayhem of an action film and the leaden pretensions of an art-house wannabe.
The animation is spellbinding, the characters are ultra-cool and the action is nonstop.

movie_review_blurb: A comedy that's actually funny.

Made by jackasses for jackasses.

That rare movie that has the emotional and psychological depth to match its stunning surface.

A witless and wafer-thin remake.
Nearly all the fundamentals you take for granted in most films are mishandled here.
Nearly every scene along the way to the movie's Psycho-like conclusion is fundamentally silly in ways that don't always seem intended.

... there's the assembly-line predictability of it all.
That rarest of family films -- an experience that delivers for all factions.
Unapologetic partisanship underscores the central question and problem of The Big Buy: For whom and what is it intended?

A lackluster and meandering exercise in psycho-sexual provocation.

A film that dares to treat people as smart and deeply curious rather than dumb and deeply cynical.

Filled with unforgettable scenes.

Gratuitously gross and/or provocative humor.

it's just the old-fashioned, yikes-this-stinks variety.

First-time director Scott Frank, who penned Out of Sight and Minority Report, shapes some sharp noirish notes.
It's Scream before Scream, minus the deconstructive verve.
It plays out like an overlong Comedy Central skit lurching for the next laugh without any remorse for the gross misfires in between.
Everything's reduced to an inane fart or ejaculation joke.
[A] pleasing B-level gore fest.
The ensuing cycle of miscommunication is endless and trying.
Bryan Bertino's psycho-thriller gets the job done for nearly two-thirds of its length. But when it shows its hand, it folds.
Too often those behind the slick 3-D animation spectacles aimed at children imbue them with too much adult humor.
The plot, too, is a sham (shades of Signs and Close Encounters), and Proyas's slick visuals do little to dress it up.
In Thor Freudenthal's heartwarming wag based on Lois Duncan's book, the strays aren't your usual mangy curs but well-groomed pedigreed show dogs who're aw-shucks cute.
Johnson holds his own against the cute wunderkinder, but nobody's a match for the f/x onslaught of the noisy climax.
Instead of opening up the throttle, Hogs ends up idling and spreading exhaust.
Even though the plot forgoes the formulaic slam-dunk, hackneyed devices, low production values, and the stilted direction (by Preston A. Whitmore II) dribble the ball off the shoe and out of bounds.
'Tis the season of the Hollywood dumps -- which is too bad because I had harbored some small hope for this latest horror offering from David S. Goyer.
Flashes of wit and whimsy notwithstanding, the future is just as sentimentalized as the past.
Just your basic slasher fare where a horde of horny teens riddled with contemptuous attitude wind up in the lair of an ax-happy psycho.
It's thin, but enough to make you forget the cold for 90 minutes.
The entire production hangs on Dillon, but he's up to the task, serving up Hank's heart with bottom-of-the-barrel bravado.
The unintentional camp makes for some eye-rolling interest early on, and French director Eric Valette does manage a few hair-raising moments, but by then, the movie has missed by a mile.
Although the director succumbs to the genreâ(TM)s temptation to wrap up a messy life with a neat, platitudinous resolution, she lets her cast give Greene and his era its due.
[Snyder] twists the brawn and battle into a cartoonish FX extravaganza with severed body parts and globules of blood flying across the screen.
As a comedy, Bob Odenkirk's penitentiary send-up is bootless.
The gags land like lumps of coal, but at least the unnatural mounds of fluffy white snow remain unsullied in the dreck.
Favreau's direction has none of the needed edge, and the coming-of-age revelations plop like the same old platitudes.
Rolle's passion and perseverance power the film, and along the way he gets a boost from rap mogul Russell Simmons and Bruce Willis.
Director Darren Aronofsky creates an eerie Eraserhead-like world that keeps the film compelling.
[It] lacks zing, but McAvoy (Atonement) handles his action-hero stint admirably.
Beyond a couple of hilarious zingers, its impact feels smug and minor.
Unfortunately, the material that De Palma chooses to hang his flair on feels like a paltry version of No Way Out as if penned by Crichton or Grisham.
Carrey doesn't break off into outrageous physical comedy bits as fans might hope, and the film does take a while to find its legs, but there is something rewarding in its quirky demeanor.
Finnes and Thurman look great as agents John Steed and Emma Peel who set out to thwart Connery's diabolical scheme, but they have zilch for chemistry.
Things roll along quite charmingly, until the action hit the courtroom and gets bogged down in a boorish, maudlin custody case.
Fortunately, the dry, courtroom banter is interjected with powerful accounts of the violent, inhumane atrocities inflicted on the slaves by Spanish merchants.
Michelle Yeoh is a the lone bright star as the Chinese operative who occasionally, and rewardingly, resorts to Jackie Chan styled chop socky combat.

The tempo of the film does well to cure the unlikely romance with just the right amount of anxiety and the leads -- especially Cook, who is wonderfully promising here -- create an earnestly heartfelt chemistry.
Not quite the type of political punchiness one would expect from Kopple, but it does answer a lot of questions about Allen who obviously had a strong hand in the film's compilation.
Nearly every element of the plot rips off the mangy 1980 comedy Caddyshack, right down to Ted Knight's controlling country-club patron and Rodney Dangerfield's nouveau riche upstart.
Everyone falls for Mary -- why wouldn't they? -- and no one is spared from the Farrellys' razor sharp raunch.
Director Michæl Mann makes the mundane exciting -- even though we all know the outcome -- with his trademark blue/dark back lighting, hyper-kinetic editing and a haunting techno score.
For the most part, director Adam Shankman keeps the mayhem comprehensible.
A salient spin on responsibility, race, and going the distance.
There's something about Susan.
It's no knockout, but it does go a solid, nostalgic 15 rounds.
Craig Brewer, the promising director who hit it with Hustle and Flow, seems to harbor a need to exorcise his white burden through films centered on black music.
Uneven but affecting.
The plot's all over the place, but director Kevin Munroe keeps it at a hare's pace. The sharp graphics impress too. It's nothing to cow about, but it does, more or less, fill its shell.

The Entertainer conjures up some charm, and DeRay Davis provides pyrotechnics as a janitor/wanna-be rapper, but like the teddy-clad bubble-bath square-off between Liu and Sheridan, it's just not enough.
Wilson and Page are compelling and Slade demonstrates a slick stylistic flair, but the over over-the-top shock pandering renders the dark lesson convoluted and hard to swallow.
If Nicolas Cage weren't a goofball with a hunky physique and droll wit, this Marvel-comic-to-big-screen adaptation would have no torque at all.
Buy the soundtrack and rent the one with Belushi.
Awkwardly paced and muddled.
Repo Men should have offered some lacerating satire, but the derivative filmmaking and reality-show dialogue take the heart right out of it.
Tamahori and the phalanx of writers implode Dick's intriguing premise into a pedantic thriller.

If you're a Doors fan, your inner Jim Morrison will be stoked by the vast archival footage in When You're Strange. Be warned, however: this documentary doesn't open any new doors, and, worse, it's negligent in its history.
Edgerton, a stuntman by trade, doesn't offer much that's new, but the script by his brother, Joel, keeps folding back in on itself, and if character credibility lags, at least the tension stays high.

Levy, despite the wit and chemistry of his leads and a killer line-up of cameos (James Franco, Mark Ruffalo, Mila Kunis), manages to make the whole thing feel like a one-season sit-com crammed onto a DVD.
What's surprising are the poignant undercurrents about race and jingoism.

Despite the talents of Jacques Perrin and Jacques Cluzaud -- the Oscar-nominated duo behind Winged Migration, who once again contribute their amazing, in-the-midst-of photography -- the most striking thing about Oceans is its banality.
Though Watts's Elizabeth brings a sense of darkness and unpredictability to the film, the hyperbolic flourishes and the melodramatic climax offset the actresses' best efforts.
It's as if you'd tuned into an episode of Punk'd with Kutcher parading around in full Bond parody -- not good.
At least there's the lovely Salma Hayek and Maria Bello to give the cockamamie proceedings some grown-up elegance.
Tolerably spoofs staples like 007 and The Silence of the Lambs.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The 3-D at its best pops (a red-gloved dancer bursts out from the screen as if diving through a window), but more often it's merely Dramamine-inducing.
At least the A-list cast and crisp direction by TV vet Susanna White lift the film out of the dung heap.
It's no Heat, but it does take in a small haul of thrills.
Through all the emotional heaves and tosses, Cena is dead on. Unfortunately, the direction by Mel Damski isn't.
If Lionsgate wants to take a bite out of the animated film market dominated by Pixar and Disney, it'll have to do better than this toothless stray.
At least Emma Stone gets high marks in this teen comedy.
Despite the cockamamie premise, the filmmaking by Zack Snyder (branching out from 300 and Watchmen) is the best use of 3D animation since Avatar.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If you were wondering about the state of our education system, Davis Guggenheim's documentary won't make you feel very optimistic.
The alleged final installment in the death-game series goes out with a whimper -- and the 3D visuals, apart from a few screen-popping squirts of blood, do little to accentuate the gore.
It ain't old-school Todd Phillips, but it *is* Todd Phillips.

The film saddles the impromptu duo with carloads of backstory, but the actors are on their game -- and that includes Rosario Dawson, who adds a deft touch as the track manager fighting corporate inanity.
Wiseman records the rituals of repetition (speed bag and footwork) in poetic long shots that often have two pugilists side by side, each unaware of the other. The cadence is both primal and hypnotic.
The premise of this low-budget sci-fi thriller might be familiar from Signs, War of the Worlds, and Cloverfield, but the lesser acting talent is more in line with Plan 9 from Outer Space.
There's a lot of Oscar timber here...

Sparks also chips in as screenwriter, so he has no excuse for the messy result, and it doesn't help that director Julie Anne Robinson works the material like a pugilist throwing emotional kidney punches.
Pink's derivative vision plays out like a mullet in the new millennium.
It's a smart meat-and-potatoes-and-gore throwback.
Vaughan's effort isn't quite as composed as it should be, but the emotional current and tart commentary on the business of who lives and who dies is stirring.
Danish director Jonas Elmer doesn't quite understand romantic nuance.
Cusack's gritty, near over-the-top performance goes a long way, as does the subtle slow burn from director Mikael Håfström, but Samuel L. Jackson needed to be nudged awake as the hotel manager.
It drops its epic posture and spews far too many double entendres.
Silly, shock-pandering lines like that nearly sink the film to Showgirls level.

The reunion of the multi-ethnic Funky Fresh Boys triggers a fusillade of un-PC misfires as the not-so-fab four try to alleviate their personal woes by entering an American Idol-esque dance-troupe contest.
The ensuing carnage is ample but not gratuitous; every arterial spray and bone crack makes a point.
[An] unbewitching brew of clichés.

Smith turns in a career-capping performance, and director Gabriele Muccino ingeniously turns the material inward, cautioning us all to be grateful for what we have, for we're closer to the edge than we think.
No glitz or highly edited voice-overs gussy up the portrayal of artists who brim with passion and are willing to do anything to pursue their dream.
Director Steven Shill and the doltish dialogue don't do much to diminish the film's overt homophobia and misogyny.
The biting revelation promised by the title of Robert Luketic's fluff never bares its teeth.
Poor Joe Pantoliano, Kid Rock, and Joanna Cassidy get mixed up in the flatulence.
movie_title: Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector (2006)

movie_review_blurb: If only they'd brought Mr. Potato Head into the mix.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If you've thought of George Hamilton only as a B-celeb with a Day-Glo perma-tan, think again.

On its fourth go-round, the can-we-cheat-death exercise has become flatter than its characters, and the racist redneck, arrogant jock, buxom but shallow soccer mom, and perky, easy-on-the-eyes girlfriends make for a pretty flat cast.
It's Scream minus the wit and verve, with poor Carrie Fisher lost as the cantankerous house mother.
Starting from a graphic novel, Sena has turned out your standard TV crime show bloated with a monstrous FX budget.
Czuchry plays the self-proclaimed narcissist with charisma, but how can you cozy up to an arrogant misogynist whose epiphany comes amid a fecal fusillade?
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The real heat comes from Beavan's reluctant wife, Michelle Conlin, a self-proclaimed shopaholic and Starbucks poster girl.
It's especially effective in exploring the pressures on the boys and their fragile dreams.
Motherhood never comes to term.
Editor-turned-director Kevin Greutert shows confidence behind the camera -- still, one can only hope that Jigsaw's gruesome Pecksniffian pedagogy gets a taste of its own blade soon.
Simpson's dialogue flies like a flat-footed homage to Mamet or Tarantino.
Not everything Judd Apatow touches is gold.
Rodriguez should have turned to Tarantino for a few pointers on non-linear narrative.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Scream 2 isn't nearly as fresh, suspenseful or witty as it's inaugural bloodfest.
Spade is uncomfortably awkward as a romantic lead -- he's better employed in supporting comic roles.
Nothing extinct here, just pure dino-might!
Vardalos is amicable and sincere, but without the assembly of mutton-munching caricatures, this romantic-comedy would be hard pressed to fill a wedding gown.
The premise may sound titillating, but writer/director Finn Taylor tries too hard, and his loosely autobiographical drama comes off alarmingly stiff and contrived.
For the most part, Tunney carries the film on her sparkle, but Finn keeps jerking her from one vignette to the next and precluding any emotional development.
It's an alluring mélange that impresses as much as it frustrates.
Not even a master of disguise can make this sloppy slapstick look like anything more than an incoherent cowpie of a comedy.
The screenplay from Neil Cuthbert feels lackadaisical in his hands and loses its playfulness early on.
No one's likely to mistake this film for Harvard material.
Despite the familiar material, Steers delivers something fresh, provocative, and unadulterated.
It's a deluge of bullets and chop-socky madness devoid of style or purpose.
Mindless mayhem.
ufus Sewell and Rupert Graves do add some thespian punch as the intrepid video director and the pampered producer, but it's not nearly enough to keep this one from extremely bombing.
Hopefully this is the last we have seen of the Unisol series, but unfortunately the dearth of creativity in Hollywood, will allow it to live for another abysmal dumbing.
A pretty funny gore-fest that delivers the goods with a few new twists.
Unfortunately, Weaver and Jeunet's efforts are short changed by the ineptness of Joss Whedon's script, that seems to find a way to make action sequences unexciting.
Lots of great cameos, too few laughs.
movie_title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn, Hollywood, Burn (1998)

movie_review_blurb: What puts the fight in Fight Club is Fincher's visual wizardry.
The film pursues its sensitive material with the appropriate degree of care, but the direction by M. Night Shyamalan turns potentially provocative moments into dull eddies of melodrama.
Even Donald Sutherland in the potentially juicy role as a self-serving old sea dog, is wasted in this big budget ill.
The songs are all written and performed flawlessly by Bjork. And not only can the pixie goddess sing and dance, she can also act.
There's too little character development and no reason to care.
Lee should have drawn up a tighter game plan but just the same his hoops hoopla still has enough game (mostly in the form of Washington) to win over the audience.
It wants to be Boyz in the Hood (Boyz in the Wood) but the obscenity laced dialogue and raw objectification of woman renders it a contrite pretender more along the lines of Booty Call and Trippin.
Wants to be one of these violent, manly yet provocative films, but unfortunately it unfurls as more of a big budgeted student film; a collage of borrowed images paying homage to great directors.
The film, directed jerkily by Walt Becker, hangs too much on the lovers-to-be and doesn't take full advantage of the screwball caricatures lurking in the wings.
This small, well-crafted coming-of-age docudrama is a real-life Revenge of the Nerds by way of Stand By Me.
The film is peppered with political jokes, bikini-clad babes, and fart gags, as if it couldn't decide what audience it's aiming at.
Sandler shows an emotional range beyond his usual mercurial knucklehead; Barrymore drops her adolescent nymph in favor of a more sensitive, mature persona.
Hawkins, so fantastic in Mike Leigh's Happy Go Lucky, gives another award-worthy performance...
For those fans who think the animated MTV series about America's most infamous delinquents rules, be prepared for the wet dream of the big screen to be a letdown.
Even Donald Sutherland in the potentially juicy role of a self-serving old sea dog goes down with the ship in this suspenseless big-budget 'thriller.'
Blood & Wine is rewarding for its performances and the material it explores, but ultimately it's messy.

Even as the historical and emotional incongruities threaten to derail the film, the acerbic and witty prose gives Mrs. Brown a humorous dimension that, at times, makes it feel like an English response to Ridicule.
Director Mark Herman conveys England's controversial mine-pit-closure program in a dark, docudrama style that echoes the gritty realism achieved in the works of Mike Leigh and Ken Loach.
The film's modest and campy success hangs on the magnificent screen presence of Milla Jovovich, an angelic warrior clad in a red dinner dress and black combat boots, with piercing blue eyes.
Williamson's take-it-apart-and-put-it-back-together stitchmanship has become an arduous borefest.
A reasonably good time for the whole mini-van clan.
Add another to the scrap heap of hip '60s and '70s TV shows reduced to cinematic rubble by the inspiration-starved minds in Hollywood.
A sprightly romp, funny, full of life lessons, and scary.
About the only thing that is lucid, in the malestrom of wham-bam effects, is the set-up for a sequel.
The rocky blur between reality and fantasy aspires to be a Hitchcockian After Hours, but at two hours plus, The Game gets played out early on.
The younger Kasdan stages each scene handsomely, but as a writer he stretches potentially witty snaps into disagreeably languorous melodrama.
A shameless exercise in self-flagellation.
movie_title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn, Hollywood, Burn (1998)

movie_review_blurb: This kind of dippy, silly drivel has no right to succeed, yet it does...
A few of the daydream sequences are uproarious, but Trippin' tries to get real too late in the game.
The miscued camp and underachieving action merely unload it as a bombastic concoction.
Warren Beatty's brave, if ramshackle, political farce tackles the dirty business of racial inequality and corporate greed with the tenacity of a pit bull.
Director Chuck Sheetz spins it into an enjoyable breeze. The humor regularly hits the mark, and the kid lessons are well baked.
Chan is saddled with the languorous, droll wit of Owen Wilson and the result is tedious.
What ever happened to Robert Rodriguez?
Holy Man saddles its star with a leaden, melodramatic script that never allows the high jinks to get rolling at Murphy's hyperkinetic pace.
This concoction of cheesy layers is hokum of the most delightful kind.
A blistering docudrama, as refreshing as it is horrifying.
Little and his posse of outcasts (Ugly Duckling, Runt, the fat pig, and Fish out of Water) endear, but the rest of the film is derivative and uninspired.
For a base, downtrodden ordeal Clark's film is one compelling trip of a movie.
Unfortunately for every gag that DeNiro and Crystal pull off -- and they do have an effective comedic chemistry -- the script strands them in eddies of frivolity.
Mac is superb as the egomaniacal man boy finally getting his come-uppance and needing to change his game. Angela Bassett is a warm, sexy plus as a sportscaster and former love interest.
Bill Nighy adds a spark as the detested stepdad, the ghoul make-up is George Romero-worthy, and the final zinger makes it all worthwhile.
This is a lowbrow, low-budget homage to the Farrelly brothers -- and a pretty poor one at that.
Bale's complete immersion into Trevor's afflicted soul and Sharin's southern fried freak make the descent into paranoia worth the journey.
Sure, the world hangs in the balance, but it's the adult-savvy everyday dynamic between Bob and Helen that saves the day.
In the end, the computer wizardry palls, but the story's heart chugs on triumphantly.
Unfortunately, Testosterone isn't as provocative as its premise or its title.
A thin bit of nostalgia.
Like the phenomenon of the title, the film suggests possible revelations but in the end is just a blur.
You're left with stilted dialogue and dark, underlit sets.
Though the experience is mind-boggling, it can also spark blurry optical overload.
In this chintzy video-game blow-up, Christian Slater battles zombies and transmogrified beasties, revealing the horror of a once-promising career turned miserable.
Kids aren't going to get the sexual innuendo, and not many adults will enjoy the blast of urine and splatters of snot and vomit.
For all its candor and spare grit, the film is more than just in-your-face pedagogy about intolerance.
Sometimes the line between family fun and cheeky humor gets blurred too far.
Tim Story's screen adaptation of the Marvel comic is cheesy in production values; it's the clash of personalities that makes the film in any way fantastic.
Despite the clichés and the profanity, there are some hilariously wicked moments.
The themes about corporate greed and blood being thicker than money resonate, but that doesn't save the film from predictability and cliché.
For a jerky, cliché-riddled yarn about the evils of fame, Undiscovered has enough sensitivity, wit, and inadvertent guffaws to rise above its lame underpinnings.
At times Tracy's a sensitive guy who just needs a hug; at others, he's an obnoxious motormouth.
The acting is stilted and the direction clunky - not that the original was any masterpiece.
A bombastic drag.
movie_title: Gone in 60 Seconds (Gone in Sixty Seconds) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: What could have been a cool concept movie buckles under an uninspired script and some treacherous miscasting.
At times, the blur between cyber-reality and reality is hard to discern, but Oshii's visual artistry is so hypnotic and original, it'll resonate even with those who aren't in the know.
Is there really a market of children out there that will find this funny or entertaining?
The artwork by director Hatsuki Tsuji and his team of animators is sharp, but it pales before state-of-the-art CGI.
Braff demonstrates a weird visual flair, but his smug script collapses into contrivance before Andrew touches bottom.
Add another one to the scrap heap of trendy, nostalgic, 60's and 70's TV shows reduced to cinematic rubble by the inspiration starved minds in Hollywood.
One of the year's most visually stylistic films.
It's a fun family safari chock full of environmental lessoning.
The whole extravaganza could have made for a plucky 70 minutes, but it packs on an additional three-quarters of an hour of saw-toothed melodrama.
movie_title: Cowboy Bebop: The Movie (Kaubôi Bibappu: Tengoku no Tobira) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Boat Trip goes bottoms up early.
The result is impressive but does little to further the experience.
War may be Hell, but in this three-and-a-half-hour Civil War epic from Ronald Maxwell, the syrupy monologues and righteous Bible thumping provide the punishment.
You know exactly how this one ends; yet getting there is such an enjoyable delight.
The odd-couple chemistry between Chow and Scott carries the film until the unimaginative buddy formula wears thin.
Safes drop through floors, sinkholes magically appear in downtown LA, and there's an enthralling chase through the waterways of Venice: it all makes for a pleasing, if preposterous, spectacle.
Disregard the negative buzz: Gigli is woeful but not disastrous.
Its forced slapstick egregiously mugs the audience for laughs.
What carries the film is the comedic pairing of stars Will Smith and Martin Lawrence, who actually improve on their contentious oddball chemistry.
It's clear that video-game-designer-turned-director Shinsuke Sato knows what he's got: when the action settles down, he wisely hangs the camera on his alluring stars.
This listless big-screen blow-up of the Sega video game reduces horror genre conventions to banal clichés.
It's a dull spectacle that makes a drive out to Carver for King Richard's Faire seem more appealing.
The direction by Bille Woodruff is erratic yet well-intentioned...
Unfortunately, Beckinsale, a wonderful actress who looks game in her painted-on leather garb, is too soft and demure to convince as the vengeful vixen.
Both Smith and actor Ben Affleck get their groove back with this affecting tale of a struggling single father torn between stalled career aspirations and parental responsibility.
Another comic book blow-up posturing to be the next big action franchise.

None of it is funny, and to make matters worse, writer George Gallo and director Howard Deutch have somehow managed to domesticate out of Jill the goofball sensuality that gave the original its quirky edge.
Director Nick Hamm exacerbates matters with his proclivity for foreboding images, be it the rising mist in the woods, the caw of a crow, or the dilapidated cabin no one should enter.
A non-stop gagfest around a subject that has no right to be funny.
French visual-FX expert Pitof directs, so the overuse of CGI is understandable, though even that can't conceal the insipid plot or Berry's ham-fisted performance.
The film's strong suit is the fish-out-of-water generational gags, and director Mark S. Waters does well to keep them coming at a rapid-fire rate.
Though the film oozes visual appeal (many action sequences are rendered with comic-book vibrancy), it's short on insight and long on cliché.
It's deeply derivative yet wholly original, an odd mix that will keep audiences on their toes.
Such defining efforts as Cocoon and Apollo 13 seem light years away for Ron Howard...
Black layers in devilish sight gag after sight gag with smooth pulpy nuance, while maintaining the requisite forward motion.
The most fun part of the film comes as the dwarves flee the elven holding block in oak kegs and shoot down whitewater rapids through a gauntlet of orcs.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A beguiling look into the paradoxical and self-destructive nature of a man who, while earnest in his desire to serve the public, remains unable to shake a sex-trolling persona infamously known as Carlos Danger.
Despite its stumbles as it heads toward the finish line, the performers hold down the fort.
It's très French and tantalizing in all the right ways, underscored by the way Kechiche ends the film: with pointed ambiguity.
In the end, this freeform history lesson is a flightless foul.

At the core of Abrams' brilliant rebranding, beyond the astute and well-measured use of high-powered special FX, is the inspired casting of Chris Pine and Zachary Quinto as the younger Kirk and Spock.

By the end, what registers is something more than just a trek through a filmography -- though it will make you want to stage your own mini film retrospective. It's a portrait of a man in full, his wisdom, his trials and his triumphs.

What's missing in Snyder's Superman is a dash of the hokey goodness that Christopher Reeve contributed to the role and the comic cold cheesiness that Gene Hackman and Terrence Stamp brought as Luthor and Zod.

Nicolas Winding Refn tosses All About Eve into the blender with alluring moodiness and bloody malice in this rapturous, sometimes ingeniously inane, tale of superficial nihilism and the obsessive pursuit of perfection.
Nothing to go ape about, but a good way to cool your heels in the heat.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The actors echo the effort with great heart, and the result is both touching and acrid.
The wonderment of Hank's journey, his universal human condition and questions of his mental health ground the film, and the Daniels have tapped into something original and moving.
IM3 is sure to sate its fan base, but it won't endear a new crowd.
It's a return to the director's roots and a clear bit of personal therapy. At the core, however, burns idealism, longing and the modulation of one's own personal views over time.

Saunders and Lumley pucker up and give it a game go. They're a disastrous pleasure to watch, but it's also a bit like driving a car that has only a CD player and no way to rope in the playlist on your iDevice.

We're a long way from the Robert Ludlum material that was so organically and intricately concerned with spy games and double dealings at the highest levels, with Jason Bourne caught up as the harried fly in the ointment.
For me I'd just be happy to follow Ms. Quinn for a day at the mall. Cyndi Lauper's "Girls Just Want to have Fun" would be the anthem. Leave the Joker at home. Ah, missed opportunities.
The filmmaker's laid-back yet probing style and quest for getting at the human condition and effects of a digital sphere enveloping society is nothing short of infectious.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It moves from beginning to end as a tightly piloted flight that proves fact trumps fiction in matters of the soul and the sky.

The film's greatest asset, besides Gordon-Levitt's complex and nuanced performance... is its unique, under-the-hood peek into the cyber-spy game and the inner workings of government security agencies.
You can almost see the filmmaking process with Wrona chumming the waters with macabre tentacles and philosophical probings only to back away and say "that's it" sans an explanation or guide-wires.
To tackle such an updating without fully loaded guns is not a wise thing.

It's an embarrassment of riches that gets close to the point of going over the edge, but the cast rein it back in to the base human elements we can't all afford to indulge in with our landlocked budgets.
The film's both a look forward and back, with the promise of a unified nation where all are treated equally, regardless of color, to be birthed from the bloody act.
Overall the film's a long play of a video game barely propped up by plot and stock personalities.
For such a simple arc with complex themes, Wild taps into the universal human condition.
What Workman has assembled is the kind of film Welles would have been happy to part of. It's a unique, warm and fair portrait of a man who was both genius and joke and well aware of it.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The matters of politics of exploitation and corporate greed get put up there on screen with great, chest-beating solemnity, but in the end... they become nothing more than the slack, cartoonish motivations of an archvillain in a Bond flick.
In the end, when all the shells have been shuffled and it's time to pull back the curtain, An Honest Liar is less about amazing you than it is about touching you.
The whole thing made me fearful for my daughter and ashamed. The Hunting Ground underscores all that and brings to light the faces wronged and those looking to make it stop.
Joy marks more of the same - not a bad thing, as it features the ever determined yet effervescent Jennifer Lawrence, back under Russell's instruct for the third time.
It's a cautionary tale that should make those driving the NFL moneymaker take pause more than they already have.
The film flies by, a wicked spin through a wicked time when everyone was guilty, no one was held accountable and the winners, who risked it all, felt like losers amid the devastation and loss.
The roots of deconstructing Hollywood and the cancerous underbelly of privilege and fame hang there but never quite connect in a meaningful way.

The culmination doesn't deliver any burning revelation, but the long, bloody crawl through frozen hell ultimately becomes a contemplation on man and morality outside the confines of a law-bound society.
Everything moves in small, sleepy slices like that, but the film remains rife with tension -- mostly between Michael's ears.
What Bay and Hogan have done here is to sidestep the politics of naming names and, in honoring the heroics of six brave men, have subtly painted the politics of a changing global landscape.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While admirable and amiable, is their least. The actors power through, but the ungodly dwelling in matters of feces and an over-the-top use of FX at the end is far short of divine.

It's a tangy olio that lacks substance and consistency, and despite that, its in-your-face moxie comes at you in all the right ways, gripping you by the gunny sack with a big glorious joker smile and never letting go.
It's a moonstruck olio of hyperbole, reality and alter-reality, and it plays together seamlessly.
High times in high altitudes doesn't necessarily spark an interest for those not at the party.
The power of "Slave" is not so much its rote plea to "not forget," but its invitation to understand.
Knight of Cups suggests [Malick's] films are no different than any other director's in one important way -- casting makes a difference.

Tight editing (there's never any dislocation in sense of place while locale hopping) and well-framed shots hold the tension, as does Hibbert's well-gamed chess match of statesmanship and foreign policy.
What ultimately elevates "Knight of Cups" above the similarly slight and indulgent "To the Wonder" are the performances.
At the end of the dawn, there's no real justice per se, just smug, contrived posturing of what's to come - something Snyder & Co. are banking on.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The cast of slightly known actors also works to the film's favor. All play their part on the well-balanced roster.
The one sure thing Nichols has to bank on is Shannon's burning intensity. The determination etched on the actor's steely face never wanes.
[Gyllenhaal is] right up there with McConaughey, Tom Hardy and Michael Fassbender as one of the most interesting and edgy male leads in film today.

The good news about the latest Marvel project to land on the screen is that it's livelier and more entertaining than the other Avenger offerings -- even if this one technically waves the Captain America banner.
The statistical probability of a nuclear accident increases every moment. Humankind has been lucky so far, which Command and Control makes poignantly clear.

Few probably knew that balancing the books could be such a lethal endeavor, or that such a cockamamie idea, especially with the normally tacit and wooden Affleck, could translate into such a satiating pleasure -- a guilty one.
There's so much to like here, and the film ends with a punch. For Roth's sake -- and McGregor's, for that matter -- you almost want a do-over.
[Trance] evokes an eerie, hypnotic wonderment, consuming you and transporting you, until inevitably, the fingers snap, the eyes open, and the rapturous trance is broken.

"Battle of the Sexes" is more than just an empowerment victory lap for women and others seeking equality; it's a heartfelt love story or two, and a fantastic time capsule resurrecting the early '70s with aplomb.
"It's too bad she won't live" - as James Edward Olmos' cop says at the end of the original - but it seems that Scott's punk-noir darling has.
One surprising thing about The Florida Project is how rife it is with hope, even as it's weighed down by the hapless, unsustainable situation of its protagonists.

It's a disappointment too that Swedish director Tomas Alfredson, who found such rhythm and bite in recent outings such as "Let the Right One In" (2008) and "Tinker Taylor Soldier Spy" (2011), seems so hobbled here.
There's little in the film that will surprise you.
The intoxicatingly strange brew - the third "Thor" flick, and fifth Marvel film that the Norse god has appeared in - gets nicely stirred by quirky New Zealand auteur Taika Waititi...
But McDonagh's vision and style is something of its own, and it operates on its own bloody terms.
"Lady Bird" is the kind of indie film like such recent hits "Moonlight" or "Boyhood" that possess mainstream crossover and critical appeal.
Guillermo del Toro returns to fine form with this fairy tale-cum-horror story that effectively echoes the texture, mood and style of his 2006 gem, "Pan's Labyrinth."
The problem with Wonder Wheel ultimately becomes its endless rotation of self-loathing, self-interested and shortsighted characters, wanting without doing.
... plenty of twists, turns and pleasant surprises to hold an audience rapt over the two-and-a-half-hour running time.
Like its plucky anti-heroine, I, Tonya is full of grit and determination, enough to make it where pedigree, decorum and odds are stacked in opposition.
It's just too bad in its rush to get small and cheeky, it didn't take stock more globally.
Unhappily, Argento never summons the courage to abandon narrative completely, so the script is continually acting as a brake while the visuals are driving forward to the next set-piece
The subtle jockeying by all three becomes a most civil parlor game, telling of an era when media were far too cozy with their subjects to justifiably claim objectivity.

The synergy between the three is so uncanny and genuine that you wonder if they weren't brainwashed and shoehorned into their roles - forever to be Reynolds, Alma and Cyril in the waking world of 2018 and onward.
[Joachim] Trier weaves a weird tapestry that ensnares its heroine and the audience alike.

[Clint] Eastwood, a capable and competent filmmaker, seems to have trusted the script and his non-actors more than his instincts.

"Annihilation" holds you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.

First-time director Cory Finley orchestrates the cloistered black comedy with veteran aplomb, and while that's a testament to the filmmaker's skill, the success of Thoroughbreds hangs entirely on the deft performances by Anya Taylor-Joy and Olivia Cooke.
Much of the film's success can be attributed to [Aubrey] Plaza, who makes her sociopathic wallflower remarkably nuanced and empathetic, beyond the trappings of the script.
Like in the Ocean films, Soderbergh's loaded A-list goes on and on.
[Good Time] is sharp, flashy filmmaking that enthralls increasingly with each turn of the downward spiral.
The combination of character, setting and weave makes well-known tropes fresh and new.
It holds its rapturous tease over us with scrumptious visuals, artful poise and dips into kink and gore that would give the Marquis de Sade reason to smile.
It's not as fresh and sassy as Guardians of the Galaxy, but it is a piquant changeup for fans who have come to find the Avengers series getting long in the tooth.
Not all the veers and neck-cranking developments pay off, but there's a lot to praise in the moody, fractious friction throughout and the enigmatic desolation in the pools of Pike's limpid blue eyes.
The driving force behind Loving is the couple's enduring commitment to each other and their children. The bond is palpable and deep.
Overall, the film's a scrumptious and enthralling drink, but not as wholly affecting as Winged Migration by any regard.
The overall plot arc and not-super-well-laid plot twists fill the space, but it's Chastain who fills the role that lifts the film above the cesspool it seeks to eviscerate.
It's an impressively bold go at such a revered presidency, and much of the project's success hangs on Natalie Portman's fully immersed and utterly mesmerizing portrait of the grieving first widow.
It's an enthralling go, with little pops of surprise and revelation that should please, nostalgically so.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Spacey's bravura performance really sells the story.

The film's portrait of pain, perseverance and heroism lingers beyond the borders of time and colored hues.
The result is something clearly borrowed, incredibly fresh and nearly perfect in light of the current political climate.
Logan, the third Wolverine spinoff from an X-Men movie empire that has grown terribly long in the tooth (or is that claw?), does a nice job of righting the ship with this elegiac closing chapter.

movie_review_blurb: The 3D IMAX visuals do impress, but the subtext - that if you behave well, the Martians will zap your mother's brain - is a little out of this world.

The director of 300 and Watchmen has plenty of visual panache, but when it comes to storytelling, he's a bombastic hack.
The actors make the most of it, and director David Bowers (Astro Boy) keeps the gags coming at an ADD-appeasing pace. What this wimp lacks, however, is heart.
