Woody Allen soars in Midnight in Paris. He suggests that no matter what era you're in you are unaware of its value, so you look back and see a better past. And the past, of course, is a selective illusion.

X-Men: First Class brings freshness and savvy to the X-Men franchise. Like Star Trek, one of the best movies of 2009, the latest X-Men is able to invest its popular series with an entertaining vitality that one might not expect.
Some movies try to solve the mystery of life. The Hangover Part 2 only tries to solve the mystery of the binge. It reaches that easily reachable bar.
Everything Must Go is not a bad movie, but saying that it's based on a story by Raymond Carver is like saying a ham dinner is based on Hamlet.
The Tree of Life is a fractured film, so they needed five different editors to put it back together. I heard the original title was going to be The Humpty Dumpty of Life.
The strength of Hesher is its acting. Joseph Gordon-Levitt is back to drawing on his natural power as an actor. He's skilled at creating absorbing human trainwrecks.
Thor is an amusement park ride through the Marvel universe from the realm of Asgard to earth, and back, and forth. Around and around. How many rides do you want to take?

Winter in Wartime is an evocative Dutch movie about Michiel, a youthful adolescent coming of age in Nazi-occupied Holland in January 1945. The film is full of symbols that give depth and texture to Michiel's fateful journey.

How does a pacifist prevail in an ugly, hostile world? How do children grow up in a world of isolation, alienation, grief, and bullying? The Danish film In a Better World won the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film dealing with such issues.
In Born to be Wild, the milk of human kindness nourishes the animals. And the audience.

The Conspirator contains parallels to today's incarceration of political prisoners and the questions of their rights, if any. It is not bold, but it is enlightening. It looks back at injustice, not in rage, but perhaps in sorrow.
Jake Gyllenhaal is the movie's great asset. He exhibits an artful ability to humanize his character in a dehumanized world of gamesmanship.
Paul has a terrific concept -- an affectionate send-up of the sci-fi genre. Paul has it ups, but it also has unfortunate downs. Instead of going to the moon, it goes to Wyoming.
Limitless may not pass a demanding test of logic. But Hitchcock once told me, "logic is dull." Limitless is certainly not dull.

Matthew McConaughey carries The Lincoln Lawyer with sheer credible willpower and personality. McConaughey has to survive fitful direction and a choppy script, but he emerges with his likeable faculties intact.

Philip K. Dick's story The Adjustment Team was published in 1954. But the movie The Adjustment Bureau only trades on Dick's name. All else is shoved aside by George Nolfi, who directed and wrote the screenplay.
What started out so promisingly loses its way as it becomes yet another mind-boggling entertainment. It could have been so much more.
Probably Clint Eastwood should not make sentimentalized, epical films about wish fulfillment. But there's Hereafter. It's a film that might make Clint's mentor the late Don Siegel look away.
The Hangover is nothing special. It's a fair-to-middling bombardment of humor thrown against the wailing walls of Las Vegas. It misses as much as it hits.
Once in a Lifetime is like a soccer team that plays good defense but lacks offense.
movie_title: Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos (2006)

movie_review_blurb: What Goes Up is an earnest morality tale. It's very uneven, but it also seems sincere.
Starting Out in the Evening has a formidable performance by Frank Langella to recommend it.

I think when they started filming Cloverfield, somebody accidentally dropped the camera. Someone else said, "Cool." So they kept dropping the camera. And they threw it, and jerked it, and kicked it. And it went into terminal spasms.
Do you want disembowelment and decapitation with your popcorn? Is gore glorious? Is brutality orgasmic? Is spurting blood the fountain of fun? If so, Rambo is 4 U.

Jumper is a popcorn movie, but without salt or butter. Too many of the kernels remain unpopped. It's like the Saturday matinees of yore. But by the time you've crossed the lobby after seeing Jumper, you've forgotten it.
U2 3D is an isle of style and sense in a sea of mediocrity.
Vantage Point is a patented representative of this year's early mediocrity. Vantage Point is trailer trash.
Will Ferrell's Semi-Pro is a dreadful comedy. It's lazy and slipshod.
The Savages is a labored labor of love about an estranged brother and sister, who have to deal with a frail and fractious father.
The Bank Job is not just another slick caper film. It's robust, messy, cluttered, and a cut well above the average crime job.
Under the Same Moon puts a human face on illegal immigration. More than that, it gives it a human heart.
When the movie 21 was announced with Kevin Spacey and Laurence Fishburne, it sounded like a winner. When everybody else involved in 21 was mentioned, it was doomed to be a loser.
Smart People is a film of chuckles about smart but chuckle-headed people.
A lot of reviewers seem to have disliked Street Kings because of its negative view of the LA police, and perhaps the country at large. That is not a problem for me.
Leatherheads tries to be a screwball comedy, but it's more The Eleven Stooges.

Ok, I give up. The Slackers win. In the last ten years, the Republican Party has had its revenge, the Nerds have had their revenge, and now the Slackers stand sloppy and tall. I stand poleaxed. The latest beating inflicted on my psyche is by Forgetting
Redbelt seems like a rush job that relies too much on the quick fix. I'm very willing to suspend my disbelief, but Redbelt becomes outlandish.
Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day is a well-acted comedy with enough old-fashioned qualities to make it an enjoyable experience for long-standing audiences.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The best movies are those that understand the human condition and have a personal vision. The Visitor is one of those rare creations. The Visitor is a parable of decency.

National Treasure: the Book of Secrets is an absurd adventure, but its absurdity is wacky and warmhearted. You have to suspend your disbelief, but so what? National Treasure: the Book of Secrets delivers on what it sets out to be: lively and

Sweeney Todd is a throat-slasher of a motion picture. It creates a new genre -- the slasher musical. Adapted from the Tony-winning Broadway musical by Stephen Sondheim, it's the tuneful tale of cutthroat's revenge.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Resurrecting the Champ is a movie I was going to recommend. It was contrived and dopey, but it seemed like pleasant entertainment. Then came the terrible last ten minutes when it casts itself on the rancid junk heap of hokum.

3:10 to Yuma is a big, brawling action-adventure with strong psychological elements. The original 3:10 to Yuma, with Glenn Ford and Van Heflin, directed by Delmer Daves, was a psychological western, and the present version expands on that.
David Cronenberg is a director who sets out to bring life (and death) back to violence. In Eastern Promises he does just that. It is a movie that will make audiences squirm and look away.
Although much of Rush Hour 3 is in Paris, it's no French pastry. It's more week-old Happy Meal.
Feast of Love is a multi-layered -- layers of baloney -- tale of pursuit of love.
The Brave One is worth seeing for the scenes between Terrence Howard and Jodie Foster.
There are a lot of movies that don't deliver on their promise. The Hunting Party is one of them. It's a disheartening disappointment.
Charlie Wilson's War features two characters who know how government is supposed to work. They also know it doesn't work as it is supposed to, so they have to subvert the system and go beyond it.
In the Valley of Elah is a powerful, emotional indictment of what contemporary war can do to young men. It is a potent moral tale. This is not your father's war.
Clooney's latest venture into panache is thriller style in Michael Clayton.

When you see No Country for Old Men, leave your preconceptions at home. But bring your Alfred Hitchcock lenses. They're useful. No Country for Old Men is a dazzling time-bomb of a movie. It is an engrossing, brutal, nerve-wracking moral tale
When American Gangster was announced, with actors Denzel Washington and Russell Crowe and directed by Ridley Scott, it seemed like a can't miss project. It missed.
Lions for Lambs is movie mutton.
700 A.D. is now 21st Century American 3-D. It's a hell of a transformation. The 3-D version of Beowulf -- the one you must see if you see the film -- is a wild roller coaster ride.
I'm Not There is coy and fatuous, but it also can be intriguing and thought-provoking. But I'm Not There makes us consider Dylan with new eyes.

Lumet's latest film, Before the Devil Knows You're Dead is an unpleasant film with unpleasant characters. It would be easy to dismiss, if it weren't directed by maestro Sidney Lumet. But the movie is labored and repetitive.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Into The Wild has been made into a prayer of a motion picture by Sean Penn. It may not touch everybody, but those whom it does touch, it will touch deeply. It is a haunting odyssey.

Iron Man is an appealing superhero movie. It's also clunky. It's welded together out of disparate pieces that clank and ping. Though at times it's leaden, Iron Man also has enough moments of pizazz to intermittently soar.

Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull -- the fourth movie about Henry Jones, Jr. -- is as comfortable as an old shoe. Or an old hat. Actually it is old hat. It's comfortable, but it's also worn and slack.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: What Happens in Vegas has mediocre direction and a strained screenplay, so how can it be any good? What carries the film is its two stars. If Ashton Kutcher bothers you, you'll probably hate What Happens in Vegas. If Cameron Diaz leaves you
Writer Charlie Kaufman is the pseudo-intellectuals' "intellectual." He's pompous, self-flagellating and pretentious. So they love him. Kaufman makes Sarah Palin seem humble.
Is Chinatown the best private eye film ever? It may well be. Nearing its thirty-fifth anniversary, it deserves a reconsideration and a celebration.

Quantum of Solace is the most obtuse title of the year. Maybe it means kick-a** action. If so, it's a very apt title. Don't be late arriving at the theater. The pre-opening credit sequence to Quantum of Solace goes just 15 seconds before the
Seven Pounds is an unexpected holiday powerhouse. Will Smith shakes off his familiar, comfortable persona, and cuts to the unsettled heart of humanity.

The Dark Knight is a good movie. It has all the ingredients to be a great movie, but it isn't one. I may grudgingly put it on my best-ten-of-the year list (a paltry group at this point), but it could have been so much more. It came so close.
Doubt is a shaggy-god story. Written and directed by John Patrick Shanley from his successful Broadway play, it has all the grace of a high school debate.

Sean Penn and gay director Gus Van Sant (Good Will Hunting) have created a warm-hearted testament to Harvey Milk, the first openly gay individual who was elected to major political office, and was then murdered/martyred.

I give thanks for westerns. Every time they seem to be about to gasp their last, dusty breath, one comes along to give them a bit of renewed life. Bless it, the western genre will not die. Last year it was the excellent remake 3:10 to Yuma. This ye

The Reader is the most undeserving of the five Academy Award nominees for Best Picture. A nice quality for a movie to have is if it has one or more characters to whom one can relate. In The Reader the two main characters are clods.

When the movie version of Frost/Nixon was being cast, Frank Langella might well have been bypassed. Jack Nicholson and Warren Beatty were mentioned, but Langella survived and got the role. On screen Langella nails -- or fangs -- Nixon. Langella does not m

In The Wrestler, Rourke -- with a scraggly mane of dyed hair -- portrays "The Ram," a once-adored wrestler, who is living in a trailer park, working menial jobs lifting boxes and behind a meat counter, trying to hawk signed memorabilia in nearly de

Revolutionary Road is a dumbed down movie. But it's not dumbed down for just general audiences; it's dumbed down for would-be intellectual audiences, people who are supposed to like books. It sorely fits contemporary times.

Defiance runs for 137 minutes, but that doesn't make it an epic. It just makes it long. Near the beginning, we are informed on screen that Defiance is "a true story." It may be a true story, but it is not truly told.
This inventive treatment will intrigue and fulfill some audience members. But not me. Despite general critical euphoria (90% favorable on Rottentomatoes), I found it a plodding tours de force.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gran Torino had the biggest wide-opening at the box office of Clint Eastwood's career. In Gran Torino Clint plays hard-bitten, alienated, anti-everything Walt Kowalski. Sound familar? Clint didn't bring back Dirty Harry, but he gave us Dirty
It's a deceptively rich film.
Last Chance Harvey is an easygoing trip abroad. It features two relaxed pros playing acting tennis -- hitting graceful lobs to each other, and then artful returns.

Demme has made two of my favorite films, Philadelphia and Melvin and Howard as well as the classic The Silence of the Lambs. In his latest movie Rachel Getting Married, the lambs never stop bleating. And they're dysfunctional.
Director Barry Levinson's What Just Happened? is about spoiled brats. But it's amusing.
Clint Eastwood is a vital force of nature. Born May 31, 1930, the unflappable 78-year old director is still creating powerful, unique movies. Changeling is remarkable evidence of that.
A second HBO movie has made its mark of excellence on TV. Recount probably would die at the box office in movie theaters, but it prevails on television. It's a hard sell.

The movie Sex and the City is a heady female fantasy -- I think. I tried to snuggle up to Sex and the City, but the attempt to snuggle for two hours and 20 minutes is in itself a fantasy. Like many typical men, I'm afraid I fell asleep.

Seeing The Happening is like going on an outing with an earnest person, who happens to be a drunk. Every time it starts to make sense, it slurs its speech and starts dropping things -- such as coherence and credibility.

A movie in which acting still prevails is Mongol. People often say, 'They don't make movies like they used to.' Maybe the Russians make movies like Hollywood used to. Mongol, photographed beautifully in Kazakhstan and the Chinese province of
About halfway through The Incredible Hulk, Ed Norton (Bruce Banner) gets his hair cut. Hair is not the only thing that winds up on the cutting room floor.

I'm a real sucker for animated rodents. I loved Ratatouille and I laughed fondly at the previews of the brave Despereaux in a movie coming out this winter. Adorable rodents, yes. Rusted robots, not so much. WALL-E is a rusted robot, who has been ge

A few actors such as Clint Eastwood, marry substance and popularity. But very few. Most actors' egos lead them to slum in the box office. I'm reminded of this often when a major, talented actor opts for popularity instead of substance when the latter beck

What do dithering tv weathermen do when they retire? They must take their lame, witless banter and their awkward timing to Hollywood to write and direct movies. That might explain Get Smart, one of the latest in a long line of humid, mediocre, tire

Step Brothers is a rowdy, rambunctious, fitful, against-the-wall comedy. Will Ferrell, John C. Reilly, and director writer Adam McKay heave comedy, like spaghetti, against the wall. About half sticks; the other half makes a real mess.

Tropic Thunder is one humongous vanity project for Ben Stiller. His initials aren't BS for nothing. If you can't get enough of bouncing Ben, Tropic Thunder is the movie for you. Ben Stiller acted in, co-wrote, produced, and directed Tropi

Alan Rickman is one of my favorite actors, and I wanted to see Bottle Shock if only for his performance. Rickman's performance is great as usual, and Bottle Shock, despite some contrivance, is a very entertaining movie.

Please send Get Well cards to the Coen Brothers. After last year's No Country for Old Men, for which they won the Oscar for Best Picture of the Year, Joel and Ethan Coen have had a relapse. Their new offering Burn After Reading is reminiscen

Imagine this conversation: A phone call between actor Bob De Niro and director Marty Scorsese. Bobby: Hello, Marty. I've been calling and texting, but you never answer. (Silence) Bobby: I'm talking to you. Are you talkin' to me? Are you talkin' to me?

Ricky Gervais has become a major international star. The British comic created and was the lead actor in the original British TV version of The Office (2006) and Extras (2007). He has won two Emmys and a Golden Globe. Now after a few bit parts his distinc
When Russell Crowe gives a lackluster performance, you know how meager a year it's been at the movies. In Body of Lies, Crowe is bogged down in a thankless role in a thankless movie.

The Express is running on two rails at the same time. There's sentiment, which is true. And there's sentimentality, which is not. At its best, The Express is a moving tribute; at its worst, it's conventional manipulation.

W. is the October surprise. The movie won't change anybody's ideas about the values of the last eight years. But it may make some of us think differently about their protagonist. If one expects -- or demands -- a Liberal screed against G.W. Bush, t

Hairspray is an energetic romp, but as a social statement -- which it pretends to be -- it's cartoonish. And as a playful look back at a time and place, it's simplistic shtik. It's a mountain of whipped cream, with an occasional chocolate sprinkle.
When is a rat a lark? When he's created by Brad Bird. Brad Bird, the animation maestro from Pixar, invents a spunky, gourmet rodent in the lively, spicy romp Ratatouille.
The Bourne Ultimatum keeps the pedal to the floor and burns serious rubber.
Talk to Me is an incisive portrait of a provocative figure. It comes very close to caricature, but remains human and lively.

Ari Folman, who wrote and directed Waltz with Bashir, creates an intriguing film. He uses unique animation which features muted, ochre imagery. It's like a nightmare from which you awake. But you stay unsettled for a long time.

If one examines Albee's The Zoo Story, Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?, and Tiny Alice as three views of the struggle for faith and the Christ myth and its nuances, the plays, on a particular level, gain a substantial meaning.

Don Siegel's Dirty Harry is an apt example of a film with a vision that few people perceive beyond its violent, flamboyant surfaces. If director Siegel might be a bit uncomfortable with a close reading of his movie, he also might be pleased that the...

Penn's comments at the 2008 Oscars might have been needed if it weren't for a previous statement by Dustin Lance Black who sensitively and appealingly, made an acceptance speech in which he spoke very personally about the pain of being gay as a youth.
Coraline is a mesmerizing tale with macabre stitching. There's no blood, but Coraline is a haunting horrorfest located in a weird wonderland.

Happy-Go-Lucky is flibbertigibbet cinema. Mike Leigh directed Sally Hawkins in this paean to a peahen. Mike Leigh, let me introduce you to Fran Drescher, Kathy Griffin, and Nancy Grace. They're your kind of women.
2008 Oscars: This is a lock. I keep trying to find a way that Slumdog won't win I can't. Let the industry have its Slumdog. This year I think I'm going to need hair of the dog.
...Around, which has the tagline Embrace the Fall, is more hopscotch than a fall. Spaltro's writing and direction could use a sharper edge, but he knows how to create arresting images.
Vicky Cristina Barcelona, which Allen wrote and directed but did not act in, is Woody at the top of his game.
John Schlesinger's Darling is a film of excessive and self-defeating brilliance.

The Last Picture Show is competent movie-making and probably deserves an audience. But its predictability and its calculation mar it for me. The values seem to me to be more contrived humanity instead of the real thing.

The Shining met the fate of several other Stanley Kubrick films when it came out; most viewers did not like it, so they rejected it. Most importantly, they did not understand it in any way which allowed them to deal with it constructively.
Lady in the Box is a film noir thriller which packs a potent punch. It has a gimmicky surprise ending, but its greatest strength is its atmosphere.
Tomcats is a raunchy, rambunctious, crowd-pleasing film.
The film Monkeybone is a raucous mess. Director Henry Selick mixes animation and live action to the noisy, clumsy detriment of both.
Down to Earth is worth seeing. Like mainstream brew, it doesnt have high potency, but it is a nice diversion.
The best thing about Must Read After My Death is that it remains roiling in the mind long after one sees it. Also Dews has made his movie with considerable technical skill.
Sunset Boulevard's entire point of view is based on a gimmick. Whether one considers it an "artistic cheat" or a valid and audacious device depends up his ability and desire to suspend his disbelief.

Watchmen is an entertaining movie, but it's more instead of Moore. In fact, the author previously had taken his name off the project. He knew what the movie form would do to his work -- it would change the tone, the rhythm, and the vision. It did.
The Jonas Brothers are a contemporary phenomenon -- a boyish trio who dazzle fangirl tweens.
The best thing about Rudo y Cursi is that despite its relying on many of the conventions of sports movies, it still keeps us unsure about what will happen at the end.
The Brothers Bloom jerks us around without end. The cons and twists pile up like debris. If The Brothers Bloom had one more twist I would have screamed.
In making yet another Star Trek, the great challenge the filmmakers... faced was to be contemporary while also respecting the past. Star Trek passes its obstacles with dazzling, time-warping colors.
Angels and Demons performs a miracle. It makes 2 hours seem like 4 hours. Like a lot of religion itself, Angels and Demons should be so much more than it is.
Hardly anyone thinks of ... Tyson as articulate and sincere. But director James Toback does and captures these qualities in a fascinating, sympathetic portrait. Tyson is a film of vast surprises.
The movie State of Play is equal to its brilliant source (the BBC television program aired in 2003). Until the end. Then it gets contrived and caves in. This article compares and contrasts the two.
The movie State of Play is equal to its brilliant source (the BBC television program aired in 2003). Until the end. Then it gets contrived and caves in. This article compares and contrasts the two.
Just because The Soloist is about a homeless person doesn't mean it should have pedestrian direction. But it does -- pedestrian and clodhopping.

State of Play is like a very filling meal. As it appears to end, one sighs with satisfaction. It was an exciting thriller with a viable resolution. ... But wait. There's more. The meal has been reheated, and thrown back slapdash on the screen.

Sunshine Cleaning is a movie that transcends the obstacles of its genre to sporadically soar to welcome heights. It is characterized by strong direction, skillful editing, and an ensemble cast that will be among the best of the year.
If you want to go into another world in which imagination leads you into recesses and crevices you haven't visited, The Man Who Fell To Earth is a fantastic guide.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

movie_review_blurb: ... full of allusions to past Hitchcock. A car is parked on Bates Avenue; a gas station man tells a cab driver it is dangerous to light a match; the kidnapers tell each other how danger makes them tingle; and the female kidnaper used a blonde wig.

The best part of Adventureland is the acting... But the direction and writing limit the actors. Mottola, who directed and co-wrote Superbad (2007), chooses the easy way, backing off anything threatening in his amiable movie.

Altman and crew have done the necessary reorganizing and reediting on Buffalo Bill and have created a terrific movie out of the troubled dust of what was. The first time I saw the movie in New York, it was explicit, contrived, and needed a lot of help.
movie_title: Buffalo Bill and the Indians, or Sitting Bull's History Lesson (1976)

movie_review_blurb: It is a rare film that can entice me to surrender my logic, but Images does just that. [It] is a film in which Altman doesn't worry about defenses. He boldly creates a spiritual vision and lets logic and caution fall by the wayside of wondrous beauty.

Duplicity is a lazy movie about corporate espionage. It's lazy because its director/writer Tony Gilroy relies on easy gimmicks and lame conventions to tell his tale. [He] uses techniques that might enliven home movies; they deaden a theatrical one.

There is a lot of Billy Wilder in [Avanti!], including the idea that age is a state of mind. The film doesn't all work, [but] when the rigid Armbruster warms up on a sunny rock,... Wilder is telling us something that is more than just fun.

For those of us who love Cinema Paradiso, the news that its Italian director Giuseppe Tornatore and his musical soulmate Ennio Morricone were getting back together to do another coming-of-age film, Malena, gave us tantalizing hope. Malena fa

Up is an engaging, exciting, warm-hearted trip at the movies. Up starts slowly, but picks up helium and soars... In 1923 Buster Keaton made The Balloonatic. 86 years later Up enters the Buster Keaton stratosphere.
Director Francine McDougall thinks of her film Sugar and Spice as "a sophisticated black comedy." Yeah, right. Its as sophisticated as a Twinkie, and as black as a marshmallow.

In Bad Habits (Malos Habitos), a reporter on TV says, "Mexico is drowning." It rains relentlessly throughout the film, creating a mood of gloom and helplessness. The characters are also drowning, emotionally and psychologically, in this vivi
300 is a fun-fest of blood, mayhem, and absurdity. At its best, it is entertaining; when it's not at its best, it's pretty dumb. It's pretty dumb much of the time.
Reign Over Me is like spending two hours with a shrink. Self-absorbed and repetitive, it has an occasional moment of truth, and a lot of hot air.
The best young actor in movies today may well be Joseph Gordon-Levitt.
The Hoax is the real thing. It's a breezy, engaging caper. It's like a heist film of the 1970s, but the pilferers are literary men not bank robbers.
Disturbia is a well-made, very entertaining thriller.

You know that the third Spider-Man had to be bigger. The third movie in a franchise goes for broke. And Spider-Man 3 is bigger, if not better. It's overdone, overlong, and overplotted. It's all over the place. This does not mean Spider-Man 3
I don't think I believed the movie Lucky You, but I sort of enjoyed it. A caveat: I enjoy watching poker on ESPN. If you don't, this movie will bore you.

The Astronaut Farmer is one of those movies that you don't believe for a moment while you're watching it, but you leave with a warm glow. But by the time you've driven home, you realize you've been conned.
Fracture is an entertaining movie that should be better than it is.
Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End is a hearty, bumpy sea marathon. For some, it will be a fun ride; for others, it will be an ordeal. I'm somewhere in between.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Knocked Up is like a Hallmark Greeting Card with crude verse. It's is an uneasy mix of ethnic humor, slacker humor, and human drama -- some is amusing, some is indulgent, and some is strained.
What's the difference between slasher films and chick flicks? In slasher films they suffer less, and they die quicker. Evening, bless its banal heart, is a chick flick in all its fatuous glory.
Live Free or Die Hard is an over-the-top, fun rampage.
Transformers is a rollicking, rousing experience.
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix is a gripping, evocative movie. David Yates has two great strengths to apply to the project. He is cinematically adept, and character is a priority for him.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In La Vie en Rose, Marion Cotillard has the role of a lifetime. And she relishes it.

Shrek the Third has the curse of the third in a bankable series. It is too often sappy, tiresome, and overblown. A franchise such as Shrek, with all the money it has accumulated, should be able to buy a little freshness and originality. But instead

Seeing Ghost Rider is like going to Saturday matinee serials at the Rialto eons ago. It's a fanciful, puerile experience -- a fun day out for 9-year olds. Ghost Rider is a ridiculous melange of cheesy effects, talentless extras, corny plot and insi
There are chick flicks and upchuck flicks. The movie Because I Said So is an upchuck chick flick.
Catch and Release will not cause Ben Affleck any husband-envy. It's a harmless romantic comedy that will garner Garner no awards and middling success at the box office.

Thanks to Gravity is as predictable as gravity. With a topic -- a young woman trying to find herself as a debater, a daughter and a woman -- bristling with potential for a fresh, keen eye, it's more a connect-the-dots script, touching fleetingly on
G.I. Jesus is what a movie at a film festival should be -- creative, original, and challenging.
This is a foul ball of a comedy -- a raunchy, raucous frat party.
The Iron Lady is an example of an actress being so much better than the film she's in. Meryl Streep, as Margaret Thatcher, presides with grand humanity, over a film that is pretty much a shambles.
V for Vendetta is a milestone. Maybe not a big marker, but a milestone nonetheless.It is anti-establishment redux.
The Night Listener shamelessly jerks its audence this way and that, until it arrives at its lacklustre anti-climactic conclusion.
Invincible is the story of Vince Papale, who was an actual figure -- a part-time bartender who went to a tryout, survived training camp, made the Eagles team, and became a Philadelphia legend.
David Mamet tones it down a second time in the relaxed State and Main.

About Schmidt drives another nail in the coffin of irony. It is as lacking in irony as its blatant crayon drawing ending. It's a synthetic antidote to an ironic world, a superficial contrivance that is getting voluminous applause from those who sho

Friday Night Lights is a feel-good movie, but it's not real. It's a hard-hitting Hallmark greeting card. It's no wonder it appealed to Larry King %u2014 it's safe, easy, conventional, and feigns incisiveness.

Million Dollar Baby adds to Clint Eastwood's legacy in ways we might not have expected. It explores emotional terrain as he hasn't done before, and it gives him a kind of role that he has never had before.
Glory Road doesn't have any of the individual moments that humanized Hoosiers, The Rookie, and Miracle. It's a feel-good sports movie by the numbers.
Blood Diamond is a movie zircon. It doesn't cut glass, but it cuts plot, character, and credibility. It could be Hotel Rwanda, but instead it's Motel Deep-Six.
The Good German is the bad movie. Except for the ambience -- the look of the film -- it stumbles awkwardly on every level.

Children of Men is a glorious mess. It's a Frankenstein monster of a movie. Part sci-fi, part thriller, part action genre, part religious allegory, it flays and lumbers after meaning-- sending off occasional sparks of style.
The most important film of 2006 was Clint Eastwood's Letters from Iwo Jima. In 20 years Letters from Iwo Jima will be a classic.
Pan's Labyrinth is a punishing, evocative poem. It is part ferocious reality and part fearful fantasy.
The unconvincing Proof of Life is a missed opportunity.
I'm a sucker for Hitchcock, and last year Jeff Nichols showed he knew his Hitch in Take Shelter (2011). But perhaps Lynne Ramsay knows her Hitchcock even better.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Ruby Sparks goes beyond quirky fluff and deals with relationships. Zoe Kazan rides her screenplay on a high-altitude flight of imagination. Although there's an occasional bump on the way, the landing is smooth.

Dear Guy Ritchie: My name is Robin Hood. I need to be brought into today's world of short attention spans, nonreading, and lovable, cantankerous heroes. If you can turn Sherlock into a glib, pompous ass, imagine what you can do for me.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Pawn Sacrifice is a character study without much character.
Z for Zachariah is post-apocalyptic claptrap.
Jimmy's Hall is more Plotloose than Footloose.
I admit that when I recently saw She's Funny That Way, I swore at the screen.
What's next, The Wolfpack Meets The Kardashians?
Because of its heart and spirit, Straight Outta Compton is even for some of those who don't know the difference between Ice Cube and Ice-T.
Mr. Hunt, your lasting assignment is to keep the IMF in Cruise control.
Grandma is more benchmark than Hallmark.
Woody skimps on logic.
Schumer flaunts shtick.
Infinitely Polar Bear might be called Infinitely Nepotism.
Basil Rathbone is long gone. And Sherlock is 93 years old.
The first half of Dope is grounded in infectious authenticity; the second half is haphazard.
MacFarlane has lost his way.
Move over, William Bendix. The Life of Riley is now female.
The Wrecking Crew is kind of a home movie -- not cinematically accomplished -- but it is fascinating.
Southpaw is MMA. Mixed Movie Arts, with the emphasis on mixed.
The Good Vibrations outlast the bad.
It's hokier on earth than on Mars. At least, in The Martian it is.
Tom Hanks is the modern persona of decency.
Youth is a hodgepodge of music and dissonance.
Concussion may have no target audience.
The Danish Girl is a love story. And it is about human decency.
As an actor, DiCaprio has made crawling his forte.
Is The Hateful Eight a blizzard of ego or the film in 2015 that has the best chance of being a classic?
If the original created dreams, the latest creates nightmares.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Hardy is an ensemble all by himself.
Damn it, Academy, give Roger an Oscar
The Big Short is cluttered and willy-nilly. Most of all, it pulls its punches.
It's a transcendent work of art.
Tom McCarthy is the best humanistic filmmaker in movies today.
Rebound is an earnest, if faltering, first step
For most of its length, Brooklyn is an enchanting, intelligent mood piece.
SPECTRE is like a strand of pearls. They're shiny, but they're artificial.
For a film titled Truth, there's a lot of hedging going on.
Steve Jobs would say, "That's not me." Sorkin would answer, "No, I've made you more human."
The Rocky franchise has a blessed, fortuitous history
How can a bleak film be dazzling? It can, when you think about it.
Children love and understand the majestic galoot.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In modern film there's a genre that is original, bracing, and meaningful.
In American Sniper, Eastwood delivers a transcendent wallop.
The Theory of Everything is the laundry detergent version of the story of astrophysicist Stephen Hawking and Jane Wilde.
Whiplash should "wow" its audiences.
I think I saw a kitchen sink flying through space.
In Birdman, ignorance goes viral.
We Are the Best! is as unique as chips and chocolate. It's also as universal as cosmic pubescence.
Copenhagen is one of those films that shimmer after they've ended.
2014 may go down as the year the music kidnapped the movies.
Gregg Araki has lost his sting.
Kill the Messenger is powerfully relevant today.
Something is amiss in Gone Girl.
Actors may be the new screenwriters.
And a puppy shall lead them.
Director Amini juggles the pairs with Hitchcockian aplomb.
War Horse -- novel and play -- is now a Spielberg symphony. War Horse is part reality and part fantasy, and Spielberg has to do a risky balancing act. It is a gallant film.
The Angriest Man in Brooklyn is like a brilliant clown stumbling off stage accompanied by a kazoo.
They wanted to make a To Kill a Mockingbird. Instead they made, To Kill an Annoying Parrot.
A Most Violent Year is original and thought-provoking. You have to think. Whoa, is that marketable?
The word surveillance has the letters "evil" in it.
Selma could have a major effect beyond the theaters.
What's not to like about Morgan Freeman?
Ex Machina will work best for those who are intrigued by the mere thought of artificial intelligence.
While We're Young is a rare experience -- it vaulted over my dire preconceptions.
A movie based on an Albert Camus story. Now that's existential.
Imagine.
Indie filmmakers have to carry a heavy load.
The sequel to a film about old age is more old age.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Hugh Grant has the best facial expression of bemusement in films.
Mr. Turner, for better or worse, is a film that stays with you.
As lyrical as Angels in America may be, it hijacks the focus.
Even a squirrelly director finds a nut once in a while.
King Lear becomes Glee.
Boyhood: Concept: A Execution: C --
You should take brownies, instead of popcorn, to Inherent Vice.
Force Majeure is the human condition under assault.
Released in the U.S. on December 25, Unbroken is a Jolie, Jolie Christmas.
Foxcatcher is one of the bleakest visions ever about the American Dream in a mainstream movie.
Can an enduring, hardy British television show make it on the big screen?
Guardians of the Galaxy is the brave new world of cinema.
Anomalisa is snide filmmaking. Ersatz creativity. It reeks of therapy.
In a sense, it's a remembrance of things past for all of us.
movie_title: Michael Jackson's Journey From Motown to Off the Wall (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Fare is representative of the independent film today. It shares many of the trials and dilemmas of that aspiring category.
It's not my cup of bile.
Nolan seems somewhat uninterested in the humans standing amid his spectacular effects.
Despite some lapses in subtlety, War for the Planet of the Apes makes the incredible mostly credible.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's Peter Parker Pastiche.
It sometimes misses its target, but it certainly keeps on firing with high velocity.
Coppola's film may have more birds chirping -- almost constantly -- than any film in history.
Wind River is so good, is it fair to wish it were even better?
Wonder Woman is a "suspension of disbelief" movie.
Chuck is a grueling, empathetic portrait of real-life heavyweight boxer Chuck Wepner.
Welcome back, Barry Levinson.
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a slapdash extravaganza careening though bluster and banality.
Stray is a one-of-a-kind indie film.
It becomes their Finest Kitchen Sink.
Kong: Skull Island wouldn't be what it is without Apocalypse Now.
Tower enlists our humanity, and then preaches to us.
The best reason for seeing The Exception is Christopher Plummer.
How does the American Dream become the American Success Story? The Founder shows us.
Stronger brings humanity back to the screen.
We replicants, who are critics, think Blade Runner 2049 is worthy of intelligent perception.
Why did The Shape of Water win the Oscar as Best Picture?
In The Light of the Moon, calculation and contrivance intrude, but fortunately creativity transcends them.
Move over Star Wars. A new force is with us.
The empty chairs have taken over.
The Post is a decent movie. That's its curse.
One wonders who the audience is for Phantom Thread. It demands a tolerant audience.
Most reviewers love it. I don't.
Those of you who thought earlier this year that Tom Cruise was on the verge of being Mummified as an actor, don't worry.
Molly's Game breaks in two.
I, Tonya is a sucker punch in the gut of the American Dream.
It sends its audience sprawling. It swerves past our preconceptions.
Mudbound is a quality film, but it doesn't have the vision or depth of the novel.
The cast often transcends the hokum of the screenplay.
The Man Who Invented Christmas puts the hum in "humbug."
LBJ is a glass half-full of Texas moonshine.
Loving Vincent takes us beyond the myth.
Even die-hard fans of Woody Allen should be perplexed.
A Good American is a documentary against the war on truth.
Elle is an elle of a film. It's a doozy. Women rule.
Of all the films of 2016, Silence may be the film that becomes a classic.
Jason Bourne was written by a film editor. That pretty much says it all.
Cafe Society is glib rather than droll or witty or incisive.
Six by Sondheim is an intriguing, human portrait of a man and his music, and if you care about creativity, you probably should seek it out.
Our Kind of Traitor replaces the book's stings with the film's melodious strings.
It's like outtakes from a failed project by M. Night Shyamalan or Mel Brooks.
Free State of Jones is a fitful product of mutual "jonesing around."
Dark Horse is an incredible tale about luck and pluck.
Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words is a riff on the creative process.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Is Sergio Leone's Once Upon a Time in the West (1968) the best western of all time?
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: The Last Hurrah is an ignored classic.
It's a gluttonous feast of special effects.
Hello, My Name is Doris suffers from the loss of credibility at the end.
Elvis & Nixon could be subtitled, The King Who Would Be Man
The memories from time past are CGI'd into oblivion.
In many ways, it's like a brilliant episode of The X-Files.
It rigs its case on the sentimental side.
What animal would director Lanthimos pick to be changed into? Would it be The Skunk?
Goodbye, Columbus becomes Goodbye, Indignation.
Hell or High Water is an elegy for the disenfranchised.
Hands of Stone is a mixed punching bag.
You can start 2017 with positive vibes.
You can start 2017 with positive vibes.
Denzel Washington is the man.
La La Land is a musical without grace.
Hunt for the Wilderpeople is a kicky treat.
What makes Born to be Blue a special film is the phenomenal performance of Ethan Hawke as the addled, wounded Baker.
Rules Don't Apply is a Warren Beatty crap-shoot.
What's all the fuss about?
Like Silly Putty, Super 8 is silly fun. It stretches, snaps, and bounces. It's as elastic as pubescent imagination.
Loving is a plaintive reminder of what once was.
One of the problems with Denial is that it lacks the fire of conscience and replaces it with cool legal strategy.
Weiner is Rehabilitation Lost.
The Birth of a Nation is a harrowing, human testament.
Times are a-changing.'
Snowden is a movie that percolates with ideas.
Sully is a film made by a pro's pro about a pro's pro.
The Nice Guys is a glorious mess of a movie.
Hail, Caesar! is the Coen Brothers at their mildest.
Lucy is trippy. It's Lucy in the Sky with Dimwits.
Calvary is not your father's Calvary.
A Most Wanted Man is The Spy Who Came in from the Tepid.
Popular sex therapist Dr. Ruth once said that sexual surrogates are "illegal." The Sessions makes them mainstream.

Hitchcock takes us through the struggle, travail, and rejections that faced Hitch as he tried to make a new kind of movie. We perhaps forget how revolutionary Psycho was in 1960. No one had ever done what Hitchcock was attempting.

Robert Zemeckis directs unevenly from an erratic screenplay by John Gatins. Flight basically is a shaky character study, but its strength is a terrific action sequence, as the pilot struggles trying to control his plummeting plane.

Where have you gone, 007? Skyfall has transformed you from the human, vulnerable, skillful spy into a Superhero Bond. In Skyfall, Bond is part Aquaman and part Road Runner, with some familial angst pilfered from Bruce Wayne. He's become an action toy.
Shifty is low-key, low budget, but high grade. It's a film about sitting and talking. And drug dealing. It builds slowly - some may want more action, but it has a surprisingly satisfying conclusion.

Argo is a skillful, dramatic entertainment. It's slick. But in its rush to be "feel-good," Argo sacrifices a lot - such as depth and credibility. It has thrills and laughs; it just doesn't have much substance.

End of Watch avoids many of the conventions of other cop movies and goes its own way. But then it veers back to the easy, most conventional of modes. End of Watch is a moral tale that unfortunately misplaces its truth.
The best aspect of Lincoln is the stellar performance by Daniel Day-Lewis as Abraham Lincoln. Day-Lewis always is devoted to finding the authenticity.
Writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson's The Master baits the audience. One may admire The Master for its scope, style, and maybe some of the acting, but its vision is myopic.

Trouble with the Curve should be titled Trouble with the Cliche. It was not written by a hitter; it was written by a hacker. It's depressing to think that Clint Eastwood's final screen appearance may be in this junkball movie.
Arbitrage is the latest in a long line of movies with touches of Alfred Hitchcock's DNA. The film reverberates with themes such as deception, ethical ambiguity, and the impact of fate.
Robot & Frank is an airy, engaging flight of fancy. It's also part caper film, part character study, and part allegory about aging. Robot & Frank shouldn't work, but it does.
David Cronenberg takes a wayward shot at making a film out of Don DeLillo's artful novel Cosmopolis. Cronenberg's version drones and flounders.
In Lawless, character wins out amidst the brutal assaults and onslaughts. The Bondurant brothers are outlaws, but they have a strong sense of frontier justice. Just like a good western does.

In Side by Side, editor Walter Murch states, "In a way, film was the church of the 20th century." But the church of film is shutting its doors. Stained glass is being replaced by digital imagery. A new religion is on its relentless way.
The Bourne Legacy moves on, and takes us on a spirited journey. Stow your baggage, and it's a trip well worth taking.

Joe (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), the loopy looper, has to time travel into another time to kill himself (Bruce Willis) so that he doesn't make bad movies. No, that's not it. So he can avoid Demi Moore. No. Oh, forget it.

Neil Young Journeys does for some of us what a rare film can do - it revives and renews our spirit. Neil Young and Jonathan Demme. Heart and soul. Wisdom and age. Fire and ashes. Lightning and thunder.
Life of Pi is not a shaggy-tiger story. It is a tale of tantalizing imagination.
This documentary, written and directed by Matthew Arnold, captures the vulnerability, naivete, and pretension of youth. He focuses on the student athletes and their irrepressible coach.
The Eagles live in both the present and the past.
Magic in the Moonlight is a trifle. But it's a Woody Allen trifle, which means it twinkles.
Hitch used illogic, but he never plummeted into hokum as Side Effects does.
Bullet to the Head is a blunt movie with a blunt star. It's also bluntly entertaining.
It's difficult to dislike Fairhaven, because it is a promising, earnest effort.
A viewer may want to watch Amour, because it is a work of art.
A lesser director would not have breathed life into Rust and Bone, but Audiard directs with skill and sensitivity, even when his characters lack those attributes.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: When you make a movie set in Philly, you'd better get it right. Knowledgeable Eagles' fans may find Russell's sense of history maddening.
Zobel has proposed an intriguing, disturbing concept. But he makes leaps. Compliance is a good film. I wish it had been a little better.
Promised Land is no Good Will Hunting (1997). It brings back director Gus Van Sant and actor Matt Damon, but it's another example of you can't go home again.
So often today, the older generation rejects movies because they think they're not for them. But Quartet is.
The British invasion of rock 'n' roll was upon America, and David Chase remembers the time with both fond and bitter memories.
Zero Dark Thirty is a skillful -- and somewhat cautious -- look at military bureaucracy. It's both hampered and elevated by its dependence on authenticity.
One might leave the theater wondering how much can one be entertaining by suffering?
Seeing The Hobbit is like going to a timeshare presentation. First you have to sit through the boring stuff before you can take advantage of the spectacular benefits.
Les Misérables is as sodden as a tear-filled hankie. Director Hooper gets bogged down by the bulk of his movie.
Django Unchained is part Red Bull and part bloody bubble bath. It's a hoot and a holler.
The Deep Blue Sea is an eloquent love song. It's both hauntingly pitiful and very human. It's love in all its labor.

Norwegian director/writer Pal Sletaune appears to have been influenced by Roman Polanski, but The Monitor is more oppressive than haunting. There is little or no sense of dread. The climax is predictable.

The best quality of this film is that it shows that "blockbusters" do not have to surrender to a bombardment of special effects. They can keep intelligence and humanity. Because of that monumental lesson, this film could become an important classic.

Although We Have a Pope is a heady concoction, it may not have mass appeal. It is blessed with a memorable performance by Michel Piccoli as the bewildered, overwhelmed cleric. But Nanni Moretti's direction at times seems as random as Melville's journey.

Goon captures the humanity of the brutal - and uplifting - game of hockey that is identified so strongly with Canada. It's no coincidence that actually, Jay Baruchel has a tattoo of a maple leaf over his heart.
Tony Kaye's Detachment is the latest installment of angst and chalk figures. Detachment basically is inauthentic and pretentious. Like most education, it blows its opportunity.

The Hunger Games is much more than a game. It is a memorable human experience. Thank the gods for the wonder of literature and the vision of movies. Some of us still hunger for eloquence on the screen.
21 Jump Street is a cockamamie movie. It's as rowdy as a dick joke. After the 21st dick joke, I wanted to jump off. And after the dick jokes there's a load of excrement jokes.

Thin Ice is choppy, its tone jumps, it has an unnecessary voice-over, and one wonders about the easy, sappy ending. One also wonders what the original movie was like before it fell through the thin ice of manipulation.

In The Forgiveness of Blood, director Joshua Marston makes a brave but risky choice by keeping almost all the violence off screen. But violence -- even unseen -- ripples far beyond the original participants.
Sleepless Night (Nuit blanche) is one frenetic French dream. It's slam-bang mayhem -- with an active intelligence.

In the Land of Blood and Honey is a relentless, disturbing chronicle of cruelty. It is bleak and brutal. Angelina Jolie is showing this could be -- and still is -- happening in other parts of the world.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Why would you cast Denzel Washington, and then cut his performance to ribbons? Orson Welles once said that a film is made in the editing room. It also can be wrecked.

A Separation shows the human struggle for respect and a better life. It's a struggle rife with human frailty. Asghar Farhadi is a sly writer and director, and leaves us with questions that are provocative and elusive.

Ralph Fiennes has created a slashing, sprawling version of Shakespere's Coriolanus. It's muscular Shakespeare. It's trimmed down - but has themes and a sensibility that fit into today's society and world.
Haywire is as entertaining as a skillful cartoon. Gia Carano is Road Runner, and her adversaries are a bunch of Wile E. Coyotes.
At its best, Undefeated is a Hail Mary TD pass. Other times, it's a routine punt. Undefeated is an anthem of decency and empathy. It's also about living on the edge - of society and life.
2011 was the year of the actress. Both Glenn Close and Janet McTeer give tour de force performances in Albert Nobbs.
Director David Cronenberg is almost always compelling. Many of his movies have potent, startling shock. But A Dangerous Method doesn't shock; it nags.
It's rare that an acting performance can carry a movie, but Ron Eldard gets a lot more out of his role than was on the page. Eldard invests his character with palpable vulnerability.
Unraveled is a con job. It has the clammy hands of its crooked main figure all over it. Unraveled is a prime example of why one sometimes should be skeptical of a documentary.
Marley is a terrific documentary. It goes beyond one figure, and captures the essence of life itself. The film is as infectious and spiritual as one of his songs.
Cellmates is an indie film that shouldn't work. And at times it doesn't, but at other times it has an offbeat integrity that engages.

Martin Sheen gives a lilting performance as dogged Father Barry. Sheen continues his professional and personal journey. The ending may not be as firm as one might want, but Stella Days is a further step in Martin Sheen's spiritual journey.

The contemporary world is smitten with "Reality Shows." Beasts of the Southern Wild should fit right in. It could be called "Louisiana Shore." It has a crowd of noisy people, who swill beer and nonsense.
The Amazing Spider-Man has surprising agility. Its agility isn't so much in its special effects, which certainly are more than serviceable. Its agility comes in its acting, writing, and direction.

Quote not available.
Michael Crawford's absence and Rossum's languorous presentation of her songs are the film's major weaknesses. Too long, it's still lush and romantic with beautiful music.
Jim Carrey is delightful as the evil Captain Olaf. It's a dark tale and maybe children will like it. I was disappointed.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Law is unconvincing as a roué, the script is juvenile and the directing is bereft of inspiration. I was expecting something dreadful but it wasn't that good.
There's a mysterious, hypnotic quality to the atmosphere of the film that grabbed me and wouldn't let go.
The characters are paper mâche, the story so predictable one wonders how anybody could foist it on an audience.
This is slow; every time I looked at my watch during the first 45 minutes, it seemed that the 101-minute running time had longer to go than the last time I looked.
Even though it was enjoyable, there are big holes in it; there's absolutely nothing that would lead anyone to believe that Bridget and Mark have anything in common.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: You gotta hand it to writer-director Bill Condon. It takes something special to have such fine actors, a subject matter that is purely sex, and make them this boring.
The film is brutally frank. Only 81 minutes long, I found it entertaining, sometimes funny, but probably a fairly accurate depiction of how things can go in Hollywood.
With one of the more preposterous climaxes in the history of film, this movie flunks every test of believability.
The real Alexander the Great conquered the world. Oliver Stone's touchy-feely-weepy Alexander would be lucky to last three rounds against Margaret O'Brien.
I admit that I'm not a fan. But if you are a fan, this is the movie for you. It's 106 minutes of Blues sung by just about every living great extant.
If you can hang in there and don't mind listening to two hours of talk, this is a fairly interesting story about two amoral, selfish, inconsiderate losers.
Quote not available.
Considering the almost interminable length of The Aviator and the accomplishments of its subject, the superficiality of this film is appalling.
The story is so convoluted I doubt that it makes any sense even if you had the time or interest to concentrate. The best part of the movie is looking at Zeta-Jones
I thought I had seen the nadir of moviemaking art. But I had not reckoned with Wes Anderson. If I had a rating lower than zero, this one would get it.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Magnificent acting; quirky, unusual script; exceptional directing; I liked it; lots of people won't.
The relationship between Flor and the Claskys is a figment of a rich Hollywood filmmaker's chimeric imagination making the film with its promising premise piffle.

I wish that it had used Bobby Darin's voice, that someone more appropriate had been cast as Sandra Dee, and that Darin had been presented with at least a few warts.
Another unwanted, unneeded remake. The mind boggles that Dennis Quaid, delivering more corny lines, is stepping into the role of the legendary Jimmy Stewart.

movie_title: In the Heat of the Night (1967)

movie_review_blurb: While this is fun, trying more for laughs than tension, it is not a film that will live in history, except for one memorable line.

A film that rates right up there with Hollywood's best romances. Kristen Stewart deserves an Oscar nomination, as does writer-director Greg Mottola.

This is your quintessential Hollywood long, boring movie...without an iota of pace...with the further detraction that it doesn't explain a thing about Olympic wrestling, a sport with arcane rules that could use some explaining.
Beatifully capturing the era, the acting by Cumberbatch and Knightley is very good, but the well-directed story doesn't need the couple of trite plot devices that diminish the end product.

Director Erik Skjolbjærg knows how to create a claustrophobic setting and he gets first class performances from his cast. The physical discomfort shown by the crew is palpable. Despite some plotholes it holds interest until just before the ending.

...long, actionless, and slow...annoying and inscrutable...There were a couple of things good about it, however. Samantha Morton gives a fine performance...and the cinematography of late 19th Century Ireland is rewarding.

movie_review_blurb: Despite the best 3D I've seen, this is one of the silliest movies of all time. Forget history, it's not even faithful to The Bible.

I can't remember when a movie has surprised me as much as this one. I was so much not a fan of the first two but with new writers and a sparkling performance by Dan Stevens as Sir Lancelot it has lots of laugh out loud lines.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: How could anybody make a film of Louie's story and omit his Billy Graham-inspired renaissance? Without this, Louie's story is just the story of every POW brutalized by the Japanese. What makes Louie's story unique is that he forgave.
